HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Everglades Pact Could Be a Model for Environmental Accord.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"THE river of grass has been given a new lease on life," Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt exulted, announcing a pact on Tuesday in which Florida's sugar and vegetable farmers are joining with a host of government agencies to defend the Everglades from the ravages of civilization.
The pact may not, in fact, assure the survival of this uniquely fragile marsh, for no one knows for certain why it is deteriorating into a garden-variety swamp. But Mr. Babbitt should be excused a touch of hyperbole. For the deal does promise a relatively happy ending to a bitter war between farmers and environmentalists that might otherwise have been fought into the next century. 
 As important, it could set a precedent for resolving some heavy-duty environmental struggles to come. "The failure to deal with runoff from land is America's most glaring, unaddressed pollution problem," says Paul Portney, an economist at Resources for the Future in Washington.
Until the 1920's, much of the southern shank of Florida was a flat, pale-green wilderness that was underwater a part of each year. Roughly half of the great marsh has since been drained for farms and suburban home sites, with 1,400 miles of canals and hundreds of pumps to buffer the annual seasons of dry and flood. The rest is state and Federal park and conservation areas.
But all is not well in this remaining chunk of humid Eden. Water pumped into the Everglades contains a dose of chemical nutrients, a combination of farm runoff, treated urban waste and acidic rain that nurtures alien plants and is probably upsetting the ecology of the grasslands. Perhaps as threatening, the artificial plumbing has disrupted the slow, even seepage of water through the Everglades, a process called sheet flow.
In 1988, a coalition of local environmentalists persuaded the United States Attorney in Miami to sue the state to clean up its act. And in 1991, a sympathetic Democratic Governor, Lawton Chiles, consented to a plan to set aside some 35,000 acres for "stormwater treatment areas" -- filtration marshes filled with plants that would absorb the offending phosphorus nutrients. The $400 million or so needed to build the system, it was assumed, would be levied against the farmers.
That set the stage for what everyone expected to be the mother of all legal battles, with the farmers using their ingenuity and financial muscle to delay implementation. But U.S. Sugar, the largest of the landholders and a company that had gone a long way to atone for the sugar industry's legendary abuse of itinerant labor, preferred to deal. And the agreement the industry has just cut with the State of Florida and the Interior Department contains more than a little something for everyone.
The environmentalists get their filtration marshes, a cleanup method the farmers believe will cost far more than alternative technologies. But the growers will get credit against their part of the bill for removing up to 45 percent of the phosphorus on their own.
This will allow -- indeed, almost guarantee -- the creation of a system of tradable antipollution credits not very different than the one now being set in place nationally to remove sulfur from power plant smokestacks. The farmers will divide the responsibility for removing phosphorus, then pay the most efficient among them to refrain from polluting. Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, thinks the farmers can remove phosphorus at less than half the cost of the marsh solution.
What J. Nelson Fairbanks, the president of U.S. Sugar, calls an "environmental peace plan" goes further than defining the farmers' responsibilities for runoff. It also includes a framework for dividing rights to Florida's water, and a technical plan for re-creating something akin to sheet flow for the grasslands south of the sugar cane fields.
There is plenty of offstage grumbling about the deal. Growers do not see why they should be obliged to discharge water that is purer than the water entering their fields. By the same token, environmentalists who have been waging guerrilla warfare against the farmers for a decade are smarting about two compromises. The pact puts a clear limit on the farmers' responsibility for the cost of the filtration marshes, and it decrees that a portion of the marshes will be built on public land.
For their part, many economists are dismayed the farmers will not be given the chance to show they could get the whole cleanup done more cheaply on their own.
But the agreement will prevent the lawyers from fiddling while the Everglades chokes on cattails. And it is a high-profile precedent for meeting a high-priority environmental challenge -- the protection of lakes and rivers from "non-point source" pollution.
For the easy part of cleaning the nation's water is almost done. Most of the gunk still entering public waterways comes from thousands of storm sewers, tens of thousands of farms and millions of lawns. One way or another, government is going to have to identify the sources and create incentives for cost-effective abatement.

HEADLINE: UNDOING OF BUDGET STARTS IN CAPITAL

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
In a tradition old as Congress itself, small groups of senators and representatives on Thursday will start burrowing into the Capitol's many unmarked and well-appointed private offices, where they will set about undoing some of the very compromises that enabled them to pass President Clinton's economic plan only a few weeks ago.
This is the conference committee on the budget measure. Its task is to take the differing House and Senate versions of Mr. Clinton's proposal and puree them into a single bill that will pass both chambers. This happens almost every time the House and Senate pass legislation, but conference committees are normally such boring and anonymous affairs that their doings pass unheralded. 
 Not this time. The economic plan, with roughly $250 billion in new taxes and $250 billion in spending cuts spread over five years, is one of the most contentious and partisan tax bills in decades. Its support in Congress is tissue-thin. And the House version -- backed by liberals -- is different in small but crucial ways from the more conservative Senate version.
Moreover, the chief bargainers are two of the Capitol's smartest and most colorful Democrats: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Chicagoan who heads the Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the Finance Committee chairman.
While the horse-trading between senators and representatives will go on mostly behind doors or by telephone, the conference will actually resemble one of those Hollywood weddings at which hordes of bouncers shoo away the public, but which wind up on the cover of People magazine anyway. Too much is at stake, both economically and politically, for the process to remain secret for long.
 
Big Stakes for Clinton
 "Usually you don't get to see a Presidency rise or fall on one piece of legislation," said one principal Congressional aide involved in the talks. "So there's more public and press interest in this." This is a common view in Congress.
Onlookers got an advance peek at the coming theatrics today, when House Republicans opened a skirmish designed to cast the Democrats as free spenders.
Among other things, the Republicans proposed to instruct the House members of the conference to accept the Senate's more modest plans for spending on food stamps, a tax credit for the working poor and tax incentives for inner-city businesses. The Senate would spend some $21 billion less than the House on those programs over the next five years.
Tonight the House voted largely along party lines, 238 to 184, to reject the Republican proposal. But it immediately voted again, 235 to 183, to adopt one small part of the proposal that urged the House conferees to adopt Senate language on the taxation of Social Security benefits. The Senate bill allows a tax increase on Social Security recipients to take effect at a higher income level than in the House version.
Democrats, meanwhile, began lining up internal support for the measure. Vice President Al Gore met at the Capitol with the 38-member Congressional Black Caucus, a group that adamantly supports the House version of the bill and whose backing is crucial to the passage of any compromise. Later, Mr. Gore called it "inconceivable" that a compromise would not be hammered out and passed by both chambers.
This morning, Democrats gathered privately to steel themselves for the conference. The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, predicted afterward that the final bill would stick close to Mr. Clinton's goal of $500 billion in deficit reduction over five years, despite some sentiment to seek a lower total.
 
Contention Over Fairness
 "Why include massive new spending in a bill intended to reduce the deficit?" the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, said as cable-television cameras carried his remarks to viewers around the country.
Because it provides "fundamental fairness for some people in our society," retorted the Democratic chairman of the House Budget Committee, Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota.
Mr. Sabo and Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, who heads the Senate Budget Committee, are the ringmasters of the conference process, jobs that entail some celebrity and somewhat less real power. They will convene the process Thursday morning with a meeting of all of the 160 or so conference members -- 58 senators and about 100 representatives, chosen largely by Congress's Democratic leaders -- and they will oversee the collating, vote-counting and word-processing that ends with a bill and a thick analysis of the economic package.
If all goes well, both chambers will pass the compromise version of the economic package in the first week of August, just before legislators take their annual monthlong recess.
Conferences usually involve a handful of lawmakers; this one is grand because most committee chairmen claim a stake in the shape of economic policy. So outsized is the bargaining that the conference will be divided into at least a dozen subcommittees.
But the size is deceptive. The vast bulk of the bill is non-controversial. At the heart of the package are but two issues: tax increases and reductions in the growth of social programs. And on those issues, the only people who matter are a handful of very powerful Democrats.

HEADLINE: MEXICO, IN SWITCH, DECIDES TO RETURN STRANDED CHINESE

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 14

 BODY:
In a sudden reversal, the Mexican Government apparently bowed to American pressure today and agreed to take responsibility for 659 Chinese refugees aboard three ships about 60 miles off the Mexican coast that were intercepted by the Coast Guard while headed for the United States.
Only hours after officials here had reiterated their stance that the smuggled Chinese were an American problem, a senior official announced that Mexico would allow the ships into port and then immediately return the immigrants to China. 
 The official, Andres Rozental, Under Secretary of Foreign Relations in Charge of North America, said in an interview tonight that Mexico was taking charge of the Chinese "purely on humanitarian grounds," because of the deteriorating shipboard conditions.
 
Pressure From Washington
 But privately, Mexican and American officials confirmed that the United States had pressed Mexico hard to help resolve the problem, which embarrassed the Clinton Administration only weeks after it announced a new policy to discourage illegal immigration.
Some American officials had voiced concern that Mexico's tough rejection of the United States request came at a particularly inopportune time.
Only four months from now, the United States Congress is to cast the decisive vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement that is intended to eventually unite the United States, Mexico and Canada in a single, tariff-free zone. Mexico's demonstrated willingness to cooperate with the United States on non-trade issues is certain to weigh heavily in the vote.
Mr. Rozental said that Alexander Watson, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American affairs, raised the issue of the immigrants in talks with senior Mexican diplomats in Mexico City on Monday. But Mr. Rozental said, "I don't think there was any major pressure or anything."
Still, the episode was the latest in a series that have seemed to define the relationship between the two countries on the basis of Mexico's overwhelming desire to see the trade agreement passed. The accord is expected to increase jobs and wages in Mexico only slowly, but it is expected to quicken the flow of much-needed foreign investment in Mexico right away.
Over the last year, Mexico has prominently reversed itself several times in disputes with the United States, and almost every time Mexican officials have acknowledged their fears for the trade agreement as a leading factor.
A United States official said that tonight, even while senior officials in the Mexican Foreign Secretariat were publicly insisting that Mexico was not negotiating over the fate of the Chinese, and would not, other officials under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari were continuing to hold out the possibility of Mexican help.
 
Decision Is Welcomed
 "Throughout this thing, there were some Mexican officials who were irritated and were unwilling to cooperate on this, and others who were willing to cooperate to work this situation out," the American official said.
In a public statement in Washington, Martin Judge, a State Department spokesman, said: "We welcome Mexico's humanitarian decision. Our discussions with Mexico continue, and we are willing to cooperate with the Mexican Government in this matter."
Mr. Judge said "consultations" on the immigation issue would continue Thursday in Mexico City.
Tonight in Washington, National Security Council and State Department officials were so sensitive about the appearance of having pressured Mexico that they would not discuss the nature of the talks that took place with Mexico this week.
On Monday, Mr. Watson met in Mexico City with Foreign Minister Fernando Solana Morales to discuss the request that Mexico accept the Chinese refugees, Mexican officials said. But the Foreign Minister expressed his displeasure at the request and its timing, four days after the request was first reported in American newspapers, and the talks faltered, Mexican officials said.
 
Treatment of Mexicans
 Mexican diplomats had shown their ire at the American request for help with the Chinese openly. They suggested it was almost hypocritical to seek Mexico's aid with the problem when, Mexico maintains, the United States habitually mistreats some of the estimated two million Mexican citizens who cross illegally into the United States each year.
For more than a year now, Mexico also has been pushing the United States to change its immigration policies to guarantee undocumented Mexican immigrants better treatment and to allow more Mexicans living on the Mexican side of the border and working in the United States to be allowed to cross legally. Mexican officials said they feared that the Clinton Administration's new harder-line policy on keeping illegal immigrants out could have negative consequences for those goals.
But Mr. Rozental insisted that Mexico did not change its position. In its written appeal to Mexico for help last Friday, Mr. Rozental said, the United States had asked that Mexico bring the three Chinese boats into Mexican ports, then process the smuggled aliens jointly with the United States and the United Nations High Commission on Refugees to determine the validity of any claims of political persecution. The United States said it would then assume the cost of sending the rest of the Chinese, most of whom are believed to have paid thousands of dollars to be passed like chattel across the Pacific.
 
Mexico's Own Plan
 Rather than accept those conditions, Mexico came up with its own plan, Mr. Rozental said.
He said the Mexican authorities would only tow the Chinese ships into port once they had made their way from their current position, about 70miles out to sea, to the 12-mile limit of Mexican territorial waters. Since one of the three ships is disabled and another is believed to be in precarious mechanical shape, Mexican officials said they expected the United States to take charge of assisting the boats to the 12-mile limit.
Mexican officials added that, as is their policy, they would not hear any claims of asylum from the immigrants. And though they have consistently accepted American compensation for processing third-country immigrants in the past, they said they would reject an offer of United States financing this time.
"These people were in really bad shape and in order not to prolong their suffering, we felt that we should get them back to China as soon as possible," Mr. Rozental said.
 
Persecuted or Not?
 A Mexican official added: "We know very well that none of these people who are coming here are being persecuted. The U.S. knows that, too. The only difference is that in the United States, the only thing you have to do is to step on American soil and cry asylum, and you get a hearing."
Mr. Rozental said Mexican diplomats had ascertained that more than 100 Chinese repatriated by Mexico in May had not been punished by the Communist Government. But American immigration officials said an additional 112 Chinese whom the United States repatriated around the same time were subsequently jailed and fined.
Mexico has long prided itself on a generous policy of providing asylum to peoples fleeing politically motivated repression.
But last year, as Mexico struggled to begin the repatriation of more than 40,000 Guatemalan refugees who have been camped on its southern border for a decade, it expelled 123,050 illegal immigrants, many of whom it said were trying to cross into the United States for economic reasons. They included people from India, Latin Americans and Asians, 427 of them Chinese.
Mexico was especially angered in May, when about 200 Chinese from a group seized in Baja California escaped from the Mexicali airport and fled toward the United States. Most were caught, but Mexico was livid when the American authorities refused to allow the Mexican plane deporting them to even refuel on Alaskan soil.

HEADLINE: Where Suburban Tribes Gather for Sand and Surf;
At Family Resorts on the Jersey Shore, Seasonal Time Creeps at a Biblical Pace

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OCEAN BEACH, N.J.

 BODY:
Like a Bedouin to his tribesmen, Richard Dupras called to the families gathered round him on the burning midday sands: "How many people did we have at dinner the other night?"
"Thirty-five," the satisfying answer came. 
 This is the annual gathering of the suburban tribes on the sands of the Jersey Shore, where time seems to pass at a biblical pace, the years counted according to the generations of new in-laws and babies sharing the beach, chairs, umbrellas, cottage. Throw a handful of sand on the beach here and in neighboring resorts like Lavallette and it is hard not to hit a three-generation encampment.
"We first came here 30 years ago, after our first six children," said Mr. Dupras of Somerville. "John, how long have you come here?" he asked a son-in-law, John Hughes, still dripping from a swim.
"Since I was a baby, in Manasquan," Mr. Hughes replied. "These are my roots." He stopped and smiled. "I used to swim in the water until, when I closed my eyes at night, all I saw were waves coming at me."
Time can seem to be suspended in the filmy sunlight that hangs over these beaches because so little has changed in all the decades since northern New Jersey's suburbs created summer outposts on this strip of oceanfront along Barnegat Bay.
Ocean Beach, the Levittown of shore resorts, has 3,000 modest cottages crammed from bay to dunes along two dozen lanes named for fish and fowl (as in Tuna Way). In the last 10 years, it has survived winter storms, recession, pollution and, a sign of how out of whack that decade was, 1980's real-estate speculators.
Now Tuna and the other ways look like they always have, a treeless camp of squat cottages next to a wide beach and the Atlantic. The beach is as wide as ever, despite the storms, and as full of children, and the water looks its cleanest in years. For beach people, who do not spend their days inside, the essentials are here for as little as $500 or $600 a week. Rentals are strong, sales are up.
"We came here when we were teen-agers, 17 years ago," said Andrea Coriddi of Whippany, who was sharing a beachfront cottage with her sister, Dana Carter of Ogdensburg, and their husbands, their four children and, for the day, their mother. "Now that we all have kids, we're coming here again."
"Ocean Beach hasn't changed at all," her sister said.
In many ways the developers of this long strip of sand re-created the suburbs from which their buyers came, complete with their preoccupation with status. To elegant Bay Head and nouveau Mantoloking, the motels and boardwalk of Seaside Heights seem honky-tonk and the tiny lots of Ocean Beach are rinky-dink.
Robert McDonough helped develop Ocean Beach and now rents and sells the properties. "When this started, back in 1946, you could come down and buy a place at the seashore and your investment would be about $3,000," he said.
"It was the first opportunity for the average person to buy a house at the Shore. This was unheard of before World War II. The only people who came down here before were the rich."
Pat Grappone of Rutherford, who bought a cottage three years ago, 20 years after her first vacation here, said, "The only thing that's different is that these cottages are $90,000 now. But if anything, it seems better now. Maybe because we own.
"You know what's nice here?" she said. "Around 6 o'clock, all the men down at the water fishing."
Whether in Ocean Beach or more preppy Lavallette, the beaches have a rhythm and form enforced by the tides, the sun and local ordinances. Surf-casters line the beach as the sun starts to drop behind them.
The beachgoers travel light, like frequent fliers, carrying only chairs, blankets and books, and as the sun peaks overhead the morning traffic flow reverses, toward home and lunch. It is fortunate that the farthest homes are only a few blocks toward the bay, because the absence of coolers is a matter of law as much as style: No picnicking is allowed.
"We bring friends down here, and they're amazed because you can't do anything on the beach," said Wanda Longo of Goldens Bridge, N.Y., recalling when the Ocean Beach Yacht Club's beach patrol confiscated even her plastic squirt bottle full of water. "But that's what keeps it nice."
Ocean Beach, as a private association, also keeps itself nice by restricting its beach to owners, renters and guests. It has a family beach because only its families are allowed.
In that sense, Ocean Beach is no less exclusive than neighboring Lavallette, a borough of second-home owners and renters, and few day-trippers, where the issue of diversity is framed mainly by the competition between the ice-cream trucks that park at the end of its avenues.
In Lavallette, even the trucks have restrictions. Only one can park on each avenue and they are forbidden to ring their bells. "They want to keep the beach natural, but the result is there are no services," said Robert Morra of Belmar, who has brought his Good Humor truck to Lavallette for 16 summers.
"People count on us," he said. "We're a service."

HEADLINE: Sales of Cars and Trucks Built in U.S. Rose 14.6% in Early July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose 14.6 percent in early July, apparently unaffected by devastating floods in the Midwest.
"We had been expecting to see some effect, but it wasn't there," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. 
 But an analyst suggested future auto sales might be depressed by the floods.
"You can move your car to higher ground, but you can't move your house to higher ground," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto industry analyst at Lehman Brothers. "The impact on purchasing or spending intentions will be more severe later."
Auto makers reported today that car sales had improved 6.6 percent and truck sales 27.1 percent for the July 1-10 period.
 
 
Brisk Sales of Light Trucks
 At the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, car sales were off slightly, but brisk sales of light trucks -- the category that comprises pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles -- more than made up for the decline in car sales.
The Chrysler Corporation does not release 10-day sales figures. Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade journal, estimated that Chrysler would have strong double-digit gains in car and truck sales.
The strong sales resulted in an annualized selling rate of 6.9 million for cars and 4.9 million for trucks. That compared with a 6.4 million rate for cars and a 3.8 million rate for trucks for the corresponding period last year.
Over the last three 10-day periods, cars have been selling at an annualized rate of 7.1 million and trucks have been selling at an annualized rate of 5 million.
 
 
Decline at Saturn
 G.M. said its car sales were off 3.5 percent while its truck sales were up 15.9 percent, for a total vehicle gain of 3.2 percent. G.M.'s biggest division, Chevrolet, turned in another solid performance, with sales up 14.9 percent. Pontiac and Cadillac also had higher sales; Buick and Oldsmobile had lower sales. G.M.'s Saturn subsidiary reported a rare decline, down 14.7 percent from a year earlier.
Ford's car sales were down a scant six-tenths of a percent, while light truck sales surged 32.9 percent, for a total vehicle gain of 12.7 percent.
Five of seven Ford division car models had higher sales. But sales of the bread-and-butter Taurus midsize sedan -- the best-selling car in the United States -- were off 21 percent for the period. Six of seven truck lines were up. At the Lincoln-Mercury division, five of nine models were up.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that Chrysler's car sales were up 57.5 percent and its light truck sales were up 32.6 percent, giving it a total sales gain of 41 percent.

HEADLINE: The Fine Print: A periodic look behind the law.;
Assets Intangible? Congress Has an Idea for You.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
If ever an issue cried out for simplification, it is the amortizing of intangible assets, a topic so bizarrely arcane that many people are ignorant of it, experts get lost in it and judges regularly disagree on just how to do it. So this spring, Congress inserted into President Clinton's economic package a proposal to do just that.
Now it is about to reap the whirlwind. 
 As lawmakers start negotiating a final version of the economic package this week, obscure issues like intangibles are kicking up nearly as much dust as Mr. Clinton's ill-fated energy tax and other better-known issues have. Clued in by their accountants, people who never heard of amortization are suddenly up in arms, complaining that either the House's or the Senate's handiwork threatens to drive them to ruin.
"It comes to the point where you squeeze the turnip enough and, hell, you're just being mashed completely," said Brian P. Smith, an official with the Savings and Community Bankers Association, whose home loans the House is accused of mashing.
"People are watching it," said Martin Sharkey, an analyst for NatWest Securities in Washington who says the measure could spur corporate acquisitions. Big money is involved here, Mr. Sharkey notes: from 1980 to 1990, the total value of intangible assets leapt to $400 billion from $45 billion.
All this cries out for answers to questions like these: What are intangibles, anyway? How does one amortize them? And what was wrong with the old way of doing it?
Here is a primer:
When a company buys a machine, or a building, or a car, it can generally write off the expense against its taxes, deducting a little of the cost from its income every year until the machine or building is worn out. In the language of accountants, the entire expense is then depreciated, or amortized.
Intangibles (from the Latin tangere, meaning to touch) are another matter. Wholly ethereal, they cannot be felt or kicked, and they do not wear out in any physical sense. But they nevertheless have value: computer programs, franchise rights, customer lists, employment contracts, even a company's reputation for good service or sturdy products, are all assets that other companies will pay to acquire.
Pay handsomely, in fact. Intangibles comprise as much as 40 percent of the value of cable-television franchises, with their big customer lists and entrenched position as the only company of their kind in most towns. The value of a big consumer-products company, with popular brand names and a good reputation, could consist of 80 percent intangible assets. A small-town insurance agency is close to 100 percent intangible, with little more than its customers and reputation for service to pass on to a buyer.
With the stakes as high as they are, many of the interested parties are very upset. Insurance agents accuse the Senate of trying to pilfer their retirement nest eggs. Unions charge that the House has become a handmaiden of Wall Street takeover artists. Wall Street takeover artists grouse that the Senate is trying to take away what the House gave them. Bankers complain that the House is pushing up the cost of home loans.
There is an Amortization of Intangibles Task Force, and a Coalition for the Fair Treatment of Intangibles. People are worried, or mad, or both, and want to shape the bill as best they can.
 
'Good Will' Off Limits
 Naturally, buyers want to write off these intangibles, just as they do factories and cars, to reduce their taxes. But the Government often balks. Sometimes it simply forbids the write-off of some assets, like a company's "good will" -- the mysterious quality that keeps customers coming back.
In many other cases it picks legal fights over issues like what constitutes the useful life of a customer list or computer program. (Companies like short lives, because that allows them to deduct their expenses quickly, and save more on taxes in the short run. The Government prefers longer lives for just the opposite reasons.)
Companies, left gun shy by these disputes, have resorted to some odd business practices as they juggled asset ledgers to maximize tax deductions and fend off I.R.S. lawsuits. "The law got to the point where in the simplest business transactions, people have to hire an army of experts to defend their tax treatment to the I.R.S.," said Kenneth J. Kies, a Washington tax lawyer and lobbyist. "We're not talking about complicated transactions. I mean, uncomplicated ones -- the sale of an insurance agency, a heating-oil business."
Mr. Kies lobbies for insurance agents, so he has a bias. But even less partial experts, like Alan Doris, a Cleveland lawyer who heads the American Bar Association Subcommittee on the Amortization of Intangibles, also agree that the current law is a mess.
 
Simple, Clear Rule
 So does Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which took up Mr. Clinton's tax package in May. He made certain that the package that came out of his committee included a simple, clear rule: all purchases of intangible assets, including good will, would be deducted over 14 years.
Mr. Doris says that the rule would allow the Government to rake in about as much tax revenue as it now does, but with greater certainty and simplicity for taxpayers. "It does an injustice to some, and it helps others who bought intangible assets with more than a 14-year life," he said. "But in the long run, it make sense for everyone."
Well, almost everyone. Last month, when the economic package went to the Senate, the Finance Committee decided to tinker with Mr. Rostenkowski's handiwork. Rather than allow companies to deduct everything, the panel limited write-offs of intangibles to 75 percent of their value.
 
Senate's Motivation
 The reasoning was no secret: the Senate panel had cut Mr. Clinton's energy tax by $50 billion, and it needed to make up the money elsewhere. Limiting the write-off of intangibles contributed a few badly needed billions.
But it also fractured whatever support Mr. Rostenkowski's original 14-year proposal had.
The nation's 500,000 insurance agents, who have warred with the I.R.S. for decades over the intangible value of their businesses, had opted for the certainty of Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, even though the 14-year period was twice what they sought.
But they are apoplectic over the Senate plan, which Mr. Kies said could drastically reduce the value of an agency's reputation and customer lists and shave as much as 25 percent off the typical $200,000 sale price of an agency.
"For our guys, their agency is typically their largest retirement asset," Mr. Kies said. "He's worked in the agency all his life, basically planning to sell it sooner or later and retire to Florida. For them, this is like a life-or-death issue."
 
Banks' Big Business
 Bankers, on the other hand, feared that the Rostenkowski plan would cut deeply into one of their least-known and most lucrative businesses: collecting and processing homeowners' monthly mortgage checks.
Although most homeowners neither know nor care, their mortgages are frequently bundled together into huge bonds and sold to investors. The investors pay the banks for the service of collecting monthly checks and sending them to the mortgage's ultimate holder -- a cost that is built into the loan fee or the interest rate.
These mortgage-servicing rights are regularly bought and sold among banks, and buyers usually write off the purchases over seven years. Bankers complain that doubling that write-off period to 14 years would lower the value of the servicing rights by as much as $100 a year -- a loss they say would be passed on to borrowers.
The mortgage-banking and savings-industry lobbyists persuaded the Senate to include a clause that would reduce the write-off period to nine years for servicing rights alone, a perquisite the bankers are now fighting to protect in the final bill.
Wall Street lobbied hard for Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, because it would make big corporate takeovers and spinoffs of subsidiaries at least slightly more attractive. That is especially true for big consumer-products companies, where corporate good will is a huge asset that until now has been worthless as a tax write-off.
But the Senate provision reducing the total write-off to 75 percent takes some luster off the notion of amortizing intangibles, and Wall Street will battle for the House version.
The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, on the other hand, argues that the big buyouts fostered by the House proposal would be ruinous to its members, mostly store clerks and other retail workers. Thousands of such workers were laid off during the leveraged-buyout boom of the 1980's, when corporate owners shut stores or fled to bankruptcy when they could not repay the money they borrowed to buy retail chains.
"Look at the leveraged buyout of Safeway," the big food chain, said Greg Caneer, a union spokesman in Washington. The buyer closed or sold its less profitable outlets, leading to layoffs, and "the spinoffs are still struggling in the marketplace," Mr. Caneer said.
This is not to say that some people are not content with either versions of the legislation. Some are.
Big-time professional sports teams are unconcerned, even though a 14-year write-off period would prove onerous in an industry where player contracts are worth millions, and the players can depreciate in one season.
Nor are Silicon Valley and its corporate customers much bothered, even though 14 years is a long time to write off the millions of dollars spent on software that is often obsolete in a couple of years.
Hollywood is also happy, even though 14 years is an eternity when millions are spent on film rights and stars for films like "Bonfire of the Vanities" whose useful lives are measured in weekends.
Of course, all three of those industries are exempted from the proposed new amortization rules in both bills.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 27.11 as Inflation Fear Subsides

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
News yesterday that consumer prices remained level in June prompted investors to set aside nagging fears that inflation and rising interest rates would squash the delicate recovery.
Oil and gold prices fell, yields on 30-year bonds sank to a 16-year low and money started pouring into the stock market, driving up most leading market indicators. 
 Small stocks made big gains, with the Nasdaq composite and the Russell 2000, two indexes of smaller issues, setting record highs.
Big stocks also put in a good showing. The Dow Jones industrial average came within five points of its all-time closing high before finishing up 27.11 points at 3,542.55.
 
The Small-Stock Surge
 "The summer rally is on the way," said Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. He said he expects smaller issues, the over-the-counter stocks, to outperform the blue chips.
"The sizzle will be in the O-T-C, and it will probably be in technology," he said.
Such sizzle pushed the Nasdaq composite up 4.02 yesterday, to 712.49. The Russell 2000 rose 1.49, to 237.84, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.99, to 450.08.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 297 million shares, compared with 237 million on Tuesday.
Patrick Davis, head of Nasdaq trading for Salomon Brothers, said the market began to climb after some anxious selling during the morning -- particularly of troubled Dell Computer -- failed to send prices tumbling.
"Everything was for sale this morning," he said. "But it rallied when that didn't turn out to be the end of the world."
Worried short-sellers -- investors who bet that stocks will fall -- helped support the gains by buying stock to offset their losses, Mr. Davis said. Nevertheless, he expressed surprise that his market had set a record.
"It snuck up on us," he said. "It doesn't feel like it's at a record level."
Among the biggest Nasdaq winners was Novellus Systems, a company that sells expensive equipment to semiconductor manufacturers. After the company projected second-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations, the stock closed up 3 1/8, to 27 1/2.
"It's a very healthy semiconductor market, which in turn has caused the semiconductor companies to increase their capacity," said Fred Wolf, vice president of Adams, Harkness & Hill Inc.
Stocks in some health-care plans -- those that take the managed-care approach favored by the Clinton Administration -- continued to grow yesterday. Oxford Health Plans was among the big gainers on Nasdaq, rising 4 points, to 75 1/4. U.S. Healthcare gained 2 3/4, to 51 1/2.
One of the newest Nasdaq stocks, Celestial Seasonings, resumed its climb toward the heavens. In its initial public offering on Tuesday, the company, which makes caffeine-free herbal teas, put forward 1.9 million shares at $20 each. The stock shot up to 29 1/4 on the day. Yesterday, it gained another 2 1/4, to 31 1/2.
 
Another Bad Day for Banks
 The chief exception to the widespread gains yesterday was in the banking sector, which cannot seem to win; investors continued to reward banks' strong earnings reports by dumping their stock.

HEADLINE: Physicist Nominated to Lead Science Agency

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
President Clinton has nominated Dr. Neal F. Lane, the provost of Rice University in Houston, as the next director of the National Science Foundation.
The appointment of Dr. Lane, a theoretical physicist who has served in the No. 2 position at Rice since 1986, would require confirmation by the Senate, but no hearings have yet been scheduled, officials said today. 
 If confirmed, Dr. Lane would replace Dr. Walter E. Massey, who left the foundation last spring for a senior position with the University of California. He had been director for two years.
The National Science Foundation, which has an annual budget of about $3 billion, is the Government's chief agency for financing basic research and college and university research in science and engineering, as well as public science education.
Dr. Lane said in a telephone interview today that the White House contacted him about the position several months ago. He met with Dr. John Gibbons, the President's science adviser, in May and returned to Washington in June to discuss the job with Vice President Al Gore. "Things were looking very promising then," he said.
"In those discussions, it was clear the Administration had a strong commitment to basic research and supporting science as part of its economic and technical plans," Dr. Lane said, "and this is what the N.S.F. does. I sensed this strong support, which was a main reason I considered the job."
The Clinton Administration earlier this year asked Congress for $200 million in supplemental financing for the foundation to increase its 1993 budget to $2.94 billion. Congress is still considering the agency's budget for the 1994 fiscal year, for which Mr. Clinton has asked a 16 percent increase to $3.18 billion.
Some scientists have expressed concern that the foundation has been moving away from its tradition of supporting small and medium-sized grants for basic research by individual investigators to supporting more applied research and large engineering and supercomputer centers.
 
'Balance Is the Key'
 "I know about the concerns that have been raised about the direction the N.S.F. has been moving, but balance is the key," Dr. Lane said. "The foundation funds a broad spectrum of activities from small grants involving only single scientists to large centers, and my perception is that it has retained its strong inclination and tradition of supporting outstanding basic research and science education."
Dr. Lane said the foundation had been "remarkably" successful in its mission and, "if confirmed, my job will be to move the institution forward on all fronts."
Much of Dr. Lane's research has focused on the collisions of atoms and molecules and predicting the outcomes of these interactions. Dr. Lane said that one disadvantage to accepting the Washington job would be putting aside this work for administrative duties. "But I'll be helping other people get their research done," he noted.
Dr. Lane, who is 54, is a native of Oklahoma City and earned bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Oklahoma. He also studied as a postdoctoral fellow at Queen's University in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
He taught physics at Rice for 18 years, starting as an assistant professor in 1966 and leaving as chairman of the department in 1984 when he became chancellor of the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs for two years. He returned to Rice in 1986 to become its chief academic officer.
From 1979 to 1980, Dr. Lane took a leave from Rice to come to Washington as director of the science foundation's physics division, and in the mid-1980's, he served as chairman of the foundation's advisory committee for advanced scientific computing, which helped in setting up a series of national supercomputer centers.
Dr. Lane is married to Joni Sue Lane, a former computer analyst, and the couple have two grown children, a son who is an electrical engineer and a daughter who is a computer analyst.

HEADLINE: A Cabaret Survives A la Carte

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14

 BODY:
It's 45 minutes to show time at the Downtown Cabaret Theater here, and much of the Saturday evening crowd is arriving early with picnic baskets of fried chicken, meat loaf and cartons of Chinese takeout.
The eclectic a la carte is standard fare at the Downtown Cabaret. Connecticut's only professional year-round theater might also be the only one in the country that encourages people to bring their own food and drink so that they can watch "Fiddler on the Roof" and have a picnic at the same time.
 
Food and Footlights
 The unusual combination of food and entertainment seems to be why it has survived so far in the middle of a declining city. But as its debts mounted and attendance fell in the last few years, the cabaret found itself far from immune from bad times. 
 Now, those who operate the theater say, it seems to be regaining its financial health, and those attending a show the other night were eager to tell why they think that is so.
"Here, I can park my car with no hassle and eat a little dinner, relax and catch a great show," said Sidney Finkelstein of Stamford, as he munched a Subway sandwich and looked around the cozy theater. Including its balcony, the theater seats just under 300, but says it attracts 70,000 people a year to shows like "Song of Singapore" and "Blood Brothers." The last is Willie Russell's musical that is now at the Music Box Theater on Broadway after its debut at the Downtown Cabaret in 1988.
One cabaret regular, Carol Lazanov-Miccio of Stratford, said the shows here were "at least as good as Off Broadway."
 
Ambiance a la Carte
 Some people bring along their own ambiance, too. They produce elaborate table settings, with porcelain plates and crystal glasses, on the large round tables where they gather to watch the shows and eat dinner.
Others are more casual and just unwrap modest sandwiches and swig canned soda or beer.
With the theater set up like a high school gymnasium on this night, the show's "Nunsense" cast will later be shooting basketballs and riding bicycles down a center aisle, even as audience members eat and drink.
The theater's 11-member staff concedes that this would seem bizarre in any other indoor theater, but it is normal at the Downtown Cabaret. Audience members participate in the show as the actors leave the stage and come down to the tables.
"It's like a big public party where everyone loves to bring in their own food and just have a good time sitting at a table with friends or total strangers," said the theater's executive producer, Richard C. Hallinan. "I think we're the only theater around where you often have a boiler man sitting next to a bank president."
 
Began at Sacred Heart
 The cabaret was started at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield in the early 1970's under the direction of Claude McNeal, professor of theater and creative writing at Sacred Heart. It has been in a city-owned building on Golden Hill Street since 1975.
There are four shows each weekend, and tickets are $16.50 to $20, although tickets are discounted to $10 the day of most shows. The theater also presents children's programs on weekends.
Mr. Hallinan, who has been running the nonprofit theater since coming from Ireland to rescue the financially foundering cabaret in 1980, said the theater was in yet another crisis now.
The theater nearly closed last year when losses totaled $120,000, total debts rose to more than $300,000 and attendance dipped to a 20-year low.
 
Some Sponsors Quit
 Operating on a $1.2 million budget -- about 75 percent comes directly from box-office revenues -- the theater has lost some major sponsors in recent years, including banks that have closed or had to cut financial support because of the economic downturn. To stay open, the cabaret has had to rely on private contributors, fund-raising and cutbacks.
"The theater had been thought to be recession-proof," Mr. Hallinan said, "but this was more of a white-collar recession and it impacted us in two ways. Our backers could no longer sponsor us and people couldn't afford to spend the money at the theater. But we're a lot like this city. We're tough and we've managed to just get by by the skin of our teeth. And now, things are definitely looking up."
Some creative cutting and budgeting has kept the theater on financial target through the first six months of 1993. It looks as though the cabaret will break even and show a nearly 10 percent increase in attendance compared with last year, said its general manager, Maggie Silverstein.
"I really don't know quite how we're doing it, but we're hanging in there and it looks like we're going to make it now," Ms. Silverstein said. "We're not out of the woods yet, but a year ago nobody thought we'd still be here now."
Directly across from City Hall on Golden Hill Street, the theater is in an old Y.M.C.A. building.
Mr. Hallinan, who lives in Trumbull, produced more than 250 plays at the Dublin Olympia Theater before 1980. He says he has never loved theater more than in Bridgeport.
"We're kind of the antithesis to a place like the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, where people drive out to an idyllic setting in the country to see a show," he said.

HEADLINE: Nelson Seitel, Associate Publisher Of The Law Journal, Dies at 78

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Nelson Seitel, the associate publisher of The New York Law Journal and a veteran of public service, died yesterday at his home in Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan. He was 78.
The cause was cancer, the paper said. 
 After more than 30 years in a variety of public posts, Mr. Seitel was recruited by The Journal's publisher, Jerry Finkelstein, as his associate in 1970. The publisher praised him as "a scholar, teacher, public official and expert in legislation and legislative drafting."
The appointment came when Mr. Seitel's predecessor, M. Marvin Berger, resigned to accept an appointment to the bench. The Journal, published on weekdays, is considered must reading by virtually every lawyer in New York City.
 
A Teaching Vocation
 Over the years, Mr. Seitel (pronounced sigh-TELL) also taught, most recently for nearly 10 years at New York Law School. Before that, he had lectured at Brooklyn College, his alma mater, and at City College.
Born in a small town in Rumania, he was brought to this country as an infant during World War I. After his graduation from Brooklyn College, he earned his law degree at Columbia University Law School. He was a lawyer, but he never practiced.
He served as director of research and planning of the city's Planning Commission, where he prepared the first master plan for housing and slum clearance adopted by the commission.
As Labor Commissioner under Mayor Robert F. Wagner he drafted an executive order that granted city workers the right to bargain collectively and established a career and salary plan for city workers.
He served as chairman of the city's Transit Advisory Board, which oversees services, equipment and fares of franchised bus operators. He headed a committee that came up with a formula to save the Staten Island Rapid Transit System when the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad threatened its demise.
Mr. Seitel wrote many government reports and helped to draft municipal ordinances and state statutes. He was counsel to various state bodies dealing with corporate law, penal institutions and local government. A report he wrote on prisons led to the state's Work Release Law.
He was serving as counsel to Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut when Mr. Finkelstein enlisted him for The Law Journal.
Mr. Seitel is survived by his wife of nearly 50 years, Josephine; two daughters, Karen Seitel of Manhattan and Joan Ackerstein of Boston, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Overview;
CLINTON REQUESTS $2.5 BILLION IN AID FOR FLOOD REGION

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, July 14

 BODY:
President Clinton, arriving here to tour a region saturated with rain and river water, asked Congress today to appropriate $2.5 billion in Federal disaster assistance to rebuild businesses, compensate farmers for crop losses and provide other flood relief.
Mr. Clinton flew overnight from Hawaii, where he vacationed for three days on his way back from Japan and South Korea, to view the damage by helicopter before visiting a water-distribution site and participating in a television and radio call-in program.
 
Clutching Gallon Jugs
 "It was awful," Mr. Clinton said as he alighted from the Marine Corps helicopter with Gov. Terry E. Branstad after the 40-minute flight. 
 "Because I come from a state that's not all that different from Iowa, I have seen whole towns flooded," Mr. Clinton said. "I have seen massive amounts of farmland flooded. But I've never seen anything on this scale before."
During his aerial tour, Mr. Clinton saw swollen rivers that had engulfed trees, houses, parking lots and railroad cars. One highway bridge near the downtown area had collapsed.
Elsewhere, torrential rains worsened flooding in several places in the Middle West. In Quincy, Ill., crews were trying to save the only bridge across the Mississippi for at least 100 miles in each direction after a 2,000-foot breach opened in a levee.
The water-distribution site President Clinton visited in Des Moines was one of the 79 set up for the 250,000 or so people who are without running water because the city's main water-purification plant was knocked out by flooding over the weekend. Several of those who came to see Mr. Clinton clutched gallon jugs and said they were happy to see the President visit.
Mr. Clinton roamed the streets of Des Moines afterward, attracting crowds wherever he went and offering television interviews that showed him in shirtsleeves standing in front of flooded streets.
 
A Welcome Presence
 His presence here seemed to be welcomed by the residents.
Rodney Anderson, 36, a pipe lineman who shook Mr. Clinton's hand, said the President's visit was "important" but added: "We need some divine intervention. He has a lot of power, but he doesn't have that kind of power. He can't make the rain end."
Mr. Clinton was slightly sunburned from his brief vacation. A photograph in today's editions of The Des Moines Register showed Mr. Clinton wading in the Hawaiian surf. He had shaved 12 hours off his three-day vacation to fly overnight to Iowa.
One sign along his route today read: "Aloha Bill. Welcome to the other big island." Most of those interviewed did not appear to begrudge Mr. Clinton his time off. Even so, White House officials said Mr. Clinton would return to the Midwest again this weekend, to view flood damage in St. Louis.
 
'Can't Stop Nature'
 The aid package the White House requested from Congress would increase the deficit because, as a supplemental appropriation over what is already budgeted for disaster assistance, it would require borrowing by the Federal Government.
Congressional approval of the flood-aid package appears virtually certain. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, was among those promising quick action.
Mr. Clinton and his aides defended asking for such spending while he was trying to win final approval for a bill that he had pledged would reduce the Federal deficit by $500 million.
"You just can't stop nature from taking its course," the President said on the radio program broadcast by WHO, the Des Moines radio station where Ronald Reagan got his break as a sports broadcaster. "And you can't afford to paralyze the American people on this."
But even as the President was announcing the Federal help, local and state officials were complaining that the amount was "totally inadequate."
 
Comment From Harkin
 "I told them don't get locked into a number," Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa told reporters as Mr. Clinton was speaking at the water-distribution site. "Whatever you're going to say is too low, and I'm just going to have to say it's too low. Our preliminary numbers are just double that."
The flooding has been blamed for at least 25 deaths. Federal officials are estimating damages in Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wisconsin at $2 billion to $3 billion, mostly in lost crops. That is far below the $18 billion in devastation from Hurricane Andrew in 1992. Last year, more than $9 billion in Federal aid was approved after Hurricane Andrew, most of it for Florida.
Mr. Harkin, a Democrat, suggested that the money should come from the defense and foreign aid. Yet Senator Charles Grassley, a Republican, called Mr. Clinton's announcement "very good news" and called the aid proposal "an example of follow-through."
Mr. Clinton and his advisers said the money they have asked for is a healthy start to a Federal commitment that will increase as new disaster assessments come in. Mr. Clinton also asked Congress to waive the requirement that states provide matching funds for such Federal assistance, the same thing he did for Florida after Hurricane Andrew.
 
Expensive but Necessary
 Last week, Mr. Clinton announced that he would steer $100 million in crop insurance to farmers and search for ways to change the crop-insurance program to ease requirements.
Christopher Edley, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget, told reporters that the deficit would increase because of the emergency assistance, but that the expenditure would be necessary for the long-term health of the region.
"The fact is, if we didn't do something to address the crisis, the economic impact would far outsrip its effect on the deficit," he said.
Mr. Clinton, who was wearing a wireless microphone so residents who had come to see him could hear his informal comments as well as the shouts of support from people who reached to shake his hand, has declared Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois and Missouri Federal disaster areas.
 
'The Sky Is Falling'
 As Mr. Clinton flew above the flooded areas wearing a pair of aviator sunglasses and leather hiking boots, he gazed out the helicopter window as Governor Branstad itemized the damage below.
Later, Mr. Clinton walked to the flooded intersection of two normally busy streets and joined volunteers in shoveling white bags full of sand. The sandbags have been used to block off flood waters and protect the ground floors of buildings.
"Chicken Little was right," said another resident, Paulette Morton. "The sky is falling."
The Clinton Administration has labored to establish a high profile on Federal reaction to the floods as the President has been traveling abroad. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, Transportation Secretary Federico Pena and James Lee Witt, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, have visited all of the affected states. Vice President Al Gore toured the region Monday.
In addition, the Army Corps of Engineers has dispatched 433 employees to help fortify levees and flood walls. Mr. Clinton said today that the response time was faster than had occurred in other recent natural disasters, including hurricanes in Florida and Hawaii.
The Des Moines fire department continued to struggle to protect the city with minimal water supplies. Since Sunday, the department has fought fires with only the water it can carry to the scene because the flooding of the city's water system has damaged the pumps that send water to the hydrants.
On Tuesday, the department acquired 10 new tankers capable of carrying 5,500 to 7,000 gallons. Late Tuesday night, the department faced its biggest test when fire struck a printing plant. The department used 70,000 gallons of water to fight the blaze, some of it trucked in from a duck pond at the Des Moines airport.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Flat Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Consumer price inflation disappeared in June, the first time in more than two years that prices remained level in a month, the Labor Department reported today.
Although the highly favorable reading was anticipated -- partly because of Tuesday's report that prices at the producer level actually declined in June -- financial markets advanced smartly on the news. Stocks rose broadly and long-term interest rates skidded to their lowest levels in decades. [Pages D10 and D18.] 
 "This is more reassurance that inflation pressures are still subdued," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist for Prudential Securities. He said he was particularly encouraged by a further easing of the core rate of inflation, which excludes food and energy prices.
 
 
Core Inflation Rate
 Without these gyrating components, the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers last month rose one-tenth of 1 percent, pulling the annual core inflation rate for the last three months down to 2.9 percent.
Prices for food, energy, clothing, tobacco and airline tickets fell in June, while medical-care costs rose less than in May. The annual inflation rate including food and energy was 2.2 percent over the last three months, compared with 2.9 percent for all of 1992.
A separate report from the Commerce Department today showed that the nation's shoppers increased spending at retail stores by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the third consecutive advance. Sales were also revised upward for April and May.
The markets had largely ignored word Tuesday of falling producer prices, apparently deciding to await confirmation from today's report before acting. Of the two gauges, the Consumer Price Index is far broader, embracing a wide variety of services as well as imported goods.
Today's report seemed to bury any remaining fears that the Federal Reserve, some of whose officials have fretted publicly of late about potential inflation, would act anytime soon to push up interest rates by tightening credit.
"The Fed is on hold," commented Darwin L. Beck, an economist for the First Boston Corporation, perhaps "for the rest of the year and even well into 1994."
Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, is scheduled to make his semiannual appearances before Congress next week to describe the outlook of the Fed for the economy and its monetary policy.
Low inflation seems to improve chances for passage of the Clinton Administration's budget plan, which many believe will restrain the economy, at least in the short run, because of its tax increases and spending cuts. Had the Fed raised rates to combat the price surge that appeared temporarily in the early months of the year, applying the additional drag of the budget plan might have been too risky.
Today's retail figures also confirmed the recent trend of the economy in continuing to grind out gains, albeit at a less than vigorous pace.
 
 
'Neither Boom Nor Bust'
 "The current environment exhibits neither boom nor bust," said John E. Silvia of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in retail sales, to $171.86 billion, was in itself a lackluster figure, analysts said. But it was considered quite respectable in light of upward revisions of three-tenths of a point each, to gains of 1.9 percent and four-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, for April and May.
That means retail sales for the spring quarter ran 1.5 percent ahead of those in the first three months of the year, when shoppers moved into post-holiday retrenchment.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity, half across retail counters and half for things like automobile insurance, veterinary fees and electricity.
The report of unchanged consumer inflation, which was the best since a one-tenth of 1 percent decline in March 1991, included a four-tenths of 1 percent decline in food that reversed increases of that amount in April and May.
Grocery prices dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent. Indexes for beef and pork, which had risen sharply this year, both fell in June and more declines could lie ahead if flood-stricken Midwest farmers step up slaughtering for lack of feed.
 
 
Housing Rises
 Housing, which makes up 41 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent -- the same as the average for the three preceding months -- while apparel prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month.
Transportation prices eased for the second straight month as drops in gasoline, air fares and automobile finance charges more than offset another sharp rise for used cars that brought the 12-month increase to 9.1 percent.
Elsewhere, charges for medical care rose four-tenths of 1 percent, half the May increase, while the tobacco industry's discounting war showed up in consumer prices for the first time and sent prices down 1.6 percent.
The overall consumer price rise's annual rate of 2.2 percent in the second quarter was down from a 4 percent rate in the first three months of the year.

HEADLINE: New Wave in Health Care: Visits by Video

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Every month, specialists at the Erie County Medical Center in Buffalo watch on a two-way video system as 6-year-old Jessica Bogdan relearns how to walk. They observe increments in progress, make suggestions to her therapist and prescribe future care -- all as easily as if the little girl were in the same room, rather than at Cuba Memorial Hospital, 85 miles away.
Some of the most revolutionary technology in medicine today is also the most familiar -- the television and the telephone. The video link between Buffalo and Cuba, N.Y., is but one example of this new approach to medicine -- called "telemedicine" -- and how it is redefining health care. 
 Fiber optic cables now transmit X-rays from far away storage centers or between hospitals. Several dozen office buildings are equipped with heart defibrillators that can be operated remotely by doctors over cable telephone lines if, for instance, paramedics are stuck in traffic. In some cases, emergency rooms are being electronically linked to correctional institutions, so inmates, in need of emergency care, need not be taken from prison.
"This is the future," said Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, chancellor of Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, where a NASA satellite system will soon allow surgical consultations between doctors in Texas and patients in places like Russia, Turkey and Saudi Arabia. "This is going to change the world of medicine."
Experts say the use of telemedicine will powerfully affect rural communities, which are chronically short of specialists, and urban centers where specialists abound.
"It will be a tremendous boon for the physician community here," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents the city's 68 private hospitals and nursing homes.
Of the city's 31,000 doctors, he said, 70 percent are specialists, and small hospitals seeking consultations from specialists are most likely to turn to the most concentrated source. "I would think that many of these link-ups would involve New York's medical centers," he said.
Most telemedicine systems are so new that hospitals have not worked out details like how to bill for the service. Several are lobbying the Federal Government to create a special reimbursement category.
And, so far, there is only speculation as to what the medical, economic and sociological effects of telemedicine might be. There are those who argue, for instance, that telemedicine will increase health-care costs, and not just because of the cost of the cameras and other equipment (a setup like the one between Buffalo and Cuba costs about $50,000; Dr. DeBakey estimates that his transmitting station will cost close to $1 million.) If expensive specialists are literally a phone call away, these critics say, they are very likely to be "visited" more often.
Others believe that the new systems will eventually lower costs. They predict that fewer specialists will be required since they could more easily concentrate in the largest medical centers, rather than opening practices in every hamlet of the country. In addition, they say, nurse practitioners and physician assistants could provide basic health care in rural areas if a doctor can be dialed up as needed.
 
From Car to Video Camera
 For the Bogdans, there have only been benefits. Two years ago, Jessica suffered a stroke in gym class, the result of a malformed blood vessel in her brain. Since then she has needed the care of doctors in more than a half-dozen specialties, and none of those specialists could be found in the tiny town of Cuba. So every month the Bogdans, with Jessica and her younger brother, drove the four-hour round trip to Buffalo, a trip that was draining on everyone.
Last summer, doctors told the Bogdans that the drives would no longer be necessary. The hospital in Cuba began a pilot program with the Buffalo hospital, with two video cameras and monitors at each site using lines from New York Telephone and U S Sprint that allow the calls to be dialed up as needed, without the expense of a dedicated private line.
For the last year, the system has been tested only with nonemergency rehabilitation cases. But next month it will be expanded to the emergency rooms of both hospitals, allowing specialists in Buffalo to advise family doctors and nurse practitioners in Cuba. Eventually, the program will be expanded so that Buffalo is linked with a variety of rural hospitals as well as area correctional centers.
Such arrangements are possible, said Dr. David Ellis, who is in charge of the Buffalo emergency room, in part because of recent advances in the quality of video pictures. "I became a believer during a test demonstration when they showed a patient with a skin rash," he said. "I could tell from the screen whether or not the rash was raised."
Other users of the system agree that it is surprisingly easy to diagnose a patient from hundreds of miles away. Barbara Bevins, nurse manager of the emergency department of Dodge County Hospital in Eastman, Ga., said her office regularly does cardiology consultations via video with doctors at the Medical College of Georgia in Augusta, 152 miles away. "Today we focused the camera on the jugular veins" of a patient with chronic heart problems, she said, "and the doctors could see how distended they were."
Video examinations are but one of the new medical applications of everyday technology. Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, short on storage space for radiologic images like CAT scans, MRI's and old-fashioned X-rays, keeps them in a warehouse three miles away in Somerville. In rush-hour traffic, the trip from the warehouse to the hospital takes far too long, said a hospital spokesman, Martin Bander, so Massachusetts General is testing a system called Radiology Storage Tracking Archiving and Retrieval, which is also being tested by hospitals in Dallas, St. Paul and Mission Viejo, Calif. The system allows a clear picture of the film to be transmitted to a screen at the affiliated hospital, where doctors can read the film.
This futuristic form of fax is in use in places like the clinic at Yellowstone National Park, where X-rays of injured hikers can be read by radiologists in West Park Hospital in Cody, Wyo.
Sensing profit in the new applications of technology, companies are maarketing products that join medicine and telephones. The New Jersey-based MEDphone Corporation manufacturers only one product, called MDphone, which looks like a hard-sided suitcase and contains a portable defribrillator, which can restart a heart by remote control over a standard or cellular phone line.
In the last two years, 100 of the $7,000 units have been sold, mostly to large companies, said MEDphone's president, Eric Wachtel. When activated, he said, the device dials the nearest participating hospital and allows someone with the patient to talk to an emergency room doctor. When the disposable adhesive electrodes are attached to the patient's chest, the doctor receives the patient's electrocardiogram, and, if necessary, the doctor can press a button to apply an electric jolt.
Less dramatic are a variety of home-testing devices which allow patients to stay at home while a doctor monitors heart rate, blood pressure and temperature over the phone. A study by Arthur D. Little Inc., a management consulting firm, last summer cites nearly two dozen such products either in use or in the works.
 
A Problem of Billing
 While this new availability of information solves many medical problems, it simultaneously raises others, from protecting the privacy of patients in an increasingly electronic world, to the liability of doctors who administer care long distance, to the problem of how to charge for it all.
At Erie County Medical Center, Dr. Ellis said, telemedicine consultations are billed at the same rate as regular consultations. But the hospital has joined with one hospital in Georgia and another in West Virginia, both of which are using similar systems, and requesting that the Health Care Financing Administration, which regulates Medicare and Medicaid, add telemedicine as a separate category.
The change would be significant because so many rural patients are also poor or elderly, and because private insurers follow the billing leads of the Federal Government. The consultations, he said, would, at least at first, be more expensive, to account for the cost of the equipment.
Other questions are more philosophical. David J. Rothman, a professor of social medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, believes telemedicine is a step toward better medical care, but he worries that, as is often the case with progress, something intangible is being lost.
For decades, he said, technology has been metaphorically distancing doctors from their patients, causing many patients to describe their doctors as callous or cold. Telemedicine, he said, is a literal distancing of doctors and patients.
"The ideals of medicine, the laying on of hands, there's no place for that here," he said. "You can't get much further apart than this."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Move Up

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market got the kind of news it likes yesterday -- that inflation is low and economic growth is moderate -- and traders responded with enthusiasm, pushing prices of Treasury notes and bonds higher.
The buying sent the yield on the 30-year bond down to another 16-year low and yields on Treasury notes to their lowest levels in more than two decades. 
 The question from here is how much further prices can rise and yields, which move in the oppositie direction, can fall. Traders, portfolio managers and anlaysts seem to be cautious -- aware of the possibility of a sudden reversal with the market at levels not seen in decades.
But for the time being, the weakened state of the economy and inflation, and the progress in Congress of President Clinton's deficit reduction plan, seem to favor lower interest rates.
 
No Signs of Bouncing Back
 "The economy is not showing signs of bouncing back and the whole political process is restrictive from the economic point of view," said John Costas, managing director of trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation. "I think that means lower yields."
In trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 rose 23/32 , and the yield fell to 6.56 percent, from 6.61 percent Tuesday. It was the fith day in a row that the yield dipped to its lowest level since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds regularly in May 1977.
The price of the 10-year note rose 11/32 and the yield fell to 5.70 percent, its lowest since the beginning of the 1970's. Yields on other Treasury notes fell as did the discount rates on Treasury bills.
The news that the Consumer Price Index for June was unchanged and that retail sales for last month rose just four-tenths of 1 percent did serve to end conclusively any thought of a rebound in inflation and a raising of interest rates by the Federal Reserve -- for now.
It will be easy now to dismiss the unexpectedly high rise in consumer and producer price inflation in the first four months of the year. The Consumer Price Index through April was rising at a 4.3 percent annual rate and had prompted two sharp selloffs in the bond market that pushed the yield of the 30-year bond over 7 percent temporarily.
But in the last two months, the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in May and was unchanged in June, bringing down the annual rate of increase for the first six months of the year to 3.1 percent, just above the 2.9 percent increase for all of 1992.
But the key to the inflation outlook continues to be the pace of economic growth. If the economy begins to grow faster than 3 percent in the second half of the year, then investors may begin to worry that there will be inflationary pressures building up in 1994. And that belief could stop a credit market rally.
"The real issue is to what extent the economy improves," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc.
Even with the strong car sales reported yesterday in the first 10 days of July, the June increase in retail sales of four-tenths of 1 percent still points to modest growth for now.
And it is likely that the outlook for the economy will continue to be modest because of the impact of the tax increases that are included in the President's deficit reduction plan. While problems in reaching a compromise between the House and Senate versions might spook the bond market from time to time, the bottom line is that the program will be a drag on the the economy.
 
Buying of Treasury Securities
 The rally in the market yesterday, however, was not all pushed by the good news on inflation. Prices were forced higher and yields lower by trading strategies and the continued buying of Treasury securities by state and local governments refinancing older, higher-interest-rate tax-exempt bonds at lower interest rates.
Mr. Costas of First Boston said that a lot of traders began yesterday thinking that prices were very high and yields low. In addition, some thought that the good news on inflation had already been factored in. So they decided to short bonds and notes, selling them in anticipation of buying them back at lower prices.
Instead there was slow, steady buying that soon forced many of the short-selling traders to buy back bonds and notes to avoid losses, which pushed prices higher. Some of this steady buying was from cities and towns that put Treasury securities into escrow accounts to pay off their old high-interest-rate bonds.
