HEADLINE: Japan Sees Little Drop In Surplus

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 14

 BODY:
Only five days after President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa announced a broad framework for trade talks, Japan's top trade official said today that the United States should not expect his country's trade surpluses to go down in the next two years.
The official, Sozaburo Okamatsu, said that while the agreement called for "a highly significant decrease" in Japan's surpluses over the "medium term," the sluggishness of the Japanese economy would keep imports here low for quite some time. 
 "My personal view is that in the coming two years the imbalance will not decrease much," said Mr. Okamatsu, who became vice minister of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry late last month and participated in the negotiations with the Clinton Administration. "Frankly, in this calendar year the imbalance will grow."
The vice minister is the highest career appointee in the ministry, and usually the most influential voice in setting policy. In his conversation today, over lunch with four correspondents based in Tokyo, he did not sound as if he was backing away from any of the commitments made by Japan.
Instead, he appeared to be interpreting the vaguely worded framework accord quite literally, noting that despite the Clinton Administration's insistence that an understanding exists about how to define the term "highly significant," the Japanese do not believe they are committed to cuts of a specific size.
His comments seemed to underscore how much of the agreement is subject to interpretation, and how many critical issues have been put off for negotiations to come. Under the framework accord, specific negotiations will take place in five more specific areas. But in none of them did Japan agree to specific targets.
"I don't believe that the present level of imbalance is normal, so we should take comprehensive measures to correct it," Mr. Okamatsu said. "But the U.S. says that means it should go down to 2 percent of our G.N.P., and there is no agreement on that at all. There is no numerical target."
In the hours after the agreement was announced last Saturday, several White House officials used the 2 percent figure, suggesting that it was part of an informal understanding. But even before Mr. Clinton left Tokyo, Japanese officials said they had fended off the Administration's efforts to put any kind of figures in the agreement, saying that would amount to managed trade.
"A highly significant reduction also depends on the United States," Mr. Okamatsu said. "If it is not accomplished, it is not the responsibility of Japan, only. It is also the responsibility of the U.S. and the condition of the world economy."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Price Report And Gold Falls in New York

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday as a positive report on inflation pointed to lower American interest rates. As such, investments denominated in Japanese yen and German marks would be more attractive than those in dollars.
The dollar slipped to 1.7170 marks in late New York trading from 1.7195 marks late on Tuesday. Also in New York, the dollar dropped to 107.10 yen, from 108.13 yen on Tuesday. 
 Gold prices also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery dropped $3.10 an ounce, to $391.40. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $391 an ounce, down $3.25.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that consumer prices were unchanged in June. This followed Tuesday's report of a drop of three-tenths of a percent in the Producer Price Index for June.
"The data drove home the idea that the Federal Reserve is not tightening credit in the near-term," said David Solin, foreign exchange manager at the Toronto Dominion Bank.
As a result, he said, many people are taking profits made on the dollar's recent gains versus the mark.
Dealers flocked to mark-denominated assets as fears of a significant German rate cut faded after the Bundesbank cut its repurchase rate only slightly.
"There's a feeling the Bundesbank might have to ease, but not tomorrow," said David Glowacki, a senior trader at NBD Bank.
 
Pound, Swiss Franc Strengthen
The Swiss franc and the British pound also rose against the dollar, as yields on assets based in those currencies are expected to rise with the rebounding British and Swiss economies.
The British pound settled at $1.5015 in New York, above Tuesday's $1.4960 level. And the dollar slipped to 1.5120 Swiss francs, from 1.5177 on Tuesday.
"The dollar is losing a bit in terms of its safe haven status, but I don't want to make too much of the dollar move today, because it is still well bid on the back of tensions" in the European Monetary System, said Lisa Finstrom of Shearson Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Witnesses for the Nation

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
As the rains continue and network reporters are still at their posts, herewith a word of gratitude for their many-sided and sustained coverage of the floods in the Midwest.
Disasters are made for the cameras, of course, and once again television has displayed nature's power. But more important, the bewilderment, loss, pain and grit in the faces on the screen has brought Americans together. And the presence on the scene of the three famous network anchors -- Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather -- has been an affirmation of national concern and solidarity that went beyond the customary functions of journalism. 
 To be sure, there was plenty to be reported, and reported it was. Farmers and barge operators told of their troubles. Weather experts and river experts explained what was happening; and why, insofar as anyone could explain it. Economics reporters predicted the effects on food prices, and officials lobbied for aid. Viewers learned something about how levees and crop insurance work and don't work.
But all those matters could have been handled as well or better by the anchors' competent colleagues on the spot. This time out, however, Mr. Jennings, Mr. Rather and Mr. Brokaw have performed a service that only they could perform. Some of their forays to hot spots have seemed to be more an expression of restlessness than of necessity, but now they have been where they had to be.
Because of the special place the anchors occupy in the routines of much of America, these very public yet oddly personal nightly visitors became emissaries, speaking for viewers as well as to them. For audiences far from the flooding, their arrival affirmed its seriousness, and for the people in trouble, they were proof that the rest of the nation was watching and worrying. Moving out of their studios and into the country, the anchors became our get-well cards to our unlucky neighbors.

HEADLINE: 'Trade Only' Walls Weaken

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
NOWHERE has the slump in decorating been felt more directly than in the to-the-trade showrooms. These exclusive arenas, often grouped in design centers in big cities, are where the business of decorating mainly takes place.
For many years it has been easier for the public to meet Madonna than to get past the receptionist in a designer showroom. But now a number of design centers are beginning to lift the so-called chintz curtain that has kept lay people from seeing, let alone buying, some of the choicest merchandise around. 
 Many showrooms are now wooing consumers for the first time. At some, they can browse freely, but purchase merchandise only with a designer. At others, consumers are allowed in to shop and buy during special events. At still other places, the public is allowed to buy at 15 to 20 percent discounts without a designer go-between.
These are soul-searching days in the world of decorating.
The stock-market crash of 1987 and the recession that followed have caused hundreds of decorating projects to be canceled or put on hold indefinitely. AIDS has also further sapped the industry's vitality by claiming scores of people in the design and architectural fields, including some of the stars and trend-setters. The business may never recover.
The showrooms -- oases of thick carpeting, fresh flowers and well-sharpened personalized pencils -- are where designers and architects, sometimes with clients in tow, can flip through thousands of fabric samples or run their fingers through scores of braided tassels. A to-the-trade showroom sells only to professionals, at a discount of about a third off retail.
Traffic is down. And antique shows, flea markets and auctions, as well as bargain furniture and fabric emporiums, have grown in popularity.
Marketing strategies are in force in decorator-only bastions like the Decoration and Design Building in New York, the Pacific Design Center in Los Angeles and the Merchandise Mart in Chicago. Tenants at the 25-year-old D and D Building, as it is known, on Third Avenue and 58th Street in Manhattan have recently emerged from a months-long debate, and have decided to remain to-the-trade only.
On July 7, the building was acquired by the Decoration and Design Building Partnership and is being managed and leased by the Merchandise Mart Properties of Chicago. A letter sent by the new owners to the tenants said the change came after "an uncontested foreclosure proceeding." The building was previously owned by D and D Associates, a division of the Aaron Diamond Realty Corporation.
"I think we're all very busy re-inventing ourselves," said Ann Pardue Sonet, a New York public relations agent who specializes in the design industry. "One thing is sure, we're not going back to the 80's."
Some fabric firms, like Brunschwig & Fils, are going into furniture; others, like George Hanson Lamps, have been bought by larger companies, in this case, the Hinson Company, a fabrics and wall-coverings concern.
The Pacific Design Center in Los Angeles has for the last few years looked for ways to allow the public in. It is part of their "consumer awareness program," said Julie D. Taylor, the center's manager of public relations. "We are inviting consumers into the building to browse and to learn about the process of professional interior design." If a customer wants to order, the building offers a referral list of designers.
Marvin Danto, the owner of design centers in Florida and Michigan, said, "We believe that consumer knowledge is good for our business, but getting the public into the showrooms is a big job."
In Dallas, they're trying.
At the Dallas Design District -- a 54-acre complex of 31 buildings -- a 15,000-square-foot marketing center with a multimedia theater is being developed as part of a promotion called the Design Experience, to open in September. The center was the first in the United States.
"The upscale consumer is who we're after," said Michael W. McAdams, president of Crow Design Centers, which owns Dallas Design District, the Boston Design Center and the Decorative Center of Houston.
Mr. McAdams said that a purchasing service will allow customers to buy some merchandise at 15 to 20 percent off the showroom list prices.
"We were amazed through the research we did last year at the number of people who didn't know that there was a design center in their home town," he said.
But at Clarence House, an upscale fabrics company that maintains 14 showrooms in the United States, there is no compromise on its to-the-trade-only policy.
In their two-story, 10,000-square-foot New York showroom with a private entrance in the D and D Building, there's really no such thing as "just looking" -- for the general public, that is. The showroom, designed by the late Jay Spectre with a striking winding staircase, has between 4,500 and 5,000 different textiles, from $24 to $2,550 a yard.
"We are very opposed to opening up the showroom to anyone but the professional interior designer or architect," said Susan S. Freedman, vice president of the 32-year-old company. "When you see 5,000 different choices, it becomes confusing. People get crazy. Our sales staff is here to serve the professional."
Suzanne Varney, president of Carleton V, a showroom in the D and D Building where fabrics range from $40 to $300 a yard, said: "We need the designer because we don't sell a finished product. Because the goods can be so expensive, if they are used incorrectly, it becomes an expensive mistake for the customer."
For the consumer, the designer is the necessary go-between. For the showroom, the professional has another value. "Decorators are like sales representatives," Ms. Varney said. "How many industries are there where your customer comes in, takes a sample and then sells it 10 times for you in a year? We don't want to live without them." Some consumers try.
"If you want something that's not only cheap but that you can take home with you, then you go downtown," said Rosi Levai, a New Yorker who is often looking for fabrics for her loft or her country house.Mrs. Levai has learned her way around the fabric emporiums that dot Broadway below Houston Street.
"I've gone to places down on Broadway, like Intercoastal, and found cottons, denims and even raffia," she said. "And often for $5 a yard. But don't expect anything fancy. It's usually a dusty basement with thousands of yards of stuff. You have to scrounge around and be prepared to get a little dirty."
You might also call it instant gratification. Being able to take it home with you has also been a factor in weakening the appeal of showrooms. "People don't want to wait anymore," said Mariette Himes Gomez,, a New York interior designer who sells has her own collection of furniture to the public in her Upper East Side showroom.
And there's fun in the hunt. Looking for the right chair, even the perfect textile remnant, anywhere but the in the traditional showroom has become a form of entertainment.
Some decorators, like Agnes Hibon, tries to cover all bases. Recently, Mrs. Hibon was scouring the showrooms at the D and D Building looking for "discontinued" fabrics for a "very limited budget job" for diplomatic clients. "I also shop downtown," she said. "Some places there are like the caves of Ali Baba."
Finding these alternative sources has become a small industry in iteself. Elysa Lazar's Home Report, a new publication, gives an almost day-by-day breakdown of auctions, antiques shows and warehouse sales in the New York area. And the "Fine Furniture and Furnishings Discount Shopping Guide," by M. Katherine Gladchun (Resources, Bloomfield Hills, Mich.; $12.95) lists more than 200 places where people can find that magic thing: a discount.
Although many to-the-trade showrooms do maintain some stock, much of the furniture and fabric must be custom ordered. Beverly Ellsley, a designer from Westport, Conn., said she goes to New York a couple of times a week because the D and D Building, "with its tremendous selection, is still the resource for fabric." But, she added, "Sometimes there's nothing behind the samples," meaning it's not in stock.
But Ms. Ellsley is not discouraged about the future of decorating. "In a poor real-estate market, people may have bought things at good prices, but they still need to be decorated," she said. "Just go to a cocktail party. Everyone is either talking about doing business with a decorator or is a decorator."

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
FOR some families with teen-agers, taking a vacation together is an exercise in frustration for both generations. For others, it's an opportunity to rebuild relationships and discover things about one another away from the day-to-day stresses of home.
"Unless you travel with your teen-agers, your time with them is likely to be limited to swapping car keys and telephone messages," said Candyce H. Stapen, a travel writer in Washington who has traveled extensively with her 11-year-old daughter and 23-year-old son. "It's a chance for you to get to know each other as people. Your kids get to see you as a person, not just a parent." 
 The key to a successful family vacation with adolescents, said travel professionals and experts in child development, is understanding and respecting one another's needs. A vacation that worked when the children were in elementary school may turn into a disaster when they are teen-agers.
"What the parents find interesting may bore a teen-ager to death," said Dr. Peter A. Wish, the director of the New England Institute of Family Relations in Framingham, Mass., and the father of a 17-year-old daughter. "A teen-ager who feels miserable on vacation will, in turn, make his parents miserable."
The last thing many adolescents want to do on vacation is sightsee. Only the rare 14-year-old can tolerate day after day of uninterrupted art museums or beautiful vistas.
"If they have to sit in a car for hours, they're likely to plug into things that isolate them from you, like a Walkman or a portable video game," said Dorothy Jordon, the managing director of "Travel With Your Children," a specialized book and newsletter publisher in Manhattan. "But part of the point of the vacation is to have them plug into their family."
Another important issue is independence. Adolescence is a time for children to experiment with being less reliant on their parents. Some of their efforts are awkward. They may go to the movies with their mother, but insist on sitting a few rows away from her. They may ask for a ride to a friend's house, but beg to be dropped off around the corner and out of sight. At times their desire to prove their independence may lead them to overlook the real dangers that come with some activities.
Family vacations offer teen-agers an opportunity to experiment with new levels of independence and self-reliance. Sports like wind surfing or rock climbing allow them to test the limits of their growing bodies.
Peer relationships are much more important for adolescents than for younger children. Teen-agers will seek out and want to spend time with people their own age. "They like a beach packed with other bodies, and something happening at night," Ms. Stapen said.
This combination of needs and opportunities can make parents worry about their teen-agers' safety. Yet, if parents keep a tight rein on them, adolescents will probably rebel.
Some cruise lines, resorts and hotels have responded by developing programs for teen-agers that complement their supervised activities for younger children. At their best, these programs offer enough structure and supervision to please the parents and enough independence, adventure and socializing to satisfy the adolescents.
Julie Halpern, the director of special markets for Hyatt Hotels Corporation in Chicago, said her company introduced "Rock Hyatt," a set of special programs for teen-agers, in 1992 after they noticed that families who had used their children's programs were going other places when those children were adolescents. "We see teen-agers as future business customers," she said.
Still, the mere presence of organized activities and special facilities for adolescents doesn't mean all children will find them attractive. "Many programs at hotels and resorts claim to be for children 13 to 17, but generally few teen-agers over 15 show up," Ms. Stapen said. "They don't want to be with the younger kids, even though they might have a good time."
 
Teen-Agers, Parents, Vacations: Perilous Mix
 IF you're going on vacation with teen-agers, one of the best things you can do is get them involved in the planning from the start. This addresses their need to be recognized as being more mature than when they were younger. For example, if they're aware of your budget and know how much things cost, they're less likely to ask for things you can't afford.
"Also, when things go wrong, they won't be as unhappy since they've made more of the decisions themselves," said Dorothy Jordon, the managing director of "Travel With Your Children," a specialized book and newsletter published in Manhattan, and the mother of two teen-age boys.
Here are some other things to consider:
Look into package plans, especially if your child likes sports.
An inexpensive room is a false economy if the only thing your teen-ager wants to do is zoom around on jet skis at $35 an hour. "You can go broke keeping a teen-ager happy with sports," said Candyce H. Stapen, a travel writer in Washington. "A package plan also means you don't turn into the bad guy who has to keep saying 'No!' "
Be considerate of one another's privacy and schedules.
One way to do this is to rent two adjacent rooms or a small suite. That way you're not being awakened at 1 A.M. when your teen-ager comes home from the disco or late movie, and you're not waking him up at 7 A.M. when you get up for a round of golf. Many hotels will offer discounts on a second room or a suite to families with teen-agers.
Don't push teen-agers to do early-morning activities.
Teen-agers are notoriously late sleepers. Pushing them to do things early in the morning that they're not especially excited about may leave them grumpy for the rest of the day. "Expect to have dinner but not breakfast with your kids," Ms. Jordon said.
If you're a single parent, look for communal dining.
You may see very little of a teen-ager who gets swept up in his own activities. "You can end up eating every meal by yourself, which can be a very lonesome experience if that isn't what you wanted," Ms. Jordon said.
Most cruise ships and resorts will allow you to share a table with others. They'll also allow you to discreetly change your seating if the company isn't to your liking.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Middle Ground on Abortion Shifting Into Terra Incognita

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Over the next few months, Congress and the White House will face one of the most complicated, unpredictable and perhaps politically perilous phases of the abortion struggle yet. Like it or not, the lawmakers will be forced to define a new political center on abortion.
Gone are the days when it was enough to simply support or oppose the legalization of abortion. Now, lawmakers have to decide whether being "pro-choice," a label many of them claim with pride, means supporting public financing of abortion for poor women, sharply curtailing the states' abilities to regulate abortion and including abortion services in a national health-care plan. 
 Lawmakers who consider themselves "pro-life" have to decide what can be realistically achieved without an abortion foe in the White House.
The issues of abortion accessibility that are now before Congress are of great subtlety and have far less public support than the question of abortion's legality. The White House has handled them gingerly in recent weeks, and the wariness on Capitol Hill is palpable.
Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, is emblematic of the lawmakers caught in the middle. "I really believe there is a national consensus on this issue that is not represented by the views of either pro-life or pro-choice lobbyists," he said. "Folks are still struggling, but they probably come down with the position, 'Keep it legal, don't encourage it.' "
But Mr. Durbin, who describes his stance "as a middle position where I get battered from both sides," said he had yet to decide how abortion services should be treated in a national health plan. "It's a tough one," he said, "and at this point I just don't have the answer."
Groups on each side of the abortion issue are pushing hard, recognizing the crucial period now beginning as Congress returns from its Fourth of July recess. Supporters of abortion rights, with an agenda that seeks to undo many of the policies of the last 12 years, have already suffered an initial, embarrassing defeat when the House approved the Hyde Amendment, which would permit Federal financing of abortions for poor women only in cases of rape, incest or when the life of the pregnant woman was in danger.
 
Signs of Trouble
 Now, abortion-rights groups are battling to keep the proposed Freedom of Choice Act, the centerpiece of their legislative agenda, on track. That measure, intended to put the constitutional right to abortion into Federal law and prohibit most state restrictions on it, faces serious and mounting difficulties.
One of the latest signs of trouble was the announcement by Senator Carol Moseley Braun, Democrat of Illinois, that she was ending her support because the bill did not go far enough to protect the rights of poor women.
Further evidence of splintering support came this week when Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat and staunch supporter of abortion rights, told reporters that Senator Braun's position was "courageous" and added that it would be difficult to move forward with the bill "without consolidated support" among abortion-rights leaders.
Anti-abortion forces, at the moment, are presenting more of a united front. Widely discounted after losses in the 1992 elections, they have retooled their strategy to concentrate on the lawmakers in the middle, and they seem rejuvenated by their victory in the first legislative round.
The National Right to Life Committee and its allies are portraying the Freedom of Choice Act as an extremist and profoundly anti-democratic measure that seeks to force a national policy of "abortion on demand" on all 50 states.
 
Time for Directness
 Each of these issues is replete with nuances, amendments and exemptions that lawmakers have rarely been asked to confront so directly.
For example, where is the consensus on Federal financing of abortions for poor women? Is it, as passed by the House, in cases of rape, incest and saving the life of the pregnant woman? What about to preserve the "health" of the pregnant woman, which anti-abortion forces assert amounts to abortion on demand? What about leaving the matter up to the states, and simply reimbursing those states that choose to pay for abortions under the Medicaid program for the poor?
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "While gradually things are moving in a pro-choice direction, there's still a crucial swing vote of people who are marginally pro-choice or pro-choice with qualifications -- and that is the fulcrum."
Representative Jim Slattery, Democrat of Kansas, argues that President Clinton will move beyond that center if he includes abortion services in his national health package. "He'll spend a lot of time arguing about abortion instead of health care," Mr. Slattery said.
As abortion-rights organizers have already discovered, the lawmakers in the middle are hard to count and hard to predict. "First of all, they hate to vote on the issue," said Representative Vic Fazio, the California Democrat who is a leader of the abortion-rights camp. "And, second, they hate to talk about it."
The White House might have been expected to try to lead the way toward a new consensus. Throughout the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton talked of making abortion "safe, legal and rare," suggesting that he would try to articulate a reproductive health program that would both protect abortion rights and work to prevent unintended pregnancies.
But abortion-rights organizers say the White House has been less than vocal on the issue as the legislative struggle heats up. Mr. Clinton submitted a budget that would have dropped the current Hyde Amendment, which allows Federal financing only when the life of the pregnant woman is in danger, but his Administration has yet to unveil the compromise language to replace it.
The Administration's stance prompted considerable grumbling among abortion-rights groups in the aftermath of their remarkably broad defeat on the Hyde Amendment.
"I would have liked to have seen them be a little more in control here on this," said Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League. "I think they're trying to avoid all kinds of controversy that might distract them from economic policy or health-care reform as a whole. But in doing so, they may be losing some very vital battles along the way that will weaken them over the long term."
Defeat on the Hyde Amendment has prompted supporters of abortion rights to review more carefully the political status of the Freedom of Choice Act. The Democratic leadership had little choice over the timing of the Hyde vote; it came on a spending bill that must be passed by the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. But those leaders can decide when -- and whether -- to bring the Freedom of Choice Act to the floor. This, in fact, is the next big strategic decision on the abortion issue.
Supporters of the bill are fighting on two fronts. On one side are abortion opponents; on the other are abortion-rights supporters who dislike the bill because it would let states deny public financing for abortions and require some form of parental or adult notification for minors.
The battle over taxpayer financing of abortions, in the meantime, moves into the Senate; abortion opponents acknowledge that they face a tougher challenge there, but after their Hyde victory they enter in a stronger position than many had expected.
But the issue of financing abortions for the poor is considered only a preview of the struggle over health care. Mr. Clinton, who explicitly promised in last year's campaign that he would include abortion services in any national health-care plan, must now decide how to handle the issue.

HEADLINE: Arizona Power Revenue Bonds

 BODY:
The Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District of Arizona is offering $580.2 million of electric system revenue bonds that were initially priced yesterday to yield a maximum 5.625 percent for an issue due in 2029.
Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company said yields on two other long maturities were 5.62 percent for a bond due 2019, and 5.57 percent for another due in 2013. 
 For shorter maturities, serial bonds are priced to yield from 2.65 percent in 1994 to 4.30 percent in 1998, 4.85 percent in 2003, 5.25 percent in 2008 and 5.50 percent in 2010.
All the bonds in the refunding issue, which are tax-exempt, are expected to be rated double-A by Moody's and S.& P.

HEADLINE: Troubles at Empire Blue Cross Reflect a Failure of Management

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You apply an unfairly broad brush when you paint a picture of blame for the dismal financial performance of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in "The Failure to Police Empire" (editorial, July 2).
Arthur Andersen & Company was retained by the New York State Insurance Department to perform a broad management and financial review of Empire's performance, not an audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards. Another independent public accounting firm has for many years audited Empire's financial statements to comply with statutory reporting requirements. 
 Our firm was engaged to help identify ways to solve Empire's problems and improve its future prospects; our role was not to assign blame for past mistakes. When we began last October, many of Empire's financial failings were already well known and well documented. Our review helped identify the course necessary to set Empire on the road to recovery. Our final report contained more than 120 detailed recommendations designed to improve virtually every aspect of Empire's operating performance and financial condition.
Developing these recommendations required an analysis of Empire's weaknesses and their underlying causes. But it is misleading to claim we "concluded that Empire's problem was primarily due to the practices of commercial competitors." That erroneously implies we concluded that Empire's management bore no responsibility for the company's poor performance.
While we determined that Empire's performance was seriously affected by economic forces and market pressures, we also concluded that Empire's management had failed to position the company as a competitive player in New York's health insurance market.
In particular, our report criticized the "autocratic" and "hierarchical" style of senior management and concluded that Empire had been "slow to appreciate the accelerating pace of change in the insurance market and even slower to respond to the ensuing challenges." To some, these management failures may reflect poor business judgment; to others, they may constitute mismanagement, incompetence or malfeasance. Those determinations are best left to others, including Empire's board of directors, regulators and elected officials.
Finally, you inaccurately suggest that our independence was compromised by the fact that Arthur Andersen & Company has had a "business relationship" with Empire. That "relationship" consisted of three prior contracts of limited duration, narrow in scope and confined to one part of Empire's organization. Moreover, the existence of these contracts was fully disclosed in our proposal to the New York Insurance Department, which agreed that this past work created no conflict of interest nor impaired our objectivity.
 
LOUIS P. SALVATORE
New York Area Managing Partner
Arthur Andersen & Company
New York, July 8, 1993

HEADLINE: South Africa Looks Better to Investors

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 6 Business Day article on reinvestment in South Africa raises important questions about the challenges faced in encouraging investment in a future democratic South Africa. However, the article lacks balance, arguing that when Nelson Mandela, the head of the African National Congress, calls for the lifting of sanctions and opens the door to investors, the reaction will be great caution from companies and investors who have a policy against investing in South Africa. We disagree. 
 The Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility has actively campaigned against apartheid in South Africa for almost 25 years.
Church investors who are part of the center hold $35 billion in their portfolios. In addition, we work closely with other social investment leaders, as well as with many state and city pension funds.
When official arrangements for the general election in South Africa next April are finalized, the call by South African democratic leaders to lift sanctions will be issued.
Concerned institutional investors, from the Episcopal Church to the United States Trust Company in Boston, from the Evangelical Lutheran Church to the Calvert Social Investment Fund are prepared to respond to that call by ending their divestment policies and encouraging corporations to invest in a new South Africa as responsible citizens.
Shareholder campaigns against companies with South African ties will end, and so will boycotts. Cities, states, colleges, unions and foundations will respond to a South Africa on the road to democracy by canceling their old policies.
This is in the spirit of supporting the struggle for change by listening to the voices of South African leaders. There will be no legitimate voices in South Africa urging continued economic pressure. How could we in the United States fail to respond in a similar fashion?
Of course, companies will continuously assess their options, but some like Digital Equipment and Lotus have already made the leap. There are now 150 companies with investments in South Africa, and scores of others are drawing up contingency plans for the future.
We expect that the call to lift sanctions will be welcomed by socially concerned investors in the United States, who will put aside past divestment and boycott policies and will instead urge American companies to invest as good citizens, following guidelines that are socially responsible in a South Africa that is free of apartheid.
 
TIMOTHY SMITH
Exec. Director, Interfaith Center
on Corporate Responsibility
New York, July 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Procter & Gamble in 12% Job Cut As Brand Names Lose Attraction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's leading maker of household and personal products, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 12 percent within four years as it seeks to cope with consumers' rising preference for less expensive products.
The announcement of cuts in Procter & Gamble's work force, which far exceed Wall Street's expectations, come as the economy has been generating new jobs only grudgingly and companies have been cutting back employment. But while many corporate layoffs have occurred in troubled industries -- from airlines to arms producers -- Procter & Gamble is a healthy company in a profitable industry. 
 As a result, Proctor & Gamble's corporate diet would appear to be a warning to other companies that face diminished loyalty from financially strained customers drawn to a growing array of lower-priced products.
 
 
Company Remains Strong
 The elimination of 13,000 of 102,600 employees around the world might seem jarring, particularly for those affected and the communities where they live. But Procter & Gamble officials said the move was intended to make a strong company stronger and more capable of keeping its leading position among the manufacturers of household consumer products.
More than three-quarters of the items that Procter & Gamble makes -- scores of brands that include Tide detergent, Pampers diapers and Crest toothpaste -- rank first or second in market share in their respective categories.
"In broad terms, it looks as if Procter & Gamble ran up against a clash of pre-existing strategies of creating brand identities and the cyclical developments of the economy at large," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "With the recession, the subsequent sluggish recovery and only moderate income growth, consumers are being choosy about what they pay for."
The belt-tightening ought to be good for the company, he added, "as it represents a trend toward leaner production costs and smaller margins."
Procter & Gamble, which is based in Cincinnati and operates in 54 countries, said that half of the 13,000 jobs would be eliminated through plant closings. About 30 of its 147 manufacturing plants around the world will be shut down over the next four years.
The other half of the jobs will be lost though a plan to reorganize operations. Company officials said that many of the cuts were aimed at eliminating duplicated jobs and would be achieved through early retirements, buyouts, normal attrition and reduced recruitment. But layoffs are also expected.
Linda Ulrey, a company spokeswoman, said at least 4,000 jobs would be lost from Procter & Gamble's United States work force of 47,500.
While acknowledging that the cuts would be unfortunate for those affected, Edwin L. Artzt, the chairman and chief executive of Procter & Gamble, said the result would be a more efficient and more profitable company.
"The public has come to think of restructuring as a sign of trouble, but this is definitely not our situation," Mr. Artzt said in a statement. "We have a healthy, growing business, a strong balance sheet, positive cash flow, state-of-the-art products and a well-stocked technology pipeline with plenty of opportunities for growth. However, we must slim down to stay competitive."
Earlier this year, when Procter & Gamble first acknowledged the possibility that it might substantially reduce its work force, its intent was lauded by many analysts who follow the company for brokerage firms. Several agreed that inasmuch as Procter & Gamble has achieved hallmark status among consumer product companies for its profitability and brand integrity, the move was shrewdly pro-active.
Now that the cuts have been made formal, some economists suggest that other companies will take comparable ambitious steps.
"That a company is doing well doesn't mean we shouldn't expect to see a reorganization of this sort," said John F. Cogan, an economist who served in the Reagan Administration and is now a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, a conservative research organization at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif.
Procter & Gamble did not identify which manufacturing plants would be closed nor all of those where jobs would be cut.
In Cincinnati, where the company is the city's largest employer, with about 14,500 people working at its headquarters and plants, 2,000 jobs will be cut. That follows a decision by the General Electric Company, another big Cincinnati employer, to reduce its work force at an aircraft engine plant by 2,500 this year and by another 1,400 by the end of 1994.
"This is pretty devastating, especially when you read executives of P.&G. telling us how bad we need the North American Free Trade Agreement," said Dan Radford, executive secretary and treasurer of the Cincinnati A.F.L.-C.I.O. Labor Council. "You hate to see a community get hit like this."
Joseph Kramer, vice president of the economic development department of the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, described the cuts as "certainly a negative," particularly after the region had gained 6,000 jobs in 1992 to offset the loss of an equal number in 1991.
To pay for the changes, Procter & Gamble said a reserve fund of $1.5 billion would be set aside, with $1.2 billion to cover the costs of plant closings and the rest for its reorganization program.
With that $1.5 billion, combined with $925 million to adopt accounting charges for deferred taxes and retiree benefits, which retroactively apply from July 1, 1992, the company said it anticipated a $500 million loss for the fiscal year that ended on June 30.
Even so, the company announced that it would raise the annual rate of its common stock dividend from $1.10 to $1.24 a share, an increase of more than 10 percent.
"These changes will be difficult for some of our employees," Mr. Artzt said. "That's the painful part of these otherwise positive and productive efforts. We will do everything we can to help those employees whose jobs may be changed or lost to relocate within the company or find a new career opportunity."

HEADLINE: L.I. Man Linked to 18 Deaths Pleads Not Guilty to Murder

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 15

 BODY:
As relatives of two murder victims linked to Joel Rifkin watched from a packed courtroom today, the unemployed landscaper pleaded not guilty to killing a 22-year-old Manhattan woman whose body was found last month in the back of his pickup truck.
"I am not guilty," Mr. Rifkin said slowly and deliberately at his arraignment here before Judge Ira H. Wexner of Nassau County Court. 
 Mr. Rifkin's statement at his brief appearance was his first public comment since his arrest on June 28, when the authorities say he confessed to killing 17 women over the last three years and dumping their bodies in rivers and woods across the metropolitan area. The state police say they have evidence linking Mr. Rifkin to an 18th victim.
Guarded by a phalanx of court officers, Mr. Rifkin, dressed in a striped shirt and gray pants, stood without expression before Judge Wexner, who ordered that he continue to be held without bail in the Nassau County Jail.
After the arraignment, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Robert Sale, said his client's plea meant that despite the confessions the state police said they obtained, Mr. Rifkin "wants to have his day in court."
 
First Murder Charges
 Earlier this week, a grand jury indicted Mr. Rifkin, 34, on second-degree murder charges in the killing of the young Manhattan woman, Tiffany Bresciani. Her body was found wrapped in a tarpaulin in Mr. Rifkin's truck by state troopers who had chased his truck after they noticed that it had no license plate. He was also charged with reckless endangerment because of the chase. The Bresciani case is the first in which Mr. Rifkin has been formally charged.
Among the spectators in the tiny, crowded courtroom were the mothers and a sister of two other women whom the police suspect Mr. Rifkin of killing. Maria Alonso, the mother of Anna Lopez, whose body was found in Putnam County, and Margarita Gonzalez, the mother of Jenny Soto, whose body washed up on the banks of the Harlem River, sat together in the courtroom. As the arraignment ended, Mrs. Gonzalez began to shriek and moan.
Mrs. Gonzalez's daughter told reporters that she and her mother had come to the arraignment to get a glimpse of Mr. Rifkin, "even if it's just for two minutes."
"To me, he's an animal," she said, as her mother dissolved in tears.
As they attempted to leave the Nassau County Courthouse, the crush of television news crews and photographers pressing in on the women became so intense that the Gonzalezes had to flee under the protection of a court officer.
Mr. Sale told reporters that because of the number of jurisdictions involved -- bodies linked to Mr. Rifkin have been found in New York City and Suffolk, Westchester, Orange and Putnam counties -- he was proposing that all the cases against Mr. Rifkin be tried in Nassau County.
 
Single Trial
 "Instead of having multiple trials before multiple juries, we'd have one trial," Mr. Sale said. He said that the various charges in each jurisdiction could be presented before separate juries in the same courtroom. Otherwise, he said, the process of trying Mr. Rifkin could take years.
Fred Klein, the Nassau assistant district attorney handling the Bresciani case, was skeptical of Mr. Sale's proposal for consolidating the cases. "It's highly unusual," Mr. Klein said. "I don't see the other jurisdictions would want to go along with that."
Kevin L. Wright, the Putnam County District Attorney, said prosecutors in all the jurisdictions involved in the case are to meet with Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, in the next two weeks. But he said there was "little likelihood" of the proposal gaining acceptance.
To try to identify possible victims, the New York State Police released photographs of a woman that were retrieved by investigators from Mr. Rifkin's East Meadow home.
Trooper Thomas R. Collins, a state police spokesman, said his agency had been unable to contact or identify the woman and requested anyone with information to contact the state police.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 8.38 Points; Other Indicators Off

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Weakness among oil, drug and technology stocks yesterday drained the momentum from Wednesday's stock market rally, causing most leading indicators to slip slightly.
Only the Dow Jones industrial average posted a gain. After sagging for most of the day, it rose 8.38 to close at 3,550.93, about four points shy of its record high.
 
Nasdaq Falls 3.80 Points
 The Nasdaq composite fell back 3.80 from Wednesday's record closing high, ending at 708.69. The Standard & Poor's Index of 500 stocks fell 0.86, to 449.22, and the American Stock Exchange composite was off 0.69 at 437.98. 
 Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 277 million shares, compared with 297 million shares Wednesday.
"It was kind of a quiet, consolidative day," Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst at MMS Internationa, said. "A little disappointing after yesterday's rally, but we were encouraged by the close." Bargain-hunting late in the day salvaged the Dow, he said.
Mr. Walberg said that given the current low inflation and interest rates, he expected the summer rally to get back on track, with a new record high for the Dow by Monday and a run at the 3,600 level by the end of the month.
With the exception of oil stocks, which fell on continued concern about the low price of crude, most gains and losses yesterday stemmed from actual earnings reports, expectations about earnings reports or rumors about expectations about earnings reports. As for earnings reports so far, Mr. Walberg said, "There has been much more good news than bad."
But bad news has taken a toll. Companies that build computer networking systems for businesses were down sharply yesterday, undercutting the Nasdaq composite.
Synoptics Communications ignited the selloff with its second-quarter report, which showed earnings in line with analysts' expectations but a 2 percentage-point decline in gross profit margin. Its stock fell 6 1/4 a share, to 31 3/4, in Nasdaq trading.
Also in Nasdaq trading, Cisco Systems, another network builder, lost 4 a share to close at 52 1/4; the Chipcom Corporation fell 3 3/4 to close at 46 3/4, and Novell dropped 1 1/4, to 23 1/2.
Drug stocks also took a beating after an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris & Upham lowered her investment opinion of 12 of them because of the growing popularity of generic substitutes and the imminent expiration of several patents. Shares of Merck & Company fell 1, to 33 3/4, and Pfizer shares lost 1 1/2 to close at 63 1/4.
Among stocks that compose the Dow, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing led the gainers, climbing 2 1/4, to 110. It was the company's strongest showing since the shock of its lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings report last month. Investors were probably drawn to the company by the good economic news of the last couple of days, Peter J. Enderlin, managing director of Smith Barney, said.
One of the most active stocks on the New York exchange was a new issue, China Tire Holdings Ltd, a tire manufacturer. The company offered 6.1 million shares at 17 each. The stock closed at 18 after 3.37 million shares changed hands.

HEADLINE: Rising Incomes Suggest Economic Recovery

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Suggesting that a recovery is finally underway in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, economists at Rutgers University said yesterday that last year personal incomes in all three states rose as fast as in the nation or faster, following three years when they had lagged far behind.
The analysis found that one distinction for the region had not changed -- its workers make more money than their counterparts in most other states. In a ranking of states by per capita incomes for 1992, Connecticut ranked first at $26,979, New Jersey ranked second at $26,457 and New York ranked fourth at $23,534, behind Massachusetts. Nationally incomes averaged $19,841 last year. 
 The economists at Rutgers, New Jersey's largest university, said a shifting pattern of income growth demonstrated that the region's long recession was over, that it was growing more prosperous and that its recovery may be picking up steam.
 
'A Distinct Turnaround'
 "A distinct turnaround in income growth occurred between 1991 and 1992," said the report. The shift, it added, "implies the beginning of an economic rebound."
But the authors of the report, James W. Hughes, a professor of planning, and Joseph J. Seneca, an economist, said one important element of recovery is lacking from the region's economic landscape. While incomes are rising for those who are employed, vast numbers of jobs that were wiped out during the recession are not being restored.
The region may be experiencing "jobless economic growth, where an improving economy coexists with a stagnant labor market," they said. Because computers and advanced telecommunications have permanently eliminated many jobs, and because companies are determined to increase the productivity of the existing workers without additional hiring, the number of jobs in the region may not rebound anytime soon.
"This ominous scenario may well be the key political-economic issue of the era," the report said.
 
Sluggish Population Growth
 And while the region's workers have benefited from a robust increase in earnings, the Rutgers analysis found that overall earnings in the region have lagged behind the national average, even in 1992. It attributed the slow increase to the region's sluggish rate of population growth, which has lagged far behind the national rate, meaning the region's pool of wage earners has also grown slowly.
Still, experts said yesterday that the Rutgers analysis was good news for a region that has been mired in recession for four years.
"It's very encouraging," said Matthew P. Drennan, an economist at Cornell University. He added that the region's fast pace of income growth was an important indication of economic strength because many of the jobs that have been eliminated since 1988 have been among highly paid managers and corporate workers.
The elimination of those jobs might have created a severe drag on income growth across the region, Mr. Drennan said. But because incomes have been rising, "it looks as though new things are replacing the middle-management jobs that have been lost," he added.
In its report, the Rutgers researchers found that per capita incomes in Connecticut rose 3.9 percent in 1992, the same rate as for the nation. New York and New Jersey fared better, with per capita incomes rising 4.3 percent in each state.
 
Paltry Income Gains
 The rate of income gains was paltry compared with the mid-1980's, when the New York region enjoyed an economic boom and when earnings soared in many industries, including construction, securities and law. In 1988, before the recession set in, all three states in the region experienced per capita income increases of 7.7 percent or more, compared with an average of 6.2 percent for the nation.
But from 1988 to 1991, the report said, income gains in the region fell far short of those in most other parts of the nation.
"We had moved from the economic penthouse to the economic basement," the Rutgers researchers said.
In 1991, the report said New Jersey, with a 1.5 percent increase in per capita income, ranked 46th among the states. Connecticut ranked 45th, with a 1.7 percent gain, and New York ranked 34th, with a 2.2 percent gain.

HEADLINE: A Long Wait for a New Life Is Not Quite Over;
For Haitian Refugees Released From Guantanamo, Housing Delay Prolongs Hardship

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
Etienne Edmont thought for sure that his odyssey from Haiti to the United States would soon be over after he was released four weeks ago from the Guantanamo Naval Base in Cuba.
After enduring 20 months of isolation from family and friends under the watchful eyes of armed soldiers, he had expected to move into an apartment in Brooklyn that New York City social workers had shown him two weeks after his arrival. 
 He is still waiting.
"We did not come here to live in a motel," said Mr. Edmont, 30 years old, sitting in the lobby of a motel near Kennedy International Airport where he has been staying. "I thought everything would go fast, but I see that is not the case."
Mr. Edmont, who worked as a money changer on the streets of Port-au-Prince, is one of about 35 Haitian refugees who are still waiting for the housing they were promised after a judge's order forced the United States to free about 200 Haitians from the Guantanamo camp. Most of the 200 had been kept there after being found to have H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Although city officials say they are moving as fast as they can to help resettle the Haitians, the refugees and their advocates say they feel as if the bureaucracy is moving at a snail's pace.
 
'Yet Another Way Station'
 "This is yet another way station for them," said William Broberg, crisis intervention director at the Coalition for the Homeless, one of several agencies involved in resettling the Haitian refugees.
While the other agencies help resettle refugees with relatives in the New York area who are willing to house them, the Coalition for the Homeless helps to find housing for refugees with no relatives in the area.
While more than 65 of the newest refugees without families have moved into apartments the city found for them, the others remain stranded in the motel because of what Mr. Bromberg described as administrative bungling. In some cases it is a simple matter of the rental checks being issued in the wrong amounts or the name of a refugee being misspelled. The checks then have to be reissued, prolonging the refugees' stay at the motel.
"What makes it worse is that the city is replicating the same thing they went through at Guantanamo," he said. "By keeping them here, it's breeding resentment."
 
'A Moral Obligation'
 Burton Blaustein, deputy commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, rejected the criticism, saying his agency has two Creole-speakers who are working seven days a week to help resettle the Haitians. In the last week, five more Haitians have been moved into apartments.
"Any complaints are way out of line," said Mr. Blaustein "We have a moral obligation to these people who have spent years at Guantanamo and we have bent over backward to help them." But he said he had no estimate on when they would find permanent housing.
The refugees' journey began in September 1991 after a bloody coup that toppled Haiti's president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Jittery soldiers roamed the streets and valleys of the mountainous country shooting indiscriminately at the populace. Others were marked for death.
Fearing for their lives, more than 40,000 people boarded rickety boats en route to the United States. As boatloads of refugees began to dot the Caribbean sea, the Bush Administration opened Guantanamo as a temporary immigration processing and detention center.
 
Economic Refugees Sent Back
 More than 10,000 were found to have a legitimate claim to file for political asylum. They were sent to the United States over the last two years to continue their asylum appeals. The roughly 200 refugees who had tested positive for H.I.V., or who were their children or spouses, were held at Guantanamo until the court order sent them to the United States four weeks ago. The others were deemed to be economic refugees and sent back to Haiti.
For the refugees still living at the motel, surrounded by the constant roar from airplanes overhead and drone of cars on the Belt Parkway, the uncertainty of their home is consistent with the constant state of flux since they were first detained at Guantanamo.
Some pass the days playing dominoes. Others smoke and listen to music from portable radios while others stroll around the neighborhood. There are no parties and no celebrations.
They eat a small breakfast of eggs and bacon in the motel's restaurant. But rice and beans and Creole-spiced meat are delivered by Haitian restaurants to the motel during lunch and dinner. The Coalition for the Homeless pays for the meals.
"We thank the Government for delivering us from the jail at Guantanamo, but our situation right now is still unchanged," Mr. Edmont said.
Another refugee at the motel, 28-year-old Donald Dupre, added: "I just want to be somewhere I can relax. It's been a long time."
 
Labeled by Fear of AIDS
 Complicating their existence, though, is the stigma of having H.I.V. Many of the 200 refugees say they are not sick because they have yet to show any symptoms common to patients with full-fledged AIDS.
"I want to be tested by an independent doctor," said Lionel Charles, 27, "Until then, I don't know."
But Widmayer Jean, 29, who spent 14 months at Guantanamo, was more strident. "It's purely political," he said. "I don't have AIDS. No one has ever given me any medications." Federal officials say that all the diagnoses were made in medical tests at Guantanamo.
As the refugees struggled to resume their lives in New York, those interviewed said they are still haunted by their stay at Guantanamo.
Because of the diagnosis of H.I.V., the refugees were isolated from the others and taken to a remote area of Guantanamo. There, they said, they shared their sleeping quarters with rats, snakes and other animals.
It was because of these conditions that last month a Federal judge in Brooklyn, Sterling Johnson Jr., called their confinement "a squalid H.I.V. camp" and ordered their release, effectively closing the refugee camp.
 
Doctors' Snubs Recalled
 The refugees said that doctors refused to shake their hands and wore gloves and surgical masks during the slightest contacts. They were kept under the constant watch of armed soldiers. And they said their living quarters were as bare as the arid mountains that surrounded the camp.
So they staged hunger strikes. They set fire twice to the tents, and the adults stopped participating in any organized activities. Four refugees tried to commit suicide by hanging themselves with sheets.
"It was like they put us somewhere and waited for us to die," said Mr. Jean, a refugee who is now living with his wife and sister-in-law in Brooklyn.
Mr. Charles, like some other refugees, said he would like to put the experience behind him and resume his life here.
"At least I was alive," he said waiting for his luggage at La Guardia Airport after his arrival last month. "If I was in Haiti, I would have been killed."
Since arriving in New York, Mr. Charles, who lives in Jamaica, Queens, with his sister, says he is awed by the subway and the teeming Manhattan skyline dotted by glass and steel buildings.
He said he hopes to get a job, save some money and eventually attend college and study law.
"I know that this place can provide a lot of opportunity and I would like to take my chances," he said. But with the national uneasiness over immigrants, opportunities may be few for the other refugees.
Mr. Edmont, who left his wife and three children in Haiti, along with 12 brothers and sisters, says he just wants to settle into an apartment so he can start working and sending money back home.
"I will do anything," he said. "My problems are big."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally Shows Market Adapting to Weak Economy

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Two truths about the continuing bond rally have been overlooked -- and may give its outlook a different shading.
Attention has been focused mainly on the positive news on inflation, which has been seen as the force driving down the yield on the closely watched 30-year bond. Its yield was unchanged yesterday at 6.56 percent, its lowest level in 16 years. 
 But another factor deserves as much credit for the downward swing: the growing belief that the economy, rather than recovering, is going to continue to be sluggish.
 
 
No Longer the Bellwether
 And the rally may have focused too much attention on the 30-year bond as an indicator of where interest rates are headed. This attention may in itself be misguided. The 30-year bond, for many traders, is no longer the bellwether of the $2.3-trillion-a-day Government securities market. And it will be less so when the Treasury begins to slash its regular auctions of 30-year bonds this fall.
The push to lower interest rates based on expectations of continuing weak economic growth will only be strengthened if the Administration wins approval for its deficit-reduction plan. The deficit plan includes major tax increases, which should be a drag on the economy. Also down the road is the Administration's health-care plan, which is likely to include even more tax increases.
For many forecasters, this means that interest rates will be moving lower even if the inflation reports over the next several months are good but not as sparkling as those for the last two months. But if inflation remains stable and economic data show that the economy is growing faster than expected, the bond market rally may run into trouble because of the prospects of higher prices in the future.
Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, said the expectation of slow growth had been a key element in the recent bond rally. "If you had a vision of an economy solidly grounded, even if inflation rates were moderate now, you would be truly fearful down the road," he said.
 
 
Not-So-Great Expectations
 Because the bond market is now counting on sluggish growth, any effort by the Clinton Administration to spur the economy, such as tinkering with the deficit-reduction package, can disturb the rally.
As for the role of the 30-year bond, its yield is still followed closely and quoted often. But the 10-year note is a better reflection of the long-term rates that affect the economy because it is a guidepost for mortgages.
Most bond traders also watch the 5- and 10-year notes. The notes are traded more actively, are used in hedging strategies and are bought heavily by cities and towns that are paying off older, higher interest-rate loans with new low interest-rate borrowing.
"For market participants, the five-year note is the bellwether," said William Pike, managing director at Chemical Securities, a primary dealer. "It comes more often," he said, referring to the regular monthly Treasury auctions, "and it is traded by more people."
The 30-year bond does not even offer a good comparison with interest rates in other countries, where 10-year maturities are typical.
These factors have eroded the bellwether status of the 30-year bond for some time. What will challenge its role even further is the Treasury's decision to cut the amount it issues by 40 percent and to hold two auctions a year instead of four.
These changes could make movements in yields and prices of the long bond more subject to extraneous factors, like supply, instead of economic fundamentals.
 
 
Effect of Supply
 "It is possible that supply considerations could exaggerate the fall in long-term rates, but I wouldn't expect them to be large," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
John P. Costas, the managing director of trading at the First Boston Corporation, summed up the status of the bond this way: "It is still the bellwether because it is the most often quoted. But it's not representative of what is going on in the market."
After the next Treasury auction in August, "it is going to be interesting to watch what happens," he added.
There will then be a six-month span with no new 30-year bonds sold. No one is sure how the bond and the market will react to such a new trading environment.
 
Treasury Market
 There was little action in the Treasury market yesterday as traders and investors took a breather after the positive reports on inflation that came out on Tuesday and Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged. Prices on Treasury notes were little changed, including the 10-year note, whose yield remained unchanged at 5.70 percent.
In the municipal market, the Puerto Rico Highway and Transportation Authority sold almost $1.2 billion in tax-exempt bonds, the second-largest municipal issue of the year. The lead underwriter was Merrill Lynch & Company.
Yields on the longer-term bonds ranged from 5.70 percent in 2017 to 5.72 percent in 2021. The issue also included about $370 million in specially designed products called derivatives, which can offer a higher yield to the buyer but come with a lot more risk.
Among these products are inverse floaters, which allow the buyer to make more in interest if short-term interest rates remain steady or fall. But if they rise, the investor's return declines.

HEADLINE: Report Suggests Ledyard Casino Is Among the Most Profitable

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn., July 15

 BODY:
The Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino may be the most profitable casino in the country, according to a newspaper report today.
The Day newspaper of New London said it had obtained a financial statement showing that the casino had a $20.4 million profit in June. That is as much as some large casinos clear in an entire year. 
 Foxwoods's total revenue, including money made at table games, slot machines, bingo, restaurants and stores, was $40.8 million last month. That ranks Foxwoods among the largest casinos in Nevada and New Jersey in terms of the money spent and lost by customers.
 
Low Expenses
 With relatively low operating expenses of $19.1 million for June, according to the report, Foxwoods is far more profitable, in terms of both total profit and profit margin, say industry analysts.
"The numbers are incredible," said Marvin B. Roffman of Roffman-Miller Associates of Philadelphia, when told of the June revenue report. "This reservation has a license to coin money."
The Mashantucket Pequot Indians decline to discuss how much the casino is making, saying they prefer to keep their finances private.
William Eadington, a professor of economics at the University of Nevada-Reno who specializes in gambling issues, said that based on the June report, gambling revenues for the year at Foxwoods could be $400 million or more. That would place it among the country's largest casinos, like the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City and Mirage Resorts in Las Vegas.
But the operating expenses for those casinos is much higher, he said, largely because they have high debts from money borrowed to build them. The Mirage, for instance, had gambling revenues of $409 million in 1990, its opening year, but its annual pretax profit was just $30 million.
Mr. Roffman said that if the report is true, Foxwoods keeps as profit about half of every dollar it takes in as revenue.
That 50 percent margin compares with 30 percent or less for a huge operation like the Las Vegas-based Circus Circus, which is considered a carefully managed company, Mr. Roffman said. Many other operators have margins of 15 percent or less.

HEADLINE: A Report Sees Legislative Perils to S.& L.'s

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Legislation intended to complete the cleanup of the savings-and-loan industry might instead drive the remaining institutions out of business, according to a new report to Congress.
The report, written by an industry advisory committee and endorsed by top officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said the savings and loan industry would be unable to compete with banks if, as legislation pending in the House required, insurance premiums paid by the industry were made the main source of financing for a Federal fund that would insure deposits in the surviving S.& L.'s. 
 The bill has been passed by the Senate. In seeking to write a politically viable bill, lawmakers stripped away most taxpayer financing for the insurance fund, leaving the financial industry with the costs.
House Democratic leaders are now struggling to find enough votes to pass the bill, which has few avid supporters. A vote has been delayed, and the report could make the task even harder, said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a senior member of the House Banking Committee, which received the report on Tuesday.
The House panel says that the Senate-passed version must be changed to avoid a potentially lethal crisis.
 
Continuing Reluctance to Tax
 The Senate's version would provide $26.8 billion for the S.& L. cleanup, and the bill before the House, $34.3 billion. Both versions restrict the use of tax money for the new Savings Association Insurance Fund, with the House bill being especially restrictive. The fund, created in previous banking legislation, is to begin operations in October, when the Resolution Trust Corporation ceases taking over failed savings and loans.
But Congress declined last year to provide new money for either the R.T.C. or the insurance fund, and the costs of the unresolved savings and loan debacle continue to mount.
The new report, submitted to the House and Senate Banking Committees, was written by an expert panel established in 1989 when Congress passed the law to begin cleaning up the savings and loan industry.
The committee based its report on data from the F.D.I.C., which predicted a large gap between the premiums that would be paid by the surviving savings and loans and the lower ones to be paid by banks, a disparity the committee said would put the savings and loans at a potentially fatal competitive disadvantage. The F.D.I.C., the Federal bank insurance fund, is not saddled with S.& L. costs from the 80's, so its premiums are declining even as the banking industry returns to health.
The committee is made up of economists and savings-and-loan industry officials, and it reflects concerns about the legislation that have been festering in the industry for months.
The report is the first detailed analysis of how the proposed legislation would affect the industry. The committee said it was "staggered" when the F.D.I.C. predicted at a briefing on July 1 how much lower bank premiums would be than those paid by the savings and loans.
Steven A. Seelig, the F.D.I.C.'s chief financial officer, says there is a risk that the savings and loan industry, as it now exists, may virtually disappear if the financing legislation is enacted without changes.
Frank N. Newman, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, said in an interview that the F.D.I.C.'s projections were "a worst-case scenario" and that the Clinton Administration hoped the House would move swiftly to enact the bill so that the R.T.C. and the new fund could operate as intended.
But the committee said it was unrealistic to think that the Resolution Trust Corporation could finish taking over the weakest remaining institutions by Sept. 30, when the new fund is to assume responsibility. It called for a one-year extension of R.T.C. responsibility, a step neither the House nor the Senate is now considering.
The report's main long-term recommendation is that the legislation be altered to absolve the new insurance fund from a $770 million annual cost of paying interest on long-term bonds issued in 1989 to begin the S.& L. cleanup. It recommended this instead be paid from tax revenue.

HEADLINE: Business Sales Up 0.3%; Inventories Grow 0.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Business sales grew three-tenths of a percent in May, the Government reported today, outpacing a modest two-tenths of a percent gain in inventories and assuring analysts that stockpiles were being held in check.
"There are some pockets of problems," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, "but they're within the retail component, and even there it's not universal. Over all, there's no inventory problem at all." 
 Mr. Niemira said the inventory growth reported by the Commerce Department was consistent with the slow-growth economy.
 
Unemployment Claims Up
 Also illustrating the sluggish economy was a Labor Department report today showing that new claims for jobless benefits edged up 2,000 last week, to 334,000.
Still, the less volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims, which analysts prefer to track because it more accurately reflects the labor situation, fell 2,750, to 339,000, in the period ended last week -- the lowest level in five months.
The Commerce Department said business sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $586.89 billion in May, up from $584.94 billion a month earlier. April's sales, originally estimated to have fallen two-tenths of a percent, were revised to a two-tenths of a percent gain.
Inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $864.27 billion, up from $862.48 billion in April and the eighth straight increase. The April advance, however, was revised to four-tenths of a percent from tenth of a percent in the initial report.
The difference between inventories and sales resulted in an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.47, meaning that it would take 1.47 months to exhaust stockpiles at the May sales pace. Analysts said the ratio was not seriously high.
A high ratio could lead to production cuts and job losses as businesses reduce orders to shrink inventories.
Retail inventories were unchanged in May after growing five-tenths of a percent a month earlier. Stocks on both the factory and wholesale levels rose three-tenths of a percent.
Retail sales grew four-tenths of a percent in May, and in an advance estimate on Wednesday, the department reported that sales again rose four-tenths of a percent in June. May sales originally were estimated to be up just a tenth of a percent.
Factory sales fell five-tenths of a percent in May, but sales at the wholesale level jumped 1.7 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Uncertainty On the Exchanges in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday amid turmoil in the European markets.
Gold prices also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery settled at $393.90 an ounce, up $2.50. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for spot gold of $393.10 an ounce, up $2.10. 
 The dollar thrived on the rumors and realities of currency intervention and uncertainty in Europe. "It's really been focused on the troubles in Europe at the moment," said Amy Smith, a market strategist for the IDEA economic consulting group.
There were rumors in the morning, ultimately unfounded, that the Danish Government was going to devalue its currency. That set the stage for extreme selling of the currency, Mr. Smith said.
 
Rumor on Repo Rate
 That in turn gave rise to unfounded rumors that the German Bundesbank was going to lower its repo rate, or the rate for repurchasing money market securities, as a way to supply banks short of cash with fresh money.
"That was the rumor that sent the dollar higher," Mr. Smith said. "There's always attraction for the dollar whenever there is chaos in the world."
Other action showing the weakness of European currencies included the interventions by the Dutch and Danish central banks to support their currencies. They both bought the Danish krone and sold the Dutch guilder.
Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, agreed that the uncertainty over European currencies helped the dollar. "Once the panic subsides, the dollar will correct down," he said.
He noted that the the central banks of France and Germany were subtly trying to bolster their currencies by quietly adjusting overnight interest rates.
In New York, the dollar traded late at 108.01 Japanese yen, up from 107.10 yen late Wednesday. It was also quoted at 1.7205 German marks, up from 1.7150 marks on Wednesday, and 5.8805 French francs, up from 5.8565 francs. The British pound was quoted at $1.4915, down from $1.5035 late Wednesday.
