HEADLINE: Iraq Oil Sale Talks to Resume But a Critical Issue Remains

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 15

 BODY:
Diplomats agreed today to resume talks next week for a draft agreement on allowing Iraq to sell limited quantities of oil, but failed to address the crucial issue of whether Iraq would ship oil through its own terminal or its pipeline to Turkey.
The talks, which began on July 7, were suspended late Wednesday so the Iraqi delegation could seek further instructions from Baghdad. 
 "There wasn't even language on that point in the draft," one diplomat said, referring to the shipping issue.
Riyadh al-Qaysi, Iraq's Under Secretary in the Foreign Ministry, said that "we have reached a stage in the negotiating process where some questions arose."
A United Nations spokesman, Joe Sills, said the talks would resume "perhaps at the beginning of the week" but gave no date.
 
U.N. Seeks Close Supervision
 The United Nations, which imposed sanctions on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, wants Baghdad to sell limited amounts of oil under close supervision. Money from the sale would be used for food and medicine, including supplies for Kurds who are supported by United Nations agencies, as well as for other United Nations costs and for reparations to victims of Iraqi forces.
Baghdad has asserted that the monitoring is too intrusive and demands that most of its oil be shipped through its gulf port of Mina al-Bakr rather than through its pipeline to Turkey. Diplomats say they believe that the United States and Britain want at least 80 percent of the oil shipped through Turkey, where it would be easier to monitor.
The limited oil sale of $1.6 billion was demanded by the Security Council and is separate from easing or lifting the trade embargo that would allow oil to flow freely. Any broad agreement between the Iraqi and United Nations negotiators would require approval by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and the Security Council.
 
Washington's View
 And Washington might decide against the oil sale because it could be seen as making life easier for President Saddam Hussein and give Iraq an opening into the market when there is a world glut in oil production.
Iraq would prefer that the oil embargo be lifted entirely without restrictions, but this depends on certification from United Nations officials that Baghdad has complied with Persian Gulf war cease-fire resolutions to destroy its most dangerous weapons. But Western powers want full compliance with all relevant resolutions before lifting sanctions.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Talks on Arms Standoff
 BAGHDAD, Iraq , July 15 (Reuters) -- The chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq, Rolf Ekeus, and Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf met for two hours today in an effort to resolve a dispute over the monitoring of missile testing in Iraq.
"I can only say that we have initiated talks and that they will continue," Mr. Ekeus said after leaving the Foreign Ministry. Mr. Sahaf is to meet again on Friday with Mr. Ekeus, who heads a special commission in charge of dismantling Iraq's most dangerous weapons under terms of the Persian Gulf war cease-fire.
Before today's meeting, Iraq issued a statement saying it was not certain that Mr. Ekeus had come with good intentions.
"This is not yet clear," Information Minister Hamed Youssef Hammadi told the official Iraqi News Agency when asked whether Mr. Ekeus had come to talk or to pave the way for an attack on Iraq. "He himself has created this problem at a time when Iraq started dialogue with the United Nations. It is our opinion that raising the issue of installing the cameras was deliberately aimed at undermining this dialogue."
 
Monitoring Ordered
 Last month, the Security Council ordered Iraq to allow inspectors to place monitoring cameras at two missile-test sites south of Baghdad or risk the threat of retaliation. The Council wants to monitor the sites, where Iraq is allowed to test short-range missiles, to insure the Government does not resume building longer-range weapons that are prohibited under the cease-fire.
Heightening the tension, Washington raised the threat of a military strike after Iraq barred United Nations officials from sealing off the test sites as a temporary measure last week.
Iraq, which has accused the United Nations of changing the rules, says the organization must lift the sanctions now because Iraq has cooperated in destroying its weapons programs. But the United Nations says Baghdad must immediately accept long-term monitoring.

HEADLINE: London Journal;
Will Minicab Force the Mighty Taxi Off the Road?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 15

 BODY:
Waiting for his next fare just off Victoria Street the other day, Robert McDonald reminisced about the good old days of driving a cab in London.
"I was proud of my badge," Mr. McDonald said, referring to the license he was granted in 1959 after two grueling years bicycling around doing "the Knowledge," the intensive study of how best to get from point to point in London through a maze of more than 15,000 streets. 
 "I used to take people all around town, especially Americans, and show them the sights, and I could tell them all about London," Mr. McDonald said, sitting behind the wheel of one of the black taxis that have long been as much a symbol of London as Big Ben. "They loved it. Today? Today, it's no fun anymore."
London's taxi drivers retain their reputation for being among the world's most reliable. But Mr. McDonald and his 22,000 fellow drivers face the biggest upheaval in the London taxi trade since cars replaced horse-drawn carriages. If the more pessimistic among them are to be believed, the end could perhaps be near for the black cab itself.
 
The Agent of Change
 The unhappiness of the drivers is to some extent a function of Britain's poor economy, which has bitten deeply into their business. But the real agent of change is the minicab, the unlicensed competitor to the highly regulated black taxis. The minicabs first went on to London's streets in the early 60's, raising the threat even then of giving the standard black taxi a run for its money.
As their ranks have swelled, minicab drivers have increasingly been charged with crimes against passengers, particularly women traveling at night. Investigations have found many of them to lack proper insurance and to be driving unsafe vehicles (most minicabs are family sedans with no modifications). The police say many of the drivers are men who are otherwise unemployed, who are violating welfare regulations by working.
There are now at least 40,000 minicabs operating in the metropolis, and if their drivers might sometimes seem to have difficulty finding Buckingham Palace without a map, they have nonetheless become widely used.
Barred from plying for passengers on the street, minicab services respond speedily to telephone requests for pickups, particularly late at night or in outlying areas where few black taxis are to be found. Their fares vary widely and are often cheaper than those of licensed taxis.
At a time when competition for passengers is intense, some minicabs have infuriated their counterparts in black taxis by illegally seeking out passengers at railroad stations, hotels and nightclubs, leading to a growing number of street fights between licensed and unlicensed drivers.
Under pressure to rein in the minicabs and better protect their passengers, the Government is trying to develop a new system of regulation to cover both the traditional taxis and their new rivals.
Drivers of black taxis would like to see a single licensing standard, which would presumably be difficult if not impossible for most minicabs to meet. The solution most widely discussed so far, however, is to license the minicabs and their drivers, but not require them to meet the same standards as black taxis for training and for vehicle size and safety.
That type of two-tier licensing program is generally supported by the legitimate minicab companies, who say they want the business cleaned up in a way that would not put them out of business, and by consumer groups supporting passenger safety.
Such proposals, though, have left drivers of traditional cabs increasingly convinced that there will soon be no competitive benefit in the practices that have always set them apart: investing two years in doing the Knowledge, and then investing $33,000, twice the cost of a family car, in a vehicle whose specifications to this day reflect considerations like the required headroom for a gentleman in a top hat.
"We're a tradition then, aren't we?" said Charles Aylott, another driver, who was chatting with Mr. McDonald. "And like everything else, the Government's throwing it away."
The changes affecting the taxis come at an unsettled time for other forms of transportation in London. The red double-decker buses, for example, are starting to fade away as new private operators begin to introduce buses of different colors.
Steven Norris, the Minister of Transport for London, said he had not yet made a decision on a new regulatory plan. He said he would lay out the specific alternatives this summer for public debate as the first step toward developing whatever new regulations and laws might be needed.
Some drivers said that whatever decision Mr. Norris makes, it would be foolish of them not to recognize that the business is changing and that they will have to change with it. One change that drivers appear likely to consider is scrapping the traditional taxi vehicle.
 
'London Taxi Has Got to Go'
 Jim Wells, the chairman of the London Cab Driver's Club, said the cost of buying and maintaining the two current models of the traditional vehicles -- one introduced in 1958, the other in 1987 -- had got out of hand.
"The London taxi has got to go," Mr. Wells said, noting that drivers often pay several thousand dollars a year in upkeep on their taxis. "It's too old-fashioned, there are too many problems with it and it's ridiculous to keep trying to bring a vehicle designed for 1958 up to 1993 standards."
"The real old bangers don't want to change," Mr. Wells continued. "But we have to be realistic. The passengers we pick up are not prepared to pay more in fares, so we have to find ways to cut costs, and the vehicle is the obvious place to look."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I used to take people all around town, especially Americans, and show them the sights, and I could tell them all about London," said Robert McDonald, a driver of one of London's black taxis. The taxis are being threatened by the minicab, its unlicensed competitor. "Today, it's no fun anymore." (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Said to Accept Parts of Plan on Gay Ban

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to accept in large measure Defense Secretary Les Aspin's proposal for a limited lifting of restrictions on homosexuals in the military, but last-minute work is continuing to answer legal questions raised by Attorney General Janet Reno, Administration officials said tonight.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aspin met for more than two hours tonight as the Defense Secretary formally submitted his recommendation for a policy that would drop the military's current ban on homosexuals but limit how open they could be about their sexuality, the officials said. 
 One official said Mr. Clinton had decided to adopt Mr. Aspin's essential "don't ask, don't tell" approach but was seeking "refinements" that would make it somewhat less restrictive and would heed warnings from Ms. Reno that the policy could violate gay soldiers' Constitutional rights.
 
Deadline Set in January
 Today was the date set by Mr. Clinton in January when, faced with strong opposition from the military and in Congress, he delayed his plan to lift the ban and asked for a new proposal.
But Mr. Clinton told Congressional leaders this afternoon that he wanted to take two or three more days to study the recommendation before he gave his final approval. He also wants Attorney General Reno and her aides to review it once more before he signs off on it, officials said.
A senior Administration official characterized the Aspin compromise as a policy of "don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue." What that means is that new recruits would no longer be asked whether they are gay. But they would not be allowed to identify themselves as homosexuals once in the armed services, except to chaplains, doctors and lawyers. Homosexual conduct on or off base would still be prohibited.
 
Legal Concerns
 But in deference to the Justice Department and homosexual rights groups, the policy would also explicitly spell out the conditions under which the military could pursue an investigation into homosexual conduct.
Aides to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aspin were working tonight on these particulars, which were apparently added after Ms. Reno told the White House last week that the policy could be hard to defend in court. Officials said she cautioned that the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection under the law could be violated if the policy went too far in prohibiting homosexuals from saying things that heterosexual soldiers were free to express. Her role in the discussion was disclosed today in The Baltimore Sun.
Under the policy, a homosexual soldier who was seen going into a gay bar or gay church could not be investigated on those grounds alone. There would have to be "credible evidence" of either an acknowledgement of a homosexual orientation or homosexual behavior, and just going into a building would not constitute that.
This notion of "don't pursue" as a way of creating a little room for homosexuals in the military to express their sexual orientation more freely outside military bases was pushed by the President on Wednesday night in discussions with Secretary Aspin, who went over it today with the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Justice Department lawyers.
For the past few weeks, Secretary Aspin has been holding discussions with the Joint Chiefs, the Justice Department and the White House, trying to identify as many of these situations as possible so the recommended policy will make it clear to the President precisely what would and what would not lead to an investigation.
 
Leaving Room
 "What everyone wants to avoid is giving room for a homophobic commander to go around launching investigations of homosexual conduct wherever he feels like," said a senior Administration official. "We also want to avoid stimulating vigilante squads who will post themselves outside of gay bars and churches, filming everyone who goes in because they think that will trigger an investigation.
"But we also want to avoid giving license for someone to go up to their commanding officer and say, 'I'm gay, and I want everyone here to know that,' " the official said.
White House officials said that approach had won the general assent of the Attorney General, but Ms. Reno's office would not comment. Ms. Reno, who seemed to be trying to play down her role in any compromise, said late today: "All we're doing it is reviewing it to make sure that we are giving the best advice to the President."
White House officials acknowledged that the compromise would fall well short of the President's campaign promise to lift the ban on homosexuals unconditionally, as long as they did not engage in open homosexual conduct.
But White House officials said Mr. Aspin's formulation was all they believed they could achieve politically at a time when a bipartisan conservative coalition in Congress has threatened to write a homosexual ban into law if the President opens the military doors too wide. The Joint Chiefs of Staff have also resisted efforts to lift the ban.
 
Avoiding a Fight
 Because the President wants to focus on his economic package, the White House wants to avoid a political battle on the issue of homosexuals in the military.
Mr. Aspin has told White House officials that the Joints Chiefs of Staff will only accept a policy that would allow homosexuals to serve only if they abstained from public or private declarations of their sexual orientation, leaders of gay rights groups have said.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff voted two weeks ago for a policy that would retain the current statement that "homosexuality is incompatible with military service." But Secretary Aspin has apparently managed to persuade the chiefs to accept different wording that describes "homosexual conduct," not homosexual orientation, as incompatible with military service.
The administration has set an implementation date of Oct. 1 for the new policy.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Continuing Struggle;
Digging Out in Face of a New Threat

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa, July 15

 BODY:
The weather forecast today scared Jill Downing like a nightmare: Rain is expected this weekend and it could bring more flooding. On Saturday, high water forced 3,500 people here from their homes.
Ms. Downing is the manager of special events in the Valley Junction section of this town, a district of antique, craft and art shops and family restaurants built on faith and life savings. On Saturday, the district was consumed by flood water and is only now beginning to clean up its buildings and raise people's spirits. 
 Today, dozens of business owners and employees tore out flood-soaked walls, pulled up ruined carpets and wiped away tears, as the sight of the damage was almost too much for some to take.
Still, it was Ms. Downing's duty to walk the muddy streets and warn people that maybe they should stop rushing to rebuild their lives just yet because the river might be back.
 
'You Want to Deny'
 "Our feeling is we don't want them to clear up now and have to do it all over again," she said. "That could be too much. But people are reacting to this almost like a death, you want to deny it's happened or that it could happen again."
But there is reason to hope that the worst is over. The Raccoon River, which sent flood waters six blocks into Valley Junction, has dropped eight feet since sodden Saturday, and people here said they were willing to take a chance that more misery would pass them by.
"We have to reopen," said Craig Laws, who runs a restaurant, his brow dripping with sweat as he scrubbed the mud and slime from a table. "We have to survive, so I'm going to take my chances. I just don't think lightning is going to strike twice in the same place in less than a week."
And besides, Mr. Laws and his neighbors are tired of being pushed around by a river, of living with friends in cramped apartments miles away, of storing their belongings in three or four different places, of hearing their children cry, of watching their businesses and jobs die.
So they have returned with their hammers and crowbars, their rubber gloves and tetanus shots.
 
A Life Turned Around
 LueVeda Lau has returned because she is no stranger to hard times. She lost a job after 25 years and used her retirement money to open her restaurant and dress shop two years ago.
"I took my hurt then and turned it into a business," she said. "I don't know what I'm going to do with this new hurt."
Donna Martin, the owner of Donna's Dolls, a clothing and craft shop, is also back, offering a cool drink to a visitor who wants to know how it feels to lose so much so fast.
"The Lord only gives you what he knows you can handle," she said, standing in her store, ruined by the flood. "But I don't know how he figured it out."
And Russ Leckband hurried back, too. He spent today tearing down a wall at his mother-in-law's flood ravaged arts and crafts shop.
"You can't look at the whole picture because that will overwhelm you," he said. "You have to rebuild board by board, nail by nail."
Cleaning up will not be easy, even if the weather spares the city.
Unlike its big sister, Des Moines, this suburb of 37,000 residents does have running water. But people from all over the area have flocked here to use it and officials have placed strict controls on its use.
Next door in Des Moines, Mayor John (Pat) Dorrain said water for bathing and fire fighting should be running through the city's pipes on Sunday or Monday.
But the water will not be safe to drink for several more weeks and officials said they thought the levee at the city's crippled water plant had been built high enough to protect it in the event of another flood.
Today, Mayor Dorrain again ordered businesses in the city not to reopen until the water service was restored.
 
Lawn-Waterer Cut Off
 People in West Des Moines are prohibited from using city water to clean up their businesses until Des Moines can restore its water system on either Sunday or Monday. The other day, the city disconnected the water of a man who refused to stop watering his lawn.
"Until this crisis is over," said the fire chief, Randy Bracken, "he's going to be like Des Moines: no more water."
To clean the half-inch of muck on the floor of his antique furniture restoration business on Fifth Street, Jack Mendrys and his employees, Roger Vriezelaar and Mike Limke, brought up flood water still sloshing around in the basement.
"I'm 46 today," Mr. Mendrys said. "Tomorrow, I'll be 50 and I'll be older the next day. We're going to be out of business for at least 60 days."
The flood's timing caught many here off guard. At a town meeting on Friday, city officials said the river would crest on Monday or Tuesday, giving people time to empty their businesses. They based their warning on the forecasts of the National Weather Service.
"Then our two-day warning turned into 12 hours," Mr. Mendrys said, adding that city officials told people on Saturday morning that the predictions had changed and trouble would arrive around dusk.
Now, Mr. Mendrys and his employees will spend the next two months working without pay. He said he hoped the promised Federal money would be available soon, but he had little faith that the Government could take a breath in less than six months. He said the Federal Government had been discussing improving the levee system for the Raccoon River for more than 20 years.
"It takes them a long time to do anything," he said.
Construction on a $20 million levee project is scheduled to begin this fall because the Raccoon River had flooded this town before. The last time was in 1990, but then the water did not rise as far or as fast.
Mr. Limke, who has worked at Mr. Mendry's shop for five years, owns a home a few blocks away. At 7:50 P.M. Saturday, his property was dry. By 8:10 P.M., water was at his back door.
"The water sounded like someone was trying to break into the house with a bulldozer," he said.
With a plastic bag of clothes over his head, Mr. Limke fled, like thousands of other here, many of whom still have not returned. People started returning Wednesday.
Craig Webber never left. Mr. Webber, a 39-year-old construction worker, spent the entire flood in his house, surrounded by three feet of water. He slept on top of his kitchen table. He fell asleep at night to the sound of about six inches of water rippling on the floor.
When he needed supplies, he rowed to get them in his rubber raft. Today, he was trying to get the water out of his basement with a bucket. "These floods don't scare me," Mr. Webber said. "I had a ladder; I was ready to go up on my roof."
But he sent his two teen-age daughters and his 78-year-old mother to stay with relatives.
"I didn't want to have to worry about them swimming out," he said.
 
Clinton Seeking More Flood Aid
 DES MOINES, July 15 (Reuters) -- President Clinton is seeking an additional $2.47 billion in Federal aid to help flood victims in the Midwest. The request includes the following:
 *$800 million for the Federal Emergency Management Agency for individual and public relief grants and contingency funds.
*$945 million for the Department of Agriculture, of which $900 would be earmarked to help cover crop losses. The rest would be used to finance soil conservation and flood prevention efforts. This is on top of $400 million already budgeted.
*$300 million in Small Business Administration loans.
 *$153 million for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, most of which would be used as contingency funds for disaster related community development and low-income housing rebuilding.
*$100 million in contingency funds to the Commerce Department for economic development.
*$100 million to finance highway repairs.
*$65 million to the Army Corps of Engineers to finance flood control works repairs.

HEADLINE: Poll Says Conservatives Dominate Talk Radio

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The talk radio and call-in programs that have become a potent force in national politics distort public opinion because people heard on those shows are far more conservative than the general population, a poll released today concludes.
The survey, by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, found that talk shows, like telephone calls and letters to elected officials, are dominated by a "vocal minority" composed largely of Republicans who are more critical of President Clinton's overall job performance and economic program, and are more hostile to him personally than most people. 
 Mr. Clinton's disapproval rating, which the poll put at 43 percent, was 10 to 15 percentage points higher among people who had talked on the radio, written their Congressional representatives or responded to call-in polls.
The survey's findings suggest that in gauging public opinion, news organizations and politicians have put too much emphasis on the views of a very active, very loud and often very angry minority.
Almost half of all Americans listen to talk radio fairly often, the survey said, with one in six listening regularly. Eleven percent said they had tried to call into a radio program, and 6 percent said they succeeded in getting on a call-in program.
Of those who consider themselves regular listeners, 24 percent identified themselves as conservatives, and 11 percent as liberals.
The survey is based on telephone interviews with 1,507 adults nationwide, conducted May 18 to May 24 under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associations. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
The most striking difference between people who aggressively express their views on call-in shows and other forums and those who do not are in how they judge Mr. Clinton.
Asked about how they viewed President Clinton personally, 35 percent of the general public said they had an unfavorable opinion, while 49 percent of the talk-radio callers registered an unfavorable opinion.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Federal Aid;
Clinton Saying Flood Relief Will Cover Just Part of Loss

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
President Clinton sought today to quell any hopes that the Federal Government alone could bear the full cost of relief for all of the damage caused by the Midwestern floods.
As his Administration's own estimates of the damage swelled to $8 billion, Mr. Clinton did say he might have to seek an increase in the $2.5 billion in immediate assistance he had requested from Congress on Wednesday. But he made clear it that he was not contemplating aid on a wider scale. 
 "The Federal Government has never compensated natural disasters dollar for dollar for every kind of disaster loss," the President said this afternoon. He said some costs would have to be borne by local governments, private sources and the victims themselves, as has often been the case in earlier disasters, including the hurricane that hit Florida last summer.
Mr. Clinton spoke after meeting on Capitol Hill with lawmakers from the eight states stricken by floods. Some, including Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, had said Congress should prepare to spend as much as $9 billion to assist farmers, business owners and other victims of the floods.
 
'A Big Distinction'
 The director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, James Lee Witt, told lawmakers privately that the damage could eventually exceed $8 billion. And Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said that "as these losses increase, we will have to come in and ask for more support."
Mr. Clinton did suggest today that another package may be needed to cover crop losses and other damage assessed in the months ahead. But he twice reiterated that the Federal obligation would be limited, saying, "There is a big distinction to be drawn between the aggregate loss and what is normally compensable by Federal programs."
The $2.5 billion in disaster assistance already requested by Mr. Clinton is to provide immediate relief before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30, and its full amount would be added to the Federal deficit, creating a new strain just as the White House is urging Congress to adopt its deficit-reduction plan.
A Republican Senator, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, today urged Mr. Clinton to underscore his commitment to the principle of defict reduction by proposing spending cuts that would offset the costs of flood relief.
But the President made clear after his meeting this afternoon, which included the Democratic leaders of Congress, that he had no inclination to risk such a politically unpopular step. He noted that the balanced-budget requirement imposed by Congress in 1990 allow an exception in cases of emergency, and said lower interest rates this year would push the budget deficit to a level well below what was estimated in January.
 
'Glad to Hear' Ideas
 "I think we can handle this," Mr. Clinton said of the added fiscal burden. "I have heard the general principle advanced it would be nice if we paid for it all with offsets, but I haven't seen any specific suggestions, and in the absence of those, I think we should just take the '90 law and proceed as is."
Mr. Clinton appeared mindful of the potential impact of the argument raised by Mr. Durenberger, who told him in a letter that it was their duty "to pursue fiscal responsibility -- even in times of disaster." Mr. Clinton said he would be "glad to hear" recommendations for spending cuts.
But he said he took heart in sentiments of flood-state lawmakers from both parties who said they were ready to work together to provide relief to those whose homes, businesses and farms have been overwhelmed by the flood. "The most important thing is that we get the aid out to those folks as quickly as possible," Mr. Clinton said.
The President is to return to the Midwest Saturday to review the extent of flood damage with governors and local officials, the White House said today. The meeting is scheduled for the St. Louis area, where the flood-swollen Mississippi River is expected to crest on Monday.
 
Third Visit Is Planned
 The visit will be the President's third to the region since the Mississippi, Missouri and their tributaries began to spill over their banks. He stopped in Iowa July 4 on the way to the economic summit in Tokyo and, after a brief vacation in Hawaii, stopped there again on Monday as he returned to Washington.
But Mr. Clinton's late-afternoon meeting at the Capitol with senators and representatives from the eight flood-stricken states provided him his first extended opportunity to listen to lawmakers' views of the widening disaster.
Only a week ago, White House officials were hearing estimates of just $500 million in total damage from the flood. And Federal officials earlier this week had estimated damages in Iowa, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wisconsin at $2 billion to $3 billion.
But Administration officials indicated today that the sweeping scale of the floods and the damage they had caused to crops had led them revise those estimates sharply upward. An Agriculture Department expert, Randy Weber, said after the Capitol Hill meeting with Mr. Clinton that most of the eight million acres of crops submerged by the floods would be lost.
Mr. Witt, the director of the emergency agency, did not publicly repeat the damage estimate of $8 billion that Congressional officials said he had made in private. But other Administration officials, Mr. Espy in particular, made it clear that more relief would be needed beyond the package requested by the White House, which includes $1 billion to reimburse farmers for crop losses.
"We think that it's a good start," Mr. Espy said, but added that he expected the Administration to have to ask Congress for more support, perhaps after completing a monthly report on crop damage that is due early next week.
In seeking to fend off pleas for more comprehensive relief, President Clinton did not refer directly to the formula adopted by the Federal Government after Hurricane Andrew last year, in which $9 billion in aid was provided to ease devastation estimated at $18 billion.
But he appeared to refer to such an approach as he emphasized that the Federal Government has never provided total relief. He said personal losses could be covered only by low-interest loans, and noted that other kinds of Federal assistance must in most cases be matched by the state and local governments.
"There are other losses that simply aren't covered by any Federal law," he added.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: Where to Get Help;
List of Major Programs That Help Flood Victims

 BODY:
Federal, state and voluntary agencies offer a wide and varied assortment of aid programs to flood victims, both individuals and businesses. The processing time can vary from a couple of hours to a couple of days or a number of weeks, depending how pressing the need and how much documentation is required. Here are the major programs, most of which are offered at disaster assistance centers:
BASIC EMERGENCY NEEDS The Red Cross, Salvation Army and other voluntary agencies offer immediate gifts of food, shelter, clothing, bedding and medicine to help flood victims while they await approval of government aid or work out their own arrangements. 
 CASH GRANTS Up to $11,900 in Federal funds is available to people who have no insurance and few if any cash resources to meet disaster needs not covered by any government or private aid program.
DISASTER HOUSING Federal grants are available to pay for up to 18 months of temporary housing or for emergency repairs to make a damaged house habitable.
HOME LOANS The Small Business Administration offers loans of up to $100,000 for as little as 4 percent interest for home repairs. Limited loans are also available to homeowners for help in making a dwelling less subject to flooding.
BUSINESS LOANS Loans of up to $500,000 are offered by the Small Business Administration to flooded businesses.
FARM LOANSFarmers and ranchers can get loans of up to $500,000 to cover production and equipment losses.
TAX ASSISTANCE Homeowners whose flood losses are not insured or are underinsured can take a tax deduction on their loss.
UNEMPLOYMENT AID People who lose their job because of a flood are entitled to unemployment assistance.

HEADLINE: Day of Bombast Before Budget Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Congressional conference on the budget got under way today with senators and representatives doing what they do best: meeting, making political speeches and having their pictures taken.
Then they adjourned until next week, when they will start on something they may not be so good at: figuring out how to lower the Federal deficit by raising taxes and cutting spending in a way that can win the support of President Clinton and a majority of senators and representatives. 
 Most elements of the deficit-reduction legislation passed by the House in May and the Senate last month are identical, or so similar, that the conferees should easily find common ground.
Both measures would lower the deficit by about $500 billion over the next five years, primarily by raising the income-tax rates for wealthy individuals and corporations, cutting military spending, and limiting the growth of Medicare.
But reaching a compromise on energy taxes, spending on social programs and a few other touchy issues is likely to be an excruciating process that will last at least until the end of this month. So the lawmakers -- as if to reward themselves with a spoonful of sugar before taking the bitter medicine -- devoted today to the kinds of events they love.
 
Courting the Cameras
 It began with all 226 conferees -- 53 senators and 173 representatives, 42 percent of the entire Congress -- meeting for the first and probably only time as a group in the cavernous Caucus Room in the Cannon House Office Building across Independence Avenue from the Capitol.
The seats were arranged in concentric horseshoes, with the most important members of the conference -- the party leaders, the chairmen and top Republicans on the budget and tax committees -- sitting in the rear tier, facing the backs of their fellow lawmakers but looking straight at the television cameras. They made speeches that anyone following the budget process had heard a thousand times. Here are sound bites:
Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, chairman of the House Budget Committee: "This is our best chance to regain control of our economic future."
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, top Republican on the House Budget Committee: "This tax and spending proposal that is before us today is a job-killer."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader: "Deficit reduction is job creation."
 
Actual Work on Tap
 The real work of the conference committee will begin behind closed doors next week, when about a dozen subcommittees will begin working on the final compromises. The conferees from the Agriculture Committees will work on the matters in their jurisdiction, those from the Banking Committees on theirs and so forth.
At lunch, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen met privately in the Capitol with Democratic senators. Afterward, he was asked by reporters what he had told them. "I told them we had to pass the bill," Mr. Bentsen replied.
In the early afternoon, the conferees from the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee met for what will almost certainly be the only time publicly. This is by far the most important subcommittee, and these are the most important conferees. They have jurisdiction over all the tax provisions and the most controversial of the spending measures, like limits on Medicare.
The session was like a rerun of the morning program with different actors speaking the same lines.
"We are in the homestretch," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "I have no illusions about the difficulty of the job ahead of us. We face an enormous task. But we cannot afford to fail."
 
Clinton Shows Up
 While this meeting was going on, President Clinton arrived on Capitol Hill. He was greeted by a large, cheering crowd of Congressional interns, and he and Vice President Al Gore worked the line, shaking hands two at a time with as many interns as they could reach.
Then Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore went into the Capitol for a meeting with Congressional leaders and sat down around a table in a room near the souvenir stand on the first floor. Photographers were allowed in briefly to shoot pictures. From the rear, a reporter asked whether the President was still committed to $500 billion in total deficit reduction and a tax on energy.
He replied, "Today, I'm here to talk about my trip to Japan, Korea and Hawaii and talk a little about the flood -- the emergency flooding legislation that I'm hoping to get through."
A staff member who sat through the meeting said the budget had not been discussed at all.
But afterward, when Mr. Clinton held a brief news conference in the Capitol's Statuary Hall, a reporter again asked him about the deficit-reduction target and an energy tax.
"How it's resolved is something the conference will have to work out," the President replied, as he stood in front of a bronze statue of Henry Clay, the Great Compromiser.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Representative Dan Rostenkowski conferring yesterday with Charles Pizer, left, legislative director, during the opening of the Congressional conference on President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan.; Representative John R. Kasich, left, speaking with Senator Pete V. Domenici, center, during yesterday's conference. (Photographs by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Here comes the bride -- from Idaho to Transylvania.
When JOHN FLORESCU, chief executive and executive producer for David Frost's television company and scion of a distinguished Rumanian family, became engaged in October to GINA CHRISTENSEN, a political consultant, he could think of only two places for their wedding. "I explained to my in-laws, who are from Idaho, that it should be in either Sun Valley or Transylvania," Mr. Florescu said yesterday. "They were intrigued by the idea." So Transylvania it was. 
 On July 31, after seven months of planning, the couple is to marry in the monastery of Sinaia, about 80 miles north of Bucharest, where Mr. Florescu's paternal grandparents were wed in 1924. A reception will follow in the Foisor Palace, a summer home occupied most recently by Nicolae Ceausescu, the dictator who was executed in 1989.
For the 200 guests, this will be no quick-toast-to-the-bride-and-groom kind of affair. There will be five days of tours, lectures, picnics, dinners and parties.
Mr. Florescu's father, Prof. Radu Florescu, is a Boston College historian who has written four books about Vlad Dracul, the man on whom Count Dracula was modeled. "He was the 15th-century tyrannical prince who was credited with impaling 100,000 Turks," John Florescu said. Guests will visit Arefu Castle, Vlad Dracul's mountaintop home.
Also on the itinerary is a visit to the Ceausescu palace in Bucharest, which Mr. Florescu said "is bigger than the Pentagon."
Guests are expected from 12 countries. "Everyone who's coming sees it as a great adventure," Mr. Florescu said. "One person is coming by motorcycle from London, another wants to fly by helicopter from Moscow and land at dusk."
"We want everyone to appreciate the beauty and history of Rumania," said Mr. Florescu, who has a prime minister, ambassadors, noblemen and academicians in his ancestry. "All we read about it is AIDS, orphans and runaway inflation. There is another side, too."

HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
Vinoly's Vision for Tokyo, and for the Identity of Japan

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
Those who have forgiven the Japanese for buying a big chunk of Rockefeller Center may find it more difficult to excuse them for snapping up Rafael Vinoly to design the Tokyo International Forum, a colossal performing-arts and convention center now going up in the heart of the Japanese capital. Rockefeller Center, after all, isn't leaving New York. But why must we travel to Japan to see major public buildings as fine as the one Mr. Vinoly has designed for Tokyo? This prodigiously gifted architect lives right here.
At least we get to see the models. Mr. Vinoly's plans for the Tokyo International Forum are on view now in the architecture and design galleries at the Museum of Modern Art, as part of the museum's continuing series of shows devoted to important public works. This is the first show in the series to feature a single project by one firm, and the honor is richly deserved. The $1 billion project, which will be completed in 1996, is one of the largest under construction in the world today. It is also among the most sublime. Mr. Vinoly's design goes far toward dispelling disillusionment with the bloated scale of recent civic projects. And it revives faith in architecture as an instrument of intellectual clarity. 
 The Tokyo International Forum isn't just an architecture story. Like the Pompidou Center in Paris, this building exploits civic scale and prominence to set a national cultural agenda. The French critic Roland Barthes described Tokyo as a city with an "empty center," a modern metropolis that revolves around the ancient, opaque and politically impotent Imperial Palace. The forum, situated two blocks from the palace gardens, will be the antithesis to this venerable void. Lucid, accessible, deftly knit into the urban fabric, the forum will provide a public stage to dramatize Japan's leading role in world affairs. More important, it will inject an outward-looking, cosmopolitan ideal into the center of today's Japan. The innocuous word "international" carries a charged meaning here: although Japan has long been subject to foreign influences, it is widely perceived as a closed society. The forum is designed to counter that xenophobic image.
Mr. Vinoly has translated this symbolic goal into an appropriately symbolic form. His design is a monument to the idea of openness. The clarity of the forum's planning, its sparkling glass surfaces and exposed structural engineering, its generous public spaces and its links to mass transit will add up to a celebration of public access. Here, light and transparency become metaphors for a reconfigured cultural ideal.
There is nothing overtly Japanese about the design. But Western architects since Frank Lloyd Wright have found inspiration in the Japanese vernacular of spare, light, spatially sonorous forms. Mr. Vinoly, born in Uruguay in 1944 and educated in Argentina, has described architecture as an "art of dealing with heaviness." For him, creating shelter is less a matter of containing space than of escaping inertia. It is this idea, rather than a facile infatuation with industrial technology, that explains the prominence Mr. Vinoly gives to structure and the lyricism he extracts from it. Like trained bodies in motion, his soaring, structurally athletic enclosures convey the thrill of triumph over gravity.
(Fortunately, New Yorkers will have the opportunity to savor that thrill, though on a much smaller scale, when Mr. Vinoly's gymnasium for Lehman College, his most important New York project to date, opens in Riverdale, the Bronx, in September.)
What is discernibly Japanese is the forum's program, which combines four theaters for performing arts with spaces for major trade shows. This union of commercial and cultural uses would be anomalous in the West; we prefer to segregate Mammon from the muses. But it is consistent with a culture where art is traditionally fused with life. That tradition may be one of Japan's strategic advantages in today's international marketplace, where, increasingly, economic exchange is cultural exchange. Straddling the porous line between art and industry, the Tokyo Forum will reflect a global economy in which creative talent has displaced the primacy of raw materials and consumer goods.
The forum's seven-acre, trapezoidal site also straddles a physical line: a border between a grid of densely built-up commercial blocks in Tokyo's central business district and the curve of a rail viaduct that cuts through it. The forum's plan takes its cue from these two urban geometries. The four theaters, one of which will be the largest in Tokyo, are aligned along the site's eastern edge, attached to a slim slab building that faces the downtown grid.
Modular in form but variable in scale, the theaters diminish in size as the site narrows toward its apex. They look across an open plaza toward the Glass Hall, the forum's most spectacular component. With curving contours derived from the rail viaduct's adjacent arc, this shipshaped atrium rises 190 feet to a crystalline roof of metal and glass, designed in collaboration with the structural engineer Kunio Watanabe. If Tiffany made skyscrapers, the result might look something like this exquisite marquise.
Unfolding as a sequence of landscaped, triangular terraces, the plaza forms a pedestrian boulevard between the commuter rail stations that lie at opposite ends of the complex. Rows of zelkova trees will turn the plaza into a garden (this reverses the arrangement at the Imperial Palace, where gardens occupy the perimeter). The trees are to be ornamental, but their airy, spreading canopies will express a structural principle. Throughout the building, Mr. Vinoly translates vertical thrust into horizontal expression. He resists gravity not by erecting tall spires but by lifting the urban horizon.
A gigantic, illuminated walk-through model is the centerpiece of the Modern's show, which was organized by Terence Riley and Anne Dixon of the museum's architecture and design department. Split down the central axis of the plaza, the model lets viewers play at being benign Godzillas. A separate model of the Glass Hall's giant steel truss, suspended from the ceiling, highlights its resemblance to an ancient Egyptian solar bark. A selection of Mr. Vinoly's energetic charcoal drawings shows him exploring the texture of light.
Sociologically or esthetically, openness doesn't come easily. Large expanses of glass are unusual for earthquake-prone Tokyo. Sophisticated mechanics will protect the glass from seismic shocks, but Mr. Vinoly understands that terror is integral to the sublime. Like a movie maker, he skillfully manipulates fear.
I suspect, too, that he regards the Glass Hall as a metaphor for modern architecture. For Mr. Vinoly's classically modern approach has also withstood shocks. It has survived public disfavor, critical disillusionment, even its own calamitous hubris.
Some may find the design excessively retrospective, an evocation of yesterday's vision of things to come. Well, those things did come, but seldom with the grace Mr. Vinoly promises to confer upon the vision. He has not launched a new style. He seeks to enlarge the expressive potential and the urban dimension of a vernacular that originated a century and a half ago with Joseph Paxton's Crystal Palace in London, designed for the first world's fair. Appearing now, at the end of a century that has seen movements rise and fall with accelerating futility, the design's evolutionary stance is refreshing. Not all radiance has perished in this brutal century: that is the elevating message that the Tokyo Forum could pass on to the next.
"Preview: The Tokyo International Forum by Rafael Vinoly Architects" is to remain on view at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, through Aug. 3.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CHRYSLER SEES RECORD U.S. AUTO SALES BY 1996

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
Chrysler Corporation officials said yesterday that they expect United States car and truck sales to surge to a record 17 million vehicles by 1996. 
 Thomas Pappert, a Chrysler vice president, said a combination of low interest rates, attractive products and an aging fleet of cars on the road is bringing people into showrooms. He predicted that American car and truck sales would hit 14.3 million vehicles this year. Mr. Pappert's prediction, by far the most aggressive forecast of Detroit's Big Three car manufacturers, compares with 1992 sales of 13.1 million cars and trucks. The all-time vehicle sales record in the United States was set in 1986, when 16.3 million cars and trucks were sold. On Wednesday, American auto makers said domestic car and truck sales rose 14.6 percent in early July to 289,191 units. For the year, domestic vehicle sales are running about 12.5 percent ahead of last year's pace.

LENGTH: 431 words

HEADLINE: Cracks in the Cuban Permafrost

 BODY:
President Clinton would risk little, and could gain a good deal, by removing America's Cuba policy from its cold war freezer.
For three decades, Washington's chief weapon against Communist Cuba has been a punishing economic embargo. But even as Fidel Castro changed from security threat to political curiosity, Congress tightened that embargo last year to make life still harder for Cubans trapped in a subsistence economy. And the new Congressional measure, the Cuban Democracy Act, has since backfired -- even in Miami, the heart of anti-Castro country. 
 Consider for example the bizarre telephone crisis. Illogically, the act asks Havana to permit freer contacts with exiles, yet makes it more difficult than ever for Cuba to earn hard currency. Some $80 million owed to Cuba for international calls has long been blocked in an American escrow account. So Havana now pressures Cuban-Americans to route their calls via Canada, which allows Cuba to recoup its share of toll revenues.
Among the outraged protesters against this practice is Representative Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, author of the Cuban Democracy Act. "We cannot allow Castro to extract profit from the desire of families to talk with their loved ones nor to set up a collection agency in Canada," he says. "The practices of these Canadian resellers are not only illegal but morally reprehensible." In other words, it's O.K. for Washington to wage economic war, but for Havana to defend itself is wrong.
A growing number of Cuban-Americans are getting tired of the standoff. The Cuban Air Force defector who became an exile hero when he flew back to rescue his wife and sons now urges a boatlift of food and medicines to the straitened island; a former guerrilla commando who spent 22 years in Mr. Castro's jails says he is prepared "to dialogue with anybody" in Cuba. Such dissenting voices emboldened the House Appropriations Committee to kill funding for TV Marti, a pet project of the hard-line Cuban-American National Foundation.
In another token of changing views, even some American conservatives have urged the Clinton Administration to end unilaterally the trade embargo against Cuba, and thus deny Mr. Castro the easy scapegoat of American imperialism. All this suggests that Mr. Clinton, who supported the Cuban Democracy Act, now has enough space to test the discretionary powers it gives him.
Why not challenge Fidel Castro to free all his political prisoners in return for a significant easing of the trade embargo? That would begin to get American policy out of the ice tray.

LENGTH: 431 words

HEADLINE: Hope for the 'River of Grass'

 BODY:
Among the most painful of America's environmental tragedies has been the slow asphyxiation of the world's largest fresh-water marsh, the Florida Everglades. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's plan to defend the Everglades from the further ravages of commerce gives the expiring patient its first ray of hope in years. But it is only a ray. A lot more hard bargaining lies ahead before anyone can declare victory.
The plan results from a month of furious negotiations among state and Federal officials and leaders of Florida's powerful agricultural interests, mainly the sugar growers. It seeks to give the vast "river of grass" what it needs most: a timely, reliable supply of fresh water. 
 First, the plan would alter and otherwise rearrange some of the canals now used to control flooding, thereby letting the water flow naturally southward toward the glades. Second, it would create 40,000 acres of filtration marshes to remove the pollutants contained in agricultural runoffs, mainly phosphorus from the huge sugar plantations north of Everglades National Park.
The Government estimates that the plan will cost $465 million. The sugar industry says it will pay two-thirds of that, but there's more than a little flimflam here. Florida's taxpayers will pay most of the upfront costs of construction while the industry will be able to spread its payments over 20 years, in dollars depreciated by inflation.
Mr. Babbitt's major achievement was to get an agreement, ending five years of legal wrangling and preventing more years of court fights, during which the lawyers would grow richer and the Everglades poorer. For that he deserves praise. But all he really has is a "statement of principles" whose details will be worked out over 90 days.
And the devil lies in those details. For one thing, the "statement" does not set forth a mechanism for enforcement -- no small omission given the ingenuity and clout of Florida's growers. For another, it commits the state and the growers to reducing the amount of phosphorus in the water to 50 parts per billion by 1997. That's progress, but 50 parts can still kill the Everglades. The statement contains a vague reference to the need for further reductions, no reference to the thousands of additional acres of filtration land that will be necessary to achieve these reductions and no reference to who will pay for them.
Mr. Babbitt's heart is clearly in the right place. Now his negotiators must construct a far tighter deal. As the Secretary knows better than anyone, there is no end to preserving the Everglades.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The U.S.-Iran Oil Scam

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Now watch carefully, everybody. This is big-time international three-card monte. The stakes are survival for the world's top terrorist regime, and billions of trade dollars for the American oil business. See how both clean the table.
The dealer is U.S. oil. He hands himself three cards, open. They are Presidential orders banning the import of Iranian oil. He shuffles the three cards, collects bets and turns one over. 
 What do you know -- it's a $4 billion trade in Iranian oil, making American oil companies Iran's biggest oil customer.
Iran wins, oil wins; you lose. The beauty part is that hardly any Americans outside big oil and government are even aware that their country is providing a major part of Iran's hard currency.
The money could be the difference between life and death for Teheran's Government. And it allows Iran to keep financing the terrorist network whose major target is the United States.
Like all good scams, the trick is simple. The Presidential orders of 1986 and 1988 prohibited import of Iran's major resource, oil. The purpose was to prevent American money from bolstering Iran and its terrorism. But -- get this part -- the orders did not specifically say U.S. oil companies could not buy Iranian oil!
So U.S. oil companies buy all the Iranian crude oil they want, transport it to South America or Europe and have it refined and sold. Sure, some of that refined oil is likely to wind up in the U.S. But who is to know or care? Certainly not the Iranians. They have their American money -- now about a quarter of Iran's annual oil exports -- and the delicious bonus of U.S. oil's marketing expertise.
In that word so dear to bureaucrats, oil is fungible; you can move it around for different purposes, different customers. Money is the most fungible stuff on earth. Iran uses its U.S. oil money to keep functioning both the Government and terrorist bomb squads.
The mullahs have Iranians by the throat, but they are also choking the once-proud national economy. Iran is hip-deep in debt, and beneath public complaints is the rumble of rebellion. Without those billions, the Government would move closer to collapse.
And certainly Iran needs oil sales to keep camps in the Sudan, its new political colony, well stocked with Iranian and other Middle Eastern specialists in terrorism.
Oh, one other thing -- the card dealer has several names: Exxon, Texaco, Mobil, Phibro, Caltex, Chevron and other familiar TV pals.
All right, fellow suckers, now you know how it works; you can leave the table. But some Americans cannot -- the people in the Clinton Administration, which inherited the mess.
The Administration recently worked out the policy of "dual containment" -- Iran as well as Iraq, no futile playing of one against the other anymore.
So Washington naturally is urging its allies to cut trade with Iran. You can see how that gets a little embarrassing when American businesses have faces greasy with Iranian oil. Exactly the same thing holds about planes. Iran hints it wants to buy some from Boeing, if it can scratch up loans. Meanwhile, the U.S. tells its allies that planes are dual-use products -- usable for war, not just peace.
As expected, some officials tell the President that if the U.S. does not buy oil from Iran, foreign companies will. So before doing anything, they say, get a strong consensus from our allies on oil and planes.
That was the argument made for arming and trading with dictators from Hitler and Tojo to Saddam and Assad. If the U.S. means so little to its allies that they prefer dealing with Iran, Mr. Clinton should tell us so, plain out.
For the U.S. the price of urging an economic squeeze is to lead or shut up. Shutting up is not a decent option. It would be appeasement of a declared enemy, the end of hope for so many Iranians who are our friends, and the survival of the Rafsanjani Government now so sweatily eager to sidle up for awhile.
That leaves President Clinton one good choice. He can speak to the American people, tell them what the oil companies are doing, pull out a pen and sign a new executive order closing the loopholes in the old ones.
That should not only end this hustlers' game, but make us stay awake the next time some dealer pulls out the cards and says gather round.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Dinkins Fires Sharp Jabs At Giuliani

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, his re-election campaign stalled in the polls, abandoned an incumbent's customary reserve and sharply stepped up his attack on his Republican-Liberal challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, yesterday -- even as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo effusively praised the Mayor as a man who "can show us how to live together as one city going forward."
The offensives by Mr. Dinkins and the state's top Democrat came on the legal deadline for the start of the race as the candidates filed petitions for the ballot and reported raising millions of dollars more for their campaigns. Mr. Dinkins took in $2.4 million in the six months ended last Sunday, while Mr. Giuliani raised $1.8 million. Each now has just under $1.5 million on hand.
 
A Joint Appearance in Brooklyn
 Aides to the Mayor and Governor said their remarks had not been coordinated. But a number of pressures -- from Mr. Giuliani's standing in the polls to the impending release of a Cuomo administration report on the handling of the Crown Heights disturbances -- have combined to keep Mr. Dinkins on the defensive. Meanwhile, some of the Mayor's prominent black and Jewish supporters recently wrote the Governor to say they hoped the Crown Heights report would not become politicized or inflame racial tensions. 
 It was in that context that Mr. Cuomo made his comments in a joint appearance with the Mayor at the Bridge Street African Methodist Episcopal Church in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. He took special pains to counter some recent reports that he was keeping his political distance from the Mayor.
"I've said it before and I will say it in the A.M.E. church and I will say it all over this city and all over this state," said Mr. Cuomo, who had sparred with the Mayor over the city's requests for more state aid last spring. "I will say it even louder and more frequently now that it's more necessary." To anyone looking for a hero, Mr. Cuomo said, "David Dinkins is an authentic American hero." He added, "He is the essence of civility and he can show us how to live together as one city going forward."
Hours earlier, Mr. Dinkins had used another public occasion to deflect questions about his own record by harshly challenging Mr. Giuliani's as a prosecutor, and needling him for offering "ridiculous responses" that avoided concrete stands on issues -- like how to structure the Board of Education -- that the Mayor is called to account for daily.
Appearing at a breakfast forum in midtown on business and economic issues sponsored by Crain's New York Business and the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Mayor defended his efforts to retain businesses and jobs and keep the city's budget balanced, and said that while he had been grappling with such problems for three and a half years, Mr. Giuliani "has done nothing -- absolutely nothing."
 
'The Mayor's Too Emotional'
 The Mayor also made in more pointed terms a claim he has suggested previously: that he is better able to unite the city's diverse groups than Mr. Giuliani. "I truly do have a fashion of relating to people that is superior to his," he said.
Told that, Mr. Giuliani's spokesman, Richard Bryers, invoked Dana Carvey's "Church Lady" character on "Saturday Night Live" and replied, "Isn't that special?" He added: "I just think the Mayor should not get so upset about poll results. It's too early in the game to get so mean. The Mayor's too emotional."
In fact, the Mayor seemed to be swatting at his rival with an unusual blend of playfulness and pique. Noting that Mr. Giuliani has said he is still developing a position paper on how the Board of Education should be run, Mr. Dinkins said, "It's O.K. if he doesn't have one, but he's had three and a half years."
He mocked Mr. Giuliani for having said that changes in rent control were "too emotional" to become part of an election-year debate, and said, "Rudolph Giuliani has never run a government." He also questioned Mr. Giuliani's record as a prosecutor, noting that some of his most celebrated cases resulted either in acquittals or reversals on appeal.
Asked later by reporters if he thought Mr. Giuliani was an ineffective prosecutor, the Mayor replied, "I won't say that." But in an unmistakable dig, he went on to add: "I don't say he's Nadjari," a reference to Maurice Nadjari, the former special prosecutor for the city's criminal justice system in the 1970's who was widely seen as overzealous and inclined to bring flimsy cases.
Mr. Bryers replied that in Mr. Giuliani's six years as United States Attorney in Manhattan, the office had 4,159 criminal convictions, 25 of which were reversed on appeal, and that the office obtained guilty verdicts in 88 percent of the cases it brought and collected more revenue for the Federal Government than any other United States Attorney's office.
Mr. Dinkins's remarks represented a sharp shift in tone from his usual lordly dismissal of Mr. Giuliani, a change that his aides said had been building gradually for weeks out of his growing frustration at what he sees as Mr. Giuliani's coasting along by attacking him without being held to the same degree of scrutiny. Four and a half months before the general election, it foreshadowed a testy campaign.
 
14,600 Signatures for Innis
 Indeed, the rematch between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani is now the only real mayoral race, since aides to Mr. Dinkins's sole remaining Democratic primary challenger, Roy E. Innis, national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, said he planned to file only 14,600 petition signatures, not quite twice the 7,500 required and not enough to withstand challenges to their validity under the state's arcane election laws.
Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, said he had not yet decided whether to challenge Mr. Innis's petitions. Any challenger has until Monday to file preliminary objections. Moving to knock Mr. Innis off the ballot could force the Mayor to curb his spending under the city's campaign finance laws -- which limit each candidate to $4 million for the primary and $4 million for the general election -- since there would no longer be an active primary. On the other hand, Mr. Innis could win perhaps one-quarter of the primary vote simply by remaining on the ballot, which could embarrass the Mayor as he moved into the race against Mr. Giuliani.
 
Giuliani Turns In Petitions
 Mr. Giuliani's wife, Donna Hanover, and their 3-year-old daughter, Caroline, took 38,530 petition signatures to the Board of Elections yesterday, far more than the 7,500 valid signatures required to get on the ballot and nearly 9 percent of all the registered Republicans in the city. Mr. Dinkins's supporters had already filed 125,000 petition signatures on Tuesday, reflecting the city's far larger Democratic Party registration and the shoe leather of their supporters in unions and political clubs.
Altogether, Mr. Dinkins has now raised about $5.6 million and spent about $4 million, his filings showed, while Mr. Giuliani has raised nearly $4 million and spent $2.5 million. Mr. Dinkins's camp estimates that he is so far eligible for about $500,000 in matching public funds, while Mr. Giuliani is entitled to about $900,000 because his average contributions have been smaller, which is rewarded under the law.
Mr. Innis's treasurer said he had raised "under $50,000" in the last six months and had "hardly any" cash on hand.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 17, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the New York City mayoral campaign misstated the amount of public matching funds for which Mayor David N. Dinkins has qualified so far. It is just over $1 million, about $100,000 more than his rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Report on Earnings Trims Storage Technology Shares

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
Shares of the Storage Technology Corporation plunged $7.875 each yesterday, a day after the company reported sharply lower second-quarter earnings that fell below analysts' projections.
The announcement, released after the stock market closed Wednesday, pushed Storage Technology's stock down to $33.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was heavy, with almost 3.2 million shares changing hands. 
 The company, which makes systems that store and retrieve huge amounts of computer data, said second-quarter earnings slid 80 percent, to $1.3 million, from $6.6 million a year earlier. After payment of a $3 million preferred stock dividend, the company lost 4 cents a share in the quarter, compared with a profit of 16 cents a share a year earlier.
Analysts had expected Storage Technology to earn 5 cents to 10 cents a share in this year's second quarter.
Storage Technology's revenues also slipped 8 percent, to $355.1 million, from $386.4 million in the comparable period a year before. Ryal R. Poppa, the company's chairman, president and chief executive, said the weak economy in Europe hurt second-quarter results. He said he did not expect results to improve until the fourth quarter.
Storage Technology, based in Louisville, Colo., also said in the earnings report that it did not expect to begin production of its long-awaited Iceberg data-storage system before the end of the year. The company reiterated that it does not expect Iceberg to generate revenues until next year.
Iceberg, which is designed to let large computer mainframe operators back up information stored on disks in seconds without having to shut down operations, has been delayed several times because of problems tying together the complex hardware and software systems. Last month the company disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation into last year's announcements about the Iceberg delays and is looking into possible violations of disclosure, reporting or insider trading requirements.
Storage Technology also announced yesterday that it had acquired the Sceptre Corporation, an Ann Arbor, Mich., supplier of software that manages data storage on cartridge tapes. Financial terms were not disclosed, but analysts said the acquisition was small and was not a factor in the stock price drop.

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED ON MILITARY RULES FOR GAY SOLDIERS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Clinton had agreed with the Pentagon, the Justice Department and the Joint Chiefs of Staff on a plan to allow homosexuals to serve in the military as long as they do not aggressively display their homosexuality or engage in homosexual conduct.
Senior Pentagon and White House officials said the accord, which was denounced today by gay-rights advocates, came together in the past two days in a flurry of meetings between President Clinton, Defense Secretary Les Aspin, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and a bevy of lawyers from the Justice Department and Pentagon. 
 Mr. Clinton is expected to announce the new policy -- which will consist of a two-page executive order and an appendix of guidelines for implementation -- on Monday or Tuesday, as soon as the Justice Department gives him its final assurances that the policy is defensible in court and some last-minute refinements are completed.
 
A Pledge Unfulfilled
 White House officials acknowledged that the plan fell short of President Clinton's campaign pledge to unconditionally lift the ban on homosexuals serving in the military, but they said it was the best they could produce given the resistance of the military chiefs and Congressional conservatives. And they said it was an important start toward futher relaxation of the 50-year-old ban.
But the officials also said that even under the new policy, any homosexual who does not want to be discreet would be better off not entering the armed services.
The Clinton plan is dubbed by officials, "Don't ask, don't tell and don't pursue." "Don't ask" means that recruits will no longer be asked about their sexual orientation. But "Don't tell" is much more complicated, and the agreement finally resolves the question of what it means to identify oneself as a homosexual, a question that had bedeviled Mr. Clinton and his advisers for months.
Formally, the plan says homosexual servicemen and servicewomen may not "tell" about their sexual orientation or conduct. But gay soldiers and sailors will be given limited room to express their sexual identity by the "Don't pursue" policy, which sets strict guidelines that make it difficult for officers to pursue accusations of homosexuality without strong evidence of repeated homosexual conduct or ostentatious display. The net effect of this loose form of pursuit is to create an implicit "private zone" for homosexuals to live discreetly, an aide to the President said.
 
Using Common Sense
 For instance, a mere private declaration of homosexuality would not trigger an investigation, nor would drinking in a gay bar or marching in a gay parade. Only a pattern of "credible information" about the open expression of homosexual identity or open homosexual conduct by a serviceman or servicewoman would be allowed to trigger such an investigation, officials said. Even then, commanders will be urged to use common sense, discretion and keep in mind the limited resources for such investigations, officials said.
Nevertheless, Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts and one of the first open homosexuals willing to accept a compromise, announced today that he could not approve of this draft plan, saying, "The victims of the prejudice would rather lose with the President on their side than win a small gain with him being perceived as having moved away."
Several key advocates of lifting the ban gathered yesterday at the War Memorial Veterans Building in San Francisco and said they were disappointed that the President seemed to have abandoned his campaign pledge to his gay supporters in deference to the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
"The people in the Pentagon should realize the President of the United States was elected by the people and he is the Commander in Chief," said Keith Meinhold, a homosexual who was discharged as a Naval petty officer and then reinstated by a Federal judge last year. "I'm concerned he may think the military constituency is more important than the gay constituency. But I'll tell you, no matter what he does, he'll never have the military constituency."
In addition, several major gay-rights groups said they have given up on influencing the policy through the President and will instead fight it through the courts as soon as it is implemented, most likely Oct. 1.
"We intend to bring a lawsuit immediately after it is announced on grounds that it violates both the constitutional provision for equal protection under the law and the First Amendment right of free speech," said William Rubenstein, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's lesbian and gay rights project, on Thursday.
Earlier in the day, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, indicated that he wanted to write the principles that make up the basis of the Clinton plan into law, instead of simply relying on an executive order, which can be easily changed.
Some White House officials said they were taken by surprise by the Nunn proposal and did not want to comment until they could study it further. The officials said that the last thing the President wants is a legislative battle over homosexuals in the military while he is trying to get his economic program passed, and they were privately contemptuous of the Georgia Senator's efforts. Senator Nunn, once considered a candidate for Defense Secretary in Mr. Clinton's Cabinet, has been fighting the President on ending the gay ban since January.
But a senior Pentagon official and a colleague of Mr. Nunn said the legislation merely codified the Clinton plan.
 
Drawing a Line
 The policy tries to draw a line between homosexual status, which will be condoned if kept discreet, and open homosexual conduct, which would almost certainly lead to an investigation and discharge.
For instance, attending a gay bar or marching in a gay-rights parade would not necessarily trigger an investigation, but if there were multiple reports or overt behavior, like kissing or holding hands, a soldier might trigger an inquiry. Only an officer of the rank of major or above, or lieutenant commander in the Navy, will be allowed to order an investigation.
Officials said that the level of "credible information" that will be required to launch an investigation into alleged homosexual conduct will be the same as that required to launch an investigation into heterosexual conduct. Clinton aides hope that this will enable the Justice Department to defend the policy as not violating the guarantee of equal protection under the law.
