HEADLINE: A Recovery That's Too Weak Results in Too Few New Jobs

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Americans are being bombarded with explanations of why the nation cannot generate enough jobs: a shortage of skilled workers, they are told, holds down hiring, along with higher taxes, global competition, expensive Government regulations, technology that automates work and cutbacks in military spending.
All of these play a role, many experts say, but the biggest problem is simply a lack of robust economic growth -- the most basic source of job creation. Until the national economy kicks into higher gear, they say, faster job growth will be hard to come by. 
 Many factors contribute to the slow economic growth. If military purchases are not replaced by some other type of spending, production declines and jobs are lost. The same things can happen if Ford moves some auto production from Michigan to Mexico, or if too many empty offices force a cutback in building construction. In the past, strong economic growth provided new jobs to absorb the displaced workers. That strength is missing now.
 
Output Is Lower, Too
 "There is much talk that this is a jobless recovery, but that is not the real story," said Marvin Kosters, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, referring to the view that the economy can expand without adding many jobs. "The real story is that the job growth in this recovery has turned out to be more or less commensurate with the job growth in previous recoveries, when you take into account that output has been less than in those previous recoveries."
The American Enterprise Institute is a conservative research organization. But Mr. Kosters's view was echoed across the political spectrum in more than two dozen interviews with economists, executives, Government officials, labor and small-business experts. It is a thesis shared by liberal economists like Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; by business leaders like Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, and by Wall Street executives like John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
They say that American consumers -- and for that matter European consumers who buy American goods -- have simply not purchased with their usual gusto. As a result, fewer workers are needed to make goods or provide services to the nation. The problem, in short, is weak demand, not a new world that has found a way to prosper without workers.
 
'The Main Difference'
 Even as the White House prepares for an international "jobs summit" this fall to try to pinpoint the causes and some solutions for what President Clinton describes as the "stubbornly high unemployment" that afflicts both Europe and the United States, the Administration is linking the lack of jobs to a lack of economic growth. In doing so, it is agreeing, in effect, with Mr. Kosters.
"We conclude that the main difference between the current situation and past situations is output," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "The economy is growing more slowly."
The latest recession officially ended in March 1991. In the 27 months since, the American economy has grown at less than half the pace of the three previous recoveries during an equivalent period. Each of the three earlier recoveries generated more than 5.5 million new jobs in the post-recession period. In the current period, only 1.5 million jobs have been created.
That is far below the pace that President Clinton needs to generate eight million jobs in his first term, as he has promised. Job creation seemed to be hitting the Clinton target early this year, as the economy briefly surged. But the job growth virtually disappeared in June, amid numerous signs that the economy itself might be faltering.
 
Another View
 There are some strong dissents to the thesis that job growth and economic growth are still linked so closely. Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, for example, argues that global competition sets this recovery apart from those in the past. Driven by this competition, he says, Corporate America relentlessly pursues greater efficiency, which means "job compression," even when sales are rising.
Ms. Tyson, too, says the emphasis on efficiency might inhibit some hiring, keeping unemployment slightly higher than it would otherwise be, even in a faster-growing economy. "I don't want to speculate about the number," she said.
President Clinton, for the moment, appears to be focusing on ways to make workers more efficient. He will appear this month at a Chicago conference, sponsored by the Labor Department, intended to foster greater cooperation between workers and bosses. The idea is that more cooperation makes a company more efficient and lowers costs, permitting managers to lay off fewer workers in hard times, and perhaps to hire when economic growth picks up.
 
Reliance on Low Rates
 But many experts insist that economic growth remains the priority. Their insistence on linking weak job growth with weak economic growth could focus more attention on the Administration's current economic policy. The White House is relying on low interest rates as the principal incentive to get consumers and companies to borrow and spend, hoping the rates will be sufficient to lift the economy enough to create jobs.
Administration officials say there is more lift to be gained from low rates than has been evident so far. But not everyone agrees that low rates alone will do the job.
"I think that you can get some economic growth from lower rates, but there is an important distinction to be made," Mr. Solow said. "If rates fall because business is pessimistic, that does not help the economy, and that seems to be happening now. I think we could get some contribution to growth by an aggressive lowering of rates, but not enough to really get the economy going."
Once that does happen, education, job training and similar work force improvements may help to bring jobs back quickly. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich notes that workers who are college educated and highly skilled are more likely, at any level of economic growth, to get jobs than the less skilled and less educated. But in an anemic economy, the educated can also go jobless, and that has been happening, according to several studies.
 
Cost of Labor
 Then there is the impediment posed by labor costs. Mr. Jasinowski of the manufacturers' association argues that complying with an array of Federal regulations is costing manufacturers $100 billion a year, absorbing revenue that might otherwise have been spent on new employees. "You get these quite large numbers and people say, 'I don't want to hire people; I will do without,' " Mr. Jasinowski said.
Others respond, however, that if sales were growing more strongly, companies would be more willing to hire despite the regulatory costs.
Corporate executives also cite the higher costs of benefits, at a time when wages are essentially flat, as a barrier to hiring. That has encouraged managers who might have otherwise hired to resort to overtime or temporary workers. Both approaches eliminate the cost of benefits.
 
Europe's High Labor Costs
 Expensive social benefits are also a drag on job growth in Western Europe. Stronger unions, higher payroll taxes and numerous regulations that prevent layoffs have made many European jobs more secure and higher paying than comparable jobs in the United States.
The overall cost of labor has made employers less willing to hire, and economists say that has kept Europe's unemployment rate above the United States'. But what has sent it up most sharply in recent years, they add, is the deep slowdown in the European economy; unemployment in the European Community now averages 11 percent, compared with 7 percent in the United States.
Cutbacks in military spending have become another impediment to job growth. Some 225,000 jobs have been lost in the last 18 months at companies that once prospered making weapons, parts and other products for the military, according to the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament.
Retraining these workers for new jobs is a Clinton Administration priority. But without stronger economic growth, Mr. Lipsky of Salomon Brothers says, the new jobs are lacking, no matter how successful the retraining might be.

HEADLINE: New York Using Speed Trap of Future: Laser Gun

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARMONK, N.Y.

 BODY:
It worked well over Baghdad; now laser warfare is coming to the median strip of I-684.
The New York State Police are using lasers the same way Air Force pilots do: to identify targets, although the patrol cars do not follow up with bombs, only speeding tickets. But the police are beginning to sound like Air Force generals as they talk about the arms race on the highways, where ever more sophisticated radar speed traps brought forth better and better radar detectors, until now. Now, the police say, they've got The Big One. 
 Laser measures speed quickly, sending out extremely short pulses of light for one third of a second, and at such a long range, nearly half a mile, that even if a detector on the speeder's dashboard picks up the signal, it is already too late, the police say.
"If your detector goes off," said Trooper Lee N. Gasparik as he took aim at the race of southbound traffic one recent afternoon, "this is what you should do: put on your signal light and pull over, because I'm going to talk to you."
The companies that manufacture detectors do not agree, of course, and some have begun offering combination radar-laser detectors. They do not see lasers as their nemesis, either, but for reasons that will not please their customers: laser has made millions of radar detectors obsolete, and the replacements commonly run between $250 and $300.
The police also say that they are pulling over more and more motorists equipped with radar detectors. Those drivers, they say, are the prime target because their cars are generally traveling the fastest. But more disturbing for public safety, statistics show that the worst offenders are driving faster than the worst did a few years ago.
According to a report last year by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the percentage of cars exceeding 70 miles an hour is 19. That is up from 6 percent in 1986, before Congress allowed the states to raise speeds on rural interstates to 65 miles an hour from 55. Most states have raised the limit on eligible roads, but New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania and Maryland have not.
(Drivers who cannot bear the thought of 55 miles an hour should also stay away from Delaware, which has no roads that meet the Federal definition of rural interstates, and Hawaii, which has 5 miles of eligible road but has not raised the limit either.)
The police are aiming at the fastest for two reasons. First, an increase in speed sharply raises the chance of death if there is an accident: a rule of thumb by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety is that for each 10 percent increase in speed, the risk of driver death goes up nearly 45 percent.
 
Red Dot in Viewfinder
 A less obvious problem is that if some cars are moving very fast, then the variation of speed among cars on the road is larger. And with some cars moving over 70 while others are in the upper 50's, the number of accidents rises, experts say.
For years the police have hunted the speeders with radar, despite some technical problems.
A radar gun fires a beam of microwave radiation in a pattern like a searchlight's, rapidly widening; at 1,000 feet the beam is 105 feet wide, which may be enough to cover both sides of a six-lane interstate. Unless the target car is the only thing on the highway, the beam is too wide to be useful at that range, so it is commonly used at a range of 600 to 800 feet.
But the beam fired by a laser gun is only 3 feet wide at 1,000 feet. The model used by Trooper Gasparik has a stock that rests on the shoulder, like a rifle stock, and in the viewfinder is a red dot to place over the image of the target vehicle. The gun sends out pulses of infra-red energy for one third of a second, and measures the pattern they form when they return, which shows the speed of the target.
The gun also measures the time the infrared takes to make the round trip, which gives the distance. Scanning the southbound traffic from the median of I-684 here, the trooper could pick out a white Nissan Altima traveling at 75 miles an hour at a range of 2,215 feet, or four-tenths of a mile.
 
Radar Detector Useless
 The technological edge provided by the laser is threefold. The trooper got a reading almost instantly after he turned on the beam, as a car swung into view around a gentle curve; the range and speed of detection would have made a radar detector useless even if the driver had one. Also, since most drivers look only 600 to 800 feet ahead, the trooper had probably measured the speed long before the driver spotted him. And at that distance, the trooper had plenty of time to make a U-turn on the median and safely swing his 225-horsepower Mustang into traffic for the chase.
The driver, a woman on her way home to the District of Columbia, was impressed with the effect, if not with the details of the technology. "I didn't see him until the very end," said the woman, who gave a reporter only her first name, Maria.
 
Resigned to Technology
 Steven S. Cowan of Northport, L.I., clocked at 75 miles an hour in his dark blue Econoline van at a range of 1,568 feet, said he never saw the police car until it pulled into traffic to snag him. He seemed resigned to this advance of technology.
The state police, in fact, are counting on that attitude. "When they hear laser, people think of the gulf war, of smart bombs," said Maj. Craig R. Masterson, the director of traffic services. "We deal in public perceptions," he said, and one result of that perception, he said, is "a reduced number of court challenges."
Not everyone thinks laser is such an improvement. At Bel-Tronics Ltd., of Mississauga, Ontario, which put a combined radar/laser detector on the market earlier this year, Rudi E. Sagl Jr., executive vice president, said that the laser beam is wider than the police think, because the unit is hand-held, and if the police officer moves just a little while holding it the signal sweeps across the highway. The size of the sweep "depends on how many cups of coffee he had that morning," said Mr. Sagl.
"The beam width in radar is quite a bit larger, I will grant you that, but with laser you do still get a warning," he said.
 
No Shortage of Targets
 At the Radio Association Defending Airwave Rights, a lobbying group that represents makers of radar detectors and, it says, the people who use them, Jason Richards, a spokesman, said, "Our beef was always that radar was not accurate, and the police always said it was." Now he sees irony in the police preference for laser as being more accurate.
At the moment, motorists are still far more likely to encounter radar than laser; there are only about 900 laser guns in use nationwide, according to the New York State Police.
There is no shortage of violators to ticket. Last year drivers in New York State collected 709,000 speeding tickets while covering 107 billion miles, or one ticket for every 151,000 miles driven. Trooper Gasparik, a 19-year veteran of the State Police and a one-man anti-crime wave, wrote 1,500 of them, although he was on the road only six months; the other six he was training new troopers.
(Take note: Trooper Gasparik usually works out of the Riverhead, L.I., barracks, and likes to stake out Route 27. He also likes to park his car in one direction and let drivers assume that he is scanning cars approaching from his rear, while he actually takes readings through the windshield and then makes a U-turn to catch his target.)
Of course, almost everyone could be ticketed, since most cars drive above the posted limit at some point. But, as Trooper Gasparik put it, "You're trying to take the most dangerous person off the road first."
 
No Safe Zone Above 55
 He denied, however, that there is a speed above 55 at which the police simply will not bother to write a ticket. "if you're driving above 55, you're on your own," he said.
Drivers sometimes complain that having such a widely flouted law is not sensible, but public safety officials counter that it makes no sense to change the law to conform to bad practices, and that no matter where the limit is set, most drivers will always go a little above it.
At the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration, the regional administrator for the area that includes New York, Thomas M. Louizou, argued that if the purpose were to write legal codes that minimized violations, "We could make murder legal, too."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Faster job growth will be hard to come by until the economy kicks into higher gear, experts say. Consumers have simply not purchased enough goods, meaning that fewer workers are needed to make products or provide services, they say. [1.]
Meat and poultry prices are expected to rise in the coming weeks because of damage to processing plants in Iowa caused by the Midwest flooding. [35.] Demand for sandbags is so high that domestic manufacturers are working overtime and record numbers of bags are being imported. [43.] 
 The executive vice president of the New York Fed, William J. McDonough, was named the president, making him the second most powerful executive in the Federal Reserve system, after the chairman. E. Gerald Corrigan will step down on Monday. [43.]
The merchandise trade deficit narrowed sharply in May, reflecting the biggest drop in the imbalance with Japan in over six years. [46.] Industrial production fell two-tenths of 1 percent in June and did not rise in May as was previously thought. [46.]
 
Companies
Prudential Securities is "extraordinarily close" to reaching a settlement with the S.E.C. of charges of securities law violations, the chief executive told brokers. The charges stem from the firm's practices in selling limited partnerships in the 1980's. [35.]
Apple Computer shares lost nearly a quarter of their value a day after the troubled computer maker announced its largest quarterly loss ever and an expensive restructuring plan. [35.]
General Motors said the Justice Department was investigating possible theft of documents by former employees. One executive said the focus was on Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua. [37.]
Picturetel shares plunged on earnings concerns even though the company introduced a new line of videoconferencing products that were praised by most industry analysts. [37.]
Fujitsu will not use information from an I.B.M. mainframe operating system software this year, moving away from trying to provide I.B.M.-compatible mainframes. [37.]
Rockwell and the University of California will pay the United States $450,000 to settle a lawsuit involving illegal gifts made at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, which Rockwell ran. [37.]
 
International
Ukraine is threatened by labor protests, declines in industrial output, hyperinflation, political quarrels and sagging agricultural production in a land once viewed as the Soviet breadbasket. [1.]
The president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development quit after an internal report criticized him for spending too freely on a new headquarters and on himself. [36.]
 
Markets
Declining technology shares dragged down the stock market. The Dow Jones industrials fell 22.64 points. [36.]
Treasury bond prices edged higher in reaction to signs of economic weakness. The long Treasury yield hit another low. [43.]
Oil prices fell sharply on reports of a breakthrough in talks on Iraq missile test sites. [45.] The dollar and gold fell. [45.]
 
Your Money
Recent college graduates with no job experience should continue to follow the classic advice: get out of debt, establish a good credit rating, start saving early and set financial goals. [32.]
Many real estate investment trusts are providing eye-catching returns. But are these investments right for everyone? [33.]
The Internal Revenue Service is taking a new tack with tax delinquents, allowing options on how to make payments. [33.]

HEADLINE: Deputy Chosen as Head of New York Fed

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
William J. McDonough, executive vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was named the bank's president yesterday, making him the most powerful official in the Federal Reserve system after the Fed's chairman.
Mr. McDonough had long been rumored to be the first choice of the bank's board, and he had the backing of E. Gerald Corrigan, who will step down as president of the New York Fed on Monday. The bank's board selected him on Thursday, and the Federal Reserve's board of governors in Washington gave its blessing yesterday. 
 Mr. McDonough, 59, the former vice chairman of the First Chicago National Bank, brings to his new post two decades of banking experience, wide international contacts and middle-of-the-road views on monetary and regulatory policy. Those who know the multilingual banker describe him as charming and say he is a pragmatic and deft politician.
In a demonstration of his political skills, Mr. McDonough repeatedly stressed at a news conference yesterday that economic growth was his top priority, something likely to play well at the White House and in Congress. "What we need in the world -- and here -- is sustainable growth," he said.
Mr. McDonough's appointment was applauded in Washington and on Wall Street. "He's really very well educated, not just in an academic sense, but in the practical experience one gets in a lifetime of application of what you know," said Wayne Angell, a governor of the Federal Reserve.
Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, who has known Mr. McDonough for years, agreed. "Unlike a lot of Fed presidents, he has operated in the real world for a long time," Mr. Kudlow said. "He's had his share of successes and failures and therefore developed a very broad and deep knowledge."
When Mr. McDonough first came to the New York Fed, Mr. Kudlow said, he had one-on-one lunches with Wall Street economists. "That's never been done," Mr. Kudlow said. "It shows he's open."
The New York Fed holds a special place among the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks. Not only does it oversee some of the largest American banks and brokerage firms, it also conducts the nation's monetary policy through domestic open market operations -- buying and selling government securities -- and through interventions in foreign exchange markets.
Its president is the only one of the regional presidents to hold a permanent voting position on the Federal Open Market Committee, the group that decides whether to raise or lower interest rates.
In his short time as a Fed insider, Mr. McDonough has been head of the bank's foreign desk, including service during the collapse of the European monetary system last summer. Since last August, he has also been in charge of the domestic desk, which conducts open market operations.
"I think Gerry did very good succession planning," said Karen Horn, the president of Banc One of Cleveland, referring to Mr. Corrigan. "He and the search committee chose a good guy, and then he gave him the experiences he needed." Ms. Horn was also considered for the presidency of the New York Fed.
Mr. McDonough's job description was more or less written by Mr. Corrigan, people involved in the selection process said. At the top of the list of requirements were high energy and an ability to deal calmly with various public pressures and crises. In its search, said one person close to the selection process, "the board looked for someone who could handle the policy questions, but more important somebody who could do the plumbing."
One controversial incident in Mr. McDonough's career at First Chicago involved his failure to act on a tip that a lease being negotiated by an executive under him involved improprieties. The lease eventually cost First Chicago $2.1 million, and the executive was jailed for fraud.
"The board looked into the issue," a spokesman for the New York Fed said. "It satisfied itself fully that Mr. McDonough had acted in an entirely appropriate manner."
Mr. Angell said: "I'm fully satisfied. The best assumption is that there was never anything to talk about."
Mr. Corrigan has played a major role in international banking issues. Mr. McDonough, who is well known to foreign central bankers, gently boasted at the news conference yesterday that he could "speak to any central banker in the Western Hemisphere in his own language."
 
Praise for Political Skills
 Mr. McDonough is well regarded in the financial community. "He's very likable, very Irish, and he's got a good political style," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Securities. Added James Annable, chief economist at First Chicago who worked with Mr. McDonough for years, "He's very, very smooth."
Describing himself, Mr. McDonough said, "The McDonough view of the world is that things are better every day than the day before."
Mr. McDonough, conveniently, is also a Democrat, reportedly another job requirement. "He will be a useful voice within the Fed, which is always negotiating the terrain with the White House and Congress," said Mr. Annable, a former Fed staff member.
Mr. McDonough and his third wife, Suzanne Clarke, live on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He has six children from a former marriage.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William J. McDonough. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Energy Nominee Faces Battle on Feminist Group

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
In another trying twist for the confirmation of Administration appointees, Senate approval of Tara J. O'Toole as Assistant Secretary of Energy is in serious jeopardy because of her affiliation with a feminist group that formerly characterized itself as Marxist.
The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee has delayed scheduling confirmation hearings for Dr. O'Toole indefinitely, and at least two powerful members of the panel have voiced concerns about her nomination for Assistant Secretary of Energy for Environment, Safety and Health. 
 Senators have complained that Dr. O'Toole, a physician and consultant at the Energy Department, has little administrative experience. But they have been most vocal about her membership in a study group, Northeast Feminist Scholars, which was originally called Marxist-Feminist Group I.
That affiliation, included on biographical materials submitted to the committee, raises questions about her philosophy and judgment, conservative senators say. The White House said Dr. O'Toole joined the group several years after it had changed its name.
 
'She Is Superbly Qualified'
 The conservative challenge to Dr. O'Toole comes as Republicans are trying to sidetrack the appointment of Dr. Joycelyn Elders as Surgeon General for her outspoken support for sex education and abortion rights. Administration officials say they will stand by both nominees, who they insist are targets of unfair political aspersions.
"The White House strongly supports her" Jack Gibbons, President Clinton's science adviser, said of Dr. O'Toole. Dr. Gibbons, who was Dr. O'Toole's supervisor at the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, added, "She is an extraordinarily fine scientist with a superb track record."
Dr. Gibbons added that Dr. O'Toole had passed a Federal Bureau of Investigation clearance procedure without problem.
William White, the Deputy Energy Secretary, said: "We believe she is superbly qualified. This Administration and this department do not embrace any Marxist ideology. According to Dr. O'Toole, she does not, either."
Supporters in the Senate have speculated that conservatives do not like certain of Dr. O'Toole's writings that suggest she might make private Energy Department contractors more accountable for errors made in nuclear and other projects.
But Senate critics seized on Dr. O'Toole's membership in the reading group. In a recent interview, Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, the ranking Republican member of the energy committee, accused President Clinton of nominating someone "from America's radical left fringe." The Senator refused further comment today.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, another influential Republican member of the energy panel, has also voiced reservations about Dr. O'Toole's political orientation.
Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who heads the energy committee, would say little about the nomination. "We're getting some more information," he said. He said he doubted the committee would hold hearings until after the August recess, which means the Senate would return the nomination to the White House unless senators unanimously agree to retain her name for confirmation proceedings past the summer.
By returning her name to the White House, senators could kill her nomination without holding a hearing or taking a vote unless the Administration decides it wants to resubmit her name and fight for her nomination in the fall. Democrats want to avoid the political turbulence that accompanied the withdrawal of Zoe Baird as nominee for Attorney General and the withdrawal of Lani Guinier as nominee for Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights.
Dr. O'Toole did not return several phone calls to her office today.
Thus far, the Administration has tried to support the nominee. In a July 6 letter to Senators Johnston and Wallop, the White House tried to minimize the importance of Dr. O'Toole's affiliation to the feminist study group.
"Dr. O'Toole has never endorsed Marxist theory, nor has she ever had the impression that any other members of N.F.S. held such beliefs," said the letter, signed by William H. Kennedy, associate counsel to the President.
Mr. Kennedy said Dr. O'Toole first made contact with the group in the fall of 1981, nearly a decade after it was founded and a few years after it changed its name from Marxist-Feminist I. "By the time Dr. O'Toole joined N.F.S.," Mr. Kennedy added, "its discussions had moved beyond economic theory, as applied to the role of women in society, to the consideration of issues related to women and society."
The group meets about three times a year and has a mailing list of about 45 people. The White House letter said Dr. O'Toole had typically led discussions on topics related to medicine and health.
In an accompanying affidavit signed by Dr. O'Toole, she said, "My understanding is that the original title of the group derived from the founding members' desire to engage in an academic and analytical analysis of women's status in society through a variety of theoretical perspectives which included but were not limited to Marxist economic theory."
But officials of the energy panel said it was their understanding that the group still had a radical orientation.
If confirmed, Dr. O'Toole would advise Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary on environmental safety and health policies as well as oversee the security policies for the department's nuclear test sites, offices and other projects.
Dr. O'Toole has worked as a senior analyst at the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, where she was principal analyst and contributor to a report called "Complex Cleanup: The Environmental Legacy of Nuclear Weapons Production."

HEADLINE: RUSSIA IS HALTING ARMS-LINKED SALE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Under pressure from the United States, Russia agreed today to halt its planned sale of equipment and technology to India that American experts said could be used to make a ballistic missile, the State Department announced today.
In a compromise that ended a bitter year-long dispute, the United States won Russian approval for the halt of the sale in return for waiving economic sanctions that had been set to go into effect today against two Russian companies involved in the deal. 
 In addition, the agreement held out the prospect of potentially lucrative joint space projects.
The dispute over the missile was the most serious disagreement between Russia and the United States on security issues since the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991. It also provided the Clinton Administration with the first serious test of its policy of seeking to penalize countries that spread technology for nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles.
 
Need for Hard Currency
 The disagreement with Russia had taken on large implications because Moscow has argued that it must be able to sell its military hardware and expertise around the world in order to earn hard currency.
Under the agreement, reached late Thursday night after intense discussions at the State Department, Russia agreed to halt the transfer of sophisticated rocket engines and related technology to India under a contract that dates back to the Soviet era, said Lynne Davis, Undersecretary of State for International Security Affairs.
Even more important in the long term, Russia agreed to adhere to terms of the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement that restricts the sale of military technology, as of November 1 and has told the Untied States that it is willing to sign the multinational agreement.
Until now, President Boris N. Yeltsin and other Russian officials have made much vaguer statements indicating that they are abiding by the principles of the missile agreement.
Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said, "This result makes an important contribution to the expanding U.S. partnership with Russia and to our joint efforts to lead the way in the global promotion of nonproliferation."
 
Could Buy Elsewhere
 Some Administration nonproliferation experts complained that the compromise may be meaningless, because they believe that Russia has already shipped much of the technology that India needs and New Delhi could get whatever technology it would still need from another source, possibly China.
Other experts praised the agreement, but noted that it does not address the larger issue of Russia's other military sales around the world as a way to get hard currency.
"The agreement is significant because it bolsters the Missile Technology Control regime and will give Russia's aerospace engineers something to do in Russia rather than in say, North Korea," said John E. Pike, Director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists. "But the real problem is things like the export of solid rocket propellant to Libya."
The agreement is likely to worsen American relations with India, which argued that it wanted to use the Russian-designed rocket engine to enter the commercial satellite-launching industry and that the engine and the technology have no military use.
 
Fears Missile Race
 The United States, however, fears that India's rocket-launching capability could lead to a missile race on the subcontinent, where tensions are already high because of the weapons buildup and nuclear programs of India and Pakistan.
In May 1992, the Bush Administration imposed sanctions against the state-owned enterprises in both Russia and India involved in the deal and tried to convince both Governments to amend or cancel it.
Last January, during his first visit to India, President Yeltsin promised that he would not buckle under to outside pressure and abandon the deal, which the United States estimated was worth between $200 million and $300 million.
Since then, the Clinton Administration made clear that it would not tolerate the continuation of Russia's fulfillment of its contract, although it recognized that it could do nothing about what may have already been shipped.
In addition to the threat of sanctions, included in legislation co-sponsored last year by then Senator Al Gore, the Administration had also threatened to suspend cooperation in space projects if the deal with India went through.
Under the agreement reached Thursday night, the United States will not compensate Russia monetarily for any financial losses. But the Americans instead told the Russians that their cooperation opens up space projects with the United States, including collaboration between NASA and the Russian space station program and potential contracts for launching American satellites on Russian rockets, that could mean $700 million in commerical trade for Russia in the next seven to eight years.
But in an important concession to Moscow, Russia will be allowed to renegotiate terms for selling some engines, but not the related technology, to India. The United States had initially opposed the transfer of both the engines and the related technology.

HEADLINE: Casino Backers Spent $2 Million in Hartford

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 16

 BODY:
Casino backers spent $2.36 million from January through June to persuade the Connecticut Legislature to allow casinos in the state, according to State Ethics Commission financial reports.
"I'm pretty confident it's the largest amount spent by any one cause," said Brenda Bergeron, staff attorney for the Ethics Commission. 
 A leading opponent of casino gambling, State Senator James Fleming, said: "It proves the battle is not over. It's clear they didn't spend that kind of money in Connecticut to just walk away. I think they'll be back to push a casino."
Gambling interests spent $500,000 in the first three months of the 1993 legislative session and $1.86 million during the last three months, according to reports that were released Thursday.
Despite the lobbying, the efforts did not pay off. Legislative leaders decided in late May not to even vote on a bill that would have allowed casinos to be built and slot machines to be run in Connecticut's pari-mutuel operations.
 
Money for Lobbyists
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. had vowed to veto any legislation that expanded legalized gambling, which meant the casino backers would have needed a two-thirds majority in each legislative chamber to guarantee that the bill became law.
Most of the $1.86 million in the session's last months was spent by New City Development Inc., the Hartford-based development arm of Steve Wynn's Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas.
Most of that paid for lobbyists' salaries and public relations work, but some has been spread among legislators in the form of trips, meals, videotapes and brochures.
"It's a lot of money, that's obvious," said Paul McCormick, the New City lawyer who filed the financial report. "A business decision was made by the Mirage to push for access to the Connecticut market. They were willing to spend money. It was a business decision. I don't think it's unusual from that point."
 
Additional Money Spent
 The figures do not include other money spent on lobbying on the casino issue, including the $36,000 that the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Council spent in the first three months of the session to block casino legalization. The tribe, which owns and operates Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino, wants to maintain its monopoly on casino gambling in Connecticut.
In addition to New City, Harrah's Club -- which had designs on a casino in Bridgeport but kept a lower profile -- spent $51,701 in the last three months of the session. The Connecticut Pari-Mutuel Association added $126,658.
Mr. Weicker has agreed to give the Mashantucket Pequots monopoly rights to operate slot machines at their Ledyard casino in exchange for giving the state a share of the revenues.
The agreement guaranteed the state $113 million this fiscal year and between 25 percent and 30 percent of the gross revenues in later years.
But if anyone else were allowed to operate slot machines, the agreement would be nullified -- a step that legislators were wary of taking in the current stagnant economy.
A report on the casino's finances obtained by The Day in New London shows that Foxwoods may have become the most profitable casino in the country. It posted a profit margin of $20.4 million on total revenue of $40.8 million in June alone, according to the report in the newspaper.

HEADLINE: Palestinian Chief Raises Risky Issue of Jerusalem

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 16

 BODY:
The head of the Palestinian delegation to the Middle East peace talks warned today that negotiations would go nowhere unless Israel gives up the eastern half of Jerusalem, which it captured in the 1967 war and has since annexed.
If Israel's position does not change, "it will kill the peace process," Dr. Haidar Abdel-Shafi, a physician from Gaza, said at a conference in East Jerusalem. "The important thing is that Israel should concede the Palestinian right in Jerusalem." 
 Palestinians want to make East Jerusalem the capital of a hoped-for future state, a goal that runs headlong into Israel's insistence that the city will remain its unified capital forever and that the subject is not open for discussion.
Officials from Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin on down have warned that a sure way to scuttle the peace talks is to demand that Jerusalem's status be put on the bargaining table, a position supported by the United States in regard to the present negotiations over an interim form of Palestinian self-rule in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
 
Christopher to Visit
 While Dr. Abdel-Shafi's remarks were not new, they cast a somber note over the negotiations at a time when new ideas have begun to surface for breaking an Israeli-Palestinian impasse that is serious enough to have persuaded Secretary of State Warren Christopher to come to the region next month on a rescue mission.
Palestinians and Israelis have both raised the possibility of forming a confederation between the Palestinians and Jordan, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres reportedly urged the proposal this week on a visiting State Department delegation. On Monday, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization announced that they would form joint committees to discuss aspects of possible political, economic and juridical relations.
A senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat, said the Palestinian-Jordanian entity would be a quick way to leap-frog negotiations over an interim agreement in the occupied territories and to move quickly to a final settlement.
"Maybe it is time to really see the possibilities of going directly toward the final status," Mr. Erakat said on Israeli television on Thursday night. "A confederation is one of the serious options for the final status."
 
Peres Sees Simultaneous Talks
 According to the Israeli newspaper reports, Mr. Peres told the visiting Americans that negotiations over a permanent settlement, based on the confederation idea, could take place at the same time as the existing negotiations of interim Palestinian self-rule.
"We would not be skipping over the interim stage, but just saying that at the end we would be implementing confederation," Deputy Foreign Minister Yossi Beilin told The Jerusalem Post.
The final word, however, rests with Mr. Rabin, and a spokesman said the Prime Minister stands by the existing formula for the talks. Under that formula, interim self-rule comes first and only then, after a period of adjustment over several years, would there be negotiations over the territories' final status.
Nonetheless, Mr. Rabin himself has not spoken out this time on the matter, even though he was cool to a similar idea when it arose a few months ago. He also presumably would not welcome direct involvement of the P.L.O. Dr. Abdel-Shafi, too, said this week that the P.L.O. had to be changed, with the powers of its chairman, Yasir Arafat, reduced in favor a more democratic, collective leadership.
"I certainly think that Arafat has some qualities that are indispensable in terms of leadership," he told Reuters this week. "But I certainly don't condone Arafat being the source of the decision-making all alone because this is, in my opinion, detrimental to the cause."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S Grows Impatient
 WASHINGTON, July 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- As his aides hinted that the Clinton Administration's patience with the pace of the Middle East peace talks might not last beyond the end of the year, Secretary of State Christopher announced today that he would make the first of what could be a series of trips to the region next month.
Speaking to reporters today, Mr. Christopher played down expectations that his trip would achieve any major breakthroughs in the stalled talks between Israel and its Arab neighbors. Aides to Mr. Christopher said he would visit Cairo, Jerusalem, Amman, Jordan and Damascus, Syria from Aug. 1 to 6, on his way home from a trip to Singapore and Australia.
Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said that if no progress was made in the peace talks this year, "you really have to assess at that point whether it's wise to continue to use the resources of the United States and specifically, the good offices of the Secretary to help the parties."

HEADLINE: Paul W. Wright, 87, Retired Headmaster Of the Groton School

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Paul W. Wright, a mathematics teacher and retired headmaster of the Groton School, died on Wednesday at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston. He was 87 and lived in Lexington, Mass.
The cause was cancer, a Groton spokesman said. 
 Mr. Wright began his 46-year career at Groton as a math teacher. He was appointed senior master in 1941, and he rose to become the headmaster in 1969, which he remained until his retirement in 1974. He was the fourth headmaster at the school, 30 miles northwest of Boston, since its founding in 1884.
During his tenure, the Episcopal-oriented private preparatory institution underwent major changes. The student body became more diverse, reflecting varied geographic, economic and cultural backgrounds. An advocate of coeducation, Mr. Wright played an important role in preparing the all-boys school for the admission of girls, which occurred shortly after he retired.
"This school never set out to train an elite class of leaders," Mr. Wright said in an interview in 1972 "We want to make our students useful citizens. If an opportunity presents itself to them to exercise leadership, we hope they would do it responsibly."
After retiring from Groton, Mr. Wright began a new career in 1975 as a math teacher at the private Belmont Hill School in Belmont Hill, Mass., teaching there until 1987.
He was born in Bellevue, Ohio, and graduated from high school there. He graduated from Williams College in 1927, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa.
In 1987, the Paul W. Wright Chair in Mathematics was endowed at Groton by two graduates in his honor. Also that year, the Paul W. Wright Fund was established at Belmont Hill School by parents of students.
Surviving are his wife, the former Margaret Ann Gainer; two sons, James of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and Paul of Princeton, N.J.; a daughter, Christina of Lexington, Mass., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond Prices Rise Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices edged higher yesterday in reaction to further signs of economic weakness.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32 , while its yield slipped to 6.54 percent, from 6.56 percent on Thursday. 
 For the seventh session in a row, the 30-year bond's yield hit its lowest level since the Treasury started regular auctions of the bonds in 1977.
Shorter-term maturities were mostly unchanged and intermediate securities ranged from 1/32 lower to 1/32 higher, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
Traders said the 30-year bond strengthened after a report that the preliminary numbers from the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index showed a drop to 76.9 in early July from 81.5 in June.
The Government reported yesterday that industrial production fell two-tenths of a percent in June, the first decline since September.
The news of economic sluggishness lent further support to market expectations of low inflation, following figures this week showing flat consumer inflation in June.
The market had little or no reaction to merchandise trade figures released by the Commerce Department showing the trade deficit narrowed sharply, to $8.37 billion, in May.
The market's attention now turns to Congressional testimony scheduled for Tuesday by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who will give members of the House Banking committee his seminannual report on central bank monetary policy. Now that the inflation scare of earlier this year has subsided, the Fed is considered less likely to tighten short-term interest rates as a way to rein in inflation pressures.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.66, to 1,313.64 yesterday.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills was unchanged at 3 percent, while the discount rate on six-month bills dropped one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.11 percent. The discount rate on one-year bills also slipped a basis point, to 3.24 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3 percent, down from 3 1/8 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 103 1/32 , unchanged from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity remained at 5.69 percent.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Off 0.2% in June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell two-tenths of 1 percent in June and did not rise in May as previously thought, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The report reflected the doldrums into which much of industry has sunk this spring. While industry represents less than one-third of the economy, activity in this sector, which tends to swing more widely than elsewere, is regarded as one of the best indicators of current conditions. 
 Other data released today expressed the effects of the weakness. The University of Michigan's preliminary July index of consumers' confidence in the economy fell to 76.9, from 81.5 in June.
Last month's decline in industrial output, the first since September, was attributed mainly to lower production of cars, light trucks, appliances and room air-conditioners, but nondurable consumer goods were also weak. And the Fed revised the previously reported two-tenths of 1 percent gain in May to show output unchanged in that month.
But even though June output, at 10.1 percent above its 1987 average, was no greater than in March, analysts said the result was not surprising in light of an earlier report showing a drop in factory payrolls and hours worked.
 
Decline Explained
 And, citing strong car sales through June, they said production would probably pick up after the usual summer plant shutdowns to replenish stocks.
"The decline in industrial production does not signal a new lapse into recession, but rather is due to the overbuilding of inventories in the first quarter," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers.
Motor vehicle assembly slumped 4.7 percent last month to a 10.2 million annual pace as manufactuers took advantage of strong demand to cut stockpiles.
Nonetheless, there were soft spots, including a 1.5 percent decline in production of goods for the home and a resumption in the decline for construction supplies.
"The economy is losing momentum," observed Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "It wasn't strictly cars."
 
Utility Output Surges
 The June decline in the Industrial Production Index would have been more severe had not utility output surged 1.3 percent as unusually hot weather pushed up demand for residential electricity.
Factory output itself fell three-tenths of 1 percent following a one-tenth of 1 percent May decline while mining, where a drop in coal output swamped a rise in oil and gas, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Today's report also showed that industry operated at 81.2 percent of capacity last month, down from 81.5 percent in May.
Production of consumer goods, the Fed report also showed, tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Excluding cars and trucks, total industrial production edged down one-tenth of 1 percent but consumer goods, without them, slipped five-tenths of 1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production" tracks index of total industrial production since January 1992. (Source: Commerce Department); "Capacity Utilization" tracks total output as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Data Show Sluggish Economy in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday as economic news from the United States and monetary turmoil abroad competed for traders' attentions.
Gold prices also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery fell $1 an ounce, to $392.90. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $392.25 an ounce, down 85 cents. 
 "We had some very mediocre news on the U.S. economy today," said Randolph Donney, director of capital market research at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production and capacity utilization both fell in June. Also, Mr. Donney said, the University of Michigan reported that consumer sentiment dropped sharply in early July.
The negative news tended to weaken the dollar, he said. A weak economy generally portends lower interest rates, driving investors abroad where they can find higher yields.
The dollar initially rose yesterday after reports that the merchandise trade deficit narrowed significantly in May and that the trade gap with Japan fell by the largest amount in more than six years. But the weak domestic economic news pushed the dollar down.
"My overall feeling is the market is just looking for an excuse for some profit taking," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
Weakness in the French franc and Danish krone had heightened concerns about the viability of Europe's exchange rate system this week.
But successful intervention by European central banks to support the krone yesterday, led by the Bundesbank of Germany and the Bank of France, eased those fears somewhat, Mr. Donney said. That helped European currencies against the dollar.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 107.55 yen late yesterday, down from 108.01 yen Thursday. The dollar dropped to 1.7160 German marks from 1.7205 marks.
The British pound also slipped, falling to $1.4860 in New York, from $1.4915 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Stubborn Forest Fires Hit Drought Areas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Like a bad idea borrowed from California, stubborn fires are burning above and below the forest floor in the drought-afflicted areas of New York and New Jersey, wearing out firefighters, forcing state police to close smoky roads and stinging the eyes and noses of people living miles away.
At West Point, where nearly 900 acres have burned, two Army Huey helicopters flew 150 missions yesterday to drop water on fires smoldering on inaccessible hillsides. Across the Hudson River at Camp Smith in Peekskill, a National Guard base, scores of volunteer firefighters plan to converge today to seal off a fire that has consumed at least 100 acres. 
 In between, the New York State Police have intermittently closed Route 6 near the Bear Mountain bridge because of smoke, and fire departments as far south as Yonkers and Mamaroneck have reported receiving calls from residents who smelled smoke.
Both those fires are believed to have started accidentally, said Capt. Raymond A. Wood, regional forest ranger for the Department of Environmental Conservation. "As hot as it was when the fires started, you would not be out in the woods unless you had to be," he said.
 
10 Days of Burning
 But in Brentwood, L.I., volunteer firefighters by yesterday had spent 10 days in a sweltering effort, so far unsuccessful, to extinguish a string of stubborn brush fires that they say must be the work of arsonists.
The smoldering Long Island fires, using a six-inch layer of decayed pine needles and leaves on the forest floor as fuel, began July 6 east the Sagtikos Parkway in an area of the Pine Barrens, known as oak brush plains, that abuts residential neighborhoods.
In New Jersey, 140 fires, most of them small, have been reported this month, state officials say. The largest covered 40 acres at the Atsion Recreation Area of the Wharton State Forest, in Burlington County.
Stephen J. Maurer, a fire warden in the New Jersey Environmental Protection and Energy Department, said that because the fires had burrowed into the leaves and debris on the forest floor, it was hard to tell when they were really out. That means "a number of people being there a lot longer than normal," he added.
The fires at Camp Smith and elsewhere have not burned many trees, only the debris and peat that form the first few inches of the forest floor. Firefighters do not think the trees themselves are dry enough to catch fire.
 
Waiting for Rain
 On Long Island, afternoon winds keep fanning embers back into flames, complained Lawrence E. Rex, chief of the Brentwood Fire Department. "It just keeps on flaring up," he said.
At Camp Smith, Chief Walter L. Groden, who is the fire coordinator for Westchester County, said: "Short of a week of rain, there is no practical or economically feasible method of extinguishing this fire at this point."
Camp Smith, a 2,000-acre installation owned by the state and used mostly for weekend guard training, is not part of any fire district and does not have a fire brigade of its own. Col. John A. Cusack, the commander, said that firefighters could build fire breaks to contain the fire but that it would burn "until it consumes its own fuel, or it rains."
The fires are the flip side of the floods in the Middle West; some of the rain that keeps falling in areas drained by the Mississippi River would in normal times be falling here, making the brush less fire-prone.
Instead, the fires here this year are much more numerous and stubborn than usual, fire officials say, and are the worst since at least the summer of 1988, when a six-week hot spell set up similar conditions.
 
Cutting Fire Roads
 All over, the firefighters have been hampered by terrain and distance from water supplies.
On Long Island, bulldozers and what firefighters call brush trucks, specially equipped to make roads into the woods, have cut fire roads and scores of swaths through the woods, flattening hundreds of pitch pines and scrub oaks. Soda cans left by thirsty volunteers litter some areas. In others, freshly felled trees lying in the smoking humus have ignited, adding to firefighters' woes.
While no houses have been damaged by the fires, the smell of smoke hung over many neighborhoods, putting residents on edge. "It's getting kind of scary," said Doris Valez, whose home on Princess Lane in Brentwood is bordered by a woods where firefighters fought a second brush fire yesterday. Chief Rex said that fire began when someone poured gasoline on a makeshift shack and set it ablaze.
Several hundred firefighters from 20 volunteer departments on the Island fought the fires at their peak. Officials said 35 volunteers have suffered heat exhaustion, and 10 had to be taken to area hospitals.
At West Point, 20 firefighters from the town of Highland Falls were working with 20 members of an Army engineering platoon. Not only does the terrain make access difficult in some areas, but one fire was burning in an area that is permanently off-limits because it is used as the "impact area" for artillery and other weapons, said Major Keith Trohoske, a spokesman. That fire was put out by dumping water from helicopters, he said.

HEADLINE: In Newark, Criminals Face a New Challenge: Officers on Bikes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Three bicyclists cruised easily down the streets of Newark, drawing stares from motorists who slowed down to let them pass.
The reason for the stares could have been the bikers' attire, a bit unusual given the above-100-degree heat: black biking shorts under short black pants, black short-sleeved shirts, black wraparound sunglasses and black bulletproof vests. If that wasn't enough to attract attention, there were the big neon-yellow words on the backs of their shirts: Newark Police Department. 
 The three bikers are officers who have forsaken their air-conditioned cars and foot patrols to join Newark's 10-member police bicycle squad, which will complete its first year in August.
At first, the Newark Police Director, William R. Celester, was not sure it was a good idea to use a bike squad to help police a city of more than 275,000 people. It took a little research and some prodding from Newark community boards and police officers to convince him.
 
An Experiment Pays Off
 "The research indicated that the bikes were more economical than patrol cars and more effective on street corners than foot patrols," Mr. Celester said. "And they were right. The bicycle program is one of the most effective police programs we have."
Newark, with a police force of 1,200 officers, is not alone in taking advantage of the two-wheel route to fighting crime, Mr. Celester said. More than 350 cities worldwide use bicycle officers to patrol their streets, including at least 15 cities and towns in New Jersey.
Bicycle squads are growing more popular because of their versatility, said Sgt. George Barr, 44, the dean of the squad, who has been with it from the start. Sergeant Barr said his officers can do things that would be daunting, if not impossible, for other officers.
"There are almost no disadvantages to riding bicycles on patrol," said Sergeant Barr, an avid cyclist even before his assignment to the bicycle squad. "We can get to places cars can't and we can go faster than a foot patrolman. In fact, there have been a couple of times that the bicycle policemen have beaten everyone else to a crime scene, even the patrol cars."
 
Element of Surprise
 The novelty of the squad has also been an advantage, Mr. Celester said.
"At first, no one had heard of police officers around here being on bicycles, so no one would pay any attention to the bikes," he said. "They were able to ride up on a crime scene and no one would move.
"Now, I think people are getting used to them being on bike, but they are so effective that it doesn't matter," he said. "I'd like to see someone else on a bicycle or on foot try to outrun one of these officers."
Out in the streets, the officers occasionally stop to remind a wayward motorist of the illegality of double-parking or to chat with someone about a problem in the neighborhood.
"One of the good things about these bikes is we can see just about everything," said Officer Raphael Bermudez, 37, as he patrolled the Hawkins Street Housing Complex with Sergeant Barr and Officer Rosa Torres, 35, the newest squad member. Within a couple of minutes, the three officers had circled through the entire complex and regrouped under a convenient shade tree.
"On a bike, I can see into cars, in backyards, up through windows, across traffic and other places that you would never be able to see from a car," Officer Bermudez said. "In fact, the other day I was riding by a parked car and saw this guy slumped down under the wheel. Apparently, he had suffered from heatstroke while sitting in the car. If I had been passing by in a car, I probably would have never seen him."
The officers usually work in groups of three, and no matter what happens, one officer keeps an eye on the bikes. The bikes' biggest disadvantage, Sergeant Barr said, is that they are far easier to steal than patrol cars.
"I don't think the Mayor would too much appreciate us letting one of these custom-ordered bicycles get stolen," Sergeant Barr said.
 
Customized Wheels
 The squad rides Schwinn mountain bikes, each one customized for the officer who rides it, with additions like strobe lights, electronic horns, spotlights and miniature computers with speedometers. And the officers have added a few extras of their own, including parking brakes made from rubber bands to help on the city's steep hills.
"This is still a developing program," Sergeant Barr said. "Every time we go out, we learn something new or see something else we need, so sometimes we just improvise."
As the officers relaxed under the tree, several neighborhood children pulled up on their bicycles and started asking questions.
"This usually happens when we come out into the neighborhoods," Officer Torres said. "One day we had so many children who wanted to ride around the block with us that it was beginning to block the traffic."
The bicycle squad works with community boards and other groups, giving speeches and setting up bicycle safety seminars for children.
"We're sort of semi-celebrities now," Officer Torres said. "We've been on television and in parades, so children see our uniforms and come up and talk to us. I see us as role models for them, to show them that police officers are human, too."
 
'We Get as Much Respect'
 This doesn't mean the bikers are not serious, Officer Bermudez cautioned.
"We are still police officers and we do actual work," he said. "We've ran down suspects before and pulled over cars in the middle of the street. We get as much respect as any other policeman, because we represent the city as much as anyone else."
Between August and December 1992, the bicycle squad questioned 165 suspects and made 35 arrests. Since then, the officers have added 77 arrests and questioned 146 suspects, a very respectable number for a new unit, Mr. Celester said. Almost a third of the cases are drug-related, he said.
The Newark bicycle squad is the first in New Jersey to work year-round, instead of just in the summer, Mr. Celester said. Because of the program's year-round success, Mr. Celester plans to expand the number of officers in the unit next month to 16.
"Of course, we have more appropriate uniforms in the winter," Sergeant Barr said, looking down at his short pants and short-sleeved shirt. "The weather conditions are really not much of a concern right now."
"Well, as far as the heat goes, we drink a lot of water," Sergeant Barr said. "The only weather conditions that the officers don't go out in on bike is when it gets below 30 degrees or it's a heavy downpour."
So what does a bicycle officer do in bad weather?
"When it gets like that, we have to suit up for foot patrol," Sergeant Barr said, smiling. "We usually end up outside anyway."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Newark's 10-member police bicycle squad will complete its first year in August. Sgt. George Barr, left, and Police Officers Raphael Bermudez, center, and Rosa Torres paused on their patrol at the Hayes East Pool. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Is Cut as Japan Imbalance Narrows

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The nation's deficit in traded goods narrowed sharply in May, to $8.4 billion, mainly reflecting the biggest reduction in the imbalance with Japan in over six years, the Commerce Department reported today.
Exports resumed their rise despite lower aircraft sales, reaching the second-highest level on record, while imports of foreign goods tumbled. 
 Although the decline in the deficit was somewhat larger than expected, analysts noted that the economies of many of the United States' trading partners remained weak and that American imports were likely to rebound as growth in the United States picked up.
Moreover, the lowered deficit with Japan was thought by some analysts to have been politically manipulated by Tokyo before it was host to the summit meeting of the seven leading industrial nations earlier this month.
"They probably delayed some shipments and persuaded some of their trading companies to speed up imports," said Edward Guay, an economist for the Cigna Corporation, the large insurer. At $3.8 billion, the American trade deficit with Japan was $1.7 billion less than in April, the biggest drop since December 1986.
Unlike the overall trade figures, the data for individual countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, so comparisons are not exact.
Other analysts here noted that Japan this week reported June figures showing its surplus with the United States rising again.
Still, it appeared that the yen's strength against the dollar has made at least some dent in the trade imbalance. The rising Japanese currency, which has hit records in recent weeks, has made Japanese cars more costly here and makes American cars more competitive at home, so long as Detroit does not raise prices too aggressively.
The United States bought $1.6 billion of new cars from Japan in May, down from $2 billion in April, today's report showed. The total was $1.5 billion in May 1992.
At the Group of Seven summit meeting, the Clinton Administration reached an agreement on a new framework for trade that while avoiding numerical targets could aid American penetration of Japanese markets.
 
Industrial Supplies Strongest
 Exports rose in May by 1.2 percent, to $39 billion, with the strongest sector, industrial supplies and materials, up $600 million. There were small declines in motor vehicles, parts and engines, in foods, feeds and beverages and in the other goods category.
The drop in imports reflected a $600 million decline in automotive goods and lesser declines for consumer goods, industrial supplies and capital goods, the report showed.
May's $8.4 billion deficit followed two months in which the deficit was more than $10 billion, a level thought unlikely to be sustained. One reason is that many American exporters have worked themselves into such good competitive shape that they can sell even in fragile overseas economies.
The monthly trade report covers only trade in merchandise and ignores private services like insurance that last year generated a surplus equal to about two-thirds the merchandise deficit.
The nation's bill for imported oil edged down $200 million, to $3.5 billion, in May as volume fell 10 million barrels while the average price was nearly unchanged at $16.72.
 
Deficit With Canada Drops
 The overall deficit with Canada, the nation's largest trading partner, declined $40 million, to $828 million, while the surplus with Western Europe shrunk by $118 million, the department also found.
The deficit widened with South Korea but narrowed with Taiwan and Singapore while the American surplus with Hong Kong expanded. The deficit with China, however, swelled $300 million, to $1.8 billion, a level 50 percent higher than in May 1992.
Trade in advanced technology products generated a $2.7 billion surplus, $100 million less than in April.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Two Views on REIT's: Buy Them. Avoid Them.

BYLINE: By Jeanne B. Pinder

 BODY:
MANY real estate investment trusts are providing the kind of returns that would catch any investor's attention. But should every investor buy?
One expert who says yes is Gregory J. Whyte, first vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, a leader in REIT's, which are a kind of mutual fund that buys real estate or mortgages, converts them into securities and passes any profit on to investors. 
 "These are great investments for individual investors," Mr. Whyte said. "I'm called every day by people asking, 'What should I buy for widows and orphans?' My response is, 'Don't buy one, buy two or three -- diversify.' But I do think you want to buy quality."
One expert who takes a different approach is John Fosheim of Green Street Advisors, a Newport Beach, Calif., firm that analyzes real estate trusts. If an investor asks about individual REIT's, which are traded like stocks, Mr. Fosheim said: "I would tell them not to, but the reason is not that I don't like REIT's. When individual investors call here, we tell them, 'Listen, this thing is fraught with danger.' Most individual investors get too focused on the wrong thing -- the dividend -- and don't ask the right questions, about interest rates and cash flows and management. Our suggestion to individual investors who want to buy a REIT is always the same: go buy a low-cost mutual fund and let the experts do it for you."
A primary factor in the popularity of REIT's is their returns. Publicly traded ones had an average total return of 19.11 percent in the first quarter, said the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts, an industry group based in Washington, compared with a 4.28 percent total return on the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks. In the second quarter, all publicly traded REIT's had a negative return of 2.8 percent, compared with a .5 percent gain for the S.& P. 500. While it is unwise to generalize about a sag in REIT fortunes from such sketchy figures, many real estate experts say that a lot of smart money bought REIT stocks in the last two years, and that bargains and opportunities are now a lot harder to come by.
There are ample reasons for investor caution. The trusts have been around since 1960, and they have a record of booms and crashes -- including a memorable crash in the early 1970's that burned a lot of investors. Even more important, not all REIT's are stars. For example, apartments are among the best real estate investments right now, but office buildings are generally considered a less desirable investment because of the glut of office space.
It also pays to remember the history of the real estate industry. The crash in values that followed the boom of the 1980's shocked traditional lenders, and most of them have stopped or sharply reduced their lending for real estate.
So real estate owners are now trying to get financing on the public markets, from average investors. And this gives some real estate experts pause -- because it means the public is paying more for buildings and mortgages than experts will pay.
"Right now, pricing for real estate is higher on Wall Street than it is on Main Street," Mr. Fosheim said. He went on to say that there were two ways of interpreting this: a bear would say it's time to get out of real estate, while a bull would say that the public markets are predicting where the private market will go -- up.
A big part of the decision of whether to buy, and what to buy, depends on research. Some people familiar with real estate trusts say that proper assessment of their risks and rewards requires an understanding of real estate that the average investor does not have. Others say experienced investors should be able to judge a REIT from public financial information and the other sources used in researching the purchase of any stock.
Richard B. Saltzman, managing director in the real estate department of Merrill Lynch, a giant in the REIT industry, said: "If they're comfortable buying individual stocks on their own, they should have the wherewithal to decide whether a real estate company makes more sense than high technology or whatever other kind of company they're considering investing in."
Mr. Saltzman and others said that probably the most important factor to consider in contemplating a REIT purchase was the quality of its managers: their reputation, experience and record of increasing assets' value. If management owns a lot of the stock, he notes, it increases the chances that it will look out for the interests of stockholders.
Prospective buyers should also try to evaluate the company's current portfolio. Some things to look for are the kind of property the trust owns, diversity of assets (many experts believe that REIT's should stay with one kind of property, for example, residential or shopping centers, to make the best use of management's experience), its income-generating ability and location (economically troubled Southern California could be a bad sign).
Beyond that, the standard issues -- general risk, capital structure, balance sheet, conflicts of interest and the like -- should be considered.
The Securities and Exchange Commission had $3.2 billion of deals in registration at the end of June in initial and secondary offerings for equity REIT's alone, Mr. Whyte said, and more in mortgage and hybrid REIT's.
That flood, he said, means that the search for quality is more important than ever, and that investors should "beware the naked swimmers."
"It's only when the tide goes out that you see who's been swimming naked," he said. "Frankly, I think that the tide is pretty phenomenal right now. In fact, you're seeing a tidal wave."
