HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Primo, Power And Amateur Athletics

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: BUFFALO

 BODY:
PRIMO NEBIOLO was still on a high as he reflected on the celebration of his 70th birthday a day earlier. He'd received an honorary degree in the morning, and in the evening received 200 guests at a reception honoring the occasion.
Today, he was a year older, still rich, still powerful and healthy enough to enjoy it. Nebiolo is also the president -- some might say, emperor -- of the International Amateur Athletic Federation. 
 Frequently painted as a dictator who rules with a heavy hand and an iron will, Nebiolo is credited, almost without exception, with making track and field a lucrative international sport as well as the spine of the Olympic movement.
Largely because of his position, he found his way onto the International Olympic Committee, even though Italy already had the maximum two seats. I.O.C. President Juan Antonio Samaranch created two wild-card seats, one of which went to Nebiolo.
He does not apologize for enjoying power. In Italian, his first name translates as "first."
"I believe that all big men in life want to get some position for themselves," Nebiolo said. "We say a lady wants to continue to be nice. A man wants to continue to be important."
While Nebiolo has made track and field lucrative at an international level, many athletes chafe under his control. One of the world's best-known athletes is challenging his power.
A day before Nebiolo's birthday, a federal judge reaffirmed an earlier ruling awarding $27.3 million to Butch Reynolds, the world record-holder in the 400 meters. Reynolds sued the I.A.A.F. after he allegedly failed a drug test in 1990. The I.A.A.F. issued a 28-month ban.
In typical bulldog fashion, Nebiolo said the I.A.A.F. would pay nothing to Reynolds.
"Never, never. He can live 200 years," Nebiolo said.
Nebiolo pointed out with some pride that the I.O.C. will require all amateur athletes to sign a waiver to the effect that they will take their grievances before a special arbitration panel, not to courts of law.
If they don't sign, they don't compete. But what happens if the world's top athletes refuse to compete?
Nebiolo shook his head. "Impossible," he said. "That method will never materialize."
There is no Primo Nebiolo on the landscape of amateur athletics in the United States, and for this, many breathe a sigh of relief.
But our amateur-sports movement certainly needs a Primo. Or at least a tough, strong-willed figure to give it some energy.
The United States does not have sports kings and emperors. We prefer to let amateur athletics operate in a largely unregulated Wild West dominated by tycoons, speculators and investors.
A special-interest group like the National Collegiate Athletic Association polices itself, creates rules that either maximize profits -- in the name of academics -- or eliminate problem athletes in the name of academic reform. All the while, the N.C.A.A. tells the government to keep out of its business.
Actually, the amateur-athletic movement in the United States needs more rigorous government involvement: The development of young athletes -- the basic exposure of young people to organized competition -- is wretched for a country with such abundant human resources.
The responsibility for development has largely been left to colleges or assumed by the private sector. And this is precisely why the Olympic movement -- outside of track and field, basketball and boxing -- lacks diversity.
Officials in the various national governing bodies maintain that development programs are improving, but access to those programs for athletically gifted, but economically disadvantaged, youngsters is limited.
Even in our bread-and-butter amateur sports -- swimming, track and boxing -- the United States is seeing the gap between itself and the rest of the world being closed by countries that have decided to make their mark in global sports and are pushing to do so.
The idea behind building solid amateur sports programs is not simply to produce Olympians, but to introduce a variety of sports to a wider, more economically diverse groups of young people.
There is simply too much idle time and too few opportunities for young people to use athletics to scale the walls of their insulated worlds.
So while amateur sports in the United States may be better off without an emperor like Nebiolo, the movement certainly needs a Primo at the top.

HEADLINE: Helping Disturbed Children

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having interned for a year at a not-for-profit child guidance agency where disturbed children are treated, I must take issue with Louise Armstrong and her book "And They Call It Help" (June 20). 
 At my agency -- and I believe it is representative of those throughout the country -- children were assessed with enormous care and caution. At no time during my tenure was a child treated simply because he was a nuisance to his parents or teachers, as Ms. Armstrong states.
To suggest that mental health workers, who typically have two to six years of graduate education, are unaware of the pitfalls of diagnostic labeling, or the economic etiology of many of our clients' problems, is ludicrous and insulting.
Child therapy modalities include play therapy, where the therapist and the child play with toys, or play board games; drawing; manipulating Play-Doh, and storytelling, perhaps aided by hand puppets. None of these techniques could be considered cruel or repressive. Children seem to benefit from them, and look forward to their next session.
 
JONATHAN FAST
Fairfield, Conn.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Diamond District;
The Sparkle's Back on 47th

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
TENANTS at 20 West 47th Street are asking their landlord, Frank Ring, about expansion space. And 10 West 47th Street and 580 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of 47th Street, have waiting lists.
At the corner of 48th Street, 589 Fifth Avenue had a 48 percent vacancy rate less than three years ago. Today, only 6 percent of its space is left, and that's going fast. 
 "We could conceivably be fully occupied within the next three months," said Jane Haigney, the building's marketing director.
After a couple of rocky years, real estate prospects are again shining in the diamond district, that long, bustling 47th Street block from the Avenue of the Americas to Fifth Avenue.
Rents, which had been plummeting at a sickening speed, are firming in the $30's for the Fifth Avenue buildings, and in the $20's for the older buildings on 47th Street.
Diamond companies that had shrunk to survive the last few lean years are expanding again. And manufacturers and dealers that were driven out in the 1980's by overcrowding and soaring rents are returning.
"People who drifted to 46th and 48th or even to the 30's are starting to drift back," said Kenneth F. Kahn, a general partner in 10 West 47th Street and 580 Fifth Avenue. And they are drifting into larger quarters, added Mr. Ring.
"People who used to only want 300 to 1,000 square feet are now asking about 3,000- to 6,000-square-foot units," he said.
In fact, many of the newly expanding firms are migrating to the east side of Fifth Avenue, crossing what had once been an inviolable psychological boundary. The East Side buildings, notably 579 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of 47th Street, and 589 Fifth Avenue, are newer, and have higher security. And, they are close to 580 Fifth Avenue, home to the Diamond Club and considered the industry's psychological, if not physical, heart.
The impact on the East Side buildings has been enormous. When Axel Stawski and his partners bought 579 Fifth Avenue five years ago, it was vacant. Today, it is 94 percent occupied, with rents from the mid-$20's to about $40.
"The two trends -- toward the eastern end of 47th Street, and toward modern space -- have both helped us a lot," Mr. Stawski said.
What has also helped, of course, is the diamond industry's fiscal health. Unlike New York's real estate industry, the city's diamond industry seems to have come through the recession relatively unscathed.
Its collective bank debt of $450 million has not gone up appreciably in the last few years. Although the average value per-carat of the diamonds that have been selling has gone down -- $472 last year, from $517 in 1991 and $537 in 1990 -- the volume of gems imported and sold has increased each year.
"We keep seeing articles that say the diamond industry is in trouble, but in fact relatively few people have had to close shop," said Lloyd Jaffe, chairman of the American Diamond Industry Association.
The upbeat news is particularly cheerful to Manhattan officials, who decided this year that the city had not been properly mindful of the industry's importance and needs.
In February, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger's office released a comprehensive study of the diamond industry -- it's makeup (one surprise: 57 percent of the industry's employees are nonwhite, despite its long reputation as a Jewish enclave), its employee base (23,000 and growing) and its contribution to the city ($57 million in annual tax revenues alone).
"This is an industry that really wants to be in New York, and we've just never paid enough attention to it," said Andy Breslau, Ms. Messinger's press secretary.
CLEARLY, that is changing. Ms. Messinger's office has sponsored workshops on how to deal with competition from Antwerp, Hong Kong, Tel Aviv and other international diamond centers. It has arranged for technology assistance grants from the state to help find ways to cut down on gem loss in processing.
It plans seminars to help family-owned businesses better incorporate nonfamily employees into their succession plans, should other family members not want to take over. And it has committed $780,000 to capital improvements around 47th Street, to make it more secure, attractive and what Mr. Breslau calls "more pedestrian friendly." Among the possible changes: Entry archways to 47th Street on Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, prominently tagged "Diamond Jewelry Way."
"The street is thriving, but its retail tenants are facing more competition than ever before," said Eric L. Waldron, whose company, Waldron Associates, manages 36 West 47th Street. "If the city can improve the street's image, it's lighting and it's security, we'll all be able to compete with the suburban malls and the discount jewelers."
District landlords are not waiting for the city to move. They are busily caring for their own buildings, particularly from a security standpoint. Many have put in extra guards, new alarm systems, and intercoms and closed-circuit cameras to check on visitors. Some of the newer buildings, like 579 and 589 Fifth Avenue, have sophisticated electronic systems that require key cards to get from a staircase to any floor, and that set off alarms if any staircase door is held open too long.
"We realized that by offering a really secure building, we could woo tenants across the Avenue," said Philip Shapiro, an Edward S. Gordon associate director who is leasing agent for 579 Fifth.
Security certainly lured E.W. International Diamond Inc. from an older building on 47th Street to 579 Fifth Avenue.
"PEOPLE could wander in and out of our old building," said Abraham S. Elias, E.W.'s vice president and co-owner. "We never had a problem, but we didn't want to take a chance." Recently, Mr. Elias expanded onto another floor at 579 Fifth Avenue. "We could probably move to a less secure building for $10 a foot less, but you don't want to have to worry when you open and close your place," he said.
But owners of older buildings are not giving up their tenants without a fight. Mr. Waldron says that 36 West 47th Street is almost full, and solvent; a couple of years ago, it was half-empty and bankrupt. His company has heightened the building's security substantially, as well as simplified the escalation clauses on leases, offered low rent and good free-rent packages to new tenants, and renegotiated older leases that called for above-market rents.
"We did a concerted marketing effort, and we offered good deals," he said. "One thing about 47th Street, when you offer good deals, the word of mouth is tremendous."
Actually, on 47th Street, word of mouth is the prime marketing tool. New York's diamond industry, despite it's multibillion-dollar size, is one in which business is done on handshakes, and personal relationships and trust often mean more than lines of credit. Because most diamond companies do not need much space -- a 400-foot booth on a diamond exchange, or a 700-foot upstairs spot for manufacturing and administrative offices would be large -- brokers rarely get involved in space negotiations. Instead, building owners walk the streets, introducing themselves to potential tenants and schmoozing with existing tenants, in hopes that they will pass the word to their cousins or sisters or brothers-in-law in the business.
For two years, management at 589 Fifth Avenue wined and dined its own tenants, asking them what they would like to see improved in the building -- queries that resulted in an extra security guard in the lobby, a beefed up maintenance staff, and a switch away from rent escalations tied to the consumer price index or porter's wages, and to flat pass-alongs of direct operating expenses and taxes. It cold-called diamond dealers and manufacturers up and down 47th Street, and sent them a steady stream of promotional premiums -- clocks, shoeshine kits, matchbook calculators, boxes of tissues -- all prominently marked with 589's logo.
"In the last year and a half, only two of the 35 deals we've done involved brokers," said Ms. Haigney. "Here, you rent when people get to know you. They just walk in your door and talk."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diamond Jewelry Way, 47th Street off the Avenue of the Americas. (Edward Ornelas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
A Taxation Tempest Over Private Schools

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IT has been chapter, verse and law since time immemorial: Thou shalt not tax private schools.
But officials of the 81 independent secondary schools in Connecticut are watching with apprehension as the trial date nears for a landmark lawsuit filed in Superior Court in Hartford challenging the Town of Windsor's right to levy a property tax on the Loomis ChaffeeSchool, founded there in 1897. 
 Beginning in 1992 the school has been taxed $65,000 a year on 28 units of faculty housing on the 300-acre campus. The school has appealed the assessment, and is seeking to recover the taxes, paid under protest, and to get assurance from the court that it will not be taxed in future.
No matter what the outcome of the suit, filed in May 1922, the loser is expected to file an appeal in State Supreme Court.
It is not unusual for private schools and their host towns to negotiate taxes on non-educational facilities. It is common for the schools to contribute substantial amounts informally to the towns in lieu of taxes.
Loomis Chaffee has not been forthcoming in that respect, said Joseph L. Hammer, an attorney at Day, Berry & Howard in Hartford, who is handling the town's defense.
Consequently, and without any mandate more specific than a state statute exempting from taxes property used exclusively for education, the town, in need of additional revenue, has chosen to tax faculty housing as noneducational property.
"All municipalities have an obligation to taxpayers to examine the real estate within their borders and to determine that all property owners are legally paying a proper tax," Mr. Hammer said. "There is no uniform application of law or custom across the 169 towns, but the fact that similar institutions are being taxed is evidence of support for Windsor's position."
Loomis Chaffee has an unusual charter, granted in 1874 by the General Assembly: It exempted the school from taxes as long as it remained an educational institution.
"It's conceivable that the court would decide the case based on the charter and make it unique to Loomis," said William H. Narwold, an attorney at Cummings & Lockwood in Hartford, who represents the school. "Over the years the town has raised the issue of taxing Loomis Chaffee more than once, but legal opinions by town attorneys have indicated that there was no authority to do so. Now Windsor is looking for revenue and took another shot at it."
Windsor is not alone in interpreting the law as excluding from tax exemption such nonacademic facilities as faculty housing, buildings rented to outsiders and excess land.
Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, which dates back to the late 17th century, has $125 million worth of property, including more than 100 buildings on 425 acres. For many years it has paid up to $30,000 in property taxes on faculty housing, accommodations that were rented to visiting parents, and off-campus holdings.
The Kent School in Kent pays more than $76,000 on noneducational facilities, and Hotchkiss School in Lakeville gives about $50,000 a year to the Town of Salisbury. "I use the term gift, not payment in lieu of taxes, to emphasize the fact that nonprofit schools are not taxable," said Robert A. Oden Jr., the Hotchkiss headmaster.
Estimates by most school business managers indicated that some towns would receive less in taxes on noneducational property than they did as donations.
"There is much interest in this suit, not only in Connecticut but everywhere," said David A. Mitchell, business manager of the Taft School in Watertown. The Internal Revenue Service recently held an investigation there to determine why faculty housing was not taxable to employees as income.
"WE insist on having faculty members live on campus to supervise students 24 hours a day, and be available to students in crises," Mr. Mitchell said. The I.R.S. agreed. "That would seem to be a conclusive judgment in my view," Mr. Mitchell said.
Taft contributes about $70,000 to the town each year. "When the town comes to us occasionally in need of additional revenues we try to help out, to be a good neighbor and support the services it renders," Mr. Mitchell said. "But tax-exempt status is essential to the maintenance of the institution."
Campuses of some independent Connecticut schools, a third of which are religiously affiliated, can be as large as Hotchkiss's 650 acres. Annual tuition, room and board can reach $25,000, property values can be as high as $125 million and annual budgets can be more than $15 million. Endowments, in many cases, are generous.
Peter Tacy, the executive director of the Connecticut Association of Independent Schools in Mystic, said, "What worries us is not money, but relationships. If we end up paying taxes there won't be the incentive to buy fire engines, environmental and other equipment for the towns, provide scholarships for local children, keep private school libraries, pools, tennis courts, golf courses, ice rinks, and other athletic and cultural facilities open to the public at little or no cost."
AN effort was made in the last session of the General Assembly to introduce legislation that would permit towns to tax the nonacademic buildings and excess land of private schools. It did not get beyond the Planning and Development Committee.
Bud Trotta, the First Selectman of Salisbury, had a particular interest in the bill because his town has three private secondary schools: Hotchkiss, Salisbury and Indian Mountain School, which occupy a total of 1,200 acres. Mr. Trotta said the town received a total of $32,000 from the three schools, adding that he believed $125,000 could be collected in taxes.
"Nobody wants to hurt the schools, but the laws are archaic," he said. "Towns should be able to negotiate settlements with private schools based on local needs. Even if the economy picks up, the world has changed. We have to look to new means of revenue to sustain communities." Mr. Tacy said he feared that allowing towns to write their own tax-exemption laws would result in "everybody winding up in court."
"People would be pitted against each other, with the lawyers the only winners," he said. "If secular schools are taxed, what about religious schools and institutions, what about hospitals and other health facilities? And would channeling that money to local governments actually reduce taxes or improve services?"

HEADLINE: 2 Finalists Battle for an Expanded Unicef

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
A FINAL decision is expected by early October in the long-running bid battle between New York City and New Rochelle over which city will become the host for the expansion of Unicef, the Manhattan-based United Nations relief organization for children.
Both cities have offered tantalizing packages of financial incentives. New Rochelle is proposing to build a 20-story building -- which would also become the centerpiece of the city's downtown revitalization efforts -- for the agency. New York City has proposed buying additional office space. The competition is unusually intense because at least six other United Nations agencies are considering moving their headquarters from the East Side of Manhattan to New Rochelle, San Francisco and Bonn.. 
 The impetus for possible relocations stems, in large part, from a cost-cutting campaign at the United Nations. But agencies also contemplate movea because of expansion needs and the lure of cheaper office space, lower housing costs and a higher life quality elsewhere.
If all of the agencies were to leave, the city would lose at least 2,600 jobs, more than a third of the United Nations workforce in New York, and up to $200 million in salaries, rents, supplies and other spending in New York -- a fifth of the $1 billion the organization contributes each year to the local economy.
Moves by United Nations agencies could also result in an exodus of smaller diplomatic missions and United Nations-related services from the city. UNITAR, the United Nations Institute for Training and Research recently transferred its offices from Manhattan to Geneva, Switzerland. Most of the agency's 32 jobs, though, were transferred last winter to other United Nations offices in New York. Another international agency, CARE, also plans to leave New York in the next few weeks. Established 47 years ago in New York, CARE will transfer its headquarters -- and 200 employees -- next month from 66 First Avenue, near 37th Street, to a five-story building in Atlanta donated by a local charity.
"Retaining the United Nations is New York City's top priority," said Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "The Mayor and I are working very closely with the entire United States Mission to the United Nations and the Secretariat to plan for the long-term needs of the entire U.N. system. We believe that the city's role as host city to the U.N. is of the utmost importance to the international nature of the city."
Germany has been particularly active in attempting to lure U.N. agencies. Among the agencies considering a move to Bonn are the United Nations Development Program, the United Nations Capital Development Fund, the Fund for Population Activities, the Development Fund for Women and the United Nations Sudano-Sahelian Office.
The appeal of Bonn, which will have considerable empty office space once the reunified Germany moves its capital back to Berlin, lies largely in the German Government's offer of free rent. Germany has also offered $184 million in relocation costs and a substantial increase in the nation's voluntary contributions to the United Nations.
Of the agencies being wooed by Bonn, the United Nations Development Program is the largest, with 1,159 employees; its payroll also includes employees from the Capital Development Fund and the Sudano-Sahelian Office. The Fund for Population Activities has 242 employees, the Development Fund for Women has 31. All work mainly with third world development; the Sudano-Sahelian Office deals with famine relief in the Saharan region.
ELSEWHERE, another agency reportedly considering leaving the cluster of office buildings that surround the monolithic United Nations Secretariat Building on the East River is the newly created United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development. San Francisco wants it to move into the Presidio, an Army base under the Golden Gate Bridge that is scheduled to be closed. The commission is now based in the Secretariat Building.
The most immediate decision, however, may come from Unicef, formerly called the United Nations Children's Fund. Founded in 1946 as the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, the agency, which has 951 employees and injects $82 million a year into the city's economy, helps developing countries improve conditions for children by providing health, nutrition and social welfare aid.
Unicef is now based in 204,000 square feet of leased space at 3 United Nations Plaza on East 44th Street, between First and Second Avenues. It also rents office space in two buildings nearby, as well as in buildings in Long Island City and Secaucus, N.J. The agency, though, wants to expand by 1995 and consolidate its operations into one or two buildings. Unicef officials have projected that the agency needs about 440,000 square feet over the next 17 years, when it expects to have about 1,500 employees.
To meet those expansion needs, the agency advertised in September 1991 for bids and proposals. From an original list of 76 sites, New Rochelle, 18 miles north of New York City, and Manhattan are the two finalists. The Unicef executive board is now expected to make its decision in early October.
The executive board had intended to select a plan in May but instead told both New Rochelle and New York City to present new final offers by June 30.
"I still think we have an excellent chance," said Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle. "If New York's plan was so good it would have been approved two months ago."
New Rochelle's proposal is to erect a 440,000-square-foot, 20-story building on a two-acre city-owned parking lot on Huguenot Street opposite the municipal parking garage. The project would be financed with 30-year bonds issued by the city. The agency would be charged an annual rent of $378,000.
The new Unicef building would become the first in a what the city hopes would become a United Nations Community District. Future plans include three other new office buildings containing 800,000 square feet, 500 units of market-rate housing, a retail complex and a parking garage. The proposal was created with the assistance of the Starrett Housing Corporation/H.R.H. Housing Corporation and the architectural firm of Kohn-Pederson & Fox Associates, all of Manhattan.
"They want to build a U.N. city there in a nutshell," said Timothy E. Boakes, Unicef's director of administrative management. "It certainly is an interesting proposal."
NEW YORK CITY'S plan, as put forth by its Economic Development Corporation and the United Nations Development Corporation, a city-state agency, is to cut the $10 million annual rent that Unicef now pays on the Unicef House, its headquarters, by $28 million over 20 years. It would also turn over the ownership of Unicef House to the agency in 2026, when the bonds issued to pay for its construction have been paid off. Unicef House is owned by the United Nations Development Corporation. The city owns the land at the site.
Additionally, the United Nations Development corporation agreed to buy up to 200,000 more square feet of space near Unicef House and eventually turn the ownership of the space over to the agency. The expansion would be financed by city-issued bonds.
"We have been able to negotiate concessions with the City of New York that no one thought was possible," Mr. Boakes said.
Among the buildings that could be used to provide spillover space are the 31-story American Home Products Building at 685 Third Avenue, between 44th and 43d Streets, which will be vacant when the company moves to Madison, N.J. in November; a 41-story tower at 633 Third Avenue, between 41st and 40th Streets, and the United Engineering Center at 345 East 47th Street.
"We have been urging the city to do everything possible to make a comparable offer," said Victor Marrero, the newly appointed United States Representative to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
The principal difference between the two bids, apart from their location, is their cost. "You could broadly say that over a 30-year period, there was a difference of $200 million," said Mr. Boakes said.
City officials, however, believe that depending on accounting methods, the savings in the New Rochelle plan, if any, are much smaller. They also note that what the agency might gain in cost-savings from the move could be erased by a loss of fund-raising dollars, possibly as much as $300 million over 30 years.
"The numbers are not really telling the full story," Ambassador Marrero said.
In April, however, a United Nations budgetary committee, the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, which reviews fiscal and personnel matters, issued a report on the options.
The report, while not endorsing New Rochelle, concluded that "the proposed relocation of Unicef to New Rochelle is clearly the most cost-effective offer, resulting in savings of $261.7 million" over three decades, "compared to the best assured offer for Manhattan."
"The European community is saying we are tired of contributing money for administrative waste," said Mayor Idoni of New Rochelle. "Ten million or $20 million saved in cutting waste could be used to feed poor children. That's what Unicef is for."
A compromise has been presented by both the budgetary committee and Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat whose congressional district includes New Rochelle. It would call for Unicef executives and up to about 10 percent of the staff to work out of the current Manhattan headquarters while the rest of the personnel work in New Rochelle.
"We'd accept," Mr. Idoni said.
THERE are, though, arguments that favor keeping Unicef in New York City. Moving to New Rochelle, for example, so far from the United Nations and the Permanent Missions, would create logistical problems, and leaving New York City would mean losing certain intangible benefits, namely prestige and a cosmopolitan environment, United Nations officials say. Indeed, in February the executive director of Unicef, James P. Grant, conceded that moving to New Rochelle would be less costly but nonetheless recommended that the agency's headquarters remain in Manhattan.
New Rochelle officials are irked by any characterization of their city as distant and provincial. "They are not moving to Kansas," Mr. Idoni said. "They are 23 minutes away by car."
Emily P. McKhann, New York City's acting commissioner for the United Nations Consular Corps and International Business, also said that there would be security concerns if United Nations agencies, such as Unicef, began fragmenting into the suburbs, particularly if foreign missions and consulates followed suit.
Approval by either the Secretary of State or Congress would also be needed for Unicef to relocate outside of the city, though neither New York City officials nor their counterparts in New Rochelle anticpate that the Federal Government would block such a move.
Ms. McKhann noted, too, that the United States Department of State and the United States representative to the 41-nation Unicef board, Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, support staying in the city.
"Clearly, this is something the city cares about," she said. "Our bid clearly meets their needs. We absolutely want them to stay."

At right is New York Deputy Mayor Barry F. Sullivan at Unicef's present site on East 44th Street. (Marilynn K. HEADLINE: The View From: Essex;
Will Publicity Change a Community's Character?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
ON a recent weekday morning two buses carrying older people arrived in Essex almost simultaneously, one from Rhode Island and the other from New Jersey. For the next few hours the visitors browsed in art galleries, boutiques and antique shops on Main Street, visited the historic waterfront and then had lunch at the 217-year-old Griswold Inn, the town's centerpiece.
Occasionally, other tourists drop in, usually in small family groups on what may well be Connecticut's most charming seacoast town, on the west bank of the Connecticut River, about six miles from Old Saybrook and Long Island Sound. 
 So far this spring and summer the number of visitors does not appear to have changed. Nor, for that matter, has anything else in Essex, where the Oliver Cromwell, the first warship in the Continental Navy, was built in 1775, as were several hundred other ocean-going sailing ships between the Revolutionary and Civil Wars.
That is good news for most residents of Essex, where the last major change occurred in the 1820's when the invention of the steamboat sent the town's thriving shipbuilding business into a sharp decline from which it never recovered. (Sad to say, business at the town's three boatyards, a legacy of the old shipyards, has been slowed markedly by the recent recession, which may also account for soup kitchens that are open on varying nights at local churches).
Apparently the invasion of outsiders that had been anticipated by some townspeople has failed to materialize in Essex, where, like Nantucket, time seems to have stood still for generations.
"A lot of people in town were fearful that Essex had been 'discovered' and that things were not going to be the same," said William G. Winterer, the owner and proprietor of the Griswold Inn, the landmark restaurant and hostelry on Main Street.
 
'Not Exactly Good News'
 Mr. Winterer, formerly an investment broker who has owned and operated the 'Gris,' as most local residents call the Griswold, for 21 years, was alluding to a book published earlier this year that listed Essex as the second-best small town in the United States. While many communities would relish the attention, not to mention possible prosperity, that such status might bring, many Essex residents were hardly enthralled.
"To many people here, it was not exactly good news," Mr. Winterer said in an interview at the white clapboard Griswold, the first three-story building in the state. "This is a very conservative, family-oriented town, and most people don't want anything changed."
Mr. Winterer, for one, was not displeased with the recognition bestowed by Norman Crampton in his book "The 100 Best Small Towns in America." (Elko, Nev., was picked as the best of the best.) "I thought it was going to be fantastic for business, but that hasn't happened," said Mr. Winterer, who became enamored of the Griswold while he was a young lieutenant training at the Coast Guard Academy in New London.
No other communities from Connecticut were included among the 100 towns, each with a population between 5,000 and 15,000. The 1990 census listed Essex's population at 5,904.
In addition to the population range, towns had to have "stand-alone economies" that provided jobs for a significant number of residents and could not be suburbs in metropolitan areas. Specific measuring criteria (Essex's standing is in brackets) included growth rate (tied for 17), per capita income (1), proportion of residents between 25 and 34 years old (13), proportion of blacks and other minorities (34), the number of physicians (8), the crime rate (72), expenditures for public education (32) and the percentage of residents with at least four years of college education (12).
 
Sleepy Little Village
 To some, Essex's standing in a few of those categories came as a surprise. For instance, the town's population actually has decreased in recent years and there are very few black and Hispanic residents of Essex. That Essex ranked relatively high in the crime category also surprised many people in a town that has no police department, only a resident state trooper, who works out of the Town Hall, and a full-time constable, and where crime is rare.
"There were some strong concerns that our ranking in the book would bring in a lot of people and perhaps change the character of the town," Bruce M. Glowac, the First Selectman, said in an interview. "But that hasn't happened, and we're still a sleepy little New England village."
Mr. Glowac did say, though, that in recent years there has been a slight influx of home buyers from "down river."
"Most of them have come from Fairfield County, New York and New Jersey," he said. "In many cases, they've bought second homes here, although quite a few have settled in Essex permanently, many after retiring. Almost all of the new residents are quality people who get involved in the community."
One of them is Joshua Crowell, pastor of the First Congregational Church, who estimates that he answered 260 calls last year as a member of the Essex Volunteer Fire Department. "The church is only about a city block from the firehouse, and I'm often the first one there," he said. "That means I usually drive a piece of apparatus to the scene. I do get some funny looks, especially when I have my clerical garb on. People aren't used to seeing a minister in a Geneva robe, tabs and bell sleeves driving a fire truck."
Most real-estate agents interviewed said they had received few inquiries as a result of Mr. Crampton's book. "We got only about a half-dozen calls," said William Foster, a broker at the Mitchel real-estate agency. "And I'm sure a lot of people here were glad. Some newcomers discover this beautiful little town and then want to pull up the drawbridge so no one else can get in. But others realize we have to be more realistic."
Only one real-estate broker, Donn Holland, the sales manager of the local Westledge Real Estate office, said his agency had received a large number of calls. He said the calls came from as far away as California. "They'd ask, 'Where are you? What are you like?' " Mr. Holland said. "Some came to visit, and I sold at least one house, to a doctor from New York, as a result of the book."
Even before the book extolling some of the town's many virtues came out, the residential real-estate business was picking up in Essex. "Things had been very slow for a long time," said JoAnn Chapman of Osage Ltd. Realtor. "But we've begun to get more second-home buyers, mainly from Fairfield County." Ms. Chapman pointed out that the biggest transaction in recent months was the sale of a home that had belonged to Chester Bowles, the former Governor, United States Senator and Ambassador, for $1.9 million.
For years, most home buyers in Essex were well-to-do retirees, many of whom had spent time in the area, and fairly affluent middle-aged couples. And most everyone owned a yacht in a a town that has three yacht clubs and two marinas. "More young families are moving in now," said Brenda Milkofsky, the curator of the Connecticut River Museum, which is on Steamboat Dock at the foot of Main Street. "I think a lot of them are attracted by our excellent elementary school, along with the overall beauty of the town. And once they're here, they find this a town with great spirit."
Middle and high school students from Essex attend regional schools in nearby Deep River.
Mrs. Milkofsky is not surprised that many townspeople were apprehensive that Essex's newfound celebrity would attract too many tourists. She recalled that, 15 years ago, townspeople overwhelmingly rejected a proposal by the state to include about 100 buildings in Essex as a state historic district. "Most towns probably would have welcomed such a move, since it guarantees that the buildings can't be torn down," Mrs. Milkovsky said. "But the perception by people here was that it would attract more tourists."
In truth, Essex has few so-called "tourist attractions." The main one is the Essex Steam Train, a collection of restored steam engines and coaches operating out of an old-fashioned depot in Essex, which takes riders on a trip into yesteryear on a 10-mile-long track along the Connecticut River between Essex and Chester. The others are the Connecticut River Museum and the Ivoryton Playhouse (Ivoryton and Centerbrook are both villages within the town of Essex), where Katharine Hepburn, a native of Hartford, made her acting debut in 1931.
Mr. Winterer, the proprietor of the Griswold, may be the only one in town able to compare Essex, "the second best town in America," with Elko, Nev., which was named No. 1 in the book.
"I've been to Elko, Nev.," Mr. Winterer said. "It's a nice town, but I assure you it can't compare with Essex."

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Leasing With an Option
 
Question: I am interested in learning more about leasing a house with the option to buy. What are the pitfalls? 
 Is there a book or someplace where I could write to find out more of what is involved?
What happens if the buyer or seller changes their mind? How binding is it? . . . Ellen M. Tum Suden, Brooklyn
 
Answer: According to Alan Yassky, president of Rockland Realty, in Spring Valley, N.Y., leases that offer an option to buy, sometimes with all or part of the rent applied toward the purchase price or a down payment, are not common these days and are generally only offered by distressed sellers.
He added that the pitfalls are generally the seller's, as the buyer is usually only risking rent that they would be paying anyway.
The buyer also has the option to close, not to close or negotiate a new deal. Sometimes, though, particularly if the deal is being structured just to enable a buyer to raise a down payment, additional option money may be required of the buyer, raising his level of risk and commitment, Mr. Yassky said.
For more information, check the real estate or business section of any local book store or contract the National Association of Realtors (312) 329-8200), which can send you a list of books on various real estate subjects.
 
Evictions in a Purchase
 
Question: I am planning to buy a six-family house. All apartments are rent-stabilized, and they are presently occupied.
I need two apartments for my family. What is the process for evicting tenants from the apartments?
Also, how should I proceed to reserve two apartments as soon as possible? Are their any time requirements or deadlines? . . . Vladimir Vasilets, Brooklyn
 
Answer: According to Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the Department of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, which oversees rent regulation in the city, after you buy the building you should state in a certified letter to the tenants that you do not intend to renew their leases because you are going to use the apartment for yourself and your family.
He also said that this letter must be delivered from 120 to 150 days before the expiration of the lease.
If the lease is expiring in less than 120 days, then the tenants are entitled to a renewal for the same length of time as the current lease, Mr. Ganim said.
He added that if the tenants refuse to leave, you can go to Housing Court, but not until the lease expires.
 
Renting a Condominium
 
Question: I own a condominium in Manhattan and want to rent it for four months. I received a copy of the sublease requirements, signed the forms and sent in my check.
Later, however, I was told that the board requires a one-year lease. I asked for written documentation on the requirement, and was told that there wasn't any "but it's somewhere in the minutes and it would take a long time to find it."
I have a tenant from out of town that expects to move in soon. What should I do? . . . Gertrude M. Brooks, Manhattan
 
Answer: Requirements restricting leasing are generally contained in the bylaws of the condominium which are filed with the declaration, according to Howard Schechter, a Manhattan lawyer.
As a general rule, though, there are no restrictions on leasing. Typical condominium documents give the board of managers right to match an offer to lease the space, but not to approve or disapprove a lease, he added.
In your case, Mr. Schechter said that you should check the bylaws to determine whether the board has the authority to restrict the term of a lease by formally adopting a requirement.
If they have not done that, then board has no right to prevent you from renting out your unit on a four-month lease, Mr. Schechter said.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Doesn't It Ever Stop? PC Price War Looms Again

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
JUST as in "Jurassic Park," the big dinosaurs -- Compaq, I.B.M., Digital and Hewlett-Packard among them -- are coming back to life and, boy, are they hungry. With the ferocity of a Tyrannosaurus rex, these giants of the computer industry are stalking and chewing up any personal computer makers not big enough, smart enough or nimble enough to survive.
The weaker PC makers have no choice but to scurry for cover. The Compuadd Corporation, following the lead of Everex Systems Inc., recently filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and laid off more than half its workers. Scores of smaller companies are going to unmarked graves. Even some fairly large American companies are disappearing -- goodbye Gecco, Fast Micro, Standard. 
 "Of the X number of advertisers we had in December, in June there was a substantial percentage less," said John Blackford, editor of Computer Shopper, a phonebook-sized magazine that carries ads for companies selling computers and components directly to users. "The first half of 1993 definitely saw a downtrend. The companies that are going away are the ones who didn't understand how to run an efficient business."
Adapt or die is the message, and the key question is how long companies have to adapt. "People want it to be over in two quarters, but we're looking at another 24 months of shakeout at all levels," said John McCarthy, director of technology research at Forrester Research Inc., a research and consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. "The summer doldrums seem to exact their toll, particularly in Europe and Japan. There's nowhere for these guys to hide."
It used to be that a company could buffer its sagging domestic sales by looking overseas, but the economic slump is worse in many quarters abroad. Business in Germany, which traditionally accounts for as much as 25 percent of European computer purchases, has declined sharply; Japan's economy is slowing.
Some companies are getting out, others are seeking protectors. The Tandy Corporation, for example, unloaded its PC business to AST Research Inc., which is expected to report a decline in earnings for its fourth quarter, which ended July 3.
Groupe Bull, a money-losing French company that owns the unprofitable Zenith Data Systems, acquired a 19.9 percent stake in Packard Bell, which contends it is profitable. Last year, when it wasn't profitable, Packard Bell had to cancel an initial public offering.
Even some of the bigger predators are getting nervous. Although the overall PC market continues to expand, "the hockey stick growth chart for many companies appears to have reached the knob on the handle," said Portia Isaacson, president of Dream I.T., a market research and consulting company in Colorado Springs.
Dell said last week it would report its first quarterly loss, while Apple surprised even the most pessimistic analysts by reporting a $188 million lossfor its second quarter, which produced a sharp plunge in its stock. Even the mighty Microsoft Corporation hints that slower times are ahead.
Now, with smaller companies on the run, big companies are preparing for what Andrew J. Neff, a senior analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, calls the "clash of the Titans."
"The coming battle between the first-tier players, most of whom have deep pockets, could result in another price war and a tougher battle for market share points," Mr. Neff said.
The homogeneity of personal PC technology, based on the Intel Corporation's microprocessors and Microsoft's software, means that the battleground is almost certainly prices.
Price wars are happy news for computer buyers, of course, and demand for computers has stayed strong. Will Zachman, president of Canopus Research of Duxbury, Mass., said he suspects that the demand has been siphoned from 1994 into 1993 as a result of the low prices, and that demand will dry up soon.
But low prices mean slimmer profits, so the big companies need to sell ever greater numbers of computers to sustain their dinosaur-sized metabolisms. To do so they need to create new markets, which they can do by cutting prices further or coming up with new products. "I suspect we're at the early stages of the extinction process for some of these less adaptable creatures," Mr. Zachman said.
Apple Computer Inc. recently got a new chief executive, cut its prices for the third time in three months and handed pink slips to 16 percent of its work force. It will introduce its Newton personal information manager later this month.
International Business Machines, which got a new chief executive earlier this year, is lopping off excess workers in five-figure chunks and reshuffling its operations. It is strengthening its line of portable computers, employing new technologies in its desktop line and preparing to enter new markets with a line of low-cost PC's called Ambras.
The Compaq Computer Corporation has a head start on the pack. It started the current price war a year ago when it got a new chief executive and dumped 2,000 jobs.
Even so, Compaq recently reorganized its PC operations, announced an intimate working relationship with Microsoft, I.B.M.'s former spouse, and vowed to cut prices again. It, too, plans to introduce a new line of low-cost computers for the consumer market and small, pen-based computers.
The combatants, Mr. Neff said, will include such companies as Hewlett-Packard and Digital Equipment, which have not managed to crack the first tier but have the deep pockets needed to sustain a long battle.
Hewlett-Packard has proven its strength with printers and advanced work stations, and it recently introduced some impressive portable machines. Digital slept through the first decade of the personal computer business but has shown surprising vigor in the last year. Digital copied its direct-sales approach directly from Dell, right down to the advertising, and is suddenly a major force.
The winners, said Ms. Isaacson of Dream I.T., will be the companies that have unique strengths and own intellectual property rights -- that is, patents and copyrights.
"When we look at computer eras past, in minicomputers it was Digital, and in mainframes it was I.B.M., because they owned the intellectual property," Ms. Isaacson said. "Today, Intel, Microsoft and Apple own the intellectual property, although Apple has been creamed by the strength of the Intel-Microsoft standard. Dell owns the customer interface, with its account control and support, and the only other approach is to be really efficient in high-volume manufacturing. I'm not sure any company fits that mold, and that's why Taiwan Inc. now builds 25 percent of the PC's sold in the United States."
But even while the big dinosaurs thrash and tangle, there may be room for new species to evolve. "We're in another paradign shift to nomadic systems like A.T.& T.'s Hobbit, Penpoint and Apple's Newton, where other types of intellectual property are possible," Ms. Isaacson said.
For would-be computer buyers, the prospect of another escalation of the price war may make it worthwhile to wait for a month or two before actually putting the money down. Grab some popcorn and go see "Jurassic Park."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
High Scores for Mutual Funds Abroad

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

 BODY:
ANYONE seeking proof of the axiom that investors look to the future -- and care little about the present -- can find it this year in the performance of foreign stock markets.
Even as Japan and much of Europe succumbed to or continued to flirt with recession, mutual funds investing there in anticipation of recovery have produced double-digit returns following a long period of lagging performance. 
 "There's been an enormous change, a reversal," observed A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, a prominent industry scorekeeper. "The four years' underperformance of the international market is over."
In fact, during the quarter ended June 30 international stock funds easily outperformed both global funds -- which invest in the United States as well as abroad -- and funds limiting themselves solely to America, where the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eked out a 3.4 percent gain.
Funds heavily invested in Japanese stocks, up nearly 35 percent during the first half of the year, have performed best, aided by currency gains roughly equaling those from the stocks themselves. Small Japanese companies showed the most zip of all.
For the second quarter, funds concentrating in East Asia, including Japan, posted a gain of about 11 percent.
Europe, where privatization is helping entice American portfolio managers, has also done well. Latin America, an earlier star, has faded and East Asian markets other than Japan have flattened and are now seen as rather thoroughly picked over.
Among professionals, it's widely accepted today that investors of even modest sums should have some foreign exposure to avoid overreliance on America's business cycle and to exploit political or sociological change.
So where do portfolio managers think they will find the biggest rewards in the months ahead?
Japan remains a possibility, various managers say, but the investment outlook is not as bright as in the first half of the year, when basic industries and financial companies soared and the yen leaped against the dollar. The strong Japanese currency magnifies returns to foreign investors but also tends to hurt earnings of the country's exporters.
"Political problems, the strong yen, poor corporate results and a sluggish economy have combined to dampen our expectations for the Japanese equity market for the next few quarters," declared William F. (Chip) Wendler 2d, vice president of Rowe Price-Fleming International.
At the same time, the political turmoil seems likely to result after elections today in a new Tokyo Government, one that in the view of Fiona Biggs, who runs two international Dreyfus Corporation funds will sharply accelerate the shift in Japanese emphasis toward consumption and away from exports.
This implies, among other things, a shrinking trade surplus and a dollar that will rise sharply against the yen. Investors in Japan these days "definitely want to be hedged," Ms. Biggs said, so stock market gains are not wiped out by losses in the currency market.
Another cautious assessment came from John R. Hickling, who runs two Fidelity international mutual funds He said he remained "very optimistic" about Japan over the long term but said earnings disappointments over the next few months would make it a risky period for stocks.
On the other hand, with "no sign of inflation anywhere in Japan," Mr. Hickling said, the bond market there looks "screamingly" attractive.
In Europe, where the lesser markets of Finland, Denmark and Italy have done best this year, followed by Switzerland, Norway and the Netherlands, portfolio managers see only moderate appeal.
Germany, the traditional dynamo, has slipped into a deep recession and its efforts to recover are hobbled by budget deficits related to reunification, analysts say.
Still, said Mr. Wendler of Rowe Price-Fleming International, Europe appears in many ways "similar to the picture in the United States some three years ago" with bond rates coming down, corporate profitability in doubt and economic and political uncertainty the dominant sentiment.
Now, in fact, may be the time to jump at certain opportunities.
"Italy is almost irresistible to a value investor -- everything is falling apart there," said Jarrod W. Wilcox, director of international investing for Boston-based Battery march Financial Management. Mr. Wilcox has a similar view of Britain, where recession might be over but political and economic pessimism remain.
Privatization is another opportunity, Mr. Hickling added, noting a political imperative for governments in, for example, France and Spain, to insure the successful sale of state-owned companies by offering them at bargain prices.
"This is a major international investment opportunity -- and I'm all over it," Mr. Hickling said.
Some people still see opportunity in Latin America, where funds are confined mainly to Mexico and Argentina, despite fresh threats to the North American Free Trade Agreement. And the booming Chinese economy may also provide more investment possibilities over the longer term, particularly if Beijing is chosen the site of the Olympic Games in 2000.
Ms. Biggs already has a favorite stock, Hong Kong-based S. Megga, that she calls "a tremendous China play" based on a joint venture with the Government for telephones and other electronic gear.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Currency Adjustments Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Karel van Wolferen makes two egregious errors in "Japan's Big Chance -- and Clinton's" (Op-Ed, July 6).
(1) He suggests that "previous yen-dollar adjustments never accomplished the desired correction in the trade imbalances." However, the currency changes of 1985-87 and attendant macroeconomic adjustments worked like a textbook in both countries: Japan's global current account surplus dropped from 4.3 percent of gross domestic product in 1986 to 1.2 percent in 1990, and America's global current account deficit dropped from 3.7 percent of G.D.P. in 1987 to less than 1 percent in 1991 (even excluding foreign contributions to our Persian Gulf war expenditures). 
 (2) He suggests that eliminating the bilateral United States-Japan trade balance should be an objective of United States policy. There is no rational basis for targeting bilateral balances in general. In this case, the pattern of world trade clearly indicates that the United States could easily run a global current account surplus despite continuing sizable bilateral deficits with Japan.
Likewise, Japan would retain a large surplus with the United States even if it met the Administration's goal of reducing its global surplus to 1 percent to 2 percent of G.D.P. -- mainly because it imports many primary products from Saudi Arabia, Australia and the like, and so must export manufactured goods to the United States and other high-income countries.
 
C. FRED BERGSTEN
Director, Inst. for Intl. Economics
Washington, July 12, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: RUNNING WILD;
The Mississippi Reclaims Its True Domain

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
NO one alive has seen the Father of Rivers yawn this high or this wide. No one imagined the Mississippi or its relatives would take such liberties, consuming so many hamlets whole, or that, if they did, technology would be nearly helpless to stop them.
There have been floods before. People in Hannibal, Mo., or Keokuk, Iowa, or Quincy, Ill., can tell you about watching their fathers and uncles pack sandbags to protect the year's corn crop or the feed store. For generations, some farmers figured floods and droughts into the cost of doing business. But then the country's big plumbing system of levees and dams, made better after every flood, was supposed to keep the rivers in their place and maintain the comfortable paradox of living on a floodplain. 
 Now the unimaginable has happened. Across the Midwestern cornbelt it has rained in biblical proportions -- 49 straight days, often in torrents. The rivers, driven past their banks, have taken back land that long ago was theirs, invading 15 million acres of farmland in eight states, forcing 36,000 people from their homes, halting river traffic for 600 miles and causing billions of dollars in damage.
From the air, from Minnesota to Missouri, from Kansas to Illinois, it looks like someone has spilled gallons and gallons of coffee on a green patchwork quilt that happens to be farms and towns. In silt rivers now wide as lakes, treetops look like bushes in a swimming pool, bridges and highways and other brave monuments to engineering are reduced to thin, threatened slivers, and even their builders know the water could take them, too, if it wanted. The floods have made the broad, S-curved Mississippi and its otherwise perfectly ordered valley look more like the Florida Keys.
Unlike earthquakes and hurricanes, floods defy the human urge to quantify. There is no single measure -- no Richter scale, or mile-per-hour wind as in the eye of a hurricane -- to gauge a flood. There are only the hundreds of crests and toppled levees on the rivers and their swollen creeks, and the thousand heartbreaks of lost soybean fields and moated Main Streets.
If the floods of 1993 have reminded people of anything, it is that the Mississippi River was never the docile pensioner some had come to think it was. It is not, after all, the Swanee. The Mississippi is America's watery aorta, draining or potentially flooding rivers in 31 states from the Appalachians to the Rocky Mountains.
"It's like talking about God Almighty himself," said Shelby Foote, the Memphis writer, who has lived his whole life on the river.
The river, ecologists and farmers say, was never supposed to follow the tight course humans have expected it to, indeed ordered it to, with their walls of dirt and concrete levees. Of course, that has not stopped people from building homes and farms and cities along the river. The Mississippi Valley's thick black soil is considered the richest on earth, impossible for farmers to resist.
But to claim the land meant making a bargain with the river, confining it to an artificially narrow path so that farms could reach as far as the shore and places like New Orleans and St. Louis could live undisturbed while their goods were carried safely from port to port. The price that river people pay is sudden and catastrophic flooding when excess rainwater, forced into a narrow channel by the levees, runs out of places to go and cannot drain naturally into the soil.
Then the river goes faster and faster, and it goes where it wishes, as it did during the flooding of the lower Mississippi in 1927, where, as William Faulkner wrote, the river "was now doing what it liked to do, had waited patiently the 10 years in order to do, as a mule will work for you 10 years for the privilege of kicking you once."
Mr. Foote was a boy during that flood. He remembers when word came that the levee had broken at Mounds Landing in Scott, Miss., north of Greenville. "It was a slow creeping rise," he said. "You can't even see it rise but if you turn away and then you look back, you see it is a little higher. Everything in its path is submerged or invaded. It presses against every crack and crevice. It's like solid wind when it comes."
Because of its might and willfulness, some ecologists argue that the very way people define a river is not particularly useful. They say that the river is not just whatever water you see in the channel, but the banks, the floodplain, in fact, the valley itself, from bluff to bluff. It is anywhere the water has been and could potentially go -- a river, Mark Twain said, "whose alluvial banks cave and change constantly, whose snags are always hunting up new quarters, whose sand bars are never at rest."
In earlier centuries, when towns in the bottomlands were invaded by river water, townspeople packed up and moved to higher ground -- as Franklin, Mo., for example, on the Missouri River, did in 1826. (Even that move could not save Franklin this time, however; the town is under water again.) Now, more than 7 million people live directly along the Mississippi, including more than 2 million around its confluence with the Missouri in St. Louis, where the two rivers are now cresting and levees straining and crumbling.
"No one is going to move St. Louis just because it happens to be in the river," said David Johnson, an aquatic ecologist who is assistant director of the School of Natural Resources at Ohio State University. "It's a question of working with the river or fighting the river. Fighting the river is almost always going to be a losing battle."
He argues for restoring the kind of wide open spaces that the river once had before Europeans and the great cities came, wetlands where the water could collect in times of severe rains. The Army Corps of Engineers reservoirs to catch the run-off, although the current flooding suggests they may not be enough. In defense of the complex and normally efficient flood control system, hydraulic engineers say that without the man-made reservoirs, the bloated river would now stretch from bluff to bluff, five miles across in spots, covering what we now know as Dubuque, Iowa, or St. Louis.
 
Return of the Marshes
 "People think of the river as their enemy," said David Lanegran, a professor of geography and urban studies at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn. "They fight the river, dike the river, pollute the river, ignore the river. Now the river is taking back its old places. You can see the old marshes coming back in the farmers' fields, all the places where the duck ponds used to be. It's almost like a ghost. The water is saying, 'This is where I used to be. This used to be my place.' "
That may be cold comfort to people whose homes and businesses are under the water. But there are some important differences between this disaster and others.
Things have changed since the days of Mark Twain, when armed guards patrolled levees to insure no one tampered with them or when, according to his stories, just about the only time a crowd would gather on the river was for a dogfight or a lynching. The flood has been remarkable for the show of volunteerism and general goodwill; there have been few reports of looting, and many of people driving for miles to work through the night sandbagging someone else's levee. It is a contrast to the country's biggest disaster of last year, Hurricane Andrew, which brought looters, and merchants jacking up the price of generators and people posing as carpenters and bilking roofless homeowners.
In Des Moines, where flooding of the Raccoon River knocked out the fresh water supply of 250,000 people, leaving residents without water to drink or take showers or fight fires or flush toilets with, people have shared well water, grocery stores have discounted bottled water and every other morning three senior citizens drive to a nursing home for the handicapped, where they deliver fresh water and personally flush all 126 toilets.
Midwesterners do these kinds of things, people here say, because even most city people originally came from small, rural towns where everybody knows everybody and it is an insult to take advantage. "These are standard, practical and utilitarian Midwestern values," said Douglas Hurt, director of the graduate program in agricultural and rural studies at the Iowa State University. "If your neighbor needs help, regardless of the spats you've had, you help him."
If there is an economic beneficiary of this flood, it is the farm states of the eastern Midwest -- Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, where farmers will get to take advantage of the run-up in crop prices due to the low supply.
"That will make the flood even more painful for farmers in the floodplains," said William Heffernan, a professor and chairman of rural sociology at the University of Missouri in Columbia. "They will be watching the highest prices in years and, they don't have anything to sell."
 
Lifting and Cleansing
 As disastrous as a flood is to those in its path, it is nonetheless part of a natural cycle of renewal just as forest fires are. The river channels grow so wide and the currents so strong they lift topsoil, carry nutrients downstream and deposit them in new soil. Iowa's loss may be Missouri's gain, but then Iowa may get its own refill from Minnesota. The heavy rains that precede the flooding can also cleanse the river waters and make a better pool for fish to spawn.
The current crisis will undoubtedly set off wide debate over ways to improve the system with an eye not to just one city or river but to the 250 or so creeks and rivers that feed into the Mississippi.
Only fairly recently in the river's history, when Congress authorized a Federal levee project after the 1927 flood, has there been any system-wide approach to flood control. But that was based in part on bringing up to code the haphazard levees of assorted farm towns who in times of desperation built wherever they felt like it. New and better levees have gone up, but they, too, can fail.
"People expect more out of what was there than was ever intended," said Harry Kitch, chief of the central planning management branch of the Army Corps of Engineers. "Any one of our structures can be overtopped if you have a big enough flood. We do a great deal of sophisticated work in rebuilding them, but there can always be a bigger flood."
The great lesson of the floods may be that humans will have to do a lot more if they are to outwit nature, if that is even possible.
"I think we as moderns tend to think that geological and meteorological changes have stopped," said said Bruce Michaelson, a professor of English at the University of Illinois at Urbana, who is writing a book about Mark Twain, "that volcanoes will no longer erupt, that hurricanes will no longer come off the coasts and the great rivers of the world are going to stay quietly in their banks so we can cruise them in our boats and barges."
But just as the river that Mark Twain romanced and revered carried the pieces of wrecked houses and trees from floods upstream, so it does a century later -- "the debris," Professor Michaelson said, "of battlefields between water and man."

HEADLINE: In Korea, Chilling Reminders of Cold War

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE are few areas in the world where the tug of war between ideological opposites is being played out these days as starkly as it is on the Korean Peninsula. There, the more familiar fare of Asian-American diplomacy -- trade wars and economic disputes -- has been suddenly overshadowed by the deadly serious business of tussling over who produces a nuclear weapon.
President Clinton, ending an economic summit conference in Japan, joined that tug of war with some trepidation last weekend, trying to decipher the erratic diplomatic signals that were being sent by President Kim Young Sam of South Korea as well as the message of foreboding he had just received in Tokyo from the Japanese Government over North Korea's threat to continue developing nuclear weapons technology. 
 Mr. Clinton and the South Koreans settled for tough talk, with the President warning North Korea that nuclear aggression on its part would bring calamitous results.
"When you examine the nature of the American security commitment to Korea, to Japan, to this region," Mr. Clinton said, "it is pointless for them to try to develop nuclear weapons, because if they ever use them it would be the end of their country."
The grim imagery of those words sounded unusually bellicose, but it did not mean a departure from a course already firmly set in American policy -- keeping the North Koreans from creating nuclear weapons. The Clinton Administration's approach to security concerns in Asia is part reaction to the worsening situation, and part holdover from previous Administrations, when Japan was first recruited to play a role in shaping an accord between the Communist north and the democratic south.
In March, the North Korean Government announced it would withdraw from the 25-year-old nuclear non-proliferation agreement that bars nations from acquiring nuclear weaponry. Its surprise announcement sparked already smoldering suspicions around the globe that Pyongyang was manufacturing enough plutonium to make at least one bomb.
But the North Koreans suspended their threat shortly afterward and agreed to discuss with American negotiators in Geneva the conditions under which they would permit full inspections of the military plant that might house the plutonium.
 
High-Stakes Chicken

 
 At a joint news conference in Seoul, Mr. Kim appeared beside Mr. Clinton to warn that "appropriate countermeasures" would be employed if North Korea were to make the wrong move. He declined to say what those measures might be, but his remarks surprised American officials.
During the past several weeks, White House officials have been puzzled by the South Korean Government, which initially appeared satisfied with the methodical approach the United States had chosen in trying to resolve the stand-off over North Korea's decision to withdraw from the 25-year-old Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty. In recent press reports, American officials noted, South Korean leaders had begun suggesting that the Geneva talks, which began on Wednesday, were a stalling tactic for the North Koreans.
The Clinton Administration has looked for other reassurances by suggesting that China, which recently reestablished trade links with South Korea, might encourage the North to comply.
"I think the Chinese Government is very interested in supporting the position we have taken here," Mr. Clinton said, pitching his comments to Beijing. "And we will certainly ask for their support."
Last week, a spokesman for the South Korean Embassy here said no surprise was intended and that his country and the United States are in synch.
"We keep getting thrown curve balls," said a senior Administration official, who asked not to be identified. "It is not unknown for some of these curve balls to come from our allies."
In addition, Japanese officials have suggested they would wait to determine North Korea's ultimate intentions before agreeing to an indefinite commitment to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty, which expires in 1995.
If the Geneva talks do not yield an agreement, Secretary of State Warren Christopher has said the United States will ask the United Nations to impose economic sanctions against North Korea.
American officials seemed acutely aware of the limits of their negotiations. Despite Mr. Clinton's warning, this country and its allies have ruled out military retaliation. Since so much of North Korea's nuclear complex is underground, a military strike has a fairly remote chance of succeeding.
 
Walking a Tightrope

 
 "North Korea bears constant and careful watching," Mr. Christopher said in an interview with reporters during the conference in Tokyo. "As far as talking with the allies, yes, I think we've begun to explore the possibility of the kind of sanctions that we might impose against North Korea."
Because using economic sanctions is problematical, American officials have a lot riding on the outcome of the Geneva talks. If North Korea has amassed enough plutonium for one or two bombs, such gradual punishment would be ineffective.
North Korea, however, is not in a much better position to hold out against pressure from their Asian neighbors and their Western allies. They extended the Geneva talks on Friday and both sides hinted they may have an agreement by tomorrow.
"We've never been pessimistic," Kang Sok-ju, the First Vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs for North Korea told reporters in Geneva.
In discussing the future of the negotiations, American officials send out calm and measured reassurances to their allies. If the talks were to break down, the senior official said, the United States' appeal to the United Nations for retaliatory action would be "very fact specific."
"It depends on how the North strays from the path we have tried to chart out for them," he said. "My hope is if they keep on moving toward the right solution, if the pace quickens or slows a little bit, we can handle that. If there's some radical departure, that makes the tightrope a little harder to stay upright on."
