HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Who Armed Iraq? Answers the West Didn't Want to Hear

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE terms of the punishment forced on Iraq since the Persian Gulf War may be most valuable for what they have taught. Rarely has a country defeated in battle been so laid bare to outside scrutiny. To the victors, the answer to how Iraq gained its power is now dispiritingly clear: it was us -- the West, and German companies in particular.
That conclusion is documented in stark detail in a new study by the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control. Based in part on the work of United Nations inspectors, it identifies the Western companies who supplied the crucial parts in what was emerging as an extraordinary Iraqi arsenal. German firms were by far the worst offenders, but others in Switzerland, Britain, France, Italy and the United States were also instrumental. Without Western help, the report's author, Gary Milhollin, shows, Iraq could never have come so close to producing nuclear weapons and long-range missiles. 
 The pattern is in some ways familiar. Countries aspiring to power have long turned to foreign merchants for muskets and machine guns. What has changed has to do with what has changed about war. Rather than in vast shipments, even the smallest of acquisitions may prove decisive in an era in which nuclear, biological and chemical weapons can hold populations hostage. And the goods sought for military value may just as well be produced by a supercomputer manufacturer or biotechnology company as by a munitions maker.
A Western bolt found in an Iraqi missile is not necessarily a sign of complicity. A bolt has many peaceful uses, too. But the picture provided by the Wisconsin Project suggests just how instrumental such dual-use trade can be. Italian technology allowed Iraq to extract plutonium, and high-performance Swiss presses gave it the ability to make nuclear weapons parts. Most of what Iraq needed to extend the range of its Scud missiles came from Germany. American computers were used in virtually all Iraqi missile and nuclear sites.
Of course, Iraq's most crucial acquisitions had even clearer military purposes. The Soviet Union openly sold Baghdad hundreds of Scud missiles; Brazil helped secretly in an effort to build an atomic bomb. But it was the wider Western flood, aided by lax laws and porous borders, that helped Iraq to refine those tools, outfit secret factories, and thereby to reach the verge of even more destructive force.
 
'Dairy Plant' Parts
 Just one example of that flow was first found in crates marked as dairy plant parts bound from Frankfurt for Baghdad. In fact the intercepted metal parts were a supplement to the 27,436 Scud missile parts worth $28.2 million that the German company, H & H Metalform, had already delivered to Iraq. A separate compression device was to have helped Iraq test a new intermediate-range missile. There was little mystery to its purpose, German intelligence found: the company had sold the same kind of rocket-testing device to Brazil.
With the most dangerous of the projects dismantled, the tension between Iraq and the West is mostly about the future. In refusing again last week to permit U.N. inspectors to install cameras at a missile-test site, Iraq made clear its aversion to the next step of U.N. oversight, which under Security Council Resolution 715 calls upon the West to keep long-term watch as Iraq begins to build new weapons.
An apparent agreement on a separate U.N. plan calling for Iraq to sell oil to meet humanitarian needs suggested that Baghdad might still be open to a last-minute compromise. But even a fence-mending visit by Rolf Ekeus, the chief U.N. weapons inspector, left unclear by Friday whether Iraq would back down or brave a Western threat of a retaliatory strike.
The new U.N. focus on monitoring -- with its fixation on products -- nevertheless carries a danger of being too narrow. There are signs that Western equipment remains a key ingredient in secret weapons programs, not only in Iraq but elsewhere.
A report to Congress last month concluded that illegal shipments by Western companies had helped Iraq repair or rebuild nearly all of the military production capacity it lost during the war. American intelligence reports have similarly warned of newly aggressive efforts by Iran to acquire the technology needed to produce chemical and biological weapons.
Iran has also ranged further afield, pressing both Russia and China for nuclear reactors that could halve the time needed to produce a nuclear weapon. North Korea has devoted its recent shopping to expertise, coming within minutes last fall of luring a contingent of Russian nuclear scientists to Pyongyang. Libya has tried to buy rocket fuel from a Russian concern. India and Pakistan have been similarly energetic.
In the American-led efforts to curb such commerce, the recriminations of the gulf war still echo. Under pressure from Washington, Germany in particular has taken steps to tighten its once-flaccid export controls. Britain has begun an inquiry to review what led its companies to assist in the Iraqi buildup, including the manufacture by Sheffield Forge-masters of 52 six-meter-long barrels for Iraq's never-completed supergun. With the Iraqi lesson as a model, Congress last fall voted to subject Iran to export restrictions as rigid as those that are in effect on Baghdad.
Not even Iran has proven anywhere near as brazen as Iraq, however, making its quest harder to detect -- and easier to minimize.
In the absence of a recognizable villain like Saddam Hussein, a private company can find the temptation of big business abroad difficult to resist. "One major foreign order is enough incentive for some of these firms to turn a blind eye to the law," said Anthony Cordesman, a Middle East expert who has advocated even more rigid restrictions.
That problem is compounded when governments send mixed messages, as a lawyer for an Atlanta banker argued last week. The client, the local representative of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, is accused of granting nearly $5 billion in unauthorized loans to finance Iraq's military buildup, and former President Bush was served with a subpoena after the lawyer said his testimony was needed to demonstrate that the client was just carrying out unstated United States policy.
Even the Clinton Administration, having vowed to subject Iran and Iraq to a new "dual containment," has yet to reject an appeal by Boeing and General Electric for special permission to sell $750 million worth of commercial aircraft and engines to Iran. Boeing has warned that a White House refusal to approve the sale would effectively surrender thousands of jobs to Europe's Airbus Industries.
 
Vague Pledges and New Pleadings
 Still more powerful pressures affect Germany and Japan, who rely far more heavily on the Iranian market. So it was no surprise that President Clinton was able to win little more than a vague pledge from other leaders at the economic summit in Tokyo to hold Iran and other rogue countries accountable for their actions. As Mr. Milhollin warns, "Most of the companies that sold to Iraq are still in business, and are still looking for sales in the Middle East."
And for governments increasingly preoccupied with job creation, it may be difficult to reject new pleadings from those who insist that their chemical or computer can do no harm.
Any sale looks less sinister when considered individually; but the lesson of Iraq might counter such complacency. As chronicled now, it shows millions of dollars in British and German machine tools used to make centrifuges; sleek new Swiss presses designed to forge nuclear weapons parts; Mercedes-Benz tractors and flat-bed trailers fitted as mobile missile launching pads. Its message is that economic security, for all its importance, remains a subset of something more fundamental.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Ph.D.'s Are Here, But the Lab Isn't Hiring

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SCIENCE professors breed science professors. More or less like mice. Throughout a career of teaching and research, one Ph.D. can produce about 15 new Ph.D.'s to teach and carry on research. If the 15 stay in teaching, and most try to, they can produce 225 more.
Countering the conventional wisdom's often predicted shortage, Dr. David L. Goodstein, a physicist and vice provost of the California Institute of Technology, says the nation faces "a chronic, systemic oversupply of Ph.D.'s, a rising tide of Ph.D.'s that we seem helpless to stem." 
 Dr. Goodstein, who has written of his concerns in The American Scholar magazine, grants that long before his progeny overrun the universe, salaries will tumble, jobs will disappear and they will have to look for other work. Those phenomena seem to have dawned.
The scientific community has yet to suffer unemployment of the magnitudes of airline attendants and steel workers. But this elite, cerebral cadre of the American work force, one for which unemployment rarely happened, has awakened to a new economy.
Statistics illustrate the toll. From 1989 through 1992, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says, the recession drove general unemployment from 5.3 percent of the labor force to 7.4 percent, an increase of two-fifths. Among natural scientists like chemists, physicists and biologists, unemployment was low -- 2.3 percent last year.
The 2.3 percent figure obscures tensions or changes among individual disciplines; demands for environmentalists, who are also in the category, are strong and likely to get stronger. Even so, that rate represents a two-thirds increase in the numbers of unemployed natural scientists over the three years, from 15,000 to 25,000.
Overall unemployment among engineers jumped even more -- 159 percent, or from 27,000 to 70,000 and to a jobless rate of 3.8 percent. Chemical engineers were hit hardest.
The job drought is also affecting undergraduates looking for jobs in the sciences. Among the 402 colleges and universities monitored by the College Placement Council in Bethlehem, Pa., offers to graduating seniors remain well below their pre-recession peaks, as have those from industries that hire the most science and engineering majors.
The council declines to disclose numbers of offers, but says those from the aerospace industry have plunged from 7.4 percent of the offers students received five years ago to 1.4 percent in 1993. Offers by oil companies fell from 9.4 percent to 2.1 percent and by drug companies from 5.2 percent to 3.9 percent.
At Princeton, David Redman, acting dean of the graduate school, said 13 percent of this university's 250 new Ph.D.'s this year were unemployed as of early July, compared with 5 percent a year earlier. Of the new scientists who find university jobs, Dr. Redman said 15 or 20 percent settle for limbo-like post-doctoral fellowships that come without health benefits or the prospect of tenure and that terminate in two to six years.
A reason for the scarcity of jobs in science and engineering is the same that effects everyone: an economy that has been slow to restore jobs that were lost in the recession. But science and engineering, like many industries, has also been struck by something else. The scientific establishment -- aerospace and defense companies and big research universities -- which provided jobs to new graduates is shrinking and appears unlikely to revive anytime soon.
Across the establishment, in the laboratories of Government, industry and some universities, hiring has stalled. In the new tight-fisted corporate economy, industrial companies like A.T.& T., I.B.M. and Westinghouse have shut or shrunk laboratories that once recruited legions of researchers.
Geopolitics is also a major factor. Peace with the Russians has choked off Federal support of weapons research. And Washington's determination to reduce the budget deficit has forced cuts in space and most nonmilitary research.
Now Congress seems prepared to kill Big Science's crown jewel, the $11 billion atom smasher in Texas, known as the superconducting supercollider, on which construction has begun. If the Senate follows the House of Representatives vote in June to stop the work, Jerome Friedman, a physicist, Nobel laureate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and one of the supercollider's planners, says 2,000 scientists will have to find something else to do -- a significant number in the elite world of physics. (Although many scientists note that the supercollider has incurred big cost overruns that helped do it in.)
Professors, of course, like Dr. Friedman say legislators ought to pause before they subject science to the same cost-cutting criteria they bring to building roads. Scientific research, says Leon Lederman, a physicist and Nobel laureate at the University of Illinois, should be as unconstrained as the pursuit of good art. "What's enough music?" he asks.
So in a time of tight budgets, science has been forced to face the same arduous scrutiny that many other important endeavors do, from health care to urban education. Even Dr. Lederman says more scientists could take jobs bringing science to secondary schools.
The culture and wage scales of science discourage secondary school teaching careers, however. Salaries are often less than half the $100,000 that many established doctors of science earn in the top universities. And the culture confers little status on the scientist who abandons the university or Government lab. "You are successful if you end up as a clone of your faculty Ph.D.," said Alan Fechter of the National Research Council.
So now there are more and more scientists competing for fewer and fewer research dollars. Despite the economy's current austerity, universities still pursue such research. As these trends continue, Dr. Goodstein says, the leading universities will crowd out the less elite, forcing them out of the research business.
So far, most university labs have survived, but not because American students are still flocking to them. Instead, graduate and undergraduate science majors are choosing careers as management consultants and Wall Street analysts. But the positions at the university labs have been filled by more and more foreign students -- some of whom pay and some of whom benefit from Federal grants and subsidies to the universities.
That raises another question. Dr. Goodstein writes in The American Scholar: "Congress and the public don't seem yet to have noticed that, while largely ignoring our own students, we are putting our money and our best talent into training our economic competitors."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS TO STATION OFFICIALS IN HANOI

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17

 BODY:
The United States will station diplomats in Vietnam for the first time since the Vietnam war under a plan disclosed today by senior American and Vietnamese officials.
The three diplomats would help the growing number of American families who visit Vietnam seeking information about missing soldiers. There have been no United States diplomats stationed in Hanoi since the French colonial period, which ended in 1954; and United States diplomats left Saigon in the south in the closing days of the Vietnam War in 1975. 
 The arrival of the officials should not be misread as a sign that Washington is preparing for normal relations with Hanoi, said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
But diplomats and Vietnamese officials are sure to see it that way, since it will allow the State Department to have day-to-day contacts with the Vietnamese Government.
The plan, proposed by the United States, was announced today in Hanoi after two days of talks on broader cooperation in investigating the fate of the 2,253 Americans still listed as missing in action in Indochina.
The 22-member United States delegation, led by Mr. Lord, was dispatched by President Clinton earlier this month when he announced his decision to end Washington's opposition to loans to Vietnam by international development agencies.
Mr. Lord said in Hanoi today that he had been given a letter for President Clinton from President Le Duc Anh that promised continued cooperation on the M.I.A.'s. "I can tell you that it expresses great appreciation for the President's decision on the clearing up of Vietnam's debts," Mr. Lord said.
President Clinton has said that Vietnam would have to expand its assistance in resolving the fate of missing Americans if it wanted Washington to consider normalizing relations. He has kept a United States trade embargo imposed when Vietnam was unified under Communist rule in 1975.
At a news conference, Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai said Hanoi was already offering its full cooperation in the search for missing Americans. "But of course there will be more determination and more efforts, and that will lead to more results," he said.
The Defense Department already has a presence in Vietnam -- investigators who work with the Vietnamese to resolve the M.I.A. cases. American officials said that the presence of the diplomats would free the Pentagon teams to concentrate on the investigations.
Mr. Lord said his delegation, which included representatives of veterans' groups, had "laid considerable emphasis" on human rights issues. "We intend to pursue this matter, and the Vietnamese side was very open," he said.
 
The Vietnamese M.I.A.'s
 On Friday, the United States gave Vietnam microfiche copies of Communist documents seized during the war, to help Hanoi determine the fate of 300,000 missing Vietnamese.
Leaders of the veterans' groups said they were pleased with the promises of cooperation, but they warned that the cooperation must be complete.
"If the Vietnamese follow through on what they've pledged, I think there will be great cause for rejoicing," said David Givans, of the Disabled American Veterans. "If they don't, I think it will cause irreparable harm to this whole process."
The United States delegation arrived a week after a visit by Senator Bob Smith, a New Hampshire Republican, who spent four days in northern Vietnam investigating reports that some missing Americans may still be alive. Senator Smith said he believed that some prisoners may still be somewhere in Vietnam.

HEADLINE: Pennies From Hell: A Nation Is Saying, 'Keep the Change'

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
In trendy Georgetown, Rocklands barbecue restaurant programs its cash register to round off to $5.70 a check that would normally total $5.66.
More than 1,000 Winn-Dixie, Kroger and other supermarkets offer customers the option of raising their tab to the next dollar, with the extra pennies and other small change designated for charity. 
 And uncounted bars, restaurants and other retail establishments across the land are ignoring register exactitude, preferring to allow 1 to 4 cents a transaction -- occasionally more -- simply to go uncollected.
 
Opposition to Small Change
 Americans have become impatient with transactions involving small change, especially pennies. Increasingly, they seek by their behavior to eliminate the one-cent coin, so prominent in the popular imagination and idiom -- penny pincher, penny arcade, "a penny saved is a penny earned" -- from daily life.
"People are rounding up totals, including tax in the price, and doing all sorts of other things," said Clark Wolf, a Manhattan restaurant consultant. New Yorkers in particular, he added, "really hate pennies a lot."
That disaffection is no doubt encouraged by the fact that inflation has cut purchasing power by 77 percent since 1967, so even children no longer bother to pick up a stray penny from the street.
Indeed, the unpopularity of the penny -- since 1982 made almost entirely of zinc -- has grown considerably of late.
As recently as 1990, the General Accounting Office said that legislation to phase it out, along with the half-dollar, would be a bad idea. Not only are pennies profitable to the Government in that their value exceeds production and distribution costs, but the agency said it had found that people were in no hurry to give them up.
"Demand for the penny remains high and the public is skeptical about the effects, particularly on the poor, of rounding retail cash transactions to the nearest 5 cents," the 1990 report said.
 
Slumping Output at Mint
 But now, reflecting lower demand despite the proliferation of sales taxes to which the penny's survival has been tied, production is on the wane. After peaking at 16.7 billion in 1982, mintage slumped last year to 9.1 billion as society found ways to avoid counting or carrying -- much less saving -- pennies. Nickel production also fell last year, to just 58 percent of the record 1989 level.
Signs of penny-shunning include the ubiquitous cups or bowls placed by merchants near registers with little placards inviting customers to take what they need to ease transactions or to leave pennies deemed unworthy of pocket room.
Few, of course, object to being told to "never mind" the few cents they owe or even to a checkout clerk's polite inquiry about participating in Kroger's "Round Up for the Hungry" program.
 
Some Customers Indignant
 But what might be called surreptitious rounding, even though the customer may receive a receipt showing the overcharge, can arouse indignation when described to consumers and to those whose job it is to protect them.
"I don't see how they can let a cash register round up," said Constantine Cotsoradis, a program manager for the weights and measures section of the Maryland Department of Agriculture. "That's fraudulent."
Jack Gillis, a spokesman for the Consumer Federation of America, which has long campaigned against inaccuracy in supermarket scanners, said he had not yet heard complaints about rounding up. But the idea of not giving notice to the customer "absolutely blows my mind," he said.
When questioned, the owner, John Snedden, and others at Rocklands barbecue here said that their aim was merely to speed transactions by eliminating pennies and that the rounding, though not necessarily to the nearest nickel, lowered as well as raised prices and so did not increase profits. In fact, Mr. Snedden said, the computer program in the registers appears to be rounding down more than up, leaving a loss for the restaurant of $30 a month.
"We're not trying to put anything over on people," Mr. Snedden said, adding that he had begun to round off only after an attempt to eliminate pennies by adjusting pretax prices had failed.
 
Practice Could Spread
 Although the practice of rounding off still appears confined to a relative handful of establishments, the potential for widespread adoption is substantial. No Federal or state bodies are charged with the regulation of cash register accuracy except for registers connected to scales, like those used to weigh meat or produce.
Moreover, today's electronic registers are highly sophisticated, able to handle easily, for example, the three-for-a-dollar situation by charging 34 cents for the first item and 33 cents for the second and third, even when the items move across the checkout counter at different times.
"You can program these things to do almost anything you want," said Richard W. Hayman, president of Hayman Systems, an independent dealer in Laurel, Md. In general, new registers are programmed by dealers to customers' specifications, but most merchants are capable, with the aid of a manual, of reprogramming them when tax rates change or for other purposes.
Nor do there seem to be any specific laws governing rounding off. When asked what strictures apply, regulators cite general prohibitions against fraud and Handbook 44, a publication of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, part of the Commerce Department.
Handbook 44, to which the states subscribe, in practice, declares opaquely that "any recorded money value and any digital money-value indication on a computing-type weighing or measuring device used in retail trade shall be in mathematical agreement with its associated quantity representation or indication to the nearest 1 cent of money value."
According to Barry Wood, a document-testing analyst at Casio Inc., an equipment manufacturer in Europe has led the way in rounding off because of the adoption there of value-added taxes on goods and because of the rapid erosion in some currencies, like the Italian lira, a fraction of which is practically worthless. In some places, bits of candy substitute for trivial change.
The practice of rounding away a country's smallest unit is "called Scandinavian rounding," Mr. Wood said.
 
No Reason to Horde
 With pennies now consisting of just 2.4 percent copper, there seems no prospect for a repeat of the 1970's experience when soaring prices for the metal helped inspire hoarding. The resulting shortage of circulating pennies was so acute that some retailers offered to buy them in bulk for premiums of up to 5 percent. Zinc, worth roughly half as much as copper, is a poor candidate for profits from household stockpiling.
Indeed, assuming continued legislative indifference, rounding off to the nickel may be the means by which the public works its will and rids itself of a coin good for almost nothing except to pay sales taxes. But the penny's extinction, and the convenience it would bring, are unlikely to come at no cost.
"I do not have personal experience of anyone rounding down," observed Mr. Wolf, the restaurant consultant. "That's antithetical to commerce."

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 17

 BODY:
A woman whose photo was found in the bedroom of Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who the police say has confessed to killing 17 women, was found to be alive and well today after an extensive search, the state police said.
The police feared the worst when they found two pictures of her in Mr. Rifkin's East Meadow home. Detectives released photographs of the woman on Thursday and asked the public for help in identifying her. 
 The police have said that they found identification belonging to women said to be Mr. Rifkin's victims in his bedroom, along with lingerie, jewelry and other items.
Today the woman was found to be alive, said a state police spokesman, Lieut. Eugene Corcoran. At her request, her identity is being withheld, Lieutenant Corcoran said. The woman was "a past social acquaintance" of Mr. Rifkin's, the spokesman said.
On Friday, the police said that several people had told them that they knew the woman and that her first name was Kathy.
Mr. Rifkin, 34, is charged with the murder of one woman whose body was found in his truck in Nassau County on June 28. He has confessed to killing 17 women, mostly prostitutes, whom he said he strangled after having sex with them, according to the police.
He is said to have dumped their bodies in woods and rivers throughout New York State.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Yo, Florio, Yo, Whitman; Foes Trade Ring Cliches

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
It is unclear just which of the New Jersey gubernatorial candidates -- the Democratic incumbent, Jim Florio, or the Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman -- threw the first boxing metaphor. But six weeks into the general election race, the state's promised political fight of the century has shaped up as a lackluster affair with each side trying to pound the other purple with prose.
Polls show Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman even in the governor's race. Behind the verbal sparring that has dominated the campaign is an attempt by Mr. Florio to soften his opponent's standing by creating public doubt about her. Mrs. Whitman's strategy has been to fend off Mr. Florio and to stress the record $2.8 billion tax increase the Governor pushed through in 1990 and the state's limp economy. 
 But Mr. Florio, a former Navy light middleweight, has clearly been the aggressor.
Among the flurry of daily jabs at Mrs. Whitman from the Florio corner is the charge that she has dodged reporters in an attempt to avoid embarrassing public blunders.
Mrs. Whitman's camp delivered a crisp response.
"If reporters want to talk to Whitman, they can look at her schedule and they can find her," Carl Golden, her chief spokesman, was quoted as saying. "If reporters are too lazy to go find her, that's their problem."
Mr. Florio unleashed what was seen as his best punch last week, his defense of the state's gun law, the toughest in the nation, which has brought him nationwide attention and has the support of nearly 80 percent of the New Jersey public. The Governor invited reporters to a gun range last week where law-enforcement officers demonstrated an array of semiautomatic weapons that are banned under the state law.
The event was staged to keep alive the repercussions of what is seen as a political blunder Mrs. Whitman made earlier this month when she visited a Jersey City gun shop, Caso's Gun-a-Rama. She told patrons there that she would support a grandfather provision allowing owners of semiautomatic assault weapons to keep them if they had bought them before the ban took effect three years ago.
Mr. Florio also used the news conference again to accuse Mrs. Whitman of dodging reporters, the issues and him. "You can't be trying to rope-a-dope your way through an entire campaign," Mr. Florio said.
It was a bow in the direction of Muhammad Ali, who in a 1974 fight against George Foreman leaned against the ropes for the first few rounds while his opponent pummeled him nonstop and then came back to defeat the spent Mr. Foreman.
Mrs. Whitman again drew on boxing images for her response.
"Rather than staging events, the Governor might make himself available to discuss the underlying causes of crime -- joblessness, low quality of education, grinding poverty -- which he has ignored for the past three and one-half years," she said in a statement. "Come on, Governor. The bell has rung; get off your stool, come out of your corner, and defend yourself at all times."
 
Ibid., Op. Cit., Cf., Headache
 In a recent New Jersey Supreme Court ruling, Associate Justice Robert L. Clifford demonstrated he is as exacting in legal writing as he is in jurisprudence with a blistering commentary on the use of footnotes.
Justice Clifford joined the court in a unanimous ruling that said a lawyer or law partners may serve as municipal attorney and municipal prosecutor for the same town. But in a separate concurring opinion, Justice Clifford said he was troubled by one aspect of the majority opinion, noting that a major point in the ruling had been relegated to a footnote instead of being stated in the actual ruling.
Justice Clifford described it as a setback "in my woefully ineffectual campaign to abolish footnotes from our opinions."
Legal footnotes are intended to serve the same purpose as those in high school term papers: to cite a reference or to add support or evidence for a statement or a opinion.
But Justice Clifford made it clear in his opinion that he thought the use of footnotes was being abused in law.
"They distract," he wrote. "They cause the reader to drop the eyes; to absorb what is usually a monumental piece of irrelevancy or pseudo-scholarship but is sometimes -- as here -- a significant pronouncement that rightly belongs in the text; and then to return, without skipping a beat, to the point of departure on the upper part of the page."
Justice Clifford concluded: "The whole irritating process points up the soundness of John Barrymore's observation." Barrymore, he recalled, once said that reading footnotes was "like having to run downstairs to answer the doorbell during the first night of the honeymoon."

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Like Flood, Policy Shift Could Topple the Levees

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 17

 BODY:
Even as the Mississippi River continues to swamp cropland and force thousands of people from their homes, a debate is taking shape in Washington and the Midwest over whether to rebuild the levees that have washed away or to dismantle some and allow flood waters in the future to cover low-lying areas, effectively turning them into temporary reservoirs.
Two assessments by the Army Corps of Engineers, one completed almost a decade ago and one done this week for The New York Times, found that flood crests in Iowa, Illinois and Missouri would have been two to three feet lower had the river not been confined by hundreds of miles of levees on both sides of the Mississippi. 
 But the engineers who conducted the assessments also asserted that the volumes of water were so great in this flood that even with levees protecting only cities, the property damage would have been just as extensive.
"I just don't see the big effect that everybody thinks," said Gary Dyhouse, the chief of the hydrology section at the Army Corps of Engineers district office here and the author of one assessment. "The levees have been breached upstream. The flood plain is full of water from bluff to bluff, in some places three and four miles across, and we are still seeing a rising crest in St. Louis."
 
'Drag on the Economy'
 Other experts, though, have taken issue with that analysis of the levees' influence on flooding. Dr. Charles B. Belt Jr., an associate professor of geology at St. Louis University, studied the last great flood that occurred here in 1973, and concluded that the levees pushed the flood waters eight feet higher than they would have been if there had been no levees.
"The corps argues a foot is insignificant," Dr. Belt said in an interview here. "Two or three feet can mean the difference in how much property is damaged. It's a legitimate question whether the Government should put more money into this system of flood protection. Should the Government be subsidizing behavior that is getting more and more expensive? As a scientist, I'm not going to answer it. But as a taxpayer, I think it's a drag on the economy."
For weeks across this region where the Mississippi River has turned once-placid farm fields into huge and muddy lakes, the debate has been played out in real life. As pressure from conservation groups and others begins to mount in Washington for tearing down some levees, hundreds of residents in south St. Louis and farm families in Quincy, Ill., have been making their opinions known with shovels and sandbags as they work day and night to strengthen levees protecting their property.
At issue in the struggle both on the ground here and in Washington is how to control the Mississippi. The debate will involve economic and environmental factors that played no role 65 years ago when the United States first began to develop the dams, reservoirs and levees that transformed the Mississippi and its tributaries into restricted ribbons of water.
 
Some See Chance for Change
 Undoing parts of that mammoth plumbing system, proponents say, would enable the country to take advantage of the river's natural system for controlling floods at much less overall cost. Levees would not have to be rebuilt at a cost of $1 million a mile or more. And flood damage in the future would be reduced, they contend. Neither the states nor the Army Corps of Engineers yet know the extent of damage to the levees and the total cost of repairing them or removing some.
Most of the levee system between St. Louis and Rock Island, Ill., the region that sustained the most damage, is owned by farmers and other private interests. The Federal Government, though, pays 80 percent of the cost of repairing private levees that fail or are damaged, and the decision of whether to rebuild all or part of the levee system rests primarily with Congress and the Clinton Administration.
Though conservationists and wildlife officials in several states have urged the Government to refrain from rebuilding every levee and allow the energy of floods to dissipate over a wider expanse of land, such a departure in the Government's long-standing response to flooding would also subject farmers to more frequent damage to their land.
That possibility has left farmers and their families in the Upper Mississippi Valley not only battling flood waters but also looking ahead to a political fight none say they want. In Clarksville, Mo., 40 miles north of here, one farmer, Sarah Sterne, can look from her porch on a hill and see flood water covering every square inch for miles, including almost half of her family's 1,000-acre farm.
 
'Doesn't Make Much Sense'
 "Our family has been here farming for 50 years," she said. "We have had great benefit from these levees. It stands to reason that if you have crops planted you want to protect them. Families earn their livelihoods out there. Tearing them down or cutting holes in them? That just doesn't make much sense to me."
But that is precisely what some conservationists, independent engineers and state and Federal wildlife agencies are beginning to call for. These experts, who include staff members of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, contend that the disaster in the Upper Mississippi Valley was made worse by the Government's flood control structures. They argue that the levees hemmed in the river, causing more water to flow through a tighter space, thus causing flood levels to rise much higher than they would had the waters been allowed to take their natural course.
They are calling for levees to be moved farther from the river's edge or dismantled. "The challenge will be for the Congress to say to the Corps of Engineers, 'You must start using the flood plain as an ally in your flood control efforts,' " said Kevin J. Coyle, the president of American Rivers, a 20-year-old river conservation group in Washington. "They need two arrows in their quiver, engineering and nature. The nature part has been sadly missing."
 
Advocates in Federal Agency
 Mr. Coyle and other advocates of the new approach are urging the Federal Government and the states to restore wetlands, develop new riverside parks, establish wildlife refuges and take other measures to develop uninhabited regions in the flood plain to restore some of the Mississippi River Valley's natural capacity to absorb huge amounts of water and diminish catastrophic flooding.
"We don't want to see people moved out of their homes," said Richard C. Nelson, the supervisor of the Rock Island office of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which manages refuges along the Mississippi. "But it's worth looking at alternatives that will cost less to maintain and could be more effective in controlling floods."
While causing jitters among farm families and small-business owners across much of the Upper Mississippi Valley, such talk has also led the Army Corps of Engineers to question the validity of the data on which the calls for a new approach are based.
Mr. Dyhouse and his colleague, S. K. Nanda, the chief hydrologist at the engineers' district office in Rock Island, readily acknowledge that levees have raised flood levels. In addition, Mr. Dyhouse said that dams and reservoirs on tributaries had withheld enough water to compensate for the extra rise because of the levees.
Late this week, with data from a river gauge in Quincy, Ill., Mr. Nanda did a preliminary analysis of the effect of levees on the flood from Rock Island, Ill., south to Quincy.
Between the two Illinois cities are private levees that protect 360,000 acres of cropland on both sides of the river in Illinois, Iowa, and Missouri. As the flood crest moved downstream, the levees were breached or flooded over. Every time a new field was swamped, the gauge recorded a drop in the river's level, usually two or three feet, Mr. Nanda said. But with the river flowing at 500,000 cubic feet per second, the gauge came right back up hours later when the fields were full of water.
"What that says is that when the Mississippi is screaming past at these flows, the lands protected by the levees don't mean much," Mr. Nanda said. "They don't have enough storage volume to make a lasting difference."
Mr. Nanda added that he was prepared to take on critics of the corps about the value of levees. "These levee districts protect land that produces good for mankind," Mr. Nanda said. "They don't get flooded every year. Maybe once in 20 or 30 years. That has to be considered. Should we give up entirely all production on this land, making it nothing but swamps? In my thinking this is a resource to be used to produce food for all of us. Once in a while we'll take the loss."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Illinois National Guard lying exhausted after they worked to strengthen the levees in Quincy, all of which are now broken. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Action Taken in 216th Session of New York State Legislature

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 17

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature recessed its 216th session at 8:44 A.M. on July 8, 13 days after its scheduled closing. Despite toiling through the Fourth of July weekend, lawmakers left much work undone. They have to return to Albany for a special session later in the year to revamp the state's hospital payment regulations, which expire on Dec. 31, and may take up other unfinished business.
The session was notable for three weeks of paralysis caused by a deadlock between the Republican-controlled Senate and the majority-Democratic Assembly on the issue of rent regulation. The Democrats eventually agreed to relax rent-stabilization laws on apartments for the wealthiest tenants in exchange for a four-year extension of rent laws. 
 Another significant achievement of the session was passage of the Environmental Protection Act, which is intended to funnel $95 million a year eventually to land preservation and other environmental purposes. But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and many legislators say that the financing behind the bill is tenuous. The money may be diverted to balance the state budget if the economy does not improve.
The Assembly passed 1,131 of the 8,433 bills introduced in that house, while the Senate passed 1,252 of the 6,212 bills introduced. A total of 837 bills passed both houses. Of those, Mr. Cuomo has signed 265 bills and vetoed 13 by today. As usual, much of the Legislature's activity came on the last day of the six-month session. Of the 1,131 bills passed by the Assembly, 104 were approved on the last day.
Following are the major actions of the session.
 
 
The Budget
 As in 1992, the most significant accomplishment of the budget's enactment this year was its completion virtually on time, only five days after the April 1 start of the fiscal year. Still, the state budget has not actually been passed before the deadline for the last nine years.
The spending plan for the 1993-94 fiscal year, including all Federal money, totals $59.4 billion, an increase of 8.4 percent over the previous year. The general fund budget, which consists of most state tax and fee collections, is $31.5 billion, an increase of 1.6 percent.
The Legislature and Mr. Cuomo raised cigarette taxes by 17 cents a pack to 56 cents, one of the highest levels in the country. They increased state aid to schools by $330 million and, in the process, revised the school aid formula so that the proportion of assistance received by New York City increased slightly for the first time in years.
Budget negotiations began in January, when Mr. Cuomo projected that the state's budget shortfall would be $3.7 billion. But New York's fiscal picture improved in the next few months -- the state finished the 1992-93 fiscal year with a surplus of about $140 million -- and that reduced the shortfall to about $3 billion. The unexpected revenue allowed the state to forgo proposed cuts in Medicaid and drug education programs and to create a $100 million reserve fund. But the Legislature still adopted a Cuomo proposal to take $516 million from a dedicated transportation fund, using it to balance the budget.
 
Energy and Environment
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Establishes a commission to manage development in the Long Island Pine Barrens.
Allows the hunting of deer and bear on Sundays in nine central New York Counties.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would set aside $94.5 million from the real-estate transfer tax and other sources by 1996 for land preservation, landfill closings and recycling programs.
Would give state agencies new powers to reduce air pollution in the New York City metropolitan area by encouraging use of car pools and mass transit and by establishing stricter automobile emissions inspections.
Would legalize use of dogs to hunt bears when it can be shown bears have damaged property or pose a threat to public safety.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have established long-term policies for the storage of low-level radioactive waste from power plants, hospitals and research centers.
Would have created new restrictions on development along shorelines and in the backcountry of Adirondack Park.
Would have prevented clustering of landfills, incinerators and sewage plants in poor or minority communities.
Would have required packaging materials to be reusable, recyclable or made from 50 percent recycled materials.
Would have prevented the state from taxing or confiscating "pollution credits" accumulated by companies that reduce air pollution more than is required by law.
Would have prohibited the release of 25 or more helium-filled balloons at a time.
Would have required state agencies to buy appliances that meet minimum energy efficiency standards.
 
Health and Insurance
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Allowed a state bailout for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and thus reduced the size of a rate increase.
Extends for one year the state's system for providing medical malpractice coverage to doctors facing judgments over $1 million.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would require a set amount of money to be spent on community mental health programs for each bed closed in a state psychiatric hospital.
Would require health insurance policies to cover immunizations and well-child visits for children up to age 19.
Would prohibit doctors from referring patients to pharmacies where they have a financial interest.
Would allow emergency medical technicians to use cats to practice the insertion of breathing tubes.
Would prohibit medical suppliers from selling details of a customer's medical history to marketers without the customer's permission.
Would let terminally ill inmates in state prisons sign "do not resuscitate" contracts.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have revamped the state's hospital payment regulations and created incentives for more preventive and family medicine.
Would have banned smoking in schools and hospitals and required separate, enclosed smoking areas in workers' cafeterias.
Would have allowed family members and friends to end life support for patients who can no longer make health-care decisions.
Would have required certification and licensing standards for contractors who remove lead paint from buildings.
Would have imposed strict constraints on the removal of lead paint from bridges and other large municipal structures.
Would have required notifying mothers if their newborns test positive for H.I.V.
Would have required the notification of spouses and sex partners of persons infected with H.I.V.
Would have prohibited Medicaid financing of medically unnecessary abortions.
Would have prohibited blockades of access to abortion clinics.
Would have required health insurers to offer policies to all classes of customers, including individuals and small groups.
Would have provided for the election of the Insurance Superintendent.
Would have created a special review board to oversee the management of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
Would have required open hearings in physician disciplinary cases.
Would have required immunizations against hepatitis B before a child could attend school.
 
Crime and Justice
 LEGISLATION VETOED: Would have instituted the death penalty as a possible sentence for some murder convictions.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would stiffen penalties on motorists caught driving with suspended licenses and allow the authorities to bring felony charges against the most serious repeat offenders.
Would allow rape victims to have confidential conversations with counselors that could not be used in court proceedings.
Would allow under-age drinkers to be sentenced to up to 30 hours of community service.
Would authorize the courts to accept statements from a victim's relatives or other representatives if the victim is physically or mentally impaired, or if the victim is a child unable or unwilling to appear in court.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have extended civil rights protections to homosexuals in areas including employment and housing.
Would have banned the sale, possession or use of many semiautomatic assault weapons.
Would have permitted New York City Police and Housing Police officers to carry semiautomatic weapons.
Would have made a rape victim's manner of dress inadmissable as evidence in court proceedings and permitted the use of Mace-type protection devices.
Would have allowed police officers who are not witnesses to or victims of a crime to testify via remote, video hookup.
Would have created a new class of crime for offenses motivated by bias.
Would have established the crime of carjacking, in various degrees, with penalties of 7 to 25 years in prison.
Would have established a DNA database within the state police to store and compare DNA information for criminal investigations and proceedings.
Would have prohibited prosecutors from using a person's possession of condoms as evidence that they engaged in prostitution.
Would have removed criminal penalties for adultery.
Would have eliminated a person's occupation as an exemption to jury duty.
Would have banned the sale of pipes and rolling paper to anyone under 18 years of age.
Would have increased the responsibilities of colleges and universities to report campus crime statistics.
 
Labor and Business
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Prohibits the State Liquor Authority from granting liquor licenses to new establishments that are within 500 feet of three other licensed bars.
Prohibits the state from hiring any contractor to do hazardous work unless the contractor provides proof of workers' compensation and disability benefits coverage.
Prohibits the release of employee health records at clinics at the work site, unless that release is authorized by the employee.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would revise the operation of industrial development agencies to give local governments a greater role in monitoring their activities.
Would allow owners of billboards on state highways to request that the state cut down trees that obstruct the view of the signs from the road.
Would establish a program to offer loans up to $1.5 million to manufacturers that employ fewer than 500 people and to businesses in economic development zones.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have allowed large employers to contract with health maintenance organizations to treat their employees' work-related injuries.
Would have allowed municipalities to exempt themselves from the Wicks Law, which requires the hiring of separate contractors for separate parts of municipal construction projects.
Would have required contractors to pay "prevailing" wages -- union rates -- on private projects awarded public money.
Would have increased the taxes that employers pay for unemployment insurance as a way to bolster the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund.
Would have placed curbs on product liability lawsuits filed against manufacturers.
Would have curtailed shareholder derivative actions, in which investors sue a company's individual directors because they dislike the company's handling of an issue.
Would have created limited liability companies, hybrid entities that receive the tax treatment of a corporation but insulate the assets of partners from legal liability.
 
Government
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Allowed New York City to delay the hiring of this year's police class by two months.
Allows New York City to sell property-tax receivables to the highest bidder.
Extends a 1992 sales-tax increase in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the personal income-tax surcharge in New York City.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Appointed H. Carl McCall as State Comptroller to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of Edward V. Regan.
Authorizes a vote on a constitutional amendment to change the state's debt practices, including allowing more than one bond issue on a ballot and prohibiting "backdoor" borrowing.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have limited campaign contributions and spending.
Would have provided public money for campaign expenses through a checkoff on state income-tax forms.
Would have extended voter registration deadlines to 15 days before elections.
Would have created a not-for-profit corporation to broadcast state government activities to cable television systems.
Would have authorized a constitutional amendment to create a fifth judicial department comprising the New York City suburbs.
Would have required candidates for State Comptroller in a midterm election to disclose campaign contributions.
Would have authorized a constitutional amendment requiring a special election when the State Comptroller or Attorney General resigns in mid-term.
Would have extended freedom of information laws to the Legislature.
Would have made the position of Inspector General permanent.
Would have permitted the limited posting of campaign signs on lampposts.
 
Education
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Authorizes schools to provide child-care services for children of pupils and school employees during school hours.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would shorten the terms for New York State regents from seven years to five.
Would cap salaries for superintendents of Boards of Cooperative Educational Services school districts at 98 percent of what the State School Commissioner earns.
Would expand the school breakfast program to include all elementary schools and schools with many low-income students.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have allowed the New York City Schools Chancellor to set performance standards for custodians.
Would have replaced the New York City Board of Education with five borough school boards.
Would have given the New York mayor control over the central Board of Education.
Would have allowed local school boards to use Channel One, the current-affairs program for teen-agers produced by Whittle Communications.
Would have provided financial incentives to encourage school districts to consolidate.
 
Consumer Affairs
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Extends a ban on sales of irradiated food for two more years.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would allow people injured by silicone gel implants or Dalkon Shield intrauterine devices one year to sue after discovering the injury.
Would require the state to license companies that buy life-insurance benefits from terminally ill people.
Would provide protections against misuse of prepayments for funeral services by requiring the money to be deposited in bank accounts under the customers' names.
Would forbid video stores to release information about customers without their consent.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have required banks to provide low-cost checking accounts and to establish a fund for low-interest business loans.
Would have established safety standards for cigarette lighters.
Would have required installation of anti-scalding devices for sinks, showers and bathtubs in apartment buildings.
Would have regulated long-term leasing of cars to consumers by limiting excessive charges for wear and tear.
 
Welfare and Families
 LEGISLATION PASSED: Would allow the state to extend the Child Assistance Program for welfare mothers to New York City.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have allowed adopted children to know who their natural parents are.
Would have required fingerprinting and authorized criminal background searches of all prospective adoptive parents.
Would have allowed local social services departments to search nationwide criminal records of prospective foster parents.
Would have required the state to pay the local share of Medicaid costs.
 
Transportation
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Approved a $9.56 billion plan by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to buy new equipment and renovate bus and subway stations.
Requires towing agencies in New York City to accept credit cards for payment of fees, and requires the Parking Violations Bureau to accept credit cards for payment of parking fines.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would allow motorists in New York City to reclaim illegally parked cars after they have been hoisted by tow trucks but before they have been towed.
Would require state re-examination of bus drivers who have had three accidents in 18 months.
Would allow the creation of high-speed ferry service between Westchester and Rockland Counties and New York City.
Would require children under 14 to wear helmets while riding bicycles.
Would allow the state to suspend or revoke the driver's licenses of people convicted of drug-related crimes.
Would impose penalties on people who knowingly use or possess forged motor-vehicle insurance cards.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have increased penalties for people convicted of driving while intoxicated.
 
Housing
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Ends rent stabilization of apartments leased by the wealthiest tenants while extending regulations on other apartments for four years.
 
Agriculture
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Permits the donation of legally hunted game, like deer, to food pantries and soup kitchens.
Dictates that kosher meat byproducts be subject to the same labeling requirements as kosher meat.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would prohibit placement of solid waste management plants on land used in agricultural production or within an agricultural district.
LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have removed various restrictions on wineries in the state.
 
Miscellaneous
 LEGISLATION SIGNED: Provides a state loan to help finance a new hockey arena for the Buffalo Sabres and makes available grants to various minor-league baseball teams around the state.
Permits New York City to permanently install outdoor pay toilets that are accessible to handicapped persons.
Allows the state to conduct background checks of prospective employees at casinos on Indian reservations.
LEGISLATION PASSED: Would authorize New York City to lease additional space in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens to organizers of the United States Open tennis tournament.

LEGISLATION KILLED: Would have allowed the simulcasting of horse races from out-of-state tracks in conjunction with races conducted by the New York Racing Association.
Would have prohibited discrimination on the basis of sex, race or religion in some private clubs.
Would have required a certificate of authenticity for autographed sports collectibles sold for more than $25.
Would have removed the $500 cap on the amount dating services may charge customers.
Would have increased the fines and penalties for parking in spaces designated for the handicapped.
Would have permitted some free-speech activities in the common areas of large shopping malls.

HEADLINE: EGYPT EXECUTES 5 MORE MILITANTS

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, July 17

 BODY:
The Egyptian Government hanged five more Islamic militants today as part of a sweeping crackdown that both officials and Islamic leaders say has inflicted the worst damage on the fundamentalist movement since it began its campaign of violent attacks 18 months ago.
The executions bring to 14 the number of militants hanged by the Government in the last five weeks, the largest number put to death for terrorist offenses here. Seven other militants, still at large, have been condemned to death in absentia. 
 Under the Government's tough new counterinsurgency measures against Islamic militants, hundreds of other suspects have also been arrested in the last few weeks, and military courts have handed down swift, and often harsh sentences.
Egyptian intelligence officials say they have penetrated many cells of the movement, arrested several key figures and uncovered large numbers of arms and bomb making equipment.
 
Militants Lie Low
 "The Islamic Group has clearly been hurt," one Western diplomat said, referring to the main organization of Islamic militants. "The question is how much, and for how long. Many of the militants are lying low and trying to wait this out."
The Islamic Group has carried out a series of bomb attacks and assassinations of police officers, Coptic Christians, intellectuals, Government officials and foreign tourists here in the last 18 months. A total of 180 people have been killed in the attacks and Egypt's $2.2 billion tourism industry has been devastated.
With the aid of Pakistan, the Egyptian Government has shut down several of the offices that had been used by the militants in the border town of Peshawar and curbed the amount of money funneled to the movement from outside the country.
The number of attacks linked to the Islamic Group, which regards Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman as its spiritual leader, have also declined.
 
Government Is Cautious
 But Government officials, embarrassed by statements last year that they had wiped out the movement only to have the attacks resume, are being cautious in assessing their progress, saying only that they have inflicted heavy damage.
"It is still too early to say whether the movement has been broken," one Government official said.
The Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anomymity, said that for all the force the Government has employed, it has not addressed underlying issues like poverty, unemployment and limits on political expression that he said had "pushed many young men into this extremist movement."
Several followers of Sheik Abdel Rahman are now in detention in the United States facing charges in connection with the Feb. 26 bombing at the World Trade Center in New York and a plot to bomb other sites and carry out assassinations there.
An aide to the cleric was arrested late Friday in New Jersey and charged with conspiracy to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak. The President's spokesman in Cairo said he had no comment on the arrest.
 
Mubarak Runs Unopposed
 President Mubarak, who faces no opposition in his bid to be nominated by the Parliament on Wednesday for a third six-year term in office, had been hesitant to carry out executions until this year.
Many of his critics say his decision to allow courts to hand down 22 death sentences, and the wide police sweeps that have left hundreds of people in jail without being charged with any crimes, may be counterproductive in the long term, although they admit that the measures have momentarily crippled the underground movement.
"This is unlike anything President Mubarak has ever done," a former high-ranking Egyptian diplomat, Tahseen Basheer, said. "And it is risky. There may be no immediate boomerang, as many in the Islamic movement go deeper underground, but the Government must begin to confront the socio-economic difficulties that create this movement, or it will only return."
The five militants were hanged consecutively today beginning at 6:30 A.M over a two and a half hour period. Three were found guilty of trying to assassinate Information Minister Safwat Sherif by ambushing his car on April 20. The minister's bodyguard was seriously wounded, but Mr. Sherif sustained only a minor cut on his hand.
Two of the three men were also found guilty of planting a bomb in central Cairo that killed a police explosives expert who was trying to defuse the device. The remaining two men were convicted of placing a bomb under tourist buses outside the Egypt Museum on March 16 and tossing a homemade bomb at a bus.
In the Cairo slum of Imbaba, a militant cleric described the setbacks to the movement as he sat over a cup of tea in a shop with several assistants.
"The movement, and especially the Islamic Group, has had to disappear from public view for the moment," the cleric said. "All these arrests, the constant police sweeps and the information the police get from interrogations have taken a toll. But if the Government thinks this is anything more than a lull they are mistaken, and when the violence begins again it will be even more vicious and deadly."
Since December the Government has arrested 6,000 suspects, many of whom have yet to be charged, according to Montasser al-Zayyat, a lawyer for Sheik Abdel Rahman.
"They are using everything they have to try and break the Islamic movement," Mr. Zayyat said in a recent interview.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Egyptian officials say they have penetrated many cells of the Islamic militant movement and arrested several key figures. Relatives visited a defendant in a military court in Cairo during the trial of 32 Islamic militants charged with murder, armed robbery and trying to overthrow the Government. (Agence France Presse)

HEADLINE: Bulgaria Has a University In U.S. Style

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLAGOYEVGRAD, Bulgaria

 BODY:
Mike Orenduff, president of the University of Maine at Farmington, seems at home at what used to be the desk of the mighty regional first secretary of the Communist Party.
It is here, in the palace that the former dictatorship built for its top officials shortly before falling from power in 1989, that Mr. Orenduff is preparing for the arrival of a third class of students for the American University in Bulgaria. A lanky professor of philosophy, Mr. Orenduff is filling in as the university's interim president. 
 Though he has adjusted to his desk and office, Mr. Orenduff has moved out of the luxurious hunting lodge that formerly belonged to Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's leader for 35 years. The American said he felt intimidated by the building's size and splendor and the army of servants who hastened to fulfill wishes he had not even felt.
"It's not what American college presidents are used to," he said. He and his wife, Lai, an art historian, moved into a small two-bedroom apartment.
Despite his misgivings, Mr. Orenduff would have stayed in Mr. Zhivkov's former lodge if the University did not need the building as a dormitory.
 
Old High School Revived
 In a similar conversion of Communist premises, the American College, a private high school that operated in Sofia, the capital, from the 1860's until 1942, has recovered its campus from the Interior Ministry and resumed classes last year. The ministry had used the school to train its forces, including the dreaded secret police.
The American University's next freshman class will raise the number of students to 600.
Mr. Orenduff said the 600 were chosen from a large pool of applicants. To be admitted into the only American university in formerly Communist Europe -- the only institution of higher education here that charges fees -- students have to pass the standard Scholastic Aptitude Test and the Test of English as a Foreign Language.
All instruction is in English, and the faculty of 35 comprises 28 Americans, one Briton, one Canadian, 4 Bulgarians and one Pole.
The English-speaking ability of the students working at the university this summer is astonishing in view of the severe isolation of Bulgaria. Most are graduates of a network of high schools throughout the country that have begun teaching most subjects in English.
 
High Scores in S.A.T.
 The candidates' scores on the S.A.T., a college-entrance test taken throughout the United States, is equally startling, Mr. Orenduff said. Out of a possible score of 1,600, the average score of the first class, in 1991, was 1,106, compared with 896 in the United States.
"They're fantastic," said Janet E. Connolly, an associate professor and a sociologist from Temple University. "They're so well read. They express a civility toward us Americans that I don't see in America."
Professor Connolly, who is 64, took a year's leave from Temple in 1991 to be part of the founding faculty, and her husband resigned as Mayor of New Hope, Pa., to accompany her. Now, she said, she is not thinking of returning to Temple. "I would like to see the first class graduate," she said. Her husband has taught a course in business law.
Konstantin Stoev, a 21-year-old student who is a native of this town of 75,000 at the foot of the Rila Mountains 50 miles south of Sofia, said Bulgarian students applied "because we believe American-style education would have greater market value than Bulgarian."
He said diplomas from the university "will be valid throughout the world" because it is accredited through the University of Maine, which supervises its academic standards.
 
A Different Atmosphere
 Some students questioned said they felt that courses did not go deeply enough into subjects to prepare them for careers. Explanations that a wide-ranging education is the goal of many American universities are greeted skeptically by young people in a hurry to take advantage of Bulgaria's conversion to a free economy.
What impresses students most is the informality of the college atmosphere and the accessibility of professors. "They try to make contact with students," said Elena Taskova, 21, who works in the information office during the summer.
"In Bulgarian schools it's very hierarchic," Mr. Stoev said.
At first students were slow to adapt, Mr. Orenduff said. "They came from a system that didn't encourage innovation, asking questions and certainly not challenging authority," he said. "It was exasperating."
"They've taken to it with a vengeance," he continued. "Now they love it. I think we've created a monster. They challenge everything. They've become like American students."

HEADLINE: Vargas Llosa Disparages Peru, and Vice Versa

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
Ask Peruvians about Mario Vargas Llosa and more often than not the reaction is surprisingly bitter.
"He hasn't lived here for three years," said Luis San Martin, a cabdriver who used to run a steel fabricating business. "How does he know what we need, what we are going through? It's easy to talk from Spain or London. But he doesn't live with the reality of the country, people getting killed every day, misery and poverty." 
 The writer, who almost became Peru's President three years ago, is now among the country's most disliked figures.
President Alberto K. Fujimori, who edged out Mr. Vargas Llosa in June 1990, has more than 60 percent popular support in polls. Mr. Vargas Llosa's ratings hover around 10 percent.
In his latest book, "El Pez en el Agua, Memorias," or "The Fish in the Water, Memories," he tries to shake off feelings of betrayal by Peru and to unveil the perpetual dirtiness of politics there, but he only succeeded in fueling his countrymen's anger.
The book devotes 10 chapters to his youth, particularly his troubled relationship with an autocratic and brutal father, interspersed with 10 chapters about his political career, which ended when he left Lima in 1990 for Europe, promising never to re-enter politics.
What angers Peruvians most is that Mr. Vargas Llosa spares no one, including former supporters of his Libertad movement.
He describes as "cheap intellectuals" those leftists who denounced American expansionism, then sought lucrative positions at American universities. And he excoriates a number of former conservative allies who have supported President Fujimori since he seized near-dictatorial power on April 5, 1992.
Hernando de Soto, one of Peru's most noted political and economic thinkers, was described as "pompous and ridiculous" by Mr. Vargas Llosa.
Sitting in the comfortable Plaza Hotel here, in the middle of a book tour, Mr. Vargas Llosa said the attacks against him did not sting that much.
"There is nothing that they can say to me that they didn't say during the campaign," he said. "I had to be specific and use names, otherwise the book would have no real weight."
He says unequivocably that he is done with politics, was a bad politician -- being too honest with the public -- and will never run for office again.
"I am returning to the ranks of the intellectuals and from there I plan, as I have always done, to be critical and express opinions and engage in polemics," he said.
Perhaps the most explosive pronouncement was his call for the United States to impose the same economic sanctions on Peru as on Haiti, after Mr. Fujimori closed Congress and the courts.
Peruvians, beaten down by poverty, guerrilla violence and economic recession, took great offense, since in large measure they saw Mr. Fujimori's actions as the only way to combat terrorism.
"The attitude here is that Vargas Llosa looks upon Peru as a Haitian dictatorship, and according to the polls the people do not think that way," said Alfredo Torres, president of the Apoyo polling group. "He is seen as elitist, an aloof intellectual who is against the country. I don't think he could ever come back to Peru. He would be insulted in the streets."
Mr. Vargas Llosa, apparently recognizing that fact, talks almost as a man without a country. "I am a Peruvian by geographical accident," he said, adding that he felt the current outcry was an attempt by enemies in the military "to use me as a scapegoat."
He concedes there could be some connection between his bitterness toward his autocratic father and his harsh pronouncements on the troubles of his country and his preference for living outside its borders.
"One thing my father instilled in me was an intense desire for liberty, to be free and not bound by anything," he said. "They criticize me for not living in Peru, but I am going to live where I please, wherever I write best."
