HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Clinton Tours Floods and Considers Sending Troops

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARNOLD, Mo., July 17

 BODY:
President Clinton made a third trip to the Midwest flood area today, this time to confer with Vice President Al Gore, eight governors and members of Congress and the Cabinet about how to relieve the misery and clean up what is turning out to be one of the worst natural disasters in American history.
But even as he and the officials gathered in a high school cafeteria here just south of St. Louis, near the sodden, nearly overflowing levees of the Mississippi, the destruction continued upstream. A bridge linking Missouri and Illinois was closed near Quincy, Ill., and a Des Moines levee threatened to give way and flood a residential and industrial area. 
 Worse, more rain began to fall over much of the disaster area, described at one point in the conference as beginning to resemble one of the Great Lakes.
As he opened the daylong session, Mr. Clinton said, "We don't want people to think they have been abandoned when the immediate emergency is over."
 
More Federal Troops
 Then the President, who had earlier taken a quick helicopter tour of the flooding near St. Louis, said he was considering mobilizing Federal troops and additional National Guard units to relieve the exhausted guardsmen who have been struggling the better part of a month in the eight affected states -- Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wisconsin -- to shore up levees and evacuate victims.
He also said he might seek an increase in the $2.45 billion in disaster assistance he has requested from Congress. He has warned several times that the Federal Government cannot and should not pick up the tab for the entire loss. But he said today that he might seek more than $2.45 billion "to reflect new damage estimates."
By some assessments, the overall loss is now pushing close to $10 billion, including the destruction of 8,000 homes and businesses, the displacement of 30,000 people, and the inundation of hundreds of thousands of acres of some of the world's most productive farm land. Furthermore, 27 people have been killed.
 
New Flooding Near Quincy
 New flooding occurred today near West Quincy, Mo., where a levee burst last night, and near Quincy, Ill., where rising water closed the approaches to one of the few bridges in that area that was still open.
Most of the flood water spread across farmland and inundated evacuated houses. But the force of the break sent a river barge crashing through the opening and into a gas station, setting off a spectacular fire.
No injuries were reported.
In Des Moines, perhaps the hardest-hit city in the flood zone, a levee on the Des Moines River near downtown began to sag this morning, and it had to be quickly patched.
In the St. Louis area, the next major danger point in the flooding, the cresting Missouri River continued to breach small agricultural levees just to the west of where it joins the Mississippi north of the city. Some homes were flooded.
South of the city, not far from where President Clinton was holding his meeting at the school cafeteria, suburban residents were desperately adding sandbags to levees where water was already spilling over. Disaster officials ordered some homes evacuated.
The Mississippi is expected to crest at St. Louis on Sunday at 46.1 feet. It rose today in front of the Gateway Arch to a record 45.6 feet. That has brought on desperate sandbagging because many levees in the area can withstand a level of only 45 feet. The levees protecting the city's business district can take a crest of up to 52 feet.
 
'More Water Coming Down'
 Earlier, the National Weather Service predicted that the river would crest at 46 feet on Monday. But the break in the levee at Quincy drew off some of that water.
"That's the plus side of things, at least for St. Louis," said Greg Deyer, a National Weather Service forecaster stationed there. "The minus side is the rain that is still falling across the flood region, particularly in Iowa. That means more water coming down, eventually, though not necessarily at record crest. It also mean the water will stay high on the levees longer, which further weakens them."
In Mr. Clinton's helicopter tour of the region this morning, he got a firsthand look at the fight against the flood, shaking his head in wonder. He was accompanied by Senator Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader from Kansas, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, who is from South St. Louis.
"All of us," he said later at the school conference, "have been very moved by what we have seen, both the pain that people have experienced and their enormous courage and often their great good humor."
Vice President Al Gore followed Mr. Clinton on his tour in another helicopter. Later, speaking at the school cafeteria, he displayed satellite photographs of the entire Midwest disaster area. "It's as if another Great Lake has been added to the map of the United States," he said.
 
Workshop in Disaster Relief
 Among the seven Cabinet officers the President brought with him were those who oversee health, housing, agriculture, labor, transportation, commerce and the budget, and their presence -- along with scores of top Federal, state and local officials -- transformed the school lunch room into a crowded workshop on disaster relief.
A blue banner behind a podium proclaimed the event a "Flood Response Mobilization and Recovery," and each participant was issued a thick briefing book with a Presidential seal.
Mr. Clinton acted as moderator for the session, much as he had in Little Rock, Ark., last fall during a similar summit meeting on economic issues and again this spring in Oregon during a session on timber issues.
The President had warned earlier this week that the Federal Government could not be expected to reimburse many flood losses. He sought today to emphasize what would be done. "People who have worked hard all of their lives deserve a helping hand," he said in his weekly radio address. "With that helping hand, the people of the Midwest will get back on their feet."
But while his meeting with the governors was generally friendly, its tone sometimes reflected the strains felt by state leaders confronted with staggering losses and rigid Federal rules.
In response to a question from Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, Mr. Clinton said he would consider the idea of waiving a regulation that requires states to match Federal contributions for disaster relief.
While expressing concern for farmers, Mr. Clinton did not pledge to revise the rules for Federal payments that can sometimes limit reimbursements to 20 percent of the value of lost crops. He said that given budget problems, it would be "virtually impossible" for Congress to be more generous.
But in response to a question from Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, Mr. Clinton told the governors he wanted to make "absolutely clear" that the Administration would add to the $2.45 billion request for assistance "as more information comes in on the losses."
In addition to the President and Vice President, the top Administration officials who traveled to the Midwest for the meeting were Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy; Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena; Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown; Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros; Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich; Health and Human Services Secretary Donna E. Shalala; Leon E. Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Carol M. Browner, the adminstrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Apart from Governors Branstad and Edgar, the governors in attendance were E. Ben Nelson of Nebraska; Walter D. Miller of South Dakota; Arne H. Carlson of Minnesota; Mel Carnahan of Missouri; Edward T. Schafer of North Dakota, and Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin.
Mr. Clinton flew later this afternoon to Little Rock. He planned to return to Washington on Sunday.

HEADLINE: Made in the U.S.A.? -- Hard Labor on a Pacific Island/A special report.;
Saipan Sweatshops Are No American Dream

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAIPAN

 BODY:
On this tiny, tropical outpost of the United States, many people describe what happens to foreign workers here as something close to servitude.
Every year, thousands of laborers from China, the Philippines and elsewhere in Asia are flown here. The workers are often bused straight from the airport to squalid barracks where they live -- sometimes for years -- as many as a dozen to a room. 
 They are put to work almost immediately in nearby factories within view of Saipan's pristine beaches, many of them laboring six days a week at about half the Federal minimum wage, stitching together American brand-name clothes.
 
Familiar Labels
 The labels would be familiar to anyone who has strolled through an American shopping mall. Over the last year, Arrow, Liz Claiborne, The Gap, Montgomery Ward, Geoffrey Beene, Eddie Bauer and Levi's have all made clothes on this palm-fringed island that is part of the American commonwealth in the Western Pacific, 5,000 miles from the continental United States.
And while many of these garments are manufactured in foreign-owned factories by foreign workers, the apparel made in the Northern Marianas often bears another familiar label: "Made in the U.S.A." The American flag flies over several of the factories.
An estimated $279 million worth of wholesale clothing, virtually all of it made by foreign labor, was shipped from here last year to the United States.
 
Part of America at $2.15 an Hour
 "We come here because we make more money here than in China, and because the recruiters in China tell us that Saipan is part of America," said a $2.15-an-hour factory worker from a village near Shanghai.
The woman, who is in her early 20's, invited a visitor into the cramped barracks room that she shares with seven other women, their beds separated only by flimsy cloth sheets. The room also serves as a kitchen.
"They are not good conditions," she says, wrinkling her nose and pointing to a mildewy hallway strewn with litter. "If we complain, then our bosses would send us back to China and take away all of our money. Our families need the money."
 
The Sweatshops
No Comment From the Mall
 The biggest industries here -- garment manufacturing, tourism and construction -- are all dependent on poorly paid foreign labor, which explains why of the 42,000 people who live in the Northern Marianas, of which Saipan is the largest, more than half are foreign workers.
While clothing from the Northern Marianas made up only about 1 percent of the $29 billion in clothing imported into the United States last year, it accounts for as much as 20 percent of the clothing sold by some large American companies.
Several big manufacturers doing business here are silent when asked about labor practices or about the volume of clothing they import. Spokesmen for Arrow, The Gap and Montgomery Ward either did not return phone calls or said they had no comment on labor conditions in the islands.
A Claiborne spokeswoman acknowledged that the company did make "a small percentage" of its clothing in the Northern Marianas. A spokeswoman for Eddie Bauer said the factories here produced only "an insignificant percentage" of the company's goods. Neither company would discuss import figures.
 
Industry Battles Abuses
 The industry's trade group, the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, said its members were doing their best to end labor abuses in the islands.
"We oppose sweatshops wherever they are," said Larry Martin, the association's spokesman. "We believe and hope that our members are abiding by all labor laws."
One clothing manufacturer, Levi Strauss & Co., has been notably aggressive in trying to end labor abuses in Saipan. While it continues to make shirts at five plants on the island, it ended its contracts last year with the island's largest clothesmaker, Willie Tan, after an investigation by Levi's found evidence of "unsatisfactory treatment of workers and violation of the law" in his factories.
While insisting that his companies never abused or cheated workers, Mr. Tan, a Philippine-born American businessman, did agree last year to pay $9 million in back wages and damages to laborers, most of them Chinese, under a settlement with the United States Labor Department.
 
Legal Servitude
 The plight of foreign workers in the Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands has outraged the few Federal investigators who have made the long journey across the Pacific -- Saipan is far closer to China and the Philippines than it is to Hawaii -- even as they acknowledge that most of what goes on here is within the law. Visitors to the islands are also startled by what they see.
"It certainly has its parallels to slavery or indentured servitude," said Neils Jensen, a Christian missionary from New Zealand who has lived intermittently on Saipan since 1983. "Many of these workers go into debt for what they think will be the privilege of working on Saipan. Because they're so deeply in debt, they can't afford to retaliate or complain or leave. Their conditions are horrendous."
Over the years Washington has granted a variety of concessions to businesses in Saipan to encourage economic growth and to end generations of subsistence living for the local islanders. For decades, the largest employer had been the United States Trust Territory government.
Under an agreement approved in 1976, the islands were exempted from the Federal minimum wage. The commonwealth government now sets its own minimum wage, which has been $2.15 an hour since 1984. (Other American territories, including Guam, which is only 120 miles from Saipan, use the higher Federal guaranteed minimum of $4.25 an hour.)
 
The Exploited
A Life of Misery Under Old Glory
 Yet the Chinese garment workers almost certainly have it better than many of the other foreign laborers here.
Thousands of Filipinos are employed in the Northern Marianas as construction workers or maids, jobs that are currently exempted from the islands' $2.15 minimum wage. Many young Filipino women are brought to Saipan to work in bars where, they say, they are forced by their employers to serve as prostitutes for the islands' tourists, most of them Japanese visitors on package tours.
The plight of Asian immigrants who are willing to take great risks to live and to work in the United States drew international attention in May, when a rusty freighter carrying 300 undocumented Chinese immigrants ran aground in New York.
In Saipan, Asian laborers arrive legally, usually in the comfort of a commercial jet. But there is plenty of evidence to suggest that many of the estimated 23,000 foreign laborers in these islands, like their undocumented counterparts in the continental United States, face a life of exploitation and misery under the American flag.
Saipan is the largest of the 14 volcanic islands that make up the Northern Marianas, scene of some of the bloodiest fighting of World War II.
 
McDonald's and TV Reruns
 After the war, the islands became a territory of the United States and eventually a commonwealth. The islanders are American citizens, and there are reminders everywhere of their ties to the United States, from the new McDonald's restaurant to a cable-television system that rebroadcasts "Murphy Brown" and the "Today Show."
The garment industry was established in the early 1980's as a result of Federal rules that allow manufacturers here to export clothing to the American mainland duty free and largely without quotas.
There are now more than 20 factories, most of them owned by foreign investors who were also lured here by the islands' liberal investment and immigration laws.
Under commonwealth law, foreign investors are welcome, and they have brought with them a flood of foreign workers who are willing to accept minimum-wage jobs that local islanders routinely reject. Most of the islanders work for the local government and receive much more than the minimum wage.
The commonwealth's Governor, Lorenzo I. DeLeon Guerrero, said that he had heard the slave-labor comparisons in discussions of foreign workers. "It is an insult to us," he said. "There's no slavery here."
But he also readily acknowledged that some employers take advantage of foreign workers. "It's very true that the conditions of these people should be far better," the Governor said. "We have to be honest about that."
 
The Reformers
30 an Hour Raise And Barbed Wire
 The local legislature approved a law this year to raise the minimum wage by 30 cents a year for each of the next seven years and to apply the minimum to construction workers. The Governor has proposed the creation of a human rights commission to protect the rights of workers.
But the reforms do not go far enough to satisfy many of the commonwealth's critics -- under the new law, Saipan's minimum wage will not match the current Federal minimum of $4.25 until 1999 -- and there are threats in Congress this year to cut off more than $120 million in Federal subsidies.
"I'm afraid that an awful lot of time and motion is being wasted trying to give the appearance of reform instead of actually making real, structural changes," said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, which oversees American territories.
American labor unions charge that, because of the low wages paid to foreign workers, the Northern Marianas are stealing jobs from textile workers in the United States. The unions want the Government to crack down on the labor abuses here.
"We have rules for protecting products, such as copyright laws, but seemingly we have no rules to protect the workers who produce the product -- if they happen to be in Saipan," said Arthur Gundersheim, director of international affairs for the Amalgamated Clothing & Textile Workers Union.
 
No Water or Electricity
 While commonwealth officials insist they are trying to improve the living conditions of foreign workers, the improvements are not evident in large Saipan neighborhoods like Susupe, where several oversize tin-roof plywood shacks serve as workers' barracks. Often they have no regular water or electricity.
In larger barracks, workers complain of living in virtual captivity, their housing ringed with barbed wire and patrolled by teams of uniformed guards.
"The girls have no freedom," said a 29-year-old Filipino who worked in a bar for five months before "escaping" last year and finding a different job. She asked that her name not be used for fear that her family in the Philippines would learn that she had worked as a prostitute.
While working at the bar, she lived with 20 other women in a three-bedroom house that they were rarely allowed to leave. "We were told that we could not go outside by ourselves, ever," she said. "The boss was afraid that we would have boyfriends and would sleep with them without getting money for him."
 
'Going to America'
 The exploitation of workers often begins long before they arrive here. Many pay large recruitment fees to middlemen in their homelands who find them jobs in Saipan. No matter how terrible the working conditions, they say, they cannot think of going home until the money is earned back.
Masudur Rahman, 30, said his impoverished family in Bangladesh sold off much of its farmland outside Dhaka, the capital, to raise the $4,000 fee demanded by the recruiters for a construction job "where the American flag is flying." Although the recruiter promised a job paying $1,500 a month, Mr. Rahman said, he never received more than $250 a month.
He said he was startled to discover once he arrived in Saipan that he, like virtually all other foreign laborers, had no right to travel on to the United States.
"The recruitment agent said we were going to America," Mr. Rahman recalled. "He never said Saipan."
 
The Exploiters
The Harsh Lessons Of Free Enterprise
 Among the garment industry employers, no one here had been more successful than Mr. Tan, whose family controls clothing factories that employ hundreds of foreign workers and ship millions of dollars worth of clothing each year to the mainland United States.
But Mr. Tan's luck appeared to run out last year, when he agreed to pay $9 million in back wages and damages to more than 1,000 factory workers to settle the Labor Department charges. The department's investigators said that workers in Mr. Tan's factories put in as many as 90 hours a week without overtime and were routinely paid as little as $1.65 an hour.
Separately, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced last year that its investigation had found "appalling living and working conditions" in Saipan garment factories and barracks, including those controlled by Mr. Tan.
Although Federal regulations require that workers receive a minimum of 100 square feet of space per person to cook and sleep, six of Mr. Tan's workers were found living in one room of 190 square feet. Toilet facilities were primitive.
 
Charges Are Dropped
 The Occupational Safety and Health Administration dropped the charges after the Tan companies made $1.3 million in repairs to the factories and barracks and agreed to pay $76,000 in penalties.
His lawyer, Robert J. O'Connor, said that Mr. Tan agreed to pay the back wages only because the Labor Department was harassing some of the factories' clients.
"The Labor Department was putting pressure on our buyers by putting out press releases implying that they were linked to slave labor," he said. ""We were coerced into the settlement."
Mr. O'Connor said that the wages had been withheld not by Mr. Tan's companies, but by Chinese Government supervisors under a longstanding agreement with the workers.
"We know that 97 percent of all the workers who work for Mr. Tan have asked to have their contracts extended," Mr. O'Connor said.
"When they are here," he said of the Chinese laborers, "they learn about free enterprise, democracy -- they become good-will ambassadors of our precepts of democracy."
That is not borne out by the scores of affidavits gathered by the Labor Department from the Chinese workers. The company "makes use of all kinds of illegal methods to steal our blood money," said Hu Li Yue, a factory mender in one of Mr. Tan's factories.
 
The Forgotten
Workers Stranded Without a Job
 Some workers arriving here on contracts receive nothing, not even jobs. Near the airport, a crumbling cinder block house without electricity or running water is home to 47 laborers from the province of Guangdong in southeastern China.
The workers arrived on Saipan in December 1991 on two-year contracts as construction workers, but the jobs they had been promised disappeared. "Now they're pretty much stranded," said their lawyer, Brian McMahon.
The South Korean businessmen who brought them here, Kim Choon Suk, says that because of a downturn in the local construction industry, he had no work for the Chinese laborers and no money to send them home.
"I do not write home anymore because I do not want my wife and my two children to know the truth of our terrible conditions," said Liu Lin Yong, a 30-year-old construction worker.
He leaned against one of the long sheets of plywood that Mr. Kim supplied to the workers to serve as beds. In one room, 22 of the men sleep side by side on the platforms. The toilets are flushed with rainwater, and the men bathe by swimming in the ocean.
"We have no money to pay for tickets to go home," Mr. Liu said, opening his wallet to show that it was empty. All it contained were a few photographs of his family. "I would go home today if I had a ticket. I would run to the airport."

 CORRECTION:
A map caption last Sunday with an article about foreign workers in Saipan misstated the year in which Washington exempted the Northern Mariana Islands from the Federal minimum wage. It was 1976; 1984 was the year Saipan set its minimum hourly wage at $2.15.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: George Williams;
Evolutionary Biology as an Approach to Improving Health

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
AN evolutionary biologist, Dr. George Williams, professor emeritus of ecology and evolution at the State University at Stony Brook, belongs to a handful of researchers who say patients would benefit if doctors took an evolutionary or adaptive approach in evaluating them.
An awareness of the evolutionary history would redefine some illnesses and explain others, according to the theory. Problems like infections, morning sickness, aging and psychological illnesses related to anxiety and stress would benefit from heeding Darwin's theory of natural selection. 
 In 1991 an article outlining the theory was published in The Quarterly Review of Biology by Dr. Williams and Dr. Randolph M. Nesse, a psychiatrist at the University of Michigan Medical School in Ann Arbor. The two joined to write "The Dawn of Darwinian Medicine," which Times Books plans to publish shortly.
Dr. Williams, who lives in Setauket, joined the marine biology department at SUNY in 1960, when it was in Oyster Bay, after earning his Ph.D. from University of California and teaching at Michigan State University. His landmark book, "Adaptation and Natural Selection," was published in 1966.
Q. How would you define the subspecialty of Darwinian medicine?
A. Definitions evolve, I suppose, and if this is a term that will continue to be used, it will undoubtedly change. But what we understand by it is the application of the theory of natural selection which is Darwin's unique contribution, to medical problems.
For any symptom you should have an adaptationist's explanation for it. For example in infectious disease, a symptom may represent damage caused by a pathogen bacteria, or it may represent your own defense against that pathogen. It is necessary for an understanding of interactions between host and parasite to know who is doing what to whom and how these activities show themselves in the symptoms that you see.
Sneezing and fever are defenses against the pathogen. Do you give the patient something to curtail the sneezing or stop the fever? There have been studies in laboratory animals that have shown that if you give a drug to reduce the fever from infectious disease it prolongs the illness. Fever is a mechanism that speeds up the defense process more than it speeds up the activities of the pathogen. This is not to say that you should be glad when you have a fever because you are defending yourself. Many defenses which have evolved are maladaptive.
I speak in moderation, and defense mechanisms can go wrong. Everyone involved in medicine including the patient, should be aware of these problems, and we're trying to increase this awareness with our book.
Q. How did you become interested in the field?
A. In 1980, I ran across a brief article by Paul Ewald on how to interpret the symptoms of infectious diseases from an evolutionary perspective. We then met while I was doing a teaching fellowship at the University of Michigan. Between us we concluded evolutionary ideas have a relevance not just for infectious disease, but in many other ways.
It probably would have remained a side issue for me until I met Randy Nesse, several years later, who was on the faculty of the medical school there. He was interested in the application of evolutionary ideas in medicine in general, but particularly to psychiatry.
Q. Why has it taken so long for Darwin's theory to be associated with medicine?
A. It has taken this theory an awfully long time to find many of the fruitful applications that it has been put to recently within biology. It's only in the last few decades that the idea of natural selection has been a major organizing concept. The kinds of training physicians get includes very little exposure to this kind of thinking. A lot of the theoretical advances in evolutionary biology that are most important to medicine are really fairly recent innovations.
Q. Has there been opposition in the medical community?
A. I don't think there has been any concerted opposition. But an inevitable kind of opposition that everyone is probably guilty of is that everyone is busy already, and here we come along and say you'd better worry about this, too.
Q. Why would doctors benefit from applying an evolutionary perspective? What are the basic lessons that they should know?
A. In the short run we can now say there are some serious gaps in our knowledge that would not be there if a few decades ago medical researchers had been aware of the relevance of evolutionary ideas. There are aspects of human biology that are really mysterious. Looking at them from an evolutionary perspective, you can't imagine how it could be that we have these problems.
One good example is morning sickness during pregnancy. During a normal part of the human life cycle large proportions of those who experience it show symptoms that we associate with disease like nausea and vomiting. Yet the only response of the medical profession to this condition is to find something to relieve these unpleasant symptoms. They have not wondered enough about why these symptoms are there in the first place. The morning sickness has evolved as a mechanism that takes account of the fact that fetal tissues are more vulnerable to toxins than are maternal tissues. A woman whose symptoms are controlled by medication may eat things that she really shouldn't.
Allergy has been studied in the same way, essentially as a way of getting rid of toxins. There are some hay-fever sufferers whose hay fever is actually doing them some good.
It's important to imagine what would be the consequence of such conditions like morning sickness and allergy in the Stone Age. Things were harsh in those days, and any serious inconvenience would have serious consequences. We expect that evolution would have eliminated this kind of problem. The fact that today so many develop these problems is something that needs an explanation.
Having 25 percent of the population grow up nearsighted is inconceivable from an evolutionary perspective. If you look at primitive tribal life today, only 1 or 2 percent are nearsighted. Something about this grossly abnormal environment that we are in now adversely affects our eyes. There is wholesale child abuse going on that is causing this myopia. Children are not designed to sit in classrooms for hours on end.
The rule should be any medical phenomenon should be put in an evolutionary perspective. Ask why did we evolve this vulnerability or condition and who benefits from this condition?
Q. Will your book be for the public or a medical text? Is the evolutionary approach being taught in medical schools?
A. The book is for the general public, but it could be used by students. Now there is no medical school that emphasizes evolutionary approaches. Undoubtedly, there are individuals on medical-school faculties who are making use of evolutionary ideas in their teaching such as the University of Michigan. The only way it will become part of the curriculum in all medical schools is for the administrators to become aware of its importance.
Q. What are the medical disorders that would most benefit?
A. Certainly infectious diseases, as well as injuries and poisoning. They all have their evolutionary aspects that need to be worked out. Diseases of old age, obstetrical and gynecological problems and mental illness. In fact, an evolutionary perspective will provide an understanding of just about all medical disorders.
Q. In The Quarterly Review of Biology you said, "Human biology is designed for Stone Age conditions." How does that affect modern medicine?
A. One hundred thousand years ago people were anatomically very much as we are today. Genes mutate very slowly. There were things that succeeded in the Stone Age, and that's what we have today, whether we need them or not. But 95 of those 100,000 years were spent in the hunter-gatherer economies, with very sparse populations. There were many diseases, but not like those of today, whose transmission mostly requires dense populations.
Our dietary preferences are one example of how Stone Age adaptations now have negative consequences. The rule was eat the sweet fruit and reject the sour. Take this and put it in a world of chocolate eclairs and cookies. We continue to go after the sweetest thing available. Sugar and fat intake is enormously greater than it ever could have been in the Stone Age, leading to new health problems.
Q. Where do evolutionary biologists draw the line between the body's healing itself and the intervention of medicine?
A. The body is attempting to heal itself in disease, but the intervention should help rather than hinder. An example is in the early stages of a bacterial infection the iron count is often low. A traditional approach by the physician would be, "Here is an abnormality we need to restore." But what in fact is happening is the liver and other organs are pulling the iron out of the blood as a way of depriving the bacteria. The iron count is not a deficiency, but instead a useful defense against bacteria.
Q. How do Darwinists explain the aging process?
A. One of the 15 chapters in our book deals with the topic of the aging process, or senescence. It is a prime example of a genetically programmed difficulty maintained as a tradeoff. It is a gradual deterioration of many kinds of adaptive performances. Dietary restrictions at any age have some longevity benefits. The biggest effects are those established early. The aging process, as we see it, is an extension of human development. To control the negative aspects of this development, we need to know more about development in general. More fundamental work in developmental biology and genetics is needed before we can intervene to slow the actual process.
Q. Are there cancers that could be better understood with a Darwinian approach?
A. The understanding that comes from a Darwinian perspective with regard to cancers is mainly discouraging. We may learn how to detect some earlier, and control others. But the picture is the older you get the more vulnerable you get to more cancers. Cancers of women's reproductive tracts are a special case where a Darwinian perspective may produce some rapid and tangible benefits.
Q. What is the Darwinists' view on the treatment and future of the AIDS virus?
A. A lot of people studying AIDS and H.I.V. are looking at its evolution and the way things we are doing affect its evolution. The urgency of this problem has focused people's attention on the evolutionary changes this organism is undergoing. Researchers' help will come from a better understanding of the evolution of the retrovirus, of which the AIDS virus is one.
Q. What are your hopes for the future of Darwinian medicine?
A. I hope that within a very few decades everyone in the medical profession realizes that nothing makes sense unless you look at it in an evolutionary perspective. There is a quote from one of the founders of modern Darwinism in this century, Theodosus Dobzhansky, whom I paraphrase. He said, "Nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. George Williams, professor emeritus of ecology and evolution at the State University at Stony Brook. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: Town Seeks Donations of Goods To Save the Taxpayers Money

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Berlin Police Department was renovating a holding cell this year, it was supposed to cost $12,000. But by scavenging parts from a jail that was being torn down, the department finished the job for $4,500.
In a similar fashion, the police department solicited a truck from a utility company to transport the police dive team. A bank gave the department used computers and wall partitions to set up a detectives' bureau, and an insurance company gave the department some furniture and office equipment. 
 "We were putting a lot of these things in the budget, but because of the economy they would get cut," said Chief Gerald R. Charamut. "If we can get what we need -- even if it's not brand new, as long as it's serviceable -- we can save the taxpayers money."
The donations to the police department are part of an active solicitation program the town has developed over the last several years. This month, for instance, the town received 5,000 binders from an architectural hardware company that will be used in the Board of Education office, and summer programs routinely use disposable cups donated by a local paper products manufacturer.
"We want to continue to offer the same services that we always have, but you've got to cut the cost, because you can't continue to jack up taxes," said the town's Mayor, Robert J. Peters. "The town is not so proud that everything it uses has to be new, and most of the items that are given to us are in excellent condition."
The town even accepts donations of items it might not need, if it thinks it can realize a profit on the deal; at a recent auction of surplus property, Mr. Peters said, about $2,000 was realized from items that had been donated to the town as surplus. The town gets the cash, and the companies got the tax write-off for the donation, and a personal note of thanks from the town's executive board.
 
No Special Treatment
 The Berlin Corporation Counsel, E. Timothy Sullivan Jr., who is also a lawyer in New Britain, said there was no possibility that any of the contributors could seek special treatment from the town in return for a donation. The town seeks the contributions to augment its services; if it had to give something back in exchange, it might as well buy the items itself.
"In no way is there a so-called 'quid pro quo,' " Mr. Sullivan said. "It just wouldn't make sense."
Mr. Peters, who is in his third year as mayor of Berlin, was elected about the time Connecticut's economy went sour, so he said he's never known anything but fiscal frugality.
"I guess I just assumed everybody was doing it," Mr. Peters said. "You've got to hold down expenses, and this is one way of doing that."
But Berlin's solicitations program was unique enough to earn a mention in the Moneysavers section of Connecticut Town and City, the newsletter of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities.
"We're not aware of any other towns doing this type of thing, although we haven't performed any definitive kind of survey," said Kevin T. Maloney, a spokesman for the organization. "It seemed very innovative to us. In these sort of bleak economic times, towns have to find cheaper ways to provide services. This program is a unique way of getting what you need."
The solicitation program makes up only a small part of the town's $3.6 million budget, with most donations worth a few thousand dollars at best, officials said. But for the most part, what is donated are capital expense items that might not otherwise make it into the budget.
 
Tables and Chairs
 For instance, the Aetna insurance company donated some tables and chairs for a police classroom that previously was furnished with the old one-piece desks that had a writing table attached to the seat, and were designed for 96-pound fifth-graders.
"To put a six-foot cop with a full gunbelt into one of those seats and try to run a class; well, it was a little uncomfortable," said Mr. Charamut.
Shawmut Bank donated to the town some six-foot-high office partitions that allowed some privacy to the three-man detective bureau, the youth officer, and the narcotics officer. Previously interviews had to be conducted in a large, open office, Mr. Charamut said. The bank also donated computers that allowed the police to keep confidential files without entering them into the mainframe computer, where others could have access to them.
 
'Good Corporate Citizenry'
 "It's good corporate citizenry," said a spokesman for Shawmut, Brent DiGiorgio. "Computer equipment has a very good secondary life, so if we can find a town to use it after we've replaced it with more modern equipment, we're happy to provide it.
"I can't say that a lot of towns approach us, though," Mr. DiGiorgio said. "What we get are a lot of nonprofits that do it on a regular basis."
Some companies donate to the town as part of a regular corporate giving program. Sherwood Industries, which operates Sherri Cup Co. in Berlin, regularly offers paper cups and other products for town functions, and paper on large rolls for use in school art programs.
Sherri also has a program where nonprofit agencies can apply for free products once a year, said the company's assistant secretary for corporate finances, Nancy C. Caccavale. She said her father, one of the organizers of the company, set civic-mindedness as one of the goals of the company 45 years ago.
"We take pride in helping out organizations, whether a church, the Boy Scouts or Girl Scouts, or the town," Ms. Caccavale said.
Northeast Utilities, which has its headquarters in town, donated a Chevrolet Suburban truck that is used by the police dive team, and a big conference table used in the mayor's office. The truck was due to be replaced anyway, and the table was sitting in a trailer after the company completed a $28 million renovation and expansion project.
 
Line Workers and Executives
 A spokeswoman for Northeast, Myra H. Ahern, said the company also donates services, sending line maintenance workers to lecture Berlin school children on electrical safety, and allowing Berlin students to follow Northeast executives around for a day as part of a careers program. The company is also the town's largest taxpayer, with a bill of more than $2 million a year.
"We feel it's essential to be involved in communities where we do business," Ms. Ahern said. "So we support programs and activities that help improve those communities."
Mr. Peters said he acts as a clearinghouse for all solicitations, to make sure one company isn't approached too many times.
"I think there are limitations to what we should be looking for from these companies, because they're in tough times too," Mr. Roberts said. "There's an old saying -- you shouldn't overstay your welcome. I want to make sure if we're asking for something, we absolutely need it, and it's not in the budget."
Mr. Peters said he also wants to make sure that the same company approached one week for a donation to the engineering department is not approached the next week for the same thing by the public works department.
 
No Frivolous Requests
 "Your credibility is important in approaching these companies, and they need to know your requests aren't frivolous," Mr. Peters said.
Sometimes the contribution doesn't cost a company any cash. Renovations at one of the town's schools recently eliminated two baseball fields that had been used by the Little League; Corbin-Russwin, a local architectural hardware company, donated the use of its corporate baseball fields.
"That's the kind of cooperation we welcome and appreciate," Mr. Roberts said. "That saved the town from having to say 'no' to a lot of young people who wanted to play ball."
One recent solicitation windfall came not from a corporation, but from another community. When the Berlin police station was built in 1976 it had a padded cell that was soon useless. Police have to be able to monitor people inside the cells in the event they try to hurt themselves, and today the standard of treatment for people who are mentally disturbed is to take them to a hospital.
 
Cells and Fixtures
 It was going to cost an estimated $12,000 to remove the padded walls, install bars, and do other renovations to bring the cell up to modern code, Mr. Charamut said. But they learned Bloomfield was building a new jail, and demolishing its old one, and Berlin asked if it could get the old cells and fixtures.
"They were going to have to pay by the pound to have the old fixtures hauled away, so they saved a few dollars," Mr. Charamut said. "And it cost us $4,500 to renovate our cell, about a third of the cost if we had done everything new."
Mr. Peters said even if town finances return to the high point of the mid-1980s, the town has learned a lesson in how to make the most out of every dollar, and he hopes it will continue with the program.
"This is the best form of recycling," Mr. Peters said. "Our attitude is, before you throw it out, let us take a look at it."

HEADLINE: Moving Ahead On a Cleaner L.I. Sound

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AN agreement last month between New York State and Westchester County to limit pollutants discharged into Long Island Sound from sewage-treatment plants in Port Chester, Rye, Mamaroneck and New Rochelle is being applauded by government officials and environmentalists as a first step -- albeit a small one -- in correcting decades of abuse of a troubled estuary.
The agreement to enforce a policy recommended by the Federal Long Island Sound Study in 1991 -- calling for no net gain in nitrogen to prevent depleted oxygen levels in the water -- is the first of its kind in the state and could act as a model for other local governments to follow, State Department of Environmental Conservation officials said. 
 Scientists say nitrogen acts as a fertilizer for algae blooms, which eventually sink to the floor of the Sound and decompose, depleting oxygen in the process. In extreme conditions, when oxygen levels drop below 3.5 milligrams per liter of water, what is known as a hypoxic condition may result, causing fin fish to flee to more aerated waters and slow-moving organisms that live on the floor of the sound, like lobsters and crabs, to suffer and sometimes die.
Already, there are signs that the Sound may be in trouble this summer, according to water samples taken from Milton Harbor in Rye and Mamaroneck Harbor by the Long Island Sound Task Force's Harbor Watch program. Nancy Seligson -- president of the board of trustees of the task force, a nonprofit environmental organization in Stamford with 11,000 members from Connecticut and New York -- said that oxygen levels were "extremely high," above 10 milligrams of oxygen per liter of water. This could signal significant algae activity now and depleted oxygen levels later, when the algae begin to die off.
In other words, the high levels of oxygen are a precursor to significant hypoxic events, said Philip M. DeGaetano, director of water quality for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Five milligrams per liter of water is considered a healthy level in the Sound.
Also, the recent high temperatures have caused the top layer of the Sound to heat up rapidly, trapping the colder and more saline water on the bottom. That condition, coupled with the lack of rainstorms that churn up and oxygenate the water, also sets the stage for a possible hypoxic event.
To reduce the chance of such events in the future, nitrogen going into the Sound must be significantly lowered, scientists say. But for now, the permit agreement with Westchester will limit the discharge of nitrogen to 5,200 pounds a day -- about the current level -- in accordance with the no-net-gain policy. The four plants involved discharge about 4 percent of all the nitrogen coming from 43 sewage treatment plants in Connecticut and New York State.
 
'Moving in the Right Direction'
 Although county officials have long expressed a desire to improve conditions in the Sound and protect marine life, they have also been reluctant to adopt practices that might limit growth and development or might prove too costly.
"No one is saying this was easy for Westchester, but it's the difference between talking about a problem and doing something about it," said Mark A. Tedesco, director of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's Long Island Sound Study office in Stamford. "It's like finally putting your money where your mouth is."
Environmentalists, who report that 10 percent of the nation's population lives within 50 miles of Long Island Sound, said that even though they were disappointed that the agreement did not go farther, they welcomed Westchester's commitment to a firm plan of action.
Ms. Seligson said the county was finally "moving in the right direction to help the most distressed estuary in the United States." She added that Connecticut communities had agreed to the nitrogen cap two years ago and is currently upgrading its plants with state funds.
 
90,800 Tons of Nitrogen a Year
 The State Department of Environmental Conservation's 15-month battle to get Westchester to agree to the nitrogen cap was hard fought, with most of the resistance to the plan coming from two sources: the building trades, which feared that an agreement would mean a moratorium on new construction so treatment plants wouldn't be overloaded, and municipal officials and taxpayers who were worried that an estimated $440 million needed to upgrade the plants to comply with long-range nitrogen-reduction plans would fall on their shoulders.
Robert Bendick, the State Department of Environmental Conservation's deputy commissioner for natural resources, called the pact "a sign of real progress tied to a legal agreement" and said that as a result, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which initially balked about signing similar contracts, now appear willing to cooperate. New York City is also negotiating with the state to limit the amount of the pollutants its treatment plants dump into the estuary.
According to county and state figures, it is estimated that 90,800 tons of nitrogen enter the Sound each year from a variety of sources: about 25,700 tons from the sewage plants in New York State and Connecticut and the rest from other official upland sources, called point sources (treatment plants along the Connecticut River, for example), and from unofficial or nonspecific sources, called nonpoint (like illegal sewer hookups and fertilizer on lawns, golf courses and farms), which feed into the Sound through rivers and streams.
Under the state's original proposal to Westchester, if a treatment plant were to exceed the nitrogen limit, new sewer hookups would have been banned. But that provision was eventually softened to make the deal more palatable to representatives of the construction industry, Mr. DeGaetano said.
 
Part of a Long-Range Plan
 The revised agreement, which will take effect on Dec. 31 next year, allows for day-to-day fluctuations at specific plants so long as the aggregate amount of nitrogen discharged remains within prescribed limits. Also, a violation will not automatically trigger a sewer hookup ban, although the state still has enforcement powers, Mr. DeGaetano said.
With the Westchester agreement finally in their pocket, state officials conceded that tougher restrictions on nitrogen and even plant upgrades could be necessary in the future. They are awaiting the results next year of the Long Island Sound Study's $4 million computer model, which will detail the impact of both nonpoint and point sources of pollution. The current agreement with Westchester, officials said, is just an initial step in what is to be a long-range management plan for the Sound.
The Long Island Sound Study, a research and management project that began in 1985, is part of the National Estuary Program and involves research institutions, regulatory agencies and concerned organizations and individuals. Its recommendations are being administered jointly by New York State, Connecticut and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
Meanwhile, the county's agreement to limit nitrogen from sewage treatment plants is being combined with efforts to find alternatives to costly plant upgrades and with studies on controlling nonpoint sources of pollutants.
For example, the permit agreement is being coupled with a $200,000 experimental nitrogen-reduction project at the Blind Brook Wastewater Treatment Plant in Rye, which could prove far less expensive in the long run than upgrading plants. The project entails using bacteria to break down nitrogen -- a chemical in human waste -- through a series of steps, ending with the release of nitrogen gas, which is natural to the atmosphere.
 
Funds for New Plants
 Adam J. Zabinksi, director of waste water treatment for the County Department of Environmental Facilities, estimated that the experimental system was reducing the 14 milligrams of nitrogen per liter of water usually discharged by the plants by about two to three milligrams per liter. .
But Mr. Zabinski was cautious about the implications of the project for the future. "While this is promising and may do some good, we don't know in the long run if it will be enough," he said.
Mr. DeGaetano also was not optimistic that the biological nutrient removal project would solve the problem. "For now, we're buying time," he said. "But in the long run, we may still be talking about big dollars to upgrade plants."
Legislation introduced in Congress, however, may provide some financing for renovating plants, he said. A bill introduced in April by Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of White Plains, and Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut, calls for $33 billion over three years to restore water quality in the Sound and 17 other estuaries. New York's piece of the pie would amount to more than $3 billion for investments in water pollution control and economic development. A companion measure has been introduced in the Senate.
 
A $500,000 State Grant
 Locally, the 31-member Citizen's Committee on Nonpoint Source Pollution, which County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke appointed last year, will unveil its findings on Thursday.
The report will focus on land-use planning, enforcement of wetlands regulations and limiting fertilizer use, among other things, said Mayor Warren R. Ross of the City of Rye and co-chairman of the committee.
A $500,000 state grant, which will use Federal Environmental Protection Agency funds, is expected to be awarded to the county in October to develop a management plan for controlling nonpoint sources of nitrogen pollution, Mr. DeGaetano said.

LENGTH: 2509 words

HEADLINE: Have Viola, Will Travel: A Working Musician's Life

BYLINE: By PATRICIA VOLK; Patricia Volk's most recent books are "White Light," a novel, and "All It Takes," a collection of short stories.

 BODY:
You think your life is crazy? Juliet Haffner has to find a violist to substitute for her in the orchestra of the Broadway show "Guys and Dolls" because her Latin American pop group only has time for two rehearsals before they record their new CD. Meanwhile, her regular flutist has a gig at the Metropolitan Museum, so now Ms. Haffner has to find a sub for him, too. Then there's a meeting with the CD cover photographer and, after that, one with an arranger, and at 6, a rewrite meeting on the album liner notes -- they need serious work. After three and a half hours wedged into the curve of a grand piano with seven musicians in a 12-by-16 walk-up behind a woodwind repair shop off Times Square, Ms. Haffner gets home close to midnight and her message machine is blinking: Be at the recording studio first thing in the morning.
This, she says, is an easy day. 
 Have viola, will travel.
Parents everywhere who dream of producing the next Itzhak Perlman take note: Freelance musicians in New York do not head for the beach when the temperature hits 100. Wallendas on the high wire of economic survival, they balance recording dates, rehearsals and concerts. As the violist for a hit show, Ms. Haffner is getting regular paychecks for the first time in her life, plus a health plan and three weeks' paid vacation. If she's lucky, really lucky, this could last five years. The downside is, all the people who call you for work forget you. Once the job is over, then what?
Q: A conductor and a violist are hitchhiking on the road. Whom do you hit first?
A: The conductor. Business before pleasure.
"Violists are the Polish joke of the musical world," says a well-known composer terrified of alienating violists. "Nobody plays the viola that well, because they come to it later in life, after playing the violin."
"First, I wanted to be a ballet dancer," Ms. Haffner says, sipping a glass of water in her West 40's studio apartment. "Then I played guitar. Then piano. Then violin. When I got into the High School of Music and Art, I wanted to stick with the violin but that first day they said, 'We really need viola players,' and my hand went up." (The viola, slightly larger than a violin, is tuned a fifth lower and has a more mellow tone.)
Ms. Haffner speaks intently. Like the head on the prow of a ship, her face conveys forward motion. Her scrunched brown hair looks like it's blowing even when she's sitting. Seventeen examples of floral bark cloth co-exist on her chairs, bed and sofa. Some are shot with gold. The feeling is 30's, cozy, feminine. Her pink Princess phone sits on a small table that holds her books, all of which are by or about Damon Runyon, on whose characters "Guys and Dolls" is based. The view from the window is of that great monument to Deco, the McGraw-Hill Building. Perfect.
"Music and Art was just so wonderful," she says. "We spent half the day playing. That's when I knew I'd be a musician. I saw it as a very social thing. I'd always be able to have friends." Friends, yes. But romance takes time. When Ms. Haffner does go out, it is usually with a musician. "I'm always amazed," she says, "that people who have different life styles live together or are married. What would I talk about with somebody else?"
MS. HAFFNER WAS BORN IN Manhattan 38 years ago and grew up in the Bronx. Her father, who still plays the violin professionally for the Bronx Opera Company and the Bronx Chamber Orchestra, was her biggest influence. "Both my parents played," she says. "So coming to music wasn't forced. Our house was filled with it. My mother knew over 200 folk songs. I grew up with my father's sound in my head. There's a picture of me in the crib listening to him. When I play, always there's the connection with my parents. Everything I'm feeling, happy or sad, goes into it. It's like breathing to me. I still think I have a natural approach that you can't really learn."
She checks the time, then snaps her black viola case shut. "If I had a dollar for every guy who says, 'Is that a machine gun?' or 'Why don't you play the piccolo?' I'd retire." Maybe it has something to do with the Et Vous cutoffs and high black satin pumps she wears, too. "Bass playing women have it worse."
Zap. Ms. Haffner heads for Carlos Franzetti's apartment to choose numbers for their new CD on the Chesky label. She started the eight-member Orquesta Nova with Mr. Franzetti two years ago so they could explore "the non-'Girl From Ipanema' side" of Latin music -- the music of dance halls, brothels and silent movies. Mr. Franzetti's living room looks like a recording studio. He runs through a Cuban lullaby on the piano: "Bay-bah-bah-bah, bay-bo-bah-bah," then switches to a plaintive song that makes you feel like falling in love or maybe that you used to be in love and now you're getting philosophical about not being in love anymore and that even though it's raining out life with all its crazy emotional complexity is definitely worth living because you keep getting wiser, that kind of song.
"Yeah, yeah," Ms. Haffner nods. "I like it." She picks up her viola and, without sheet music, plays the song back to Mr. Franzetti.
 
Zing Went the Strings Of Her Viola
 Back uptown, 45 minutes before show time, Ms. Haffner grabs a bite at the Film Center Cafe, her favorite "hang." She got the "Guys and Dolls" job because somebody recommended her to Seymour Red Press, the orchestra contractor for the show. She didn't have to audition. With a master's from Juilliard, Ms. Haffner is a world-class sight reader. Coming cold to a jumble of notes, she appears to play them perfectly.
"I have a list of the real good people in town," Mr. Press says. "I've never heard Juliet play solo, but she's got a good reputation."
Dick Behrke, a composer and conductor of music for commercials, has never heard her alone either. "She's on our list, though," he says. "You get the names from a concertmaster like David Nadien."
Mr. Nadien says: "I've never heard her solo." But, "she's a professional and a member of the union. It's possible some people may have heard her."
And Jerry Zaks? "She seems devoted and dedicated," says the director of "Guys and Dolls." "I've never heard her play."
Marin Alsop, music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, actually has heard Ms. Haffner: "Her sound is distinctive. Her playing has a lot of personality. Once, walking down the street at the Aspen Music Festival, I heard music coming from a window and I knew Juliet was there."
 
Into the Pit At 'Guys and Dolls'
 Ms. Haffner checks her watch again. She races to the Martin Beck Theater, where, deep underground, past a steel door, there is a dingy gray area, the orchestra locker room. She shifts gears. Her energy level escalates. She smiles a Loretta Young smile, big, white, with dimples like parentheses and, tres gaie, introduces the guys: "Ray Beckenstein, saxophonist extraordinaire . . . Roger Wendt, French horn extraordinaire . . ." A man wanders around half-dressed. Musicians lounge, doing crossword puzzles, sipping Diet Cokes. Two men fiddle with a closed-circuit television and another readies 300 pounds of dry ice for pumping "smoke" onto the stage. "Five minutes!" the stage manager shouts.
Ms. Haffner climbs upstairs to the pit, a hole that has earned its name. Twenty-six musicians are hunched beneath the stage, invisible to most of the audience. The only place Ms. Haffner can put down her chocolate mints is by her foot. The walls are cinder block, wires all over the place. The modern cure for everything is everywhere: duct tape. There's a photo of Paul Newman glued to the wall. A metal net dangles two feet above. "The pearl catcher," Ms. Haffner explains. "During 'Take Back Your Mink,' when Adelaide rips off her pearls, the players were getting hit."
At 8:10, the conductor hikes his pants. "This is it," Ms. Haffner whispers. Lights dim. Edward Strauss raises his baton and dives into the overture. He sings along, hops, makes inverted O.K. signs, laughs, flamencos, goose necks, punches air, davens and flings his arms like Maurice Curry in his "Intro to Tap" class at the 92d Street Y. From the pit, you can't see anything on the stage, not even feet. "It's like listening to the radio," Ms. Haffner says, "only louder."
Her big moment comes during "Adelaide's Lament," a two-bar solo. She rocks sideways when she plays. You see sound in her face. Sometimes her eyebrows go pizzicato. In an orchestra, Ms. Haffner says, the viola "provides harmonic color, the inside voices of a chord." Yet when she is onstage, "I'm in another world, a deeper space. It's beyond thinking about the music. You're embraced by it. It takes over."
Between numbers, notes get passed, checkbooks get balanced, letters get written. A pregnant violinist loses herself in an article entitled "On Breeches and Twins at Home." Part of the brain stays alert to vocal cues. When one of the characters declares ". . . he will not be a gambler," the players drop what they're doing, pick up their instruments and launch into "I'll Know." When a number is loud, they use earplugs. When it's louder, they bounce in their seats, synchronized, like the Nairobi Trio. They crack each other up. Ms. Haffner suggests a new category for the Tonys: "Best Choreography in the Pit."
The music seems smooth, even though on this particular night seven subs are playing. There are eight "Guys and Dolls" performances a week. The latest contract lets the musicians miss four of them. Every night Edward Strauss looks down and sees faces he's never seen before.
It's a week later. Ms. Haffner has to find another sub for the show. She's booked her other group, the one that plays American jazz, for a New York Mercantile Exchange dinner at the Waldorf.
Originally, this group was an all-female quartet called the Satin Dolls. Then Ms. Haffner met a violinist named Andy Stein and wanted him to join. The Dolls wanted to split all decisions four ways. Ms. Haffner wanted Andy. "I call the shots," Ms. Haffner says. The Dolls became a sextet called the New York Strings. Now both her groups are all men. "There's a certain sexual energy when you're playing an instrument," she says, "when you're having this kind of dialogue. I think that's part of it. And men are much more relaxed and straight ahead. I'm speaking generally."
Even groups made up of people who have to find subs have to find subs. The Strings have two tonight. Everyone shakes hands, violating the Never Shake Hands on the Bandstand rule. You're supposed to look like you play together all the time.
Ms. Haffner smiles and jokes, despite the fact that the Starlight Roof has only delivered one chair for six people. "They always say everything will be there but it isn't," she says, shrugging. In a tiny black sample suit a mother would call "smart," Ms. Haffner deals firmly with the hotel staff as 350 commodities dealers funnel into the ballroom. The head of the exchange starts talking about "triple nine fixes" and, finally, the chairs come. The Strings burst into "S'Wonderful." Nothing prepares you for a big-band 30's tune played swing style on strings. It's quirky and high-spirited. You don't know whether to swirl like Fred and Ginger or do-si-do.
People eat through speeches and talk through music. The Strings don't seem to notice. "The dinner's the thing here," Ms. Haffner says. "At Carnegie Hall, people pay to listen. But in clubs, you play, the blender makes daiquiris. The greatest jazz musicians in the world earn their living that way. Even Mozart had to go in through the kitchen."
 
Yellow Birds Don't Fly With Orquesta Nova
 It's rehearsal time. As Ms. Haffner's substitute gets ready for the Martin Beck Theater, Orquesta Nova, a chamber group dedicated to Latin American music, plays Astor Piazzolla's wistful "Milonga del Angel." They segue into "Tango for Astor," which sounds more like Tweety chasing Sylvester. This is not the kind of music you hear on the beach sipping Yellow Birds out of coconuts.
"Everyone thinks South American music is people running around with bananas on their heads," says David Chesky, who, along with his brother, Norman, produces the group's CD's. "It's not."
The first CD didn't make any money, but Mr. Chesky is not worried about the new one, "Salon New York." He leaves Ms. Haffner and Carlos Franzetti alone. "People of their caliber, you don't tell what to do."
Orquesta is a good-looking group.
"That's why I pick 'em," Ms. Haffner says, laughing.
Juliet Haffner is not what you'd call "struggling." She doesn't have to pile into a car and drive to Vermont for $200 gigs anymore. No more nursing homes or hostile maitre d's who make you stand in the hall. If she played every performance of "Guys and Dolls," she would gross $47,216 a year. Asked if she'd like to do a Broadway show again, she says: "Not if it's like 'Les Miz.' " Why not? "Let's just say," she notes carefully, "I prefer the tunes of the 30's, 40's and 50's." Ms. Haffner plays what she wants to play. People call her. She has recorded Broadway original-cast albums and the soundtracks for 28 movies. Still, as the synthesizer takes over, she'd have to be numb not to feel it.
"Ten years ago, 70 percent of commercial music was composed for acoustic instruments," says Mr. Behrke, the composer-conductor. "Today, it's 25." The synth is to music what diet shakes are to dining: they fill you but you don't feel satisfied. It's quicker, easier music, the Black Death of sound.
"Computers don't need health insurance," Ms. Haffner says in her "What can you do?" way. "The American Federation of Musicians can't say, 'Don't use a synthesizer for esthetic reasons' or 'You need 50 string players on this date or we'll strike.' "
 
Two Freelance Gigs Make a Quiet Day
 It's 10 A.M. Ms. Haffner adjusts her headphones at a recording studio. She's got a Ponderosa restaurant spot, 22 seconds of original music with an eight-second musical logo, or tag. The orchestra runs through the piece. It sounds like they've been playing it since birth. It's call-to-action Movietone News music. Picture thousands of steaks marching, proud of their beefdom.
"Lots of secure, arrogant rhythms, please," says Mr. Behrke, and the musicians run through it one last time. Everybody's happy. Client is happy. Agency is happy. Producer is happy because client and agency are. Ms. Haffner will get $80, plus another $20 if it plays within 13 weeks of being recorded. It's a pretty quiet day for her. Only two freelance jobs. Not that she has any trouble hopping from Mozart to Gershwin to sirloin. "I think about what the sound is like," she says, "what needs to be said."
On the street, viola in hand, she fades into the crowd. Off to Weill Recital Hall? Clinton Recording Studios? The New York State Theater? When Ms. Haffner crosses her ankles to play, you see them. There they are: pink parabolas, rubber taps on the soles of her black satin shoes. If you've ever wondered what kind of person needed those, now you know.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Translating Diversity Into High-Tech Gains

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago, when Silicon Valley was just beginning to boom, the electronics industry was notorious for being composed almost exclusively of white male engineers born in the U.S.A.
Times have changed. 
 "It's a very dynamic situation," says Marian Stetson-Rodriguez, president of LinguaTec Inc. of Sunnyvale, a 13-year-old company founded to help Silicon Valley companies improve cross-cultural communications.
"You can go into a company around here nowadays and find people from Tonga, South Korea and Romania working side by side. And even appearances can be confusing. We have people who look African-American but are from Somalia or Suriname. I know of one manager who looks Chinese and has a Chinese name, but speaks perfect English and comes from Argentina."
The increasingly multicultural business community is the result of the migration of professionals and other workers, largely from Southeast Asia, India and Mexico, to the high-tech mecca that is Silicon Valley. It offers a glimpse at the opportunities and challenges that the rest of American industry may soon face, as demographers estimate that white males will become a minority in the work force at the turn of the century. But for technology executives now, the change has already meant new thinking about managing a diverse work force and new programs to better understand it.
The polyglot pandemonium is greatest at companies, like chip fabricators, disk drive makers and PC assemblers, that have large manufacturing lines. These include Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Apple, Silicon Graphics, LSI Logic, Quantum and Conner Peripherals.
But perhaps the most extreme case is the Solectron Corporation, an assembly company in Milpitas. A couple of years ago, the company surveyed the backgrounds of its 3,200 employees and found 30 nationalities speaking 40 languages and dialects. As confusion, even tension, mounted from cross-cultural signals, Solectron instituted a landmark cultural awareness program.
The man behind the program was William Yee, Solectron's vice president for resource development and civic affairs, who has taken a year's leave to help the United Way with similar problems. Born in Santa Barbara to Chinese immigrant parents, Mr. Yee was, by his own description, a "banana: yellow on the outside and white on the inside."
A veteran of I.B.M., Memorex and Apple, Mr. Yee came to Solectron assuming, he said, that he would bring "understanding and empathy" because of his Asian background. Instead, he said, "what I discovered was that, even though I grew up in that world, after 30 years in industry I had lost that perspective."
Mr. Yee discovered how little he knew about his own culture almost from the first day on the job. Calling together a group of managers, most of them Asian immigrants, Mr. Yee announced his training ideas in typical American pep-talk fashion. Everyone nodded in agreement. He easily remembers the moment: " 'Any questions?' I asked. None. 'O.K., great!' I said, 'Let's go do it!' And nothing happened for three months.
"It turned out that nobody had been willing to disagree or ask a question in front of their peers," he said. "I had to go out and establish communication links on an individual basis." One of his first programs taught employees to be more forthright in expressing opinions.
Glen O. Toney is corporate vice president of human resources at Applied Materials Inc. in Santa Clara, which has a work force nearly as diverse as Solectron's and a major division in Japan that conducts daily videoconferences with the home office.
"What I've learned," Mr. Toney said, "is that people have different approaches -- a different logic, in fact -- but all can produce results. But you have to learn patience and improve your listening skills."
"And it's more that just listening," he added, admitting that he comes away physically and mentally exhausted from his video meetings with Japan. "You have to combine their words with their unique cultural context and then derive a meaning from those variables. Listening becomes quite intense."
The irony of his experience is not lost on Mr. Toney, one of the few African-American executives in Silicon Valley: "You learn to value the ideas of people unlike yourself."
Edward T. Hall, a cultural anthropologist, has written of the importance of two cultural types. He divides cultures by the way they view time -- as either fixed (monochronic) or flexible (polychronic) -- and by what they emphasize in personal interaction -- either explicit information (low context) or subtler signals, like status and timing (high context). The problem often comes because most United States executives are low context/monochronic, while their foreign-born employees are typically high-context/polychronic.
Ms. Stetson-Rodriguez adds these suggestions for bosses:
First, create a level playing field. With so much diversity, there is a tremendous risk of sending mixed messages. Go for simplicity: "Companies with the strongest and most consistently communicated corporate culture -- those that provide a consistency in their expectation of performance -- have generally dealt with this change the best."
Second, in communicating with employees, develop a strategy of patience and clarification. Let the employee get to the end of what he or she is saying. Give no signals of approval or disapproval. Then repeat back or summarize what you've heard to make sure you've got the message. Reward assertiveness.
Third, and perhaps most important, "understand what your own culture is doing to color the interactions you get into. Too many American executives say, 'I'm normal.' If you can get objectivity on your own culture as affecting your actions, attitudes and assumptions, you are already halfway there."

HEADLINE: U.S. Acts Inconsistently on Macedonia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report of the arrival of American ground troops in Macedonia is a reminder of serious contradictions in Clinton Administration policy toward that republic and its civilian population ("Balkan Update," July 6). American military participation in the "Macedonian tripwire" follows by only a month the imposition of a de facto embargo on certain products made in Macedonia and consigned for the United States market. 
 The United States and United Nations now embargo all Macedonian goods produced for Serbia and Montenegro. Although Serbia is Macedonia's largest trading partner, it has complied with that embargo. Any United States policy that further punishes Macedonia for cooperating with an American and United Nations-led embargo is counterproductive.
The two policies taken together -- military protection on the one hand, economic punishment on the other -- show clearly that the Clinton Administration has not organized coherently the political, trade and economic components of its Macedonia policy.
Why will the Administration deprive of a livelihood the same lives it will risk American soldiers to save?
On June 3 the Committee for the Implementation of Trade Agreements, an obscure creature of the United States Commerce Department, told Macedonian factories and workers: you can't ship some 200,000 men's and boys' wool suits produced for American buyers.
The committee's policies are conditioned by the domestic textile and apparel complex, whose officials meet regularly with their Government counterparts in the Commerce Department. The Clinton Administration's eagerness to accommodate the textile and apparel protection lobby prevents it from recognizing the importance of offering economic support to Macedonia. One form of economic support -- which, incidentally, won't cost taxpayers a dime but will result in consumer savings -- would be rescind the backroom trade agreements committee embargo.
Those 200,000 suits are not going to make a discernible difference in the United States balance of trade. But the wages paid to make those suits will feed families in Macedonia and will help support the United States mission to preserve Macedonian life and social order. The Clinton Administration must reverse its embargo on wool suits as an important first step in shaping a coherent Macedonia policy.
 
LAURA E. JONES
Exec. Director, United States Assn.
of Importers of Textiles and Apparel
New York, July 8, 1993
