HEADLINE: JAPANESE REJECT OLD GUARD BUT SPLINTERED VOTE MEANS A STRUGGLE FOR A COALITION

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, July 19

 BODY:
Thirty-eight years of single-party rule by the Liberal Democrats ended in elections on Sunday, but the party retained enough seats to insure a struggle for command of the Government with a new generation of opposition leaders.
The loss, the party's biggest since it was created with American backing in 1955, was a measure of the tremendous discontent with the scandals and influence-peddling that have plagued the conservative incumbents for five years. Voters flocked to three new parties made up largely of defectors from the Liberal Democrats. 
 Together the new parties seized more than 100 of the 511 seats in the powerful lower house. The Liberal Democrats won 223 seats, 33 shy of the majority needed to guarantee control.
 
The Other Big Loser
 In another sign of the shattering of the old order, the Socialists, Japan's largest postwar opposition party, suffered a crushing defeat, losing nearly half their seats.
Early this morning each leading candidate in the fractious two-week campaign declared victory.
The Liberal Democrats said they would seek to extend their reign, and this afternoon Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said that he would not resign his post, as least until a new Parliament is convened within a month. Asked whether he would seek another term as Prime Minister, he said he would "if I have the support of the party."
In the other corner, Tsutomo Hata, a leader of the Japan Renewal Party, called on the Liberal Democrats to step down gracefully "with the regular procedures of constitutional government."
Leaders of all parties immediately assured the public that there would be no major changes in policy, including Japan's approach to the United States.
 
Well, Now What?
 But no one could confidently predict what kind of coalition would finally be stitched together, or even from what party a prime minister would be drawn. There were many predictions that whatever government emerges, it will be so fragmented that elections will have to be held again within a year to consolidate the opposition groups.
"We are entering a new era, a coalition era," said Morihiro Hosokawa, the head of the Japan New Party. "It will be a very, very difficult time." The party's creation last year began to break up the political glaciers that have ground against each other throughout the cold-war era.
But if the country was at a critical turning point, it was difficult to see on the streets.
On a drizzly Sunday at the tail end of rainy season, only about 67 percent of the country's 93 million registered voters, a low turnout by Japanese standards, cast ballots in the 129 legislative districts, some of which hold more than one seat.
That may reflect the mixed feelings of voters who say their anger at corruption is tempered by their fear of economic uncertainty.
The Liberal Democratic leadership played to those fears throughout the campaign, spinning out scenarios of economic ruin, power failures like the ones in the Philippines and Italian-style street crime if the governing party lost power to an untested group.
Political analysts said the negative campaigning struck a deep chord in the instinctively conservative electorate, and probably saved the Liberal Democrats from far more damaging losses.
On Sunday night the results were barely counted when leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party began hinting in television interviews that they were preparing to dump the 73-year-old Mr. Miyazawa.
 
Liberal Democrats Stand Firm
 The secretary general of the party, Seiroku Kajiyama, whose efforts to delay a political reform bill last month touched off a revolt that forced the election, said he would start negotiations immediately with smaller parties on an alliance that would "fulfill the people's will to allow the L.D.P. to continue as the ruling party."
But in several different statements this morning, Mr. Kajiyama appeared to be trying to edge Mr. Miyazawa out of office. Several party leaders were quoted in the Japanese press as saying that the Liberal Democrats stood no chance of attracting another party to ally with it while Mr. Miyazawa, whose popularity ratings have been in the single digits, remains in office.
Both opposition politicians and many of Japan's influential newspapers hailed the end of what they called the "1955 regime," under which the Liberal Democrats became a permanent, increasingly corrupt ruling party and the Socialists a carping, ineffective opposition.
 
'A Sweeping Transformation'
 "Our country's political structure has undergone a sweeping transformation," Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest daily, said in an editorial this morning. The Liberal Democratic Party, it said, "should consider the fact that the splitting of the conservative camp into multiple parties offers a good opportunity for the party to purge itself of its dependency on money power and other evils."
The election essentially left the Japanese political system divided into three major camps, with the Liberal Democrats remaining the largest faction.
In addition to the 223 seats the party won, it has access to more than 15 votes from independents with strong ties to the party. Three times in the past, such firm allies have enabled the party to achieve a majority in Parliament even when it fell short in the polls.
 
Lining Up Coalitions
 While the Liberal Democrats retain far fewer seats than the 275 they won in 1990, the party appears better situated than any other group to form a minority government, albeit one that party leaders concede would be weak.
Because a fifth of the party's members in the lower house bolted in mid-June, abandoning Mr. Miyazawa during a crucial vote of confidence, the election resulted in a net loss of only four seats, according to a reckoning by Mr. Kajiyama, who declared the results Sunday a victory.
The second major camp consists of a loose alliance of five opposition parties that had hoped to freeze the Liberal Democrats out of power. But they took only 195 seats, and many experts doubt whether such a coalition can attract and hold enough allies to form a government.
Included in that opposition camp are the Socialists, who won only 70 seats, a stunning setback from the 136 they took in 1990.
It also includes the Japan Renewal Party, whose chairman, Mr. Hata, a former Finance Minister, led the revolt against Mr. Miyazawa. Ignoring critics who said his party was old Liberal Democratic wine poured into new bottles, Mr. Hata's group turned in a remarkably strong performance, claiming 55 seats.
Mr. Hata is frequently mentioned as a possible successor to Mr. Miyazawa, assuming his opposition coalition holds together.
Early this morning a beaming Mr. Hata appeared at a news conference with Ichiro Ozawa, the brooding political strategist who operated behind the scenes to pull off the defection from the Liberal Democrats.
But Mr. Ozawa said little: party officials still feel that his long service as the political lieutenant to the ruling party's fallen power-broker, Shin Kanemaru, makes him a risky public presence. Mr. Kanemaru goes on trial this week on charges of tax evasion.
 
Little Guys With Muscle
 The third and perhaps most strategically important camp is also the smallest: The Japan New Party and a like-minded group that broke away from the Liberal Democrats last month and formed Sakigake, or the Harbinger Party. They took 48 seats.
They have not declared what coalition they will join, and their swing votes will probably determine which party rules and who serves as prime minister. Both the Liberal Democrats and the other opposition groups are expected to court them heavily.
"The question is, who can form a coalition that will last," said Yasanori Sone, a political scientist at Keio University. "But the thing to remember is that the whole Japanese political system has changed. This is just the first step in a broader political realignment, and it may take years."
The political upheavals resulting from the election, however, began immediately, over the question of the next prime minister.
 
Loss of a Monopoly
 Under the old political regime, that question was solely the province of the Liberal Democrats. The party's many factions competed to promote their leaders, usually striking deals behind the scenes that involved spreading the spoils of office to the party's many constituencies.
This time, factional politics is irrelevant, and what only a year ago was the largest faction, headed by Mr. Takeshita, is virtually wiped out.
Under the Constitution, the prime minister must be selected at a special session of Parliament within 30 days of an election. If a prime minister is not selected on a first ballot, then the two top vote-getters compete in a runoff.
Among the names being talked about within the Liberal Democratic Party are Toshiki Kaifu, who was ousted as Prime Minister two years ago for promoting political reform too ardently; Michio Watanabe, a party elder and former Foreign Minister who had to resign because of what is believed to be a terminal illness, and Masaru Gotoda, 78, who is widely respected as a clean politician. Several younger members of the party are also vying.
Among the opposition leaders, Mr. Hata and Mr. Hosokawa, of the Renewal Party and the New Party, seem to be the leading candidates. But it is unclear how much support they could garner from other members of the coalition. Mr. Hosokawa said Sunday that he expected his group to put up "one candidate in the first round."
 
Once Shunned, Now on TV
 If anyone needed a sign of the changed center of power in Japanese politics, it was evident Sunday night at Mr. Hosokawa's New Party headquarters, on a back street in Tokyo.
Last year Mr. Hosokawa, a former governor of Kumamoto Prefecture on Kyushu Island and a direct descendent of the samurai family that once controlled that wealthy region of Japan, complained to an American reporter that the Japanese news media would not take his ideas or his rebel party seriously.
On Sunday his headquarters was jammed with television cameras, and every five or ten minutes he appeared on a different network as questioners sought to find out where he would throw his newly won votes. Like any good Japanese warrior, he bowed deeply and let on nothing of his plans.
For many Japanese, the struggle will be a remarkable sight, unlike anything Japan has seen since the raucous days just after the end of the United States occupation of Japan. But a third of today's population was not yet born when the Liberal Democratic Party was formed, with covert support from Washington. A stable party in America's pocket was considered vital to the anti-Communist cause.
 
Sliding Out of Power
 Over the years, though, the party grew bloated and corrupt. The Recruit scandal in 1988, which led to Mr. Takeshita's resignation, was the first sign that party members were selling influence on a huge scale, and using the proceeds for both their personal fortunes and their campaign coffers.
There were promises of reform, but they were never fulfilled. Mr. Gotoda, the Liberal Democratic leader, suggested in an interview a few weeks ago that if the party had dealt with the Recruit scandal right away, it might not be facing the loss of power today.
In 1989, Recruit cost the party control of the less powerful upper house of Parliament for the first time. The upper house, which has no say in the Government budget, can still block or slow other legislation.
The fervor faded and the party recovered in 1990, but the scandals never seemed to end, each revealing a new layer of collusion between Japanese companies -- often small concerns trying to break into markets here -- and the political world.
 
Reform? What Reform?
 Bribes took on vast proportions. In the latest investigation, into a scandal involving a transport company called Sagawa Kyubin, there was yet another layer: the party, it was alleged, hired organized crime figures to silence critics of Mr. Takeshita shortly before he took office in 1987.
But endless promises of reform led nowhere.
Mr. Miyazawa vowed to pass a reform bill this spring, but was stymied by Mr. Kajiyama and other prominent conservatives who had little interest in upsetting the status quo. Mr. Kajiyama seemed to bet the issue would go away; he bet wrong. The issue became a rallying call for reformers, who broke with the party, and it led to Mr. Miyazawa's downfall.

HEADLINE: Cheap Beeps: Across Nation, Electronic Pagers Proliferate

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
At the Countryside Mall in Clearwater, Fla., parents cruise the stores as their children nap or play games at the mall's child-care center. What happens if one child bites another, complains of a stomachache or begins to sob inconsolably?
Scott Kaufman, who heads the center, can instantly dial the number of the hand-held pager that the parents are given as part of the child-care service. Hearing the beep, mom or dad knows to scurry back. 
 "Parents love the beepers," Mr. Kaufman said. "They're not out of touch."
 
 
Many Uses
 Millions of other Americans have adopted paging technology for all sorts of uses beyond the popular stereotype of the beeper as a tool for doctors, plumbers and drug dealers. Nationwide, nearly 53,000 people a day are signing up for paging service, which can cost as little as $7 a month in fees. The devices start at less than $60.
In 1990, 9.9 million pagers were in service in the United States, according to Economic and Management Consultants International, a Washington firm that specializes in paging issues. By the end of this year, the number is expected to reach 19.2 million. And, the firm predicted, by 1997 the nation would probably have more than 33 million pagers in use.
Commonly known as a beeper, for the sound it makes when activated, the device is a simple radio receiver that in most instances is assigned its own telephone number. When the number is called from a telephone, the call goes to a special radio-transmitter network that sends out a signal to the designated pager. Typically, the signal displays the phone number of the person seeking the paging subscriber.
Among those who swear by their pagers is Victor Bishara, a real estate agent in Highland, Calif., near San Bernardino. Blind since infancy, Mr. Bishara has been able to work through Braille computer printouts, special software for drawing up real estate contracts -- and a pager programmed to alert him whenever a client leaves a voice-mail message on his office telephone.
"Consultation is critical to my job," said Mr. Bishara, whose real-estate business is now hectic after a long fallow period during the recession. "Pagers give my clients instant gratification when they have a question."
Paging service will probably change in the near future, from a passive one-way device to a two-way send-and-receive system that in many cases could serve as a lighter and cheaper alternative to desktop or portable telephones. Sophisticated beepers may soon be able to send faxes and remotely check for electronic messages on an office computer.
"This is a very exciting time for the paging industry," said Terry L. Scott, the president of Paging Network Inc., which is based in Plano, Tex., and is the largest paging concern in the country, with 2.6 million subscribers. "Pretty soon you'll have an answering machine and fax machine that fits in your pocket."
One reason for the beeper boom is that in a country where most college-educated adults have trouble programming their videocassette recorders, the pager is the ultimate user-friendly device.
Small but telling improvements have also helped build demand. Some units silently vibrate instead of emitting a head-turning beep in movie theaters and restaurants. And some models, not yet widely adopted, can function as little billboards that display not only phone numbers but also brief text messages or information services like stock quotations. These are more expensive, selling for at least $200.
Manufacturers including Motorola and NEC America make pagers as thin as credit cards, as well as see-through pagers in so-called fashion colors like Sizzling Yellow and Vibra Pink to attract younger consumers. Once sold mainly through specialized shops, pagers are now widely available, not just in telephone and consumer electronics stores, but also at Wal-Mart, Service Merchandise, Walgreen's and their rivals.
 
 
Operating Costs
 With $2.2 billion in revenue last year, the paging business is still dwarfed by the $8.8 billion in annual revenue for the cellular industry, even though in 1992 paging had 15.3 million subscribers and cellular had 11 million. The paging industry takes in less because it charges less. Its operating costs are much lower than those of the cellular industry, which also uses radio waves to distribute its signals.
Because paging messages use only short bursts of data, rather than the continuous stream of voice conversations of cellular phones, many more customers can simultaneously use a given swath of radio frequencies. For each 10 seconds of one cellular conversation, the paging network can carry more than 100 numeric messages.
Paging networks are also cheaper to build than cellular phone networks. The Mobile Telecommunications Technologies Corporation, known as Mtel, a national paging company based in Jackson, Miss., estimated that in a city like Dallas it costs $500,000 for enough transmitters and equipment to carry paging services with the capacity for 300,000 subscribers. It would take up to $10 million for cellular equipment for a comparable number of voice customers, the company said.
Consumers have benefited from robust competition in the paging industry. In a given metropolitan area, dozens of competing service providers may be vying for customers.
 
 
'Falling Prices'
 In the 1970's, when the industry was much smaller and still mainly a plumbers-and-doctors business, pagers cost about $300 and monthly service fees ranged up to $50. Today only the most sophisticated devices capable of receiving text cost more than $300. Most cost much less and many can be leased for only a few dollars a month. And the average monthly bill for paging service has fallen to about $17 for people who own their pagers and $23 for those who lease them.
There is far less competition in the cellular phone industry because when Federal regulators established the cellular networks, they licensed only two companies in each metropolitan market. The idea was to give companies the incentive to invest the larger sums required for building the systems.
Of course, paging is still a rather limited technology. Motorola's top-of-the-line pager, the Advisor (list price $349), can hold up to 40 short messages, each of which can be displayed on a four-line screen. But sending such messages evokes the days of Western Union: callers dictate their messages to an operator, who then types the message into a special transmitter for dissemination over the pager network. In these systems, callers to any beeper on the system dial the same number, and the messages are dispatched by the operators through switching systems.
 
 
Federal Approval Process
 To speed up the process and eliminate operators, pagers would have to become two-way devices, which is likely to be the end result of a lengthy Federal approval process under way. Last month Mtel received clearance from the Federal Communications Commission to develop advanced pagers that could send and receive but would require more radio frequencies. A system might be operating by 1995.
Mtel already operates Skytel, the largest nationwide paging service, with about 218,000 subscribers in the United States. With its next-generation pagers, Mtel envisions a system in which a caller would receive confirmation that a paging message had been received -- something that is not possible with the current technology. The devices might also be able to capture and play a short voice message, which would be a boon to the blind, like Mr. Bishara, the real estate agent.
Or pagers might someday be merged into cellular telephones. Mtel and Motorola recently agreed to field-test a new phone that incorporates paging. Few cellular customers give out their cellular phone numbers because subscribers must pay for incoming as well as outgoing calls, an expensive proposition.
But with a pager phone, especially one that displays both text and numbers, an inexpensive pager message might say, "The boss is calling," so the subscriber can scurry to take the call -- or choose to ignore it.

HEADLINE: After Chavez, Farm Union Struggles to Find New Path

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COACHELLA, Calif.

 BODY:
Three decades after Cesar Chavez founded the United Farm Workers, which brought hope to thousands of impoverished laborers, the union is struggling for survival.
From the lemon groves in this desert community to the tomato fields outside Stockton in the San Joaquin Valley, many workers today toil under conditions not seen since the charismatic Mr. Chavez first took up their cause in a series of hunger strikes, boycotts, marches and protests in the 1960's and 1970's. 
 Mr. Chavez's death in April has thrown the organization into a leadership crisis that compounds an identity crisis that already existed: Should it spend its money and energy seeking support from middle-class consumers, or should it be in the field organizing and fighting on behalf of workers?
 
Boycott Ineffective
 Indicative of the union's lack of momentum is the fact that few Americans know that for the last six years it has been urging consumers to boycott grapes and that in that time grape sales reached record levels.
The union began the boycott to get grape growers to limit the use of pesticides. It contends that the growers use more "cancer and birth-defect causing pesticides" than any other California industry.
But the apparent ineffectiveness of the boycott has led some of the union's supporters to worry that Mr. Chavez may have left behind little more than his name. While that name is being liberally applied to things like streets, parks and holidays celebrating Mr. Chavez's birthday, these testimonials provide little for the workers on the front lines of the nation's food supply.
"You've really got abysmal conditions, conditions that are as bad as at any time in the post-war era," said Clete Daniel, a professor of American labor history whose book "Bitter Harvest" (University of California Press, 1981) records the California farm labor movement.
"It's hard to see any vestiges of the achievements of the 1970's," Professor Daniel said. "If you know all the struggle and sacrifice that occurred in the course of building the farm workers' union and see how few lasting gains have been achieved, it's very, very discouraging."
 
Economy in Slump
 The United Farm Workers today reports about 10,000 members, down from more than 70,000 in the 1970's. Illegal immigrants from Mexico and Central America, more willing to work in spite of low wages and poor conditions, have diluted the union's strength. And it does not help that the California economy remains in a slump despite an improving picture elsewhere in the nation.
While the union faces such large problems, conditions in the fields have become nearly as grim in many cases as they were before the union wrought improvements.
For example, union officials say, because of lax enforcement, children are again illegally being put to work harvesting crops and some growers are paying $2 an hour or less, in violation of Federal minimum wage laws. The labor contractors who supply growers with groups of workers in return for fees charge the workers exorbitant rates for rent, transportation and food. The infamous short-handled hoe, which forces workers to stoop for hours, has reappeared in some fields despite being banned by California law, and there are growing reports of sexual harassment of female workers by growers and labor contractors.
In addition, the union has been hit with a $2.9 million legal judgment resulting from an Arizona case in which a grower accused union leaders of illegal tactics in a boycott of the company's lettuce. The award could bankrupt the union, which has $2.5 million in assets, but U.F.W. officials say they are optimistic that it will be overturned on appeal.
 
Challenge for New Leader
 Confronted with so many problems, can the union's new president, Arturo Rodriguez, succeed where his father-in-law, Mr. Chavez, ran into obstacles.
"I alone could never think of replacing Cesar Chavez," Mr. Rodriguez said in an interview. "He's just an extraordinary human being. But I have a great team of people to work with. The rest of the leadership of the organization is very dedicated, very committed to wanting to see Cesar's dreams come true."
Mr. Rodriguez said Mr. Chavez's death, in a paradox, had helped the union, creating a resurgence of interest in it and in the welfare of farm workers. Many people, on learning of the boycott of table grapes, have volunteered to help promote it, he said.
In Los Angeles, officials recently agreed to rename Brooklyn Avenue, a main thoroughfare in heavily Hispanic East Los Angeles, Avenida Cesar Chavez. A new center for Chicano studies at the University of California at Los Angeles will be named for Mr. Chavez. The California Senate recently declared Mr. Chavez's birthday, March 31, a state holiday, and city leaders in Delano, Calif., Mr. Chavez's home and the site of the union's first headquarters, renamed a park for Mr. Chavez despite years of tension between the union and city officials.
"You would never believe that in Delano, Calif., you could go before the City Council and get any support for us," Mr. Rodriguez said. "And yet all of those things are becoming a reality for us. There's a tremendous rebirth taking place."
 
Some Gains Seen
 It remains to be seen whether interest can be sustained, and whether Mr. Rodriguez can translate the current revival of interest in the union into tangible gains in the fields. Already, some are complaining that Mr. Rodriguez is putting too much emphasis on public relations and not enough on organizing workers.
Mr. Rodriguez said the union had learned from experience that support from consumers was essential to bringing growers to the bargaining table. Thus a good part of the organization's resources are being spent on mailings, bumper stickers, buttons and videos to persuade people to stop buying grapes. Still, growers continue to report record harvests and sales.
"The fight needs to be conducted in the fields where the workers are," Professor Daniel said, "but more and more the effort is addressed to this boycott, to consumers and environmentalists and to people interested in the use of pesticides and the use of toxic chemicals in growing our food."
Experts said the union's primary message in the current boycott -- that pesticides threaten the health of consumers -- has not struck home in the way that public anger over farm working conditions fueled the successful boycotts of the 1960's and 1970's. And a new political climate combined with shifting attitudes toward unionism in general has not helped.
David Duarte, a 28-year-old native of Mexico, is a worker whom the union has helped. He earns a basic union wage of $5.25 and has health benefits, unemployment insurance and worker's compensation, thanks to a union contract.
Despite poor health and a cramped living situation -- he shares an apartment with his parents and seven siblings -- Mr. Duarte is grateful for the U.F.W.
"We have security," he said in Spanish during a recent union rally here. "We have stable work, and we have rights."

HEADLINE: Daley Is Bluntly Criticizing Clinton

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 11

 BODY:
Before the Illinois primary last year, Bill Clinton was so solicitous of Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago that he was defensive about his overtures. "I was not buttering up the Mayor!" the future President declared.
These days, no one, certainly not the Mayor, is accusing Mr. Clinton of buttering up Mr. Daley, a Democrat who has presided over the nation's third-largest city since 1989. 
 If anything, Mr. Clinton has brought only bad news to Mr. Daley and his brother. And the Mayor has responded with very blunt, and very public, critiques of the President.
In his harshest outburst, a few weeks ago at an impromptu gathering with reporters, Mr. Daley accused Mr. Clinton of breaking promises, not coming through for political allies and, perhaps most cutting of all, losing his political focus. "If he keeps backing off, the people will lose confidence in him," he said. "People want a strong leader. You have to stand for something."
 
Frustration in Other Cities
 Mr. Daley's remarks could be dismissed as lingering bitterness from a man whose younger brother was passed over for a Cabinet post. But they also reflect frustration with the White House even from Democrats whose cities stand to get far more attention than they did under the recent Republican administrations. While they were not as direct as Mr. Daley, several members of the United States Conference of Mayors at the group's annual meeting in New York last month chastised the President for not keeping his promises to cities.
Mr. Daley is not nearly as potent a force in national Democratic politics as was his father, Richard J. Daley, who ran what was considered the last large political machine in the country.
Though overshadowed by his father's storied political history, Richie Daley is not without power. While he did not endorse Mr. Clinton before last year's Illinois primary, he gave Mr. Clinton a much-needed boost, appearing with him at a press conference here. And the political skills of his brother, William Daley, a Chicago lawyer who ran the Clinton campaign in Illinois, were viewed as crucial in winning the state for Mr. Clinton in November.
 
Tension Over Cabinet Post
 The tension began in December, with word that William Daley would not be named Secretary of Transportation, a job that even Clinton aides agreed that he had been led to expect. Mayor Daley may have figured he could take solace in Federal financing for 1,000 new police officers in Chicago and $66 million in Federal block grants he anticipated Mr. Clinton would channel here. But when the President's plan to give the economy a quick boost was scuttled in Congress, such hopes vanished.
The last straw came in June when a protege of the Mayor, Richard Devine, was passed over for United States Attorney in Chicago. Acceding to the wishes of the two Illinois Senators, Carol Moseley Braun and Paul Simon, Mr. Clinton picked James Burns instead.
The next day, this city's plain-speaking Mayor could not hide his frustration with his President. "I don't care about appointments," he told the group of reporters. "I don't need appointments. What I need is money to put people to work and money for health-care programs and educational programs, which we were promised."
A few weeks later, sitting behind the desk that his father used when he ran this city for 22 years, Mr. Daley had cooled off. He insisted that he was not bitter over what happened to his brother, and that he understood that it was only custom for the President to nominate the Senators' choice.
 
No Regrets From Daley
 But the 51-year-old Mr. Daley, known for his political instincts, offered no regrets for what he viewed as a constructive assessment of a President whose success he wants.
"I just said: 'You have to make a decision. You have to get on with it,' " Mr. Daley said. "Because four years goes by very quickly. I was just sending a message. Basically, get your house in order."
It is a message that no doubt was heard in the White House, where Mr. Daley, who has maintained reasonably high popularity ratings, is considered an important ally.
Mr. Daley is "very important because he's somebody who really speaks for and has the political instincts of the average taxpayer in the city of Chicago," said David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who twice served as the Mayor's campaign manager. "Earning his continued support is important. Illinois was always just a rock for us. We need to keep it that way."
 
Trying to Smooth Relations
 So it was no surprise that Mr. Clinton sought to smooth things over with the Mayor's 45-year-old brother, inviting Bill Daley to play golf recently and appointing him to the board of the Federal National Mortgage Association Board.
David Axelrod, a close adviser to Mayor Daley who also worked for the Clinton campaign, said the Mayor's frustrations were largely based on his high expectations after 12 years of Republicans in the White House. "To reduce whatever frictions there have been to issues involving his brother would really be off base," Mr. Axelrod said. "There's 12 years of pent-up needs boiling out here and elsewhere."
Indeed, during an interview in his office here a few days ago, Mr. Daley could barely contain his impatience about the new Administration and how things get done or, more aptly, don't get done in Washington. Again and again, he returned to the theme of decision-making, offering practical advice from a hands-on manager.
Sounding much like Mr. Clinton's gadfly, Ross Perot, Mr. Daley derided Washington as a "company town" that has gone bankrupt. "Washington breeds incompetency," he said. "The more you stay in Washington, the more you're out of touch with reality."
 
Push for Improvement
 There is little polish from Richie Daley. No rehearsed lines. Ask him what Mr. Clinton should do to improve his operation, and he replies with a burst of suggestions, some, perhaps, naive: "A lot of things. First of all, I think the whole White House thing should be reorganized into a different system. He has the whole system that Bush and Reagan and Carter and Nixon created and kept it going. He needs more than one chief of staff. It's impossible!"
He did not, however, address the down side of having several chiefs of staff, like building more of the bureaucracy and poisonous competition that he said was destroying the Government.
And for someone so willing to give counsel, Mr. Daley seemed at times oddly out of touch. Asked whether David R. Gergen, the much publicized White House addition as Mr. Clinton's counselor, was a wise addition, Mr. Daley was speechless. Then he asked, "The Supreme Court?" Finally, an aide told Mr. Daley who David Gergen was.
Nevertheless, Mr. Daley says with confidence that he knows who could best run the Federal Government. "Mayors," he said, "see what can work and what cannot work. They see it on a daily basis."
What about Governors? Mr. Daley's reply may not please the former Governor of Arkansas: "They're too far removed."

The Media Business

HEADLINE: Politics Can Change Rapidly but Economics Can't

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, July 19

 BODY:
When President Clinton came here two weeks ago, he sensed a historic opportunity and pressed more aggressively than any of his predecessors for a breakup of the collusive forces that have made Japan such a frustrating market for United States companies.
Sunday's election did shatter the old political order, which was dominated by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party, but there was little immediate prospect that the economy would be thrown open to the same bracing jolt of change, or that Japan's trade surpluses would begin to shrink any time soon. 
 It could take years for United States companies to reap economic benefits from the upheaval because no party won a clear majority, and thus the prospect is for unstable coalitions and more frequent elections.
 
The Terms of Battle
 Sunday's election had been cast as a battle waged on numerous fronts, a conflict between the old generation and the new, a struggle to shed institutions designed for the cold war, an attempt to purge the governing Liberal Democratic Party of endemic corruption. Some even characterized it as a battle between the old tilt toward producers, which was based on the powerful alignment of interests between Government and business, and a new emphasis on consumers' interests.
The idea that consumers ought to be given the benefit of open markets and inexpensive imports was at the heart of President Clinton's pitch, as when he told a group of university students here, "You have a common cause with the people of America." Change, he insisted, "would benefit both of us."
One fact the election results have borne out is that the old leftist opposition forces are near collapse; the real struggle for influence is within an expanding, if fragmented, conservative movement.
 
Change, Yes, but Slowly, Slowly
 Though three new conservative parties emerged in the past year, each trying to distinguish its policies, they share certain assumptions with the Liberal Democrats about the basic strengths of the economy and why change has to be slow and careful.
"The outcome of the election this time will not affect trade relations in any meaningful way," said Takashi Inoguchi, a professor of politics at Tokyo University. "It will take some time. Any change is likely to be piecemeal."
For instance, the most powerful new party is the Japan Renewal Party, led by a former Finance Minister, Tsutomu Hata, who has called in vague terms for economic deregulation and decentralization.
But when he was asked directly last week if he thought the time had come to break the "iron triangle" that bound politicians, business and Government in a collusive embrace and that left consumers paying some of the highest prices in the world, he commented, "Producers are consumers, too, and we cannot forget their interests."
 
Common View on Security
 In some respects, the election results could draw the United States and Japan closer. On security issues, the Government has supported American policy for decades, but it has had to tread carefully for fear of inflaming the pacifist passions of the leftists in Parliament. Now, all the leading parties are conservative, generally favoring a strong security relationship with the United States and an active role for Japan in international affairs.
Thus, whether the Liberal Democrats remain in power as part of a coalition or not, the loudest opposition voices will be largely pro-American on security issues.
But President Clinton has stressed repeatedly that economic issues have replaced security and political concerns as the basis of the relationship, and so the new Government's trade policies are likely to be scrutinized with the greatest care by Washington.
The problem will be the pace of change. Japanese politicians and Government officials generally accept the fact that the trade surpluses are too large and that the regulatory regime that discriminated against outsiders has to change. The new conservative parties have pressed these themes with more energy than the Liberal Democrats did.
 
Fixing Domestic Economy First
 But the economy is stuck in a recession. With companies already vulnerable and profits plummeting, the Government is unlikely to open markets to fresh competition that could worsen the situation and risk Japanese jobs.
In addition, the bitter political struggles for power that are expected could leave the next several governments weak, making it even more difficult for politicians to override the overwhelmingly nationalistic instincts of the bureaucracy, the engineers and keepers of Japan's unusual economic system.
It could also mean that both the governing and opposition parties that emerge will be loath to upset potential contributors, with the prospect of another election in less than a year.
A key problem is the recession. The Government pushed through two big fiscal-stimulus packages in the past year, but they have had only a modest impact. Washington is demanding that the Government take further action swiftly: the faster the Japanese economy grows, the more imports it will absorb.
 
How to Spend Money
 While the bureaucrats in the Finance Ministry have been willing to increase public-works spending to try and jump-start the economy, they have staunchly refused to consider a tax cut, which would put money into the pockets of consumers. United States officials have been urging Japan to give consumers a tax break rather than pump money into the business community with contracts for new roads, bridges and sewage-treatment plants.
This could prove an early test of the pace at which the old assumptions that drive Japan Inc. will come into question, and how much benefit President Clinton will really reap from the political changes here.
Seiroku Kajiyama, the secretary general of the Liberal Democrats, still the largest party in Japan, seemed to anticipate such questions when he commented Sunday evening, "Any changes must be made within the framework of stability."

HEADLINE: As Campaign Warms, Dinkins Manager Is Cool, Calm and Directed

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Four years ago, Bill Lynch led David N. Dinkins to victory against a battle-weary Democratic incumbent -- and then on to become New York City's first black Mayor -- by coaching a hungry team of liberal outsiders from a Times Square building so seedy that his staff shared elevators with porno actresses between scenes.
The knock on him then: He was a roly-poly former labor organizer who was always behind schedule, refused to delegate or share strategy, and had never run such a big campaign. 
 Today Mr. Lynch is marshaling the Mayor's re-election effort from a 32d floor aerie in the polished Art Deco corridors of the old McGraw-Hill building on West 42d Street. The knock on him on now: He is a disorganized former deputy mayor who is always behind schedule, refuses to delegate or share strategy, and has never run a campaign to re-elect such a battle-weary incumbent.
"I took it then, I'll take it now," Mr. Lynch said evenly last week, shaking his head just a bit. "What I've got to be careful about is that it doesn't make me lose focus."
This potato farmer's son from the East End of Long Island is used to disproving his doubters, but he has surely never faced a bigger job. Mr. Dinkins is locked in a virtual tie in the early polls with his old Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been biding his time and building support.
The Mayor has to defend a tenure that happened to coincide with the worst national recession in half a century, in which the city lost some 400,000 jobs and City Hall repeatedly scrambled to keep the budget balanced with gum and toothpicks.
Having won in 1989 by two percentage points with a fragile multi-ethnic coalition on a promise of racial healing, Mr. Dinkins has been called to account for periods of violence in Crown Heights and Washington Heights. He is struggling to woo back defecting supporters, especially Hispanic voters who are now moving to Mr. Giuliani in large numbers.
 
A Blunt Approach
 Last week, under growing pressure, Mr. Dinkins sharply stepped up his criticisms of Mr. Giuliani, attacking his record as a prosecutor and accusing him of ducking the issues. It was an unusually blunt approach for any incumbent this early in an election -- especially for the circumspect Mr. Dinkins -- and a testament to the Mayor's challenge.
Mr. Lynch, who left his job as a deputy mayor to help run the Clinton campaign in New York State last year and then went on to the Mayor's campaign, knows the rap from friends and critics alike: The Mayor is insulated by the perks of power and doesn't see the people enough; he is too defensive in the face of criticism; the campaign is writing off skeptical white voters and counting on building up black turnout to win. Mr. Lynch just doesn't seem to be doing enough.
"I really think that the race is still the Mayor's to win, and there are many people who want him to," said City Councilwoman Joan Griffin McCabe, who represents a diverse district in Brooklyn that includes the Hispanic areas of Sunset Park, the housing projects of Red Hook and the gentrified brownstones of Park Slope -- all spots where the Mayor needs to do well. But she complains that Mr. Dinkins has not been visible enough.
 
Where Is the Mayor?
 "These people want to see the Mayor visit their neighborhoods, walk their streets, stop into their delis and their bodegas," she added. "That's all they want to do. They want to see that the Mayor cares about their blocks."
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge of the Upper West Side, strong Democratic and Dinkins turf, said her campaign workers this month had trouble getting voters to sign nominating petitions with Mr. Dinkins's name on them. "He's become so inaccessible, he's almost regal," she said. "You don't see him around. You see him on TV, which is unfortunately often in the evening and in a tuxedo. It is not an image of strength."
Some backers wonder whether Mr. Lynch is doing all he can to counteract these perceptions. "I don't see the evidence as to lots of sophisticated strategic thinking," said one strong Dinkins supporter, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Maybe it's all happening. You wouldn't necessarily expect to see it yet."
Such criticism of his boss's style hurts and baffles Mr. Lynch, who is responsible for making the most of Mr. Dinkins's strengths and minimizing his weaknesses. He ticks off a week's schedule of the Mayor's appearances to show that he is hardly in hibernation but stressing his incumbency and the powers that go with it.
 
The Long View
 It also seems likely that Mr. Lynch has been playing a bit of possum. He was willing to concede to Mr. Giuliani a moment of excitement and a wave of publicity in May when Mr. Giuliani persuaded Herman Badillo, the city's most prominent Hispanic politician, to drop out of the Democratic mayoral primary and run for Comptroller with Mr. Giuliani instead.
Mr. Lynch has always preferred the long game and he is banking on luring Democrats home to the Mayor's side in November by linking Mr. Giuliani to 12 years of Republican economic policies that hurt the city.
Only one criticism seems to really incense Mr. Lynch: the suggestions that the Mayor is writing off white voters. At the mention of that, he grabs a sheaf a computer runs and begins thumbing through tallies from 1989 in mostly white districts where Mr. Dinkins lost, but racked up respectable showings.
They include Councilman Anthony Weiner's district in the Midwood, Flatbush and Sheepshead Bay neighborhoods of Brooklyn, where Mr. Dinkins managed to pull 22 percent of the vote, or Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan's on Staten Island, where Mr. Dinkins took 32 percent.
"I'm not letting those go!" Mr. Lynch said, jabbing his finger onto the page for emphasis. "I think we might be able to do even better."
Part of the problem may be that Mr. Lynch does much of his best work very quietly. Two months ago, while Mr. Giuliani and his chief strategist, David Garth, were wooing Mr. Badillo, Mr. Lynch was busy with shuttle diplomacy of his own: across the Triborough Bridge to Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens County Democratic leader.
Mr. Manton was angry at a lack of access and jobs for party faithful at City Hall, so Mr. Lynch arranged a rapprochement with the Mayor. The unspoken gain: Mr. Manton leaned, hard, on his old friend, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, to drop out of the race, leaving Mr. Dinkins a clear march to the nomination, with only a token fight from Roy E. Innis.
"People say, 'What's he doing?' " Mr. Lynch said of his critics. "I think the record now shows what we were doing last spring: getting the kind of support we needed. As we move forward to the fall, I hope the same question will be asked and that the answer will be as clear."
 
Accentuate the Positive
 Just as he did four years ago, Mr. Lynch is concentrating on field work, backed by the Mayor's allies in organized labor, to turn out his core supporters, while preparing a broad appeal to New Yorkers through television commercials created by the Washington-based media consultants Robert Shrum and David Doak.
No one is talking yet about what those advertisements will say, but it's not hard to guess that they will emphasize the Mayor's having seen the city through tough times largely intact, while eking out small improvements around the edges, like increasing library hours to their maximum levels in half a century, hiring thousands more police officers and seeing declines in all major categories of reported crime.
Even the Mayor's critics say such a message, properly delivered, could have strong appeal.
"A large bloc of moderate and liberal Democratic voters are looking for a reason to support him, and so far he hasn't given them one," said Councilman Weiner, who acknowledges that he has been at odds with the administration for months. "But he has some salvageability. Even in areas where he is unpopular, no one is that thrilled about Rudy Giuliani."
The Rev. Al Sharpton, who met last week with the Mayor to complain that he hasn't given enough attention to energizing his black supporters, said: "I think the Mayor needs to do a crash reading of "A Tale of Two Cities' and divide his time between Manhattan and the outer borough communities -- black, Jewish, Latino, all of them. He's not in the churches, he's not in the housing projects, and unless he gets the message down there, the people are not going to reach up and grab it."
 
$100,000 in Small Bills
 Mr. Lynch says he is listening, but he is also just keeping on. There are stops to make, speeches to write and money to raise -- next at 200 small house parties on Tuesday night, at which each host has been asked to raise $500 or more from friends.
It's a Lynch event, with a new touch. At the last house parties, on the night of the Academy Awards, the telephone conference call hookup was so faint that most guests could not hear the Mayor. Now Mr. Lynch has a typical low-tech solution: For $300 he has bought 15 minutes of time on WWRL-FM, and the Mayor will address the guests over the air.
"We're colored," said Mr. Lynch, smiling softly at one of the self-mocking references to his race and aw-shucks reputation that he delights in using to catch his detractors off guard. "And smart."

HEADLINE: STUDIES SAY SOOT KILLS UP TO 60,000 IN U.S. EACH YEAR

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Several studies have concluded that tens of thousands of deaths are being caused in the United States each year by a form of air pollution that for the most part falls within current legal limits: tiny particles of soot that are inhaled.
Rough calculations emerging from studies at the Environmental Protection Agency and the Harvard School of Public Health suggest that 50,000 to 60,000 deaths a year are caused by the particle pollution, a far larger number than any other form of pollution and one that rivals the death toll from some cancers. 
 The deaths occur mostly among children with respiratory problems, people of all ages with asthma and the elderly with illnesses like bronchitis, emphysema and pneumonia.
 
Sources of Particles
 The new findings, disclosed gradually over the last two and a half years, will require environmental scientists and industries to re-evaluate their approaches to air pollution, and will probably require the Federal Government to rewrite its standard for particle pollution. The troublesome particles are mainly thrown into the air by industrial plants, with a small proportion coming from the exhausts of diesel vehicles.
Paul Portney, vice president of Resources for the Future, a not-for-profit environmental research group, said that of the $35 billion a year the nation spends for all its scrubbers, catalytic converters and other air-pollution control efforts, only a fraction is directed toward the small particles, which are 10 microns or smaller in diameter. (By comparison, a human hair is about 75 microns in diameter.)
Only one-third of all air pollution expenditures go to remove particles, and most of that goes to decades-old efforts like devices on power plants that catch only particles larger than 10 microns in diameter.
 
Need to Review Standard
 Regulatory effort has been focused more on other types of pollution, like ozone and sulphur dioxide, that have been shown to damage health; it is uncertain whether they cause death. It is believed that indoor air pollution like second-hand cigarette smoke and radon cause the greatest health damage among pollutants, apart from the particles. Each is estimated to cause 5,000 or more cancers a year.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment, said: "The E.P.A. must now undertake a thorough review of the particle standard. The agency under the Bush Administration never even got started with the legal requirements that this standard be reviewed. By law it should have been finished last year."
Ronald H. White, director of environmental health for the American Lung Association, said the evidence for deaths due to particle pollution was now great enough that the association would soon sue the E.P.A. in hope of getting the agency to revise its standard and begin stricter enforcement of it.
But some scientists say the evidence is not yet good enough to make policy decisions. The evidence is based on epidemiological studies, which cannot conclusively establish a cause-and-effect relation between a substance and its health effect; for that, detailed biological studies of the effect of substances on the tissues themselves are needed.
Dr. Jonathan Samet of the University of New Mexico said: "What is missing is understanding the biological basis of the effect they are describing. We shouldn't make major policy decisions about causes of death based on the kind of evidence we have so far.
"The effects are not massive, not like the London fog of 1952 in which thousands of people died, but are more subtle. Before we make the big decision to control particles more, with the costs of doing that, we need to fill out the story more. We need to do actual exposure studies with people to see how particles affect them."
Dr. Samet said he believed that there still might be other ways of explaining the deaths linked to pollution -- for example, combinations of factors like respiratory illness, coming with a heat wave, at the same time as a pollution episode.
 
'Need for More Data'
 Rob D. Brenner, chief of policy in the E.P.A.'s air pollution office, said: "We have a real concern about the new data. If it turns out that recent analyses show that particles are the much more significant problem than they seemed to be, our efforts to control particles and our acid rain initiatives will not be enough. We will have to do more." But he added that there was now a debate within the agency about what to do.
The E.P.A. missed last year's deadline to review and update the particle standard. It appears that unless a significant policy change occurs soon, the delay will continue for some time.
"One of the things we feel on the research side very strongly is the need for more data," said Dr. Peter W. Preuss, the E.P.A.'s director of policy for the Office of Research and Development. But because of limited manpower in agency laboratories, he said, "I'm not sure we are going to do any of that research soon."
In early budget estimates, the E.P.A. has not set aside money to review the particle standard for the next fiscal year, but the agency is planning to spend $10 million to revise the ozone standard.
Particles have been among the most obvious and longest-known forms of pollution. During times of stagnant air, the particles make a haze or fog that blankets cities or rural valleys. Such pollution has been recorded as early as the 17th century in England. Among the most famous episodes was the London pea soup of 1952 that killed 4,000 people in a few days.
 
Difficult to Study
 But particle pollution has been relatively neglected and difficult to study. Particles of all kinds are in air, so the polluted substance that must be studied is "urban air," a hodgepodge with clumps that vary in size and chemical makeup and that change from one location to another and from day to day.
This makes for a messy experiment when researchers try to expose animals to "urban air" in a laboratory. In addition, it has been difficult to separate the components of air pollution because sulfur dioxide, ozone and soot all tend to be pumped into the air together and are present when samples are taken.
Thus, until now, particle pollution has been relatively neglected while other types of pollution like ozone and sulfur dioxide have been much scrutinized.
The discovery that particles are the worst type of air pollution was eventually made because of several coincidences.
There is believed to be only one place in the United States that has a very large amount of pollution that is made up almost entirely of particles, while being low in ozone and sulfur dioxide. In this place, Utah Valley, there is only one large source of pollution, a steel mill, which was operated continuously for years, then shut down for a year because of a strike, and then turned on again.
Because the area has long had hospital admission records and others computerized, the Utah Valley has become sort of an experiment designed specifically to discover the effect of particle pollution.
Into this ready-made experiment came Dr. C. Arden Pope 3d, an environmental economist at Texas A & M University who moved to Provo, Utah, a few years ago.
 
Brown Cloud in the Sky
 "It was clear that Utah Valley had a pollution problem," Dr. Pope said. "I could see it in the air: in the winter time there is a combination fog and smog, sort of a brown cloud hanging in the air."
Dr. Pope checked hospital admissions before, during and after the steel mill strike, and compared those to the level of small particles in the air. This kind of pollution is the most worrisome because it can be breathed into the lungs; it consists of particles 10 microns or smaller in diameter.
He saw that the admissions to the hospital for respiratory-related illnesses like pneumonia and asthma jumped 50 percent to 90 percent during the times the particle pollution was above 50 micrograms of breathable particles for each cubic meter of air, and dropped when the plant was closed and fewer particles were in the air. The Federal Government's standard does not consider air hazardous until it reaches 150 micrograms of such particles per cubic meter.
At the E.P.A., Dr. Joel Schwartz, the lone epidemiologist among scores of toxicologists, noticed the report, which was published in The American Journal of Public Health.
Dr. Schwartz also found that another scientist, Dr. Douglas W. Dockery of the Harvard School of Public Health, had carried out studies of daily pollution levels in six Eastern cities. There, the particle pollution had been measured every day, an unusually good record since the Federal Government requires only one measurement a week.
Soon the three scientists were working together, carrying out their own studies in Utah; Steubenville, Ohio, and Philadelphia, as well as digging up data from other cities.
 
Decline in Lung Capacity
 In Utah, further studies found that children's breathing, as measured by a spirometer, was reduced when particle measurements were high: they lost about 6 percent of capacity if the pollution went up to the legal limit of 150 micrograms. They found a decline of about 3 percent in lung capacity of adults for each 100 micrograms measured in the air.
The three scientists also found that the death rate in Utah rose in proportion to particles in the air, on a steady slope in which each 100 micrograms of particle pollution increased the death rate 16 percent.
The pollution during this period was steadily below the legal limit, and averaged 47 micrograms, less than a third of the Federal standard.
They also found that particles were directly linked to health effects and the increasing or decreasing of ozone or sulfur dioxide were not.
 
Steady Rise in Deaths
 The scientists also noted that the effects of high particle levels were noted immediately, on the first day of high levels, and trailed off after several days of lower levels.
In Steubenville, from 1974 to 1984, they found a steady rise in deaths of 4 percent for every 100 micrograms of particle pollution, at the same time no association was found with ozone pollution.
In St. Louis, deaths increased 16 percent for each 100 micrograms of particles, and in a study in East Tennessee, deaths increased 17 percent for each 100 micrograms. In both these studies, death rates were increased somewhat in association with sulfur dioxide and ozone, but at levels far smaller than the association with particles.
One of the largest studies, looking at particle pollution and deaths between 1973 and 1980 in Philadelphia, found that deaths increased about 7 percent for each 100 micrograms of particles, and 5 percent with each 100 micrograms of sulfur dioxide.
All of the studies were designed to take into account other factors that might have explained lung problems, including other pollutants, smoking, and extremely hot or cold weather.
Despite the apparent large threat of particle pollution, Dr. Schwartz said he was optimistic that the E.P.A. could reduce the pollution with relatively small economic damage to the country.
"If we consider how much protection we can get for our money, we can do a lot with a relatively small investment," Dr. Schwartz said. He said that taking particles out of smoke stack emissions was relatively cheap, and some newer devices like "bag houses," filter-lined bags like vacuum cleaner bags, now can draw as much as 99 percent of particles out of the air without companies having to expend great sums on catalytic converters.

HEADLINE: For Microsoft's Rivals, It's a Question of Fairness

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16

 BODY:
Is the software industry leader Bill Gates accountable to a higher authority? Look for an answer this week, when the Federal Trade Commission is expected to consider longstanding industry complaints that the Microsoft Corporation competes unfairly.
For years rivals of the Microsoft have groused publicly and privately that the company and its chairman, William H. Gates, have used hardball tactics to dominate the software business. They say Microsoft has unfairly leveraged its near monopoly in personal computer operating system software, linking it with sales of its spreadsheet, word-processing and other application software that faces greater competition. They also accuse the company of nefarious pricing schemes. And they even contend that Mr. Gates has inserted devious code into his programs to make non-Microsoft programs incompatible with the company's products. 
 But proving these charges has been difficult.
 
February Deadlock
 After investigating Microsoft for two years, the F.T.C. deadlocked in a February vote on whether to charge Microsoft with violations of antitrust laws and directed its staff to re-study the matter. A second vote by F.T.C. commissioners is scheduled for Wednesday, and industry executives expect another deadlock, even though the F.T.C. staff is said to have prepared a narrower case against Microsoft this time -- reportedly in hopes of persuading the commissioners to take action against the company.
Many in the industry believe that in February, the F.T.C. staff was recommending against Microsoft for its pricing practices. This time, many believe, the case may have been narrowed to the issue of whether Microsoft designed its popular Windows program to discourage customers from using a rival operating system.
There are four possible outcomes to the commission's vote: close the case, delay action once again, begin a formal investigation or file a criminal complaint.
In February the commission deadlocked 2-to-2 with a fifth member, Roscoe B. Starek 3d, recusing himself because of an undisclosed financial conflict. Now, industry executives say, if Mr. Starek continues to abstain from voting, the swing vote will belong to Mary L. Azcuenaga, a commissioner who joined the F.T.C. as a Reagan Administration appointee and was reappointed by President Bush. In the first vote, she was one of two commissioners voting not to take action against Microsoft, but primarily because she said she needed more information.
Despite her Republican background, Ms. Azcuenaga attended a "renaissance weekend" retreat last winter held by President-elect Clinton, and she is reported to have developed close ties to the Clinton Administration. And so, many in Washington and in the software industry will be watching Ms. Azcuenaga's vote as a possible indicator of White House thinking on the case.
For an Administration that says it is committed to supporting United States high-technology industries, Microsoft could represent a potent symbol -- though whether as an exemplar or a predator is a matter of debate.
"The United States software industry still holds 90 percent of the worldwide market," said Lucianne Painter, a financial analyst at Salomon Brothers. "Are you going to disrupt that kind of success story given what's going on with the economy?"
 
'I'm Very Concerned'
 And yet, Microsoft's success has raised feelings of deep bitterness in the computer industry, along with questions about how the company has consolidated its power.
"I'm very concerned about Microsoft's position and conduct," said Charles Ferguson, an industry consultant and author of a recent book on I.B.M. titled "Computer Wars." "There's substantial evidence that they are a ruthless and powerful company and that they skirt the margins of ethical behavior if not crossing them."
Mr. Gates was not available for comment on Friday because he was on a plane to Washington to meet with F.T.C. officials to defend his company. And his general counsel, William Neukom, was already huddling with the F.T.C.
Microsoft has consistently denied accusations of unfair dealing, and it has said that its strategy of offering steep discounts on its software when sold as a package of several products is a common practice in the industry.
The last few months have seen aggressive lobbying of the F.T.C. by Microsoft's competitors. The Novell Corporation, whose chairman, Ray Noorda, has been an outspoken Microsoft opponent, has led the opposition, employing two Washington law firms and, more recently, a well-connected Washington public relations firm, in an effort to influence the commission's evaluation of Microsoft.
 
Congressional Interest
 There has also been Congressional interest lately. On Tuesday, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, fired off a letter to the five F.T.C. commissioners as well as to Anne K. Bingaman, the head of the Justice Department Antitrust Division. He bluntly suggested that it would be a waste of the taxpayers' money to have spent three years investigating Microsoft only to wind up again with a tie vote and no decision.
"If the commission remains deadlocked," Senator Metzenbaum wrote to Janet D. Steiger, the chairman of the F.T.C., "I would strongly urge you to refer the case to the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division for an independent review."
But such a change in venue is highly unlikely, some longtime antitrust experts say.
"It's possible at some point an asteroid will hit the earth," said Art Amolsch, editor of FTC Watch, a Washington-based newsletter. "It's possible that this could get moved to Justice. We're looking at the same odds."
Mr. Amolsch said that if the Justice Department was to take up the case, Microsoft could cry foul. "It amounts to harassment if two agencies of the Federal Government successively investigate a company for the same issue," he said.
But already, the Microsoft issue seems to be a moving target. According to a number of industry executives, the original F.T.C. staff report focused on a variety of matters, including allegations that Microsoft engaged in "exclusive dealing" by pricing its MS-DOS operating system in such a way that compels its customers to use other Microsoft products.
Now the staff's comments to the commissioners appear instead to focus on Windows 3.1, a popular Microsoft program that works with MS-DOS.
Several industry executives said F.T.C. staff members have been questioning Microsoft about a small piece of software code in a test version of the Windows program. The code issued a warning when outside programmers tried to run the program with DR-DOS, a Novell operating system that is intended to be compatible with MS-DOS.
The warning said that the operating system had not been tested for compatibility with other companies' operation systems. The piece of software was left in the version of Windows that Microsoft shipped to the public in 1992, although it had been disabled so that the warning did not appear on users' computer screens.

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Sheepshead Bay at Odds on a Waterfront Proposal

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Of all the transformations and evolutions that New York City neighborhoods have undergone in the last century, few are as stark as that of Sheepshead Bay.
This is a place where Sousa played, where the wealthy raced horses, where at least one America's Cup-winning yacht was berthed and where the first trans-Atlantic phone call was placed. 
 But it was also the place where Robert Moses put the Belt Parkway, bisecting a community and leaving wounds that many think have never healed. Today, there are burned-out storefronts, rat-infested vacant lots and almost no place to park. Residents suggest a car-theft ring may be the most thriving local enterprise.
 
'This Is the Crossroads'
 Against that backdrop one might expect that a proposal to build a new Loehmann's store, a discount seller of high-quality women's clothes, would be welcomed with open arms.
But it hasn't worked out that way.
Loehmann's wants to build its store directly across the street from the fishing boat pier that provides Sheepshead Bay with a center of commerce and a sense of self. Supporters say it is the first good news in years, perhaps the last chance to reverse the neighborhood's decline. Opponents say it will kill the fishing boat industry, tourism and the neighborhood's special flavor.
"If being at the crossroads means more of nothing or the hope of something, this is the crossroads," said Jesse Masyr, the lawyer for the developer promoting Loehmann's.
Glistening just beyond the debate's edges is the hope of reviving one of the community's great treasures, Lundy Brothers restaurant. Though it closed 14 years ago, both supporters and opponents of Loehmann's envision different paths to reopening what the city Landmarks Commission in 1991 called "the last of the great seafood palaces."
"It would be like the Dodgers coming back to Brooklyn," declared George Pantelidis, one of five owners of the Spanish Colonial Revival building that once housed the restaurant.
Mr. Pantelidis, who is among the supporters of Loehmann's, believes that a project of its size could jumpstart Sheepshead Bay's stalled economy by making banks more comfortable about lending to others.
City and state development agencies have extended $3 million in loan guarantees to reopen Lundy's if Mr. Pantelidis and his partners can arrange the $10 million to $12 million in private financing they estimate will be needed to rebuild the restaurant. But he thinks the Loehmann's proposal is essential to obtaining the private loans.
Loehmann's opponents take the opposite view. They think Lundy's has a better chance of reopening if their vision of a quaint, city-subsidized fishing village materializes.
The foes of Loehmann's include environmentalists, planning purists, civic groups and businesses fearing the waterfront store development will come at the expense of other businesses a few blocks away. But the most vocal are the owners of so-called party boats, which take people on deep-sea fishing trips for $28 a day.
"Don't pull the plug on Sheepshead Bay," George Richford, president of the Sheepshead Bay Fishing Fleet, told the Board of Standards and Appeals, the city agency that will rule on Loehmann's request for a zoning variance. "Fish and women's clothes don't mix."
Loehmann's would be directly across from the boats at Emmons Avenue and East 21st Street. The developer, Anthony Clemenza, intends to charge the 85-store national chain a very low rent, using the store as an anchor to attract smaller stores at much higher rents a square foot.
"This is going to be the rebirth of the Bay," said Mr. Clemenza, who failed to secure city approval in an earlier effort to build a condominium complex on the same property.
 
Dispute Over Parking
 John Nikas, chairman of Community Board 15, which supports Loehmann's, says he has already received inquiries from a sporting goods store, boutiques and restaurants wanting to be near Loehmann's.
Opponents rail that a Loehmann's would destroy the community by swallowing up what few parking spaces remain for party boat patrons, kill other nearby retailers and obliterate any chance of the fishing village dream. Loehmann's says its plans include adequate parking, which it is prepared to further increase by moving to attendant parking to use space more intensively.
But foes also see the debate as an opportunity. "For heaven's sake, let's keep the community's spirit going," said Myrtle G. Whitmore, president of the Brooklyn Civic Council, a consortium of cultural, educational, civic and professional groups.
The most tangible evidence of this community spirit is a planning document prepared by the Bay Improvement Group and presented as a bound volume to a number of city agencies. The idea is to replicate the sort of waterfront developments done in cities like San Diego, Vancouver and Boston, not unlike a proposal Mayor Edward I. Koch championed unsuccessfully in the mid-1980's. Quaint stores would hew to nautical themes, kiosks would offer shells and saltwater taffy, signs would denote special crossing areas for fishermen, and so on. A rejuvenated Lundy's would be the piece de resistance.
All that is needed, said Steven Barrison, president of the organization, is for the city to kick in $10 million or $15 million to get things going.
The issue is all coming to a head at the appeals board, which has held one hearing and has another scheduled on Tuesday. The matter before the board is whether to allow a building of more than 27,000 square feet in a zone where 3,500 square feet is the biggest store allowed. A decision may take months.
While the fate of Loehmann's and Lundy's hangs fire, it is clear that residents have not given up on their community. One sign is the Sheepshead Bay Beautification Project, whose 200 members have raised $20,000 in small contributions.
Its first big projects is to paint fanciful murals on the plywood covering Lundy's shattered windows, in part to give an impression of local spirit.
"It's an old-fashioned barn raising," said Peter Romeo, president of the group.
