HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
The Long Bond's Magic Numbers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
What will derail the rally that has carried the yield on the 30-year bond to its lowest level in 16 years, within a whisper of 6.50 percent? Not much, two market economists say.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, predicts that the long bond's yield will reach 6.50 percent soon, and then "grind" its way lower. But he thinks it will take some "unexpected event" to test 6 percent. 
 Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, is more optimistic. He is "holding out for 5.99 percent," which, he acknowledges, would not be significantly different from 6.01 percent. But sounding as though he was marketing his own forecast, he said that 5.99 percent sounds much more dramatic.
On Friday, news that consumer confidence fell in July and that industrial production declined two-tenths of 1 percent helped drive down the yield on the 30-year bond, the United States Treasury's benchmark credit instrument, another few notches. It finished the week at 6.54 percent.
 
Plenty of Encouraging Data
 For Mr. Lipsky, the force that would pull yields lower is an improvement in expectations about inflation. The market, he said, does not need more evidence that the economy is sluggish, or even more encouraging price data than was reported for June, when producer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent and consumer prices were unchanged.
"If investors began to believe that current inflation rates were sustainable in the intermediate term," he said, "rates would fall further."
He could not think of an "unexpected event" that might push the yield below 6 percent. But if there were such a development, the way he thinks the market is now leaning -- against lower interest rates -- it would provoke a quick drop in rates.
Mr. Lipsky said many traders have been reluctant to believe that rates would continue to fall. "This has been a very grudging rally," he said. "It has been very cautious and the Street has been short," an allusion to traders' not buying bonds because they think that rates are already too low.
 
And for Lower Rates Yet . . .
 But he said developments like these would add to downward pressure on rates:
*Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, makes his semiannual report to Congress on Tuesday on the central bank's monetary policy. Mr. Lipsky thinks that Mr. Greenspan's testimony will reaffirm the Fed's anti-inflation emphasis. Approval of President Clinton's deficit-reduction package, including tax increases that would restrain the economy, would further reduce the threat of inflation.
*Congressional approval of the free-trade agreement with Mexico would reduce fears in general of the kind of trade protectionism that can lead to higher prices and higher inflation.
*Further currency turmoil in Europe and the expected further cuts in interest rates by European central banks could provide more pressure to lower American interest rates, as the Germans try to restart their slumping economy and keep the European Monetary System together. Both rate cuts and currency turmoil ought to help the dollar rise, he said, with a stronger dollar attracting foreign investors to the American bond market.
Mr. Lipsky has a caveat. He is worried that there will soon be a selloff in the market as it pauses for a normal correction after the strong price rise and yield decline took the market into rarely charted waters.
 
Federal Funds Rate Stability
 For Mr. Soss of First Boston, there are two forces behind his forecast of a 5.99 percent yield on the 30-year bond over the next six months. One is the continued sluggishness of the economy and the other is his belief that the Fed will keep short-term interest rates stable for longer than most analysts expect.
"The economy cannot get out of its own way enough to prevent rates from falling further," he said, "and the Federal funds rate is locked at 3 percent."
Mr. Soss is confident that economic growth is going to remain sluggish -- his estimate is an annualized 3 percent for the second half of the year -- because, he said, interest rates, after adjustments for inflation or for current expectations, are still pretty stiff. He noted that with producer prices three-tenths of a percent lower in June, financing inventories of goods entails a loss, making businesses reluctant to fill their warehouses and thus holding down production.
"Why hold anything in inventory if there is a negative carry?" he asked. "You can't have the exuberance of a speculative inventory, and that is why rates keep coming down."
 
Mortgages and Jobs
 He suggested that there was a similar problem with housing sales, despite the lowest mortgage rates in decades. People just do not have confidence that they will still have a job, that their salaries will be going up at the 7 percent rate now typical for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, or that the value of their house will rise enough to cover the 7 percent interest, he said.
On the Federal funds rate, Mr. Soss believes that the central bank will leave it at the current 3 percent, its level since September. The Fed uses this key rate, which is the interest charged on overnight loans between banks, to set its monetary policy.
A reason not to change the Federal funds rate, he said, is the sluggishness of current growth, with the economy apparently creeping along at an annual rate of less than 2 percent for the first half of the year. Two months ago, with fear of renewed inflation, many analysts were betting that the Fed would raise this rate by the fall.
In addition, there will be more reason to keep this rate stable because tax increases in the deficit-reduction plan and implied in a Clinton Administration health-care proposal will restrain potential growth.
"You've got a tax increase that will kick in just in time for Christmas," Mr. Soss said. "And then health-care reform to follow."

HEADLINE: Economists' Advice for Clinton

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's promise to focus on the economy "like a laser beam" created great expectations among the nation's economists. But in the six months since his inauguration, many of them have been sounding increasingly disenchanted with his policies.
Some say the President promised and did not deliver. Others, who thought his can-do approach would bolster confidence and provide the economy with a catalyst, complain that uncertainties, backpedaling and prospects of much higher taxes have sown fear and confusion among business and consumers. 
 "We've moved from one President who seemed to be out of touch to another President who is also out of touch with what's needed in the economy," said Stephen F. Hiebsch, manager of economic research at the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company in Oklahoma City, who said he voted for President Clinton because of campaign promises to focus on business investment, education and the nation's roads, bridges and other support systems.
 
A Program Off Track?
 While some economists defend the budget now on Capitol Hill as a big step toward taming the Federal deficit, many complain that the economic program -- from the budget to health care to trade -- has veered seriously off track.
To be sure, economists are no less fickle than other Americans. Some of the unhappiness probably reflects disappointment in the President's limited power to get things done: to date, the Administration has found trouble getting its way in Congress. Paul Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Nobel laureate in economics and a longtime Democrat, has said, "You've got a President with no influence."
Further, the Administration is stuck with an economy that, while expanding at a modest pace, is struggling to overcome the lingering effects of overbuilt real estate, military cuts and feeble growth in the rest of the world.
Still, said Richard T. Curtin at the University of Michigan, who tracks consumers' moods, "It's the lost opportunity that's frustrating." He acknowledged that the President cannot deliver fast-paced, 1960's-style economic growth, but said there was enough room "to move from a stop-and-go expansion to one that proceeds more steadily."
What do the economists want the President to do? Three themes emerge over and over again: pare or postpone tax increases while pushing for tougher, more enforceable spending caps; go slower on health-care changes, and push harder for the free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada.
What many of them say they do not want, even if politically feasible, is to revive the $30 billion stimulus plan that was supposed to give the economy an immediate shot in the arm but was shot down by Congress earlier this year.
"Hands off would be better," said Alan Sinai, managing director of Lehman Brothers. "Let the economy work out the kinks. We're simply going to have to live with what growth the economy can produce."
Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University, said, "Most economists don't want the Administration to prime the pump, to just go out and spend."
On the budget, the concern is not only that a big tax increase could hurt economic growth next year, but that it would fail to bring the deficit under control.
Of course, the President's options are limited because the House and Senate have already passed their versions of the budget. But as the differences between the two versions are hammered out, he does have some room to press for smaller tax increases that would take effect at a later date than in the House version of the bill.
 
Calling the Whole Thing Off
 Some economists take an even stronger stand, urging the Administration to forget the current budget package. "The best thing they can do for the economy is to figure out a politically acceptable way to walk away from the program even if it meant less deficit reduction," said Ed Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. Raising taxes, said Mr. Yardeni, is likely to weaken the economic recovery without necessarily solving the deficit problem.
Many of the economists in this camp, however, did not buy the original Clinton plan, and remain opposed as much for ideological reasons as for fear that the recovery is unacceptably weak.
Still, few economists are willing to go so far, largely because they fear that interest rates would jump if the Administration failed to get a deal. And because the broad outlines of both bills -- higher top income-tax rates and a 35 percent corporate tax -- are similar, they urge the Administration to tinker around the edges.
"The most important thing is to get the budget passed, and erase the uncertainty," said Laurence H. Meyer, who runs an economic consulting firm with that name in St. Louis. "You don't turn back."
In fact, he and others said the President's biggest impact on the economy so far has come not from programs themselves, but from the waiting.
"There's no question Clinton confusion is slowing the economy," said Mr. Ratajczak at Georgia State.
Worried that higher corporate taxes will undermine business investment in new plant and equipment, one of the few sources of strength in the economy, several economists want the Administration to minimize increases in the tax burden on smaller businesses.
"Even if it means a little less deficit reduction, the best package may be one that restores some of the growth provisions," said Jerry Jasinowski, an economist who is president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "If you have to make trade-offs at the margin, you are better off not increasing business taxes that will stifle growth and jobs."
Charles Wolf, dean of the Rand Corporation's graduate school and director of economic research at Rand's National Defense Institute in Santa Monica, Calif., said he would favor a bill from the conference committee that "has more of the investment incentives and less of just raising taxes."
At the same time, some economists are pushing for toughening the procedures in the budget for enforcing limits on spending growth. "It will help to have a President who says he supports the concept of spending caps and I'll be faithful to them," Mr. Meyer said. "That would increase dramatically the credibility of the whole thing."
Many economists say a Clinton health-care program is an even bigger source of uncertainty for most businesses because it may involve higher payroll taxes. There is growing sentiment among economists that the Administration should go slower on the issue -- and proceed with far greater care.
"This is too important to do fast," Mr. Meyer said. "We're changing health care. This is one of the most important bills in recent history, and it's only reasonable that it be a consensus solution."
Referring to the Administration's tough talk on health-care changes, Rudolph Penner, an economist at KPMG Peat Marwick and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said: "Their first rule should be 'thou shalt do no harm.' People have been particularly careless; they have not been sensitive to the damage they can cause to businesses with remarks about price controls here and payroll taxes there."
Some economists also spoke of the potentially stimulative effects of increased trade, saying the President should be pressing harder for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"I would like to see this free-trade agreement pushed real hard," said Mr. Hiebsch of Oklahoma Gas and Electric. "If free trade is good between Texas and New York and between Kansas and Oklahoma, I can't believe free trade wouldn't be good between Mexico, Canada and the U.S."
Diane Swonk, senior regional economist and vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, agreed. "Nafta is our insurance policy that Mexico doesn't back off from its reforms," she said. "Without it, medium and small exporters get locked out. What we're hearing from our customers is that the uncertainty has already slowed a lot of momentum."

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Electricity Consumption

 BODY:
The heat wave this month will raise overall electricity consumption in the region above last year's levels, according to utilities officials. Demand for electricity fell last year, after a rise the year before, a year that also had unusually hot summer. Three-fifths of that decline came in residential use, which is chiefly affected by use of air conditioners. Generally, the troubled economy has moderated residential usage, which rose through the 1980's as consumers bought larger homes, many of them with central air conditioning, and acquired personal computers, microwaves, color TVs and other consumer appliances.

HEADLINE: Cable Outduels Free TV

 BODY:
Congressional efforts to help broadcast television may be thwarted if the first two deals negotiated under last year's Federal cable law are any indication.
Congress was alarmed by the decline of free TV and eager to pump money to local TV stations. So it required cable operators to negotiate with broadcasters for permission to carry their signals. Now cable retransmits those signals for free. 
 But if Congress hoped to aid broadcasters, it created a peculiar mechanism for doing so. A sole cable operator would bargain separately with the network-affiliated and independent broadcasters in each region. Monopolists usually win such bargains, and the first two deals prove the point.
First, the Fox network signed a deal with Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator. Under the agreement, T.C.I. will continue to carry Fox broadcasts for free. But T.C.I. will pay Fox to create a new cable channel and Fox will also turn over some of the proceeds to its affiliates.
It's easy to get wrapped up in a game of whether cable or broadcasters won. But the important issue is whether viewers won. In this case, they have. Fox affiliates, many of which are small and struggling, get financial help and, in addition, viewers get a new cable channel.
But the deal announced last week between ABC and Continental Cablevision, the nation's third largest cable operator, is more troubling. Again, the cable operator will continue to retransmit signals without paying the network-owned broadcaster. And, again, the cable operator will pay the network -- ABC -- to create a new cable channel, in this case devoted to sports.
The deal should help the ABC network. But local affiliates come away with no money and may lose viewers to the new cable station. And more sports will probably migrate from free TV to cable. To a Congress that set out to help save free television, this deal is at best a mixed blessing.
The ABC-Continental deal delivers a potentially crippling blow to CBS and NBC in their coming negotiations. With ABC on the Continental system, the other two networks can hardly afford to withhold their signal in search of a big payoff. Again, Congress's will may be thwarted.
Negotiations continue between broadcasters and cable operators. The outcomes could turn sour for cable viewers if negotiations break down and one or more of the networks are dropped. But viewers will also lose if local broadcasters don't come away with cash or other economic benefits and free TV continues to slide. Over-the-air TV -- with its coverage ranging from traumatic events like the Kennedy assassination to entertainment like the World Series -- is an important social glue that binds Americans together.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
The Edge Of the Wave

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Here and elsewhere in East Asia the visiting American feels as if he is at the edge of an enormous wave of growing prosperity and power. We know about the economic success of Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and South Korea. But to see it up close -- to see how far and how fast it has come -- is astonishing.
Just a few decades ago, Hong Kong was a place filled with struggling refugees from Maoist China. Today the annual per capita income is $18,000, moving past that of Britain and other European countries. People live longer here than in the United States, and infant mortality is lower. 
 Hong Kong has some of the most architecturally arresting skyscrapers anywhere, notably Norman Foster's Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank.
Hong Kong's businessmen and bankers are moving heavily into China. Last year Hong Kong money accounted for 60 percent of all foreign investment in China.
China is the great question that looms behind the dazzling sights of Hong Kong and the rest. It, too, has had phenomenal economic growth in the last few years. If that continues, and the present inflationary overheating of the economy can be controlled, one can easily foresee East Asia becoming the leading force in the world economy. Japan would be only part of a larger success story.
But of course the question about China is more than economic. It is political: Can the People's Republic, still nominally professing Communism, allow the degree of autonomy needed for an innovative society? Will the Government hold to the course of reform to a market system; or may it, in fear of losing power, launch one of the waves of brutal repression that have occurred periodically since the revolution?
Uncertainty about China is a factor in just about everyone's life here. For Hong Kong reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. And despite the great mixing of money and people in recent years -- 20 million crossings to China last year from Hong Kong, which has a population of less than 6 million -- profound differences remain between the two societies.
"We speak a common language, and we share a common history," said Christine Loh, whose family has been in Hong Kong for five generations. "But we are worlds apart.
"China is in some ways a medieval country. They are still trying to grow by edict. We are modern, professional, international. China now has no sense of its own moral values: nothing but get rich quick. We in Hong Kong do have a moral basis, the values of the rule of law."
Ms. Loh is an unusually outspoken person in a place where many are already muting their voices for fear of offending Beijing. A highly successful businesswoman, she was appointed by the British Governor, Chris Patten, to Hong Kong's Legislative Council. Did she think she would still be there after 1997? I asked.
"If I am," she said, "they will be allowing a few cats to meow. The Legislative Council will be the loyal opposition in Hong Kong if we have our promised 'autonomy.' Beijing will have to learn that opposition is not counterrevolution."
But was there any real chance that Beijing would allow that kind of vocal opposition?
"Yes," Ms. Loh said, "if Beijing wants Hong Kong to be the engine of growth, the merchant banker for China. It's what the world defines as 'autonomy' that matters. If the world regards Hong Kong as just another part of China, why should it continue to have preferential status in GATT and 30 other international arrangements?"
Ms. Loh supports Governor Patten's plans to make the Legislative Council modestly more democratic, which have aroused Chinese fury. But she is skeptical of British intentions.
"No matter how engaging Chris Patten is," she said, "is he ever going to be more than a tragic hero? He may be let down by his own Government. The British want to exit honorably. In order to do that they have to have a punch-up with China. When that has gone on long enough, they may just say, 'We tried.'
"But we in Hong Kong have to overcome our own fears, and a tendency towards self-censorship. If it doesn't work, this is not the place to live. Some people have already voted with their feet. I think we have to try to make it worth staying."
Hong Kong will undoubtedly be more like China after 1997. But there is a chance that China will be a bit more like Hong Kong, too. And that would mean a lot to the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For a Rational Drug Policy, Look to Treatment;
Punishment Pushers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Phil Gramm's support of mandatory minimum sentences is unfortunately based on faulty logic ("Don't Let Judges Set Crooks Free," Op-Ed, July 8). Much of his argument is premised on a study by Morgan Reynolds of Texas A & M University that calculated the time people committing crimes could expect to spend in prison. Senator Gramm concludes that people committing serious crimes can expect to serve only a matter of days and therefore prisons have little deterrent value. 
 The problem with this is that the study by Morgan Reynolds looked at prison sentences per crime, not per conviction. More than half of all serious crimes are never even reported to the police, and fewer than 10 percent result in a conviction.
Unless arrests increase dramatically, the harshness of prison terms is never going to be of much consequence. Since arrest rates increased by 30 percent in the 1980's, it is unrealistic to expect our beleaguered police departments to continue this rate of increase indefinitely.
Despite Senator Gramm's contention, the criminal justice system has become much harsher, with the number of inmates more than doubling in the last decade. If the goal was to send a message to potential criminals, the continuing high rates of crime and violence indicate that the message has not been very effective.
Perhaps it is time to send a different type of message to communities devastated by unemployment, drug abuse and poverty.
 
MARC MAUER
Asst. Director, Sentencing Project
Washington, July 8, 1993

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
In This Emergency, Agency Wins Praise for Its Response

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill., July 19

 BODY:
Looking ahead to a multibillion-dollar cleanup in five states, the head of the Federal agency that manages the Government's response to disasters said today that the greatest damage from the Mississippi River flooding was likely to be to roads, bridges, sewers, electrical utilities and other parts of the Midwest's public works systems.
James Lee Witt, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, added that he and other Federal agency heads, including Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, were working to find the money to rebuild the levees damaged by the floods and were beginning to think about building stronger levees to provide protection from future floods. 
 The Mississippi River flooding is providing the first real test of Mr. Witt's ability to manage FEMA, a much-maligned agency during the last several years. So far, he is getting favorable reviews, and the agency's performance appears to be a political plus for President Clinton, Mr. Witt's longtime friend. But Mr. Witt warned that the toughest challenges could lie ahead.
Mr. Witt said he had largely rejected arguments by conservationists and others who have called on the Government to remove some levees and develop a new approach to preventing damage from Mississippi floods.
"What we are interested in is mitigation, in helping to prevent damage and disasters," said Mr. Witt, who ran the Arkansas Office of Emergency Services for over four years before President Clinton appointed him head of FEMA. "That means finding money to relocate homes out of the flood plain. It can mean raising the elevation of homes through the Federal Flood Insurance program. It also means finding money to rebuild levees."
 
Tallying the Damage
 Mr. Witt's comments came today during an interview in this river town, where the flood water has been falling and more than 1,000 residents are beginning to wade back to their homes and businesses to look at the damage. Local and state officials are also assessing the damage to things like roads and utilities, which have been under water for weeks. Mr. Witt said the reports from these officials were disturbing. Fixing all the damage will be very expensive, he said, although he declined to estimate the cost.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Witt said, he visited Black River Falls, a town on Wisconsin's Black River that had been flooded. The flood had diminished and officials were checking the damage.
"They found 5,000 feet of their sewer system had collapsed from the flood waters," Mr. Witt said. "I'm just telling you we're going to have a lot of infrastructural damage. Roads have been under water for weeks and their bases are soft. Electrical wiring and electrical systems have been ruined. It's very early in this disaster."
Mr. Witt was in Illinois today to look at damage in Quincy, where levees protecting a bridge were washed out over the weekend, and to meet relief workers at the FEMA field headquarters his agency has set up in an IBM building near this city's airport.
Wearing jeans, ostrich-skin cowboy boots and a belt with a big brass buckle, Mr. Witt appeared relaxed. But he is at the center of a natural calamity with lasting economic implications for thousands of Americans in the Midwest and considerable political significance for the President, whom he has known well for almost 20 years.
By almost every measure, Mr. Witt's early performance managing the flood response is being received well by flood survivors, local officials and members of the agency's staff, who are running field offices and aid centers in five states.
 
Agency Is Praised
 During a series of brief interviews on Sunday outside an aid center in St. Charles, Mo., near St. Louis, not a single flood victim complained about FEMA. "I was surprised, to tell you the truth," said Susan Paul, who was helping her mother apply for benefits. "I expected a big, slow bureaucracy, and it wasn't anything like that. They really seemed interested in helping us."
Similar praise is also heard on this side of the river. "We've had nothing but positive comments," said Bob Turek, a reporter for WGEM-AM, a radio station in Quincy that has been broadcasting flood news. "People tell us they're getting help."
Mr. Witt, the first professional emergency manager to head FEMA since it was established in 1979, is happy to hear the praise but cautions that the worst is yet to come. According to FEMA, just over 20,000 people have registered for help along the Mississippi and its tributaries in five states, and Mr. Witt said he expected many more to seek help after people got a better idea of the damage.
Nevertheless, any good words are welcome at FEMA, an agency whose reputation was bruised by Hurricane Hugo, which hit the Carolinas in 1989, and then tattered by Hurricane Andrew last summer in Florida. In both emergencies, survivors, local politicians and members of Congress criticized FEMA for being unprepared. After Hurricane Hugo, President George Bush lost confidence in FEMA; when Hurricane Andrew struck, he appointed the Secretary of Transportation, Andrew H. Card Jr., to supervise the response.
Unlike those hurricanes, which struck quickly and affected tens of thousands of people in much smaller and distinct regions, the Mississippi floods have come more slowly and predictably, a factor that helped Mr. Witt make early preparations. Weeks ago, members of his staff said, Mr. Witt began holding morning conference calls with state and Federal disaster officials to plan for the floods, a tactic he has continued.
For instance, before the levee broke in Quincy and closed the bridge between Illinois and Missouri, Mr. Witt was making plans to put in a ferry service, said Richard W. Krimm, a deputy associate director of FEMA. Mr. Witt has also played an important role in setting up almost 100 sites in Des Moines for residents to get drinking water.
In Missouri and Illinois, checks to survivors for renting temporary housing began to be sent out late last week, just days after Mr. Clinton declared the region a disaster area on July 9.
 
Backing of the President
 "He's meant a lot to us in the agency," Mr. Krimm said. "He's brought with him all that experience about what states need in a disaster. And he has the full backing of the White House."
Mr. Witt, 49, was reared on a farm in Arkansas. A few years after graduating from high school, he opened his own construction business. For 10 years, he was the elected county judge, equivalent to a county administrator, in Yell County, Ark., and then was appointed the head of the Arkansas emergency response agency.
"What we know is what is happening here is only the beginning," he said. "The most important thing now is to be prepared early and to stay prepared because when the flood water goes down, the Federal Government, the states, everybody involved needs to be geared up."

HEADLINE: G.M. Plans Rebates to Settle Suits

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would give a $1,000 rebate for the purchase of a new truck to each of the millions of current owners of 1973 to 1987 G.M. pickups with side-mounted fuel tanks, thus settling 36 class-action lawsuits.
The value of the rebates could conceivably exceed $5 billion, although G.M. said the settlement would not be a financial drain on the company. 
 The settlement did not resolve the company's dispute with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, a Federal agency that has requested a recall of the trucks. The safety agency contends that placing the fuel tanks outside the frame rails of the truck created a safety defect.
 
G.M.'s Position
 General Motors has refused to recall the vehicles and "continues to maintain that the fuel systems in these full-sized pickup trucks do not have a safety-related defect," William O'Neill, a company spokesman, said in announcing the settlement.
He said the settlement did not involve any recall or modification of the trucks, which "have an excellent safety record over the past 20 years."
The settlement is subject to approval by a Federal judge in Philadelphia and by a state judge in Marshall, Tex., where some suits were filed.
Lawyers for the plaintiffs said they could still seek damages for injuries because the settlement applied only to economic loss because of the trucks' reduced resale value. "They can also benefit from any future recall that might result" from actions by the highway safety agency, said Elizabeth Cabraser, a lawyer for one group of plaintiffs.
Critics of the trucks say they are more likely to catch fire or explode in an accident than vehicles made by other companies. A jury in suburban Atlanta awarded $105 million in February to the parents of a Georgia teen-ager who was killed in a fire in a G.M. pickup accident in 1989. The company is appealing the judgment.
Certificates good for a $1,000 price reduction on a new General Motors truck will be given to current owners of the older vehicles after Thanksgiving, the company said. Estimates of the number still running and eligible range from 4.7 million to 6 million.
Dianne Nast, a lawyer in one of the 36 class-action lawsuits, said it was an "excellent settlement for the owners, some of whom have 20-year-old trucks that cost $2,300."
Analysts said that if all of the owners took advantage of the $1,000 offer, the company's obligations could total $5 billion to $6 billion.
G.M. says it will not take a charge against earnings related to the rebates. Mr. O'Neill said that because the plaintiffs would only benefit when they bought a new truck from the company, "the settlement will not have a material adverse impact on G.M.'s financial condition."
The rebate certificates will be good for 15 months and can be added to any other rebate or incentive. Owners can give the certificates to family members or exchange them for $500 certificates that they can sell.
John A. Casesa, an auto industry analyst at Wertheim Schroder, said the program was a clever move. "They are using a potentially negative situation to bring people into the showroom, perhaps even bringing in new customers," because the certificates could be transferred, he said.
The settlement was announced late yesterday, after the stock market closed. Earlier, G.M.'s shares ended the day unchanged at $47.75.
Ms. Cabraser said the settlement would provide "an economic incentive to get these trucks off the road."
Still, Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, said her consumer advocacy group would join with the Center for Auto Safety to ask the judge to amend the deal. "There is no incentive to repair the trucks or get them off the road," she said.

HEADLINE: Panel Wants Airlines to Get Tax and Regulatory Breaks

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
A Government commission charged with reviving the airline business said today that it would recommend tax cuts and regulatory relief to help reverse what it called the industry's "abysmal financial condition."
In preliminary findings that were cheered by the industry, the panel called for exempting airlines from any new tax on transportation fuels, rolling back taxes on passenger tickets and revising the Federal income tax code so that money-losing airlines would not be subject to the alternative minimum tax. 
 The commission also recommended that the Transportation Secretary convene a financial advisory committee of outside experts to warn of ill-advised mergers and other ventures.
The panel said the airlines, through taxes on fuel and tickets, had paid "more than their fair share" of the costs of building and operating the air-traffic control system.
To lower the costs and improve the efficiency of air-traffic control, the panel also endorsed the idea -- long debated but never adopted -- of turning the Federal Aviation Administration's air-traffic control functions over to a self-financed independent corporation. Such an entity would operate outside the Federal budget and could issue bonds for financing.
The commission also recommended that foreign companies be allowed to own as much as 49 percent of the voting stock of an American carrier, provided the foreign company's base country maintains a liberal aviation policy. Current law allows foreign companies to own up to 49 percent of the equity in an airline, but only 25 percent of voting stock.
 Executives of the airline industry greeted the report with enthusiasm.
Al Becker, a spokesman for American Airlines, said: "We were encouraged by the basic thrust of the report and the issues that were adopted. We want to have a chance to really study the decision thoroughly."
A spokesman for United Airlines said the company was reviewing the report and would have a statement later in the week.
The effect on the Federal budget poses one of the biggest obstacles to adoption of the panel's recommendations to aid the industry, which has lost $10 billion in three years.
A House-Senate conference committee is working out details of a tax package with the goal of passing a five-year budget by the end of August, before the airline commission is scheduled to complete its work. The airlines demanded that President Clinton endorse exempting them from a tax on transportation fuels, as the Senate did in its budget bill. But the House has approved a tax on transportation fuels, and the Administration has not made clear its view.
"The industry needs to beat back the energy tax proposal before we turn our attention to the commission's other ideas," said Jim Landry, president of the Air Transport Association. Still, he called today's proposals "thoughtful and comprehensive."
The commission is made up of industry and labor officials, economists, financiers and lawyers. Its chairman is Gerald L. Baliles, the former Governor of Virginia. It was appointed by President Clinton in the spring; final recommendations are to be made by Sept. 20.
The commission's report carefully rejected any suggestion of a return to the days of Government regulation of airline ticket prices and routes. But its members argued hard over just how far the Government should go in correcting the course of the industry.
Two economic questions took up much of the group's time. The first was how much of the industry's turmoil to blame on the desperate price-cutting behavior of bankrupt airlines, and what if anything to do about it.
Initially, the panel considered declaring that there was no conclusive evidence that price-cutting by bankrupt airlines was a major factor in the industry's plight. After debating the point, the panel voted to call this one of several such factors.
It then recommended changes to bankruptcy laws that would, in effect, speed the process for airlines.
The second issue was whether the Government should try harder through its licensing powers to influence airlines' financial decisions.
The panel said that when the Transportation Department reviews the financial fitness of airlines to operate it should use its certification process to persuade airlines not to go too deeply into debt. But in its recommendation for an outside advisory committee, the panel gave the body no enforcement powers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Acquisition by Olsten May Gain It Some Respect on Wall Street.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:
AS No. 3 in the temporary office help market, behind Manpower Inc. and Kelly Services, the Olsten Corporation has gotten little respect from Wall Street. But the company may be on the verge of shedding its Rodney Dangerfield complex.
The company's $525 million acquisition of the Lifetime Corporation in Boston, primarily a provider of home health-care personnel, will catapult Olsten into the nation's leading provider of home health care, the fastest-growing segment of the economy. The deal, when completed, will double Olsten's revenues to more than $2 billion. 
 But to Wall Street, the deal's importance goes beyond mere size. "This simple merging of operations should be immediately active to earnings and there is the real potential for substantial profit increases beyond any current estimates," said Judith G. Scott, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "This merger will also provide Olsten with an entree to Europe, a market of enormous potential for the company."
Olsten is not unfamiliar with the home health-care staffing business, having entered it during the mid- to late-70's and starting a more aggressive push in 1985. Three years ago, the company bought a division of the Upjohn Corporation that specializes in home health-care personnel. Unlike Olsten, Upjohn was unable to make its business grow and unloaded it at a fire-sale price. Olsten paid $58 million for a division with sales of $200 million. Today, Olsten's health-care staffing business is a $375 million operation, accounting for about 32 percent of the parent company's total revenues. Lifetime will increase that to 45 percent.
 At the core of Olsten's operations is the temporary office worker business. The company has 700 offices across North America, representing about 192,000 clients, including many of the Fortune 1,000.
Corporate America's current love affair with "temps" has enabled companies to add staff during peak times and avoid the cost of permanent workers.
In a March research report, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said that Olsten, after being hurt by the recession, began to re-establish positive momentum in mid-1991. And because the economy is still in the early stages of a recovery, the report added that the outlook for this particular business appears to be favorable for at least the next two or three years.
In fact, the move by corporations to trim staff and let outsiders do clerical and back office work helped the temp office staffing business, in Olsten's case, raising first-quarter revenues by 22 percent, to $267.4 million, and net income by 47 percent, to $5.3 million, or 20 cents a share.
One of the fringe benefits of the acquisition of Lifetime is its temporary office staffing business in Britain, called Office Angels. This gives Olsten an opportunity to leverage its expertise to obtain a toehold in Europe.
While some investors note that Lifetime's high-priced debt, of $155 million with interest rates as high as 10.5 percent, could act as a drag on Olsten's earnings, Frank N. Liguori, Olsten's chairman and chief executive officer, said that paying down the Lifetime debt would go to the top of his agenda after the transaction was completed. Further, he pointed out that Wall Street analysts familiar with the pending acquisition saw the merger as adding to Olsten's bottom line.
In fact, Baird's analyst, Ms. Scott, estimates that earnings should increase to $1.15 a share in 1993, compared with 87 cents a share in the previous year. Her estimate had been $1.10. Her 1994 estimate is $1.50 a share, up 10 cents from her previous estimate.
At the close of trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, Olsten's stock was at $25.625 a share, down 12.5 cents.

HEADLINE: GAY RIGHTS IN THE MILITARY;
Clinton in Crossfire

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
In announcing his compromise on homosexuals in the military, President Clinton today sought to close the book at last on an explosive issue that had become a glaring benchmark of the White House's own political naivete.
But the announcement, carefully staged before an audience of military brass, will not be enough to make the furor go away. Indeed, it now threatens to haunt Mr. Clinton even through his re-election campaign three years from now. 
 "I think it will be used against him every time he opens his mouth," said Albert McAlister, the Democratic state chairman in South Carolina, where, Mr. McAlister said, sentiment had run strongly against any change in the Defense Department's longtime ban on homosexuals' serving in the armed forces. "If you talk to people down South about the President, sometimes the first thing they'll say is they talk about his position on gays in the military."
Advocates on the opposite side of the debate, particularly those who demanded a complete lifting of the ban, are not cheering either.
"This will only guarantee that the debate will become more bitter, more divisive and a bigger political issue," said David B. Mixner, a major Clinton fund raiser among homosexuals last year, whose relations with the President have been strained over military service. "This was one of those moments in anyone's Presidency where he either hears a call to greatness or surrenders. He made no principled fight. He didn't address the nation until today, and that was to concede defeat."
 
Midwinter Mistakes
 Some White House officials now acknowledge that it was a mistake for Mr. Clinton to have begun acting on so emotionally charged an issue only days after his inauguration last January, particularly without adequately consulting the military chiefs and the Congressional leaders whose opposition to an outright lifting of the ban proved insurmountable.
And in trying to defuse the issue by delaying a decision then and seeking a compromise, Mr. Clinton only prolonged the debate, extending the period in which he was vulnerable to criticism that he had abandoned his campaign promise.
Although Mr. Clinton has insisted that he never became preoccupied by the issue -- spending but a few hours, he said, on his efforts to overturn the ban -- no other matter has caused him so much political agony on so many different fronts. Critics on the right are furious that he would propose giving "special treatment" to homosexuals. Those on the left have lambasted him for backing down from his campaign pledge.
 
Early Damage
 From the beginning of his Presidency, the issue only served to erode his stature as Commander in Chief and his relations on Capitol Hill, particularly with Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee and advocated the Pentagon's ban. The debate also made it nearly impossible for the White House to dispel a notion that he was consumed by the issue at a time when it was the economy that demanded his attention.
All the furor arose from a campaign pledge on a matter that was not the most important issue -- either to him or even to homosexual rights groups, most of which were far more concerned about the fight against AIDS. Perhaps as a result, neither he nor they anticipated how bitter the fight would become or how easy it would be for others to exploit.
"I can't think back to a President hurt so early on by his own hand -- not since President Ford's pardon of Richard Nixon, and that was a very different kind of issue," said Barbara A. Perry, a professor of government at Sweet Briar College in Virginia. "He did not anticipate the vociferous nature of the opposition."
Today few on either side of the issue were willing to give the President a break. Gary L. Bauer, president of the conservative Family Research Council, who supported the Pentagon's ban, sounded strikingly similar to opponents of the ban, saying Mr. Clinton had failed to demonstrate moral leadership.
Mr. Bauer said that had the President stood by his earlier pledge, "I think people would respect that more, that he has the courage of his convictions."
Even so, Mr. Bauer added, Mr. Clinton's compromise "undercuts the idea that he's a moderate, because he still comes across as beholden to the gay rights constituency."
Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service, a gay advocacy group, also spoke of a failure of moral leadership. "The President could have lifted up the conscience of the country," Mr. Stoddard said. "He could have fulfilled the country's yearning for moral leadership. Instead, he acceded, without a fight, to the stereotypes of prejudices he himself had disparaged."
The religious right shows no interest in letting the Clinton-and-homosexuals theme fade from the political dialogue, or from the mailings of fund-raising groups. But the main question that Democrats face is whether the Republican Party, which has been skittish about "family values" issues since they backfired during last year's campaign, will now harp on the issue of homosexual rights.
Homosexual rights advocates made clear today that they would not allow the military service issue to disappear. The Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund and the American Civil Liberties Union announced that they would file a court challenge on behalf of "the tens of thousands of lesbian and gay service members who are denied their constitutional protections under the new directive."
And the President, who had spent months fending off questions about what policy he would adopt, found today that the questions were not yet at an end. Several hours after announcing the new policy, he held a news conference on his dismissal of William S. Sessions, the Director of the F.B.I., but was peppered mostly with queries about homosexuals and the military.
Once again, he was in a defensive posture. "First of all," he said in response to a question that no President likes to be asked, "I think I did stand by my principles."
Mr. Clinton does have his sympathizers, gay rights advocates who note that even under the compromise he has moved more boldly than any other President to insure equal rights for homosexuals.
"I really hand it to him, he's shed political blood on this issue," said Representative Gerry Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, a homosexual. Mr. Studds said that although he had favored a full lifting of the ban, "I really think it's important to keep a perspective here."
"If this man had not been President," he said, "this wouldn't even be on the national agenda. It's a small step, but Clinton was able to do something that makes life less awful, or less unbearable, for some gays and lesbians."

HEADLINE: Home Repair or Retail Ruin?

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Liberty Avenue in Queens, beneath the shadows of an elevated subway line, still resembles one of New York City's traditional neighborhoods, a cluster of Italian delis, Laundromats, pastry shops and a hardware store, called Molbegott's, that draws people precisely because they can ask Mr. Molbegott himself how to fix their plumbing.
"I find everything I need right on this avenue," said Wanda McCaffrey, 43 years old, of Richmond Hill as she shopped on Liberty Avenue, pulling her nephew on a tricycle. "You don't have to go very far for anything." 
 But to Mrs. McCaffrey and many of her neighbors, this small commercial ecosystem -- one of many small shopping districts that have for generations served as modest Main Streets across the city's urban sprawl -- is being threatened by one of the large discount retailers, staples of the suburban landscape, that have begun staking out a foothold in the city.
Fearful that a sprawling Home Depot home-repair store would destroy the particular character and manner of their neighborhoods, residents and merchants from Ozone Park and Richmond Hill have gone to court in an effort to block construction of the store at Aqueduct Raceway. They maintain that the company did not submit to the appropriate environmental, zoning and legal reviews before receiving a building permit in May -- a charge city and company officials reject.
 
Judge Denies Foes' Request
 Last week, a state judge in Queens refused to halt construction, saying that the issue should instead be decided by the city's Board of Standards and Appeals, which is to hold a hearing next month.
The legal wrangling echoes the deep concerns of towns and cities across the nation as large retail chains erect vast outlets in their midst. To many, the fundamental question is whether old downtowns and shopping districts can survive alongside these warehouse clubs, super supermarkets and other retail behemoths, which offer a vast selection of goods in bulk and at rock-bottom prices.
In New York, the Department of City Planning is rewriting its zoning policy to encourage these large discount retailers. Officials argue that they are a needed source of jobs and tax revenues. They say that neighborhood protests ignore the benefits to a city that has for years lost retail dollars and jobs to the suburbs.
"It's a matter of the city catching up with what's been invested in the suburbs," said Eric A. Kober, the department's director of housing, economics and infrastructure.
 
Bradlees, Pathmark and More
 In the last three months alone, Bradlees Inc., a chain of 126 stores based in Braintree, Mass., has announced it will open its first store in New York City, in Atlantic Center in downtown Brooklyn. Pathmark plans to open a superstore in Astoria. Home Depot Inc. of Atlanta, which has 227 warehouse-style stores, including eight stores on Long Island, plans to open two more in Queens -- one at the former Taystee Bread factory in Flushing and the other at Woodhaven Boulevard and Metropolitan Avenue in Forest Hills. And two other retailers have asked for zoning permits to build new stores.
To the active opponents in Queens, however, their protests portend further clashes like those that have greeted the retail giants elsewhere.
"Putting these stores in neighborhoods in New York City is far different from putting them on Long Island," said John Van Der Tuin, a lawyer for the community organization in Queens, called Coalition for Community Preservation and Stabilization. "The question is, what does this type of store do to the neighborhood it's moving in?"
Ozone Park and Richmond Hill are like many neighborhoods in Queens: modest and insular. The streets are tidy and quiet, and people want to keep them that way.
So when the digging, drilling and pounding began inside Aqueduct several weeks ago, it stirred a small revolt. With his house just 40 yards from the construction site, Dennis D'Aquilla, a dispatcher for Con Edison, began to wonder what it would be like to live alongside the Home Depot.
His thoughts raced: he envisioned trucks -- big ones -- roaring through the neighborhood with heavy cargoes while crowds of shoppers coursed through the street toward the store.
"It shook me," said Mr. D'Aquilla, who has helped rally opponents. "I was forced to get involved. My backyard was right next to this monster."
To a large degree, the character of Richmond Hill and Ozone Park, where every block resembles every other, is formed by Liberty Avenue, the main artery. Small businesses have been there for many years, and their owners are usually behind the counter making sales and small talk.
 
Sharing May Not Last
 Joseph Scarpantonio got one of his first jobs working at Molbegott's nearly two decades ago as a stock boy, and now he owns his own hardware store and restaurant on that very same strip.
Mr. Scarpantonio, 47, says the businesses there have always kept close ties and good relations -- sharing customers and even borrowing supplies from one another. He wonders how long the neighborliness will last once Home Depot moves in.
"I don't see people working as a team if Home Depot comes," he said. "It'll be different. People will be fighting each other just to make sure they're the ones who make the sale."
Martin Molbegott, his old boss, agrees. 'What's happening is that only the strongest stores will survive," he said, "and the mom and pop stores won't."
Not everyone, though, makes such gloomy predictions.
Robert Mereweather, a plumber from Richmond Hill, is still partial to the quick, personal service along Liberty Avenue. (He said he once left a Home Depot in a rage after waiting about an hour for service.)
But he says he believes that the Home Depot will create enough competition to drive the prices of the smaller shops down. "You won't catch me in line at Home Depot just to save a few dollars," he said. "But I'm all for it, if it gets the local guys to bring down their prices."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Moscow Draws Line on Cigarette and Liquor Ads

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
As the smog of Communism lifted over Moscow several years ago, enabling a market-oriented economy to take root, products like Reebok shoes, Benetton clothes, Sharp electronics and Estee Lauder cosmetics were suddenly available to people who had known only the shoddiness of domestically produced consumer goods.
Then, as the avenues of exposure opened, companies began using traditional methods of advertising to keep their corporate logos fresh in Muscovites' minds. Among the most visible images around town on billboards and storefronts have been advertisements for Western cigarettes and liquor. The United States alone accounted for $197.6 million in tobacco exports to Russia last year and $24 million in alcohol exports, according to the Department of Commerce.
 
 
Promoting Health
 But just as the United States, Italy, Singapore, Sweden and other countries restricted advertising for tobacco and alcohol as a way to promote health and safety, the Moscow City Council passed a resolution this month that would banish such advertisements from billboards, kiosks and bus shelters, as well as from local newspapers, magazines and Russia's national television network. 
 The Council also called on the advertisements to be taken down within a month -- a highly unlikely prospect. With cigarettes and alcohol having been national indulgences for centuries, causing a variety of health problems, the city government has urged that the Russian Parliament extend the ban on advertisements for cigarettes and alcohol nationwide.
In any case, not every politician in Moscow has warmed to the idea that the city should be turned into a screaming endorsement for all things Western. As Sergei Rogozhkin, the deputy chairman of the city's mass media department, told The Moscow Times, an English-language newspaper, "We have good reason to think about limits."
The Council's bill requires approval from the Mayor's office.
But a tide of opposition is already growing, leading to speculation that even if the ban becomes law, it is virtually certain that it will neither be honored nor enforced.
Igor Pisarsky, president of the Russian Association of Advertising Agencies, an organization of Moscow's 17 leading ad agencies, said last week: "There is no way they can enforce this. The Moscow City Council has no right anyway to impose such a ban, especially on TV networks that are funded by the Government."
Unlike in the United States, cigarette makers advertise on television in Russia, but only after 10 P.M., when fewer children are likely to be watching.
For Western business interests, particularly American cigarette companies, fighting the ban is critically important. With the smoking population in the United States steadily declining, by nearly 3 percent a year for the last 12 years, companies like Philip Morris, R. J. Reynolds and B.A.T. Industries have found an eager buying public in Russia and other former cold war markets. The Marlboro brand is still the best-selling Western product in what used to be the Soviet Union.
With Philip Morris likely to keep recent price cuts on premium brands in the United States, a move Reynolds will probably match, the need to expand sales abroad becomes more acute.
But as the Moscow bureaucracy chugs along, hardly any faster than in days of old, Western companies are finding they can do little more than wait to see exactly what they are up against.
A spokesman for RJR Tobacco International said most companies would probably comply with whatever measures were passed.
"It's frustrating to be even implicitly accused of violating a regulation," Richard Marcotullio, the RJR official, said. "There are not that many defenders of the tobacco industry as it is. If we were to do something illegal, people would jump on us twice as hard as on anybody else."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Among the most visible images in Moscow are advertisements for Western-made cigarettes and liquor. But to promote health and safety, the Moscow City Council passed a resolution this month that would ban ads from billboards, kiosks, bus shelters, print media and Russian national television. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: For Better or Worse, Official In Michigan Makes an Impact

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 19

 BODY:
Depending on whom you ask, Fred Ruden, a Kalamazoo County Commissioner, is either a persecuted champion of the underdog or a short-tempered bully who verbally assaults anyone who dares disagree with him.
At the heart of the debate is whether his mental illness has anything to do with it. 
 Since taking office in January, Mr. Ruden has made late-night telephone calls to perceived political enemies, bombarded the commission with critical memorandums and overturned three vending machines of The Kalamazoo Gazette after an editorial in the newspaper angered him.
He has also created a community mental health board, made commission meetings more accessible to the public and argued passionately for better services for people with disabilities.
 
Severe Mood Swings
 Mr. Ruden, an unemployed bill collector with a law degree, has been found to be afflicted by manic-depression, a condition that causes severe mood swings. He says he wants to help pave the way for others who have disabilities.
But some mental-health advocates say his combative behavior has only perpetuated the stigma that most people tend to associate with the disorder.
"Fred's behavior has scared people," said Elizabeth Plasick, a co-founder of the Kalamazoo County Alliance for the Mentally Ill. "People are writing letters to the editor, saying he's a loose cannon."
Ms. Plasick, one of Mr. Ruden's early supporters, said his behavior had "set back years of progress" in destigmatizing mental illness.
The 38-year-old Commissioner does not deny that he can be "undiplomatic" at times, and he acknowledges that he needs to be more tolerant of others' views. But he does not make any excuses for his passion about the causes he believes in.
"You don't have some crazy commissioner tearing up the town down here," he said. "'My personal anger leads to public good."
Mr. Ruden acknowledges that several recent incidents, including the attack on the vending machines, occurred after he temporarily stopped taking lithium, the drug that controls his condition.
Some commissioners say that they are sympathetic to Mr. Ruden's illness but contend that his confrontational style and quick temper may be too volatile for politics.
"He can really get quite abusive," said Richard Kleiman, the chairman of the commission. "He thinks everybody is out to get him."
Some mental-health advocates say the fact that the commission is unwilling to accommodate Mr. Ruden's sometimes erratic behavior is just another example of discrimination.
"People don't understand mental illness," said Bev Lewis, president of the Kalamazoo County Alliance for the Mentally Ill. "The symptoms are not visible, like having a cast on your arm. The only reason you know someone is mentally ill is their behavior."
Ms. Lewis said Mr. Ruden has a quality that she believes is lacking in many other politicians: an instinct for doing the decent thing. "Fred has made a tremendous impact on the delivery of services here," she said.
Mr. Ruden talks openly about his illness. He said he began having intense mood swings while attending Michigan State University in the 1970's. In his third year at the Emory University School of Law the mood swings got so bad that he was granted a temporary psychiatric leave.
He also said he twice tried to commit suicide before his disorder was finally diagnosed, in 1986, as manic depression. He became an outspoken critic of the local mental health system after a doctor tried to cut off the lithium that had restored his balance.
Last fall, running as a Democrat, Mr. Ruden waged a $200 campaign for a seat on the commission and defeated a 14-year incumbent. He lives in a government-subsidized apartment on the $7,700 the county pays him annually.
Few people dispute that Mr. Ruden has improved local mental-health services. Even before he was elected, his rostrum-pounding speeches persuaded the commission to create the mental-health board.
 
Buses for the Disabled
 Since taking office he has pushed the commission to end its practice of holding daytime meetings of small committees, where many substantial decisions were made but which few citizens could attend.
He has also succeeded in getting the commission to approve financing for a bus service for disabled people, has advocated minority and female representation on committees, and has fought for labor and debtors' rights.
"I think Fred makes a lot of people uncomfortable because he talks about things in public that people don't want to talk about," said Mary Powers, Mr. Ruden's strongest supporter among his fellow commissioners.
"At these meetings, you look around and people put their head down and say, 'Oh, God, do we have to hear it again?' " Ms. Powers added. "But Fred feels so intensely about things -- and that's what our society needs a lot more of."
But even she admits, "There are times I just have to say, 'Fred, shut up.' "

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3.9% Increase Is Proposed By A.T.& T.

BYLINE: By VERONICA BYRD

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would increase its rates for some long-distance residential and business calls an average of 3.9 percent.
The proposed price increases, if approved by the Federal Communications Commission, would take effect on Aug. 1. 
 A.T.& T. said the increases were needed to offset higher operating costs and investments in a transferable "800" service, which was put into effect on May 1. With the transferable service, customers can change long-distance carriers and keep their "800" numbers.
The rate increases are "part of an ongoing effort to align prices with expenses," Mark Siegel, a spokesman for the company's consumer services division, said. "I'm sure we will see actions like this again."
The stock market reacted favorably to the proposed rate increases. A.T.& T. shares gained $1.125 yesterday, closing at $64.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The rate increases are considered a sign that while the rate war among the telephone industry's giants is less aggressive, it is far from over as the companies raise prices to make up for slower expansion and call volume.
For residential customers, the actual increase on their monthly bills will depend on the types of calls made. For those making only domestic calls, the increase will be less than 1 percent, Mr. Siegel said. For some calls made during evening hours, charges will decrease slightly.
 
International Calls
 Individual customers' direct-dialed international calls to 56 countries will increase an average of 3.8 percent.
Charges on calls to the United States from 27 countries using A.T.& T.'s USA Direct service will increase an average of 15 percent. With USA Direct, people overseas can call the United States directly, or with the assistance of an English-speaking operator, from more than 120 countries.
Rates on calling-card and operator-assisted calls will increase an average of 3 percent. The service charge on those calls will not be affected.
The consumer rate increase is expected to generate $193.2 million a year, Mr. Siegel said. The company declined to provide figures on the increase expected in business-calling revenue.
"We tried to absorb general increases of the cost of doing business, such as inflation and operational expenses, with cost containment and technology improvements," said Mike Granieri, a spokesman for A.T.& T. Business Communications Services. "But every now and then, the costs cannot be offset."
Rates for most business service will increase an average of 3.9 percent. The rises will apply to most interstate domestic and international long distance, to "800" calls and to data-communications services.
Daniel P. Reingold, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, said the rate rises "signal the trend toward more rational pricing in the industry in contrast to the aggressive price cutting seen a couple of years ago." He said it was highly likely that competitors, particularly the MCI Communications Corporation, will "come close to matching the increases."
"The companies have been following each other's rate changes quite closely in the last year," he added.
The last consumer rate rise was in December 1992, when charges went up for directory-assistance services and for USA Direct rates.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Recession's Romantics Fix Up Their Factory

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
IT didn't take long for somebody, probably Adam Smith, to make the connection between the value of a product and the wages of the people who make it. When $350 in raw materials are made into a $15,000 automobile, it equals happiness and high wages. Fifty cents worth of chopped beef flipped into a 75-cent hamburger equals low wages and woe.
Because they understand this rule, because they were determined to save the factory they built -- and maybe because they were a little bit lucky -- the men and women at Garry Precision Screw Machine were not among those who lost 24,500 well-paid manufacturing jobs in New Jersey last year. 
 Garry makes interconnect devices, which, when the plant was founded in the mid-1950's by Rudy Koppell, generally meant manufacturing the prongs and sockets that form the connections in electrical plugs. Since then, with the arrival of the age of microelectronics, the interconnect business has boomed. In every computer, microwave oven, videocassette recorder and sophisticated weapon of war, there are thousands of tiny brass plugs, prongs and soldering connections, each precisely machined, slotted, notched, crimped, chamfered and polished by companies like Garry Precision Screw Machine.
The late Mr. Koppell, "old Mister Koppell" the people at Garry still call him affectionately, built Garry into a $30 million a year business by the time, in the pattern of these things, he decided to sell out and retire rich. The company was then passed from one international company to another, each one more remote and less interested in caring for an old-line family business than the one before.
The last owner, a $4 billion conglomerate, decided to make Garry a "captive shop," manufacturing only for the parent company's products and jettisoning decades of loyal customers. "It was crazy," said Sam Mark, Brooklyn-born and a Garry executive since the Koppell days. "This isn't a captive shop, it's a job shop. They ran us into the ground."
Indeed. Last September, the conglomerate decided it didn't need Garry's production any more, and the little plant was not important enough for the owners to waste time on finding a willing buyer. So the factory on the southbound side of United States Highway 1 was simply shut down, its 150 workers dismissed, the milling machines drained of lubricating oil and consigned to an industrial auctioneer for piecemeal sale.
"Well, we were just optimistic, I guess," said Richard Rueshoff, a machinist with 33 years' experience at Garry, explaining why people did what they did then. "We just thought we'd find a way to keep going."
Mr. Rueshoff and a half dozen other machinist foremen entered the silent factory a few months after the shutdown to oil and hand-turn the bearings on the precise, Swiss-made cutting machines. They feared that if the bearings dried out and sat idle in one position too long, they would develop flat spots, a problem for the new owner who the Garry people figured had to be out there somewhere. There was no question of anyone's paying them to do this.
Meanwhile, Sue Whitaker, who had worked in the front office, sat in her kitchen and called suppliers of the metal rods the plant turned into connectors, keeping abreast of price changes. She fed the information to Bob Lewis, who had been head of operations, so he could quote tentative prices on jobs from a plant that technically didn't exist and that he in any case didn't even work for.
And Mr. Mark, the laid-off plant manager, began calling former customers, asking, "What if?" as in: What if you were to buy this place and put us all back to work?
"It wasn't strictly proper, because we didn't even have a plant to sell them -- it belonged to the auctioneer," Mr. Mark said. "But sometimes you've got to shoot craps."
We could pause and remember that in too many cases, it all ends there: snake eyes. Manufacturing is in recession, after all. The ex-owners probably knew what they were doing when they decided to break up and sell off the plant. The manufacturing jobs that did vanish last year are proof that for many men and women who work with their hands, the news from the front office is often bad and stays bad.
But not for the Garry workers, not yet. Wire-Pro Company, a nice, family-owned South Jersey company, returned Mr. Mark's call, and said yes. The auctioneer said yes. The state Commerce Department stepped in with some financial incentives for Wire-Pro, and on the Monday before last, July 12, Garry Precision Screw Machine Company reopened its doors to an initial staff of 25 laid-off workers and a small military contract.
"We're going to get them all back," Mr. Mark, general manager once again, said of the other, still waiting workers. "Somewhere down the road, we'll bring them back. Because we have aspirations."

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed as Dow Gains 6.99

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with little news to affect the overall market. Instead, individual stories moved individual stocks, with the technology sector weighing over everything.
The weakness in technology was a carry-over from last week, when concern over earnings touched off a sell off. 
 I.B.M. lost 2, to 43 5/8, as 4.5 million shares changed hands. The stock is now at its lowest level in 18 years, which, some market analysts recollected, was after a particularly brutal bear market.
Traders said Rick Martin, an analyst with the Chicago Corporation, said in an interview on CNBC yesterday that I.B.M. "cannot go up as long as book value is going down." He projected that a drop in the computer company's book value would come from trimming payrolls by up to 75,000 jobs in the next six to 12 months.
 
25,000 Job Cuts Expected
 Next week the giant computer company is expected to release its second-quarter earnings, and Mr. Martin expects the company to announce that 25,000 jobs will be cut.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.99 points to close at 3,535.28, as the volume of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 216.4 million, down from 263.1 million on Friday. Declinging issues outpaced gainers by 1,070 to 852 and the Big Board composite slipped 0.12 point, to 247.33.
Trading on the Nasdaq was brisk as the composite fell 3.90 points, to 695.83. Apple Computer fell 1 7/8, to 25 5/8, Digital Equipment dropped 1 5/8, to 37 5/8, while Microsoft tumbled 2 3/8, to 78 3/4.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up 0.28 point, to 446.03, while the American Stock Exchange composite fell 2.99 points, to 433.48.
Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said another force that weighed on the market yesterday was the Commodity Research Bureau's price index, which was up 2.83 points, to 218.01, because of the flooding in the Midwest and a rise in crude oil prices.
"Initially, this put pressure on bonds because of its inflationary nature and a damper on equities," he said.
Members of OPEC, looking to set production quotas amid a market in oversupply, called for an emergency meeting in the next couple of weeks.
The increase in oil prices helped oil stocks, which lifted blue-chip issues, but the technology weakness weighed on the small stocks.
Mr. Jarrett said some of the positives in yesterday's market included the Travelers Corp., up 1 3/8, to 31 3/8, on good earnings numbers, and Caterpillar, up 1 5/8, to 79 5/8.
He said negatives were accentuated by the drug stocks, which continued to show weakness, led by Merck, down 1, to 32 1/8.
