HEADLINE: Old Faces, New Politics in Japan

 BODY:
What happened to Japan's predicted electoral revolution?
The morning after the vote, many familiar faces could still be found at center stage. The Liberal Democrats remain the biggest party -- by far. Prime Minister Miyazawa even talks about hanging onto his job, at least for a few weeks. 
 Yet Sunday's election results portend a very different Japan. The old political arithmetic that assured the Liberal Democrats a permanent majority over a dogmatic and marginalized Socialist opposition has been replaced by a new math of fierce competition from new center-right groups, some of them composed of disaffected members of the old guard.
After the votes were tallied, the Liberal Democrats held 223 seats, their combined center-right rivals held 175 and the Socialists were left with a mere 70. In the short term, various permutations could produce a working majority of 256. In the longer term, a new era of competitive politics has almost certainly arrived.
That competition means politicians will need to pay attention to the interest of ordinary voters, not just the old "iron triangle" of bureaucrats, business leaders and Liberal Democratic faction bosses.
For Americans, the new politics, after an awkward transition period, should make it easier to achieve some long-sought goals, like more open markets, less behind-the-scenes bid rigging and more readiness to stimulate consumer demand during recessions.
Democratic accountability by itself won't dissolve economic tensions. Consider, for example, America's sometimes testy trade relations with democratic France. But generally, democracies do better at working out their economic quarrels without slipping into the kind of demonization that has poisoned ties between the U.S. and Japan.
The old political system was a hybrid of Japanese feudalism and General MacArthur's postwar democratic reforms. Launched with American support in 1955, the Liberal Democratic Party won solid backing from generations of Japanese voters and successive U.S. Governments as the best vehicle for rebuilding a war-ruined economy, restraining militarism and assuring a pro-Western security alignment during the cold war.
Eventually that system was undermined by its own remarkable success. Japan emerged as an economic powerhouse and the West won the cold war. Today the main political issues are how Japan wants to use its new wealth to build a more livable society and what role it chooses to play in a world no longer defined by East-West conflict.
Issues like that can't be solved by technocratic "guidance" from the old iron triangle. Only democratic debate and competitive politics can provide satisfactory answers. Sunday's vote makes that kind of democratic competition possible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Workers of the World, Get Smart

SERIES: Build a Better Workplace -- Second of two articles

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is Secretary of Labor.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Throughout the industrialized world, there seem to be too few good jobs to go around. The problem manifests itself differently in different countries, but the failure of any country to insure good jobs for many able and willing citizens raises a troubling question: Do advanced nations have to choose between good jobs and more jobs?
Over the past two decades, Western Europe has experienced growth in wages but stagnation in employment. Between 1975 and 1992, the real -- that is, inflation-adjusted -- average wages of manufacturing workers in France, Germany, Italy and Britain grew by 30 to 50 percent. But unemployment in European industrialized economies has risen close to a staggering 11 percent. 
 How does America compare? On the narrow score of the number of jobs, we rank quite well. Since 1975, our economy has generated nearly two million new jobs per year. And although our current unemployment rate of 7 percent is disturbing, more than 800,000 jobs have been created since January, as economic growth has begun to stir.
Our bigger long-term problem is creating jobs that pay well. The average wages of America's production workers, adjusted for inflation, are the lowest they've been since 1967. Eighteen percent of full-time workers don't earn enough to keep a family of four out of poverty; this level is up from 12 percent in 1979. And more Americans who want full-time jobs are working part-time instead.
Wages and incomes in the U.S. have become more unequal since the early 1970's. They have risen for upper-income workers, remained stagnant for the middle class and fallen for those at the bottom. In no other advanced industrialized nation is the income gap so wide between the managers and professionals and production workers.
Must we accept a diabolical trade-off between good jobs and more jobs as factories move to places around the world where labor costs less and as smart machines take on more tasks at home? I believe that a trade-off is not inevitable if we draw the right conclusion from the underlying employment trends.
The pattern of wage inequality in the U.S. provides an important clue. From 1980 to 1991, the weekly real earnings of full-time workers over the age of 25 who had graduated from college rose 9 percent. That's not so bad. But the real weekly earnings of similar workers who had only completed high school dropped 7 percent. And similar workers without high school diplomas suffered a drop in earnings of 14 percent. Today, the weekly earnings of full-time workers over 25 who are college graduates are more than 50 percent above the earnings of otherwise similar workers who are simply high school graduates.
The pattern of unemployment provides a second clue. In Europe and the U.S., the uneducated and unskilled have been hardest hit. While college graduates did not escape the prolonged recession in the U.S., only 3.2 percent were unemployed last year compared with 11.4 percent of those who dropped out of high school.
The long-term crisis in advanced industrial nations reflects in part a shift in relative labor demand against less-educated workers and those doing routine tasks and toward workers with problem-solving skills. So, how do we move a workforce suited to one sort of economy quickly and smoothly into a world grown suddenly quite different?
No country has yet found the formula. But different countries have illustrated different ways to get it wrong. The continental European approach has been to have Government intervene heavily in the wage-setting process and seek to preserve the existing pattern of employment. This has prevented the gap between high-wage and low-wage workers from widening much, but it has not directly addressed the profound changes in the demand for skills. Such policies have maintained wages and job security for the employed, but they have retarded the creation of new jobs.
In the U.S. and Britain, employers have responded more directly to changes in labor force supply and demand. The result has been greater inequality in wages and working conditions. The apparent payoff from this Faustian bargain is a rate of U.S. job growth over the last two decades that has been the envy of Europe. Nevertheless, job growth in the U.S. and Britain has been punctuated by high unemployment in recessions and tarnished by worsening problems of permanent loss of jobs.
A third blind alley is protection from exports. No advanced nation is blameless. Yet escaping from global markets through protectionism is no solution. New technologies will reduce the demand for less-skilled workers even if borders are sealed. And many of the high-wage jobs of the future will be tied to exports and jobs that service the export industry. Protectionism cripples economic progress while failing to save jobs.
Americans have traditionally cast their lot with open trade. In recent years, we have wavered. But in Tokyo, President Clinton led the Group of Seven industrialized countries another major step down the path of openness. The trade agreement initialed there has sharply improved the odds for a new global accord. The President also established ground rules for measuring how far Japan opens its market. The odds of advanced nations adapting to a changing world are higher than they were before the summit meeting, holding hope for our own economic recovery.
In addition, the President's proposed sharp reduction in the budget deficit will remove a significant source of uncertainty about the stability of the world economy and aid recovery.
But domestic policies -- specifically five -- are also needed to deal with the mismatch between the skills Americans have and the skills the economy requires. They are a good basic education for all children, affordable college, school-to-work apprenticeships for young people who don't go on to college, transition help to new jobs for displaced workers and lifetime learning in the workplace.
This list essentially describes the Clinton agenda for the workforce. Some parts of it are already embodied in legislative initiative, others are still taking shape. The imperative of investment in the workforce is so compelling and the goal of building of America's skill base so broadly shared that the debate remains remarkably free of partisan wrangling.
The closing years of this century and the start of the next will be dominated by the advanced countries' efforts to adapt to the new economy. America enters this era with advantages. Our still enormous wealth gives us scope for experimentation and a margin for error. Most importantly, economic dynamism and openness to change are woven deep into our culture.
Our greatest weakness has been the failure to invest adequately in our own learning. In the emerging global, high-tech economy, the development of our human resources will be the key means of creating wealth.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in Israel, Excelled in Role of Good-Will Ambassador

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's trip to Israel is now history, but to the 34 delegation members who accompanied New York City's Mayor the story is incomplete. We admired the energy and involvement of news media representatives, but since they were excluded from most of the meetings with Israeli leaders, they may not have known some aspects of the trip. 
 We knew the prime interest was in the motive for the trip and the handling of the Crown Heights violence two years ago. Neither of these concerned the Israeli leaders, so that discussion of them surfaced only in press interviews. There was a small and quite ineffectual attempt at a demonstration during the dedication of New York Square -- some 30 people mustered by Rabbi Avi Weiss stood holding placards at a substantial distance. It was not a popular effort as far as the Israeli leaders were concerned and fortunately did not interfere with the program.
Discussions with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres on such subjects as peace in the Middle East and economic concerns were fascinating. At no point was there any reference to the motives for the Mayor's visit, since it was understood by Israeli leaders he was fulfilling a promise to return after the Persian Gulf war, which he made when he visited Israel while Scud missiles were falling.
But what struck everyone in the delegation was the great regard in which the Mayor was held by both Ministers and by Mayors Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem and Shlomo Lahat of Tel Aviv. He was universally greeted as a friend and literally embraced. The delegation was diverse and disparate. We were clergy members, civic leaders, government officials and business representatives. We barely communicated the first day, but by the second day we had become family. Once the familial relationship evolved, I found I was suffering from the same intestinal tremors I experience when any family member performs in public. Borough Presidents Claire Schulman of Queens and Ruth Messinger of Manhattan, City Councilman Stanley Michaels and James Harmon, the president of Wertheim Schroder, all of whom spoke on various occasions, were wonderful.
Most of all, the Mayor was impressive. I haven't heard him referred to as a statesman, but the term is apt in describing his speeches, his appearance and the admiration he evoked. We hope he will continue to travel to countries where New Yorkers have roots. Such trips can result in economic advantages and in easing tensions in divided neighborhoods, where such visits can give reassurance. The Mayor's fulfillment of his promise to revisit may not have affected the campaign or laid to rest the specter of Crown Heights, but it created a tremendous amount of good will.
 
ELINOR GUGGENHEIMER
Pres., New York Women's Agenda
New York, July 10, 1993

HEADLINE: HOUSE AIDE LINKS A TOP LAWMAKER TO EMBEZZLEMENT

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The former postmaster of the House of Representatives has told prosecutors that he helped Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the powerful Illinois Democrat, embezzle $21,300, according to prosecutors, defense lawyers and public records that describe some of the transactions.
The former postmaster, Robert V. Rota, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Washington today to one count of conspiracy and two counts of embezzlement and said he had helped an undisclosed number of lawmakers embezzle tens of thousands of dollars since his appointment in 1972 until 1992, when he resigned.
 
Important on Big Issues
 Government and defense lawyers said the guilty plea was a significant step toward indicting Mr. Rostenkowski, but it could be weeks before the Government moves against the Chicago Democrat. Still, the plea today by Mr. Rota, who has agreed to testify against Mr. Rostenkowski, came at a delicate moment, when the House and Senate have just begun negotiations on Mr. Clinton's economic program. 
 As chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Rostenkowski will be one of the central figures in those talks, and Mr. Clinton will also need him badly in months to come as Congress considers health care, welfare, trade and other issues.
 
Calls Unanswered
 In a court appearance today, Mr. Rota did not identify Mr. Rostenkowski, referring instead to "Congressman A" and to "Congressman B," who, the former official said, had stolen $9,300. The Government also did not identify either lawmaker, but documents supporting Mr. Rota's plea arrangement clearly showed that Mr. Rostenkowski was Congressman A and that Joe Kolter, a Democrat who lost his Pennsylvania seat last year, was Congressman B.
Mr. Rostenkowski's aides said the lawmaker was in Chicago today. Calls to the lawmaker there were not answered and no one answered the door at his home. The aides in Washington declined to discuss Mr. Rota's guilty plea. The lawmaker's Washington lawyer, Stanley Brand, did not return telephone calls.
J. Ramsey Johnson, the interim United States Attorney in Washington, said: "Mr. Rota has admitted that he allowed the House post office to be used as a convenient and, until this investigation, largely untraceable source of illegal cash for selected members of Congress. Over the course of two decades, at the insistence of certain Congressmen, Mr. Rota repeatedly took cash from House post office funds and turned it over to these members." There is as yet no indication of how many lawmakers were involved or who any of the others might be.
Mr. Rota, a 58-year old career Congressional official who resigned as the post office scandal erupted last year, admitted today that he had provided the lawmakers with a cover so that they could steal from expense accounts for office supplies through transactions that appeared to be legitimate.
Members of Congress are given allowances to pay for office expenses like pens, stationery and postage. They can obtain such items from House storerooms and the House post office by signing vouchers against their allowances. Lawmakers can send ordinary mail without stamps under their franking privileges but need them for overseas mail and to use specialized services like certified mail and insured mail.
Mr. Rota said that in some cases he had taken vouchers from members of Congress that showed postage purchases but instead of stamps he had given them cash. In other instances, he said, he exchanged the vouchers for stamps, but he would then take the stamps back for cash.
Mr. Rota's story, which emerged today from his own words and through Federal prosecutors, provided a startling glimpse into the life of a figure familiar on Capitol Hill but seldom seen outside Washington: the Federal patronage employee eager above all to please those who gave him his job.
 
Seen as Political Favors
 Throughout the scheme, prosecutors said, Mr. Rota did not make any money. Rather, he helped others profit illegally as a political favor.
The former postmaster is a Pennsylvanian who began his career by working in the cloakroom and rose through the ranks of the House bureaucracy under the patronage of Representative Thomas Morgan, a Pennsylvania Democrat who was the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and retired in 1976 after serving 32 years.
Mr. Rota, who oversaw a staff of 160 and an annual budget of $4.4 million, was well known in Congress for doing favors for various lawmakers. One recalled recently that Mr. Rota would routinely approach members and ask, "What can I do for you?"
Mr. Rota said he gave $11,500 in cash to Congressman A and $4,300 to Congressman B, from May 1985 to May 1987. He also said he gave $9,800 in cash to Congressman A and $5,000 to Congressman B from July 1989 to April 1991. The amounts ranged from $900 to $2,800 for Congressman A and from $600 to $2,000 for Congressman B.
The court records provided the numbers of the vouchers that Mr. Rota said were used to cover up the transactions. Publicly available records show that in each case where a voucher by Congressman A was listed, the voucher number corresponded to one signed by Mr. Rostenkowski and that the vouchers attributed to Congressman B were signed by Mr. Kolter.
 
Accusation Denied
 Mr. Kolter, who lives in New Brighton, Pa., did not return a telephone message left today on his answering machine. His Washington lawyer, Alan Baron, said he had not seen the court papers but heard speculation today that his client was Congressman B. Mr. Baron said his client had done nothing improper and had not been involved in any plea bargaining.
Mr. Rota said the two-year hiatus in the payments occurred because a new Supervisor of Accounts at the post office was installed whom Mr. Rota did not know and could not trust to carry out the scheme. But after that supervisor left, Mr. Rota said, he was replaced by a patronage employee whom he did not identify today other than to say that he was sponsored by Congressman A.
The position described by the prosecutors had been occupied James C. Smith, who worked in a basement office of the postmaster across the street from the Capitol, single-handledly controlling the disbursement of thousands of dollars in cash and stamps. He was sponsored for his job by Mr. Rostenkowski, according to Congressional documents.
 
Employee Granted Immunity
 Lawyers involved in the case said Mr. Smith, who is no longer in the job, had been granted immunity by prosecutors and had been lined up to testify against Mr. Rota if he had failed to reach a plea agreement. Mr. Smith is also prepared to testify against Mr. Rostenkowski, the lawyers said.
Mr. Rota also confessed that he had lied to investigators at least three times to cover up the scheme. If he is used as a witness in a trial against lawmakers, his credibility could be attacked because of this admission.
The plea was the culmination of a two year-long investigation that began when a post office clerk was discovered stealing cash from one of branches on Capitol Hill. That investigation and a separate inquiry last year involving significant overdrafts at the House Bank came to symbolize ethical laxity in Congress and led, in turn, to a perception that contributed to an anti-incumbent fever that sent scores of legislators down to defeat or forced them to retire.
Prosecutors said Mr. Rota was scheduled to be sentenced Oct. 12 and faced a maximum prison sentence of three years and fines of as much as $300,000.
"What Mr. Rota did was to place the services of his office and the United State funds under his control at the disposal of certain United States Congressmen, knowing full well that he was aiding the embezzlement of money from those funds." Mr. Johnson said. "What Mr. Rota got in return was to keep his job as an officer of the United States House of Representatives."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the legal problems of Robert V. Rota, a former House Postmaster, misstated his resignation date in some editions. Mr. Rota, who was the subject of an investigation into corruption in the House Post Office during his two decades as Postmaster, resigned in 1992, not 1991.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Is Upbeat On Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, gave a surprisingly upbeat assessment of economic growth today but said the news on inflation was disappointing, signaling that the central bank was poised to raise interest rates if inflation accelerated.
Testifying before a House subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said he was disappointed that inflation "has at best stabilized, rather than easing" as might be expected when the unemployment rate hovers near 7 percent. 
 In recent months, the Federal Reserve has walked a tightrope between wanting to keep interest rates low to spur growth and wanting to talk tough on inflation to help keep price pressures in check.
 
Takes aA Stern Tone
 Today, Mr. Greenspan took a sterner tone on inflation despite weak recent economic data and a drop in inflation in May and June after a price spurt early in the year. He seemed to be indicating that the Fed was not ruling out raising rates, however unpopular that would be.
The bond market was jarred by Mr. Greenspan's testimony, and short-term interest rates rose as some investors focused once again on the threat of an increase in interest rates. [Page D20.]
Mr. Greenspan estimated that the economy grew by an annual rate of 3 percent in the second quarter -- a considerably stronger showing than the predictions of many private economists. Despite anemic growth in the first quarter, he said, the economy seemed to be on track, and he forecast growth of 2.5 percent for the year, with the jobless rate slipping to 6.75 percent by December.
 
Backs Clinton Plan
 Saying that the expectation of deficit reduction had helped lower long-term interest rates, the Fed chief used his testimony to badger Congress to approve the Clinton Administration's plan to cut deficit spending by $500 billion over five years.
In his understated style, Mr. Greenspan said, "Should that expectation be thwarted, then I think the markets would react in a negative fashion."
He rejected suggestions that the deficit package be scaled back to $400 billion, warning that the markets "will react appropriately negatively" if Congress backs down.
In its new semiannual forecast, the central bank predicted inflation of 3 percent to 3.25 percent this year and 3 percent to 3.5 percent next year. The Fed forecast economic growth of 2.5 percent to 3.25 percent next year.
Mr. Greenspan said that after the spurt in prices a few months ago, the low May and June inflation figures "have helped assuage concerns that new inflationary pressures had taken hold." Yet "on balance," he said, "the news on inflation this year must be characterized as disappointing."
In May, the Federal Reserve decided to tilt its monetary policy in favor of higher rates, but it has yet to act on that conclusion.
Mr. Greenspan said the increase in gold prices over the last few months was worrisome because it reflected an expectation of inflation. The 7 percent jobless rate and slack in capacity utilization should point to lower inflation, he added.
"The role of expectations in the inflation process is crucial," he said. "Even expectations not validated by economic fundamentals can themselves add appreciably to wage and price pressures" and risk derailing growth by encouraging higher interest rates.
Although Mr. Greenspan forecast that high consumer debt and military-spending cuts would restrain growth for months to come, he said the foundation was being laid for strong growth. Assuming that the Government resolved questions about the budget and health-care costs, he said, "the U.S. economy should eventually emerge healthier and more vibrant than in decades."
 
Lower Monetary Targets Cut
 Mr. Greenspan said the central bank had reduced its goal for growth in the money supply next year. Generally, strong monetary growth leads to inflation and to stronger economic growth. The central bank lowered its growth target for the M-2, the most closely watched monetary measure, to a range of 1 percent to 5 percent, down from 2 percent to 6 percent adopted in February. Last year, its target was 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent.
Many economists and lawmakers have assailed the Fed for puny growth in the money supply, calling this a major reason for the sluggish economy. But Mr. Greenspan said the usual links between monetary growth and economic growth had broken down, asserting that the economy could grow sufficiently with less of an increase in the money supply.
Finding that the money supply had become an unreliable guide for policy, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed was increasingly looking to a new guidepost to help it steer toward a desired growth rate -- "equilibrium real interest rates." Real interest rates are nominal rates minus inflation, and the equilibrium rate would be the real interest rate that would keep the economy operating at its potential without spurring inflation.
Using this approach, the central bank might conclude, for example, that real interest rates of 2 percent produced solid growth without fueling inflationary pressure. So it might aim for 4 percent interest rates if the inflation rate, and inflationary expectations, were 2 percent.
 
A Diplomat, as Well
 At the hearing, by the House Banking subcommittee on economic growth, legislators generally ignored monetary-policy questions and tried to coax Mr. Greenspan into supporting their positions in the budget battle. He declined their invitations.
Like any good conservative, he said it is preferable to reduce the deficit through spending cuts, rather than tax increases, arguing that spending less is a surer way to hold down the deficit. But when Republicans urged him to say that a dollar in tax increases hurts growth more than a dollar in spending cuts, he gave a diplomatic answer. He noted that spending cuts hurt the economy, as is evidenced by arms cutbacks, and that tax rises hurt, too, noting that some businesses had delayed expansion out of a fear of possible new taxes.
Mr. Greenspan criticized the House for delays in approving new financing for the Resolution Trust Corporation, which liquidates failed savings-and-loan institutions, a delay that he said is costing $1 billion a year.
"The failure to fund the R.T.C. is just adding to the costs of something which the American Government -- that is, the American people -- are already obligated for," he said.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Are Stalled Despite Low Interest Rates

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Despite the lowest mortgage rates in two decades, the pace of new home construction stalled in June, the Commerce Department reported today, apparently because buyers remained worried about the economy.
Floods in the Midwest also took a toll on the annual rate of housing starts, which was stuck at 1.25 million units, the same as in May. Analysts said the full impact of devastating rains in the nation's midsection may not be known for months. 
 Applications for building permits weakened in June by 1.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.11 million units, a poor sign for future building activity. Applications had risen 1.8 percent in May.
 
Disappointing Numbers
 "The June housing starts are disappointing relative to earlier expectations that housing would be one of the major driving forces to the expansion," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York.
The rate of new-home building is a good measure of consumer participation in the national economy because it is a sign of willingness to make long-term commitments. The June rate was 10 percent above the rate a year earlier of 1.14 million units.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages, available for 8.04 percent in mid-January, dropped to 7.16 percent by mid-July, a level not seen since 1972, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Variable-rate mortgages were available as low as 4.53 percent.
Such low rates would normally be a potent buying incentive if consumer confidence was not being battered by fears about jobs and taxes.
On Capitol Hill today, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified before Congress that the pace of economic growth in the second quarter likely picked up to an annual rate of 3 percent from the first quarter's anemic seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The Fed chief reiterated his concern about potential inflation in the economy. Housing industry analysts say they worry about reports the Fed favors a pre-emptive strike against inflation by raising interest rates that are considered vital to keep housing expanding.

HEADLINE: Ex-Detroit Police Officer Testifies He Never Struck Victim of Fatal Beating

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 20

 BODY:
A former Detroit police officer charged with murder in the fatal beating of a driver told jurors today that he never struck the victim.
Walter Budzyn, one of three former police officers on trial in the fatal beating of the driver, Malice Green, last Nov. 5, also testified that he had not seen any other officer become violent with Mr. Green. 
 Prosecution witnesses have testified that Mr. Budzyn straddled Mr. Green and swung a flashlight at his head.
Mr. Budzyn, 47, and his former partner, Larry Nevers, 52, are accused of second-degree murder. A third former officer, Robert Lessnau, 33, is accused of assault.
 
First Defense Testimony
 The three defendants, who were dismissed from the police force after Mr. Green's death, are white. Mr. Green, 35, an unemployed steelworker, was black. The death raised racial tensions in Detroit, but there has been no testimony that race was a motive in the beating.
Mr. Budzyn's account, the first by a defense witness in the trial, differed markedly from previous testimony.
Mr. Budzyn said he and Mr. Nevers were patrolling the city's west side when they spotted a car with bullet holes in a passenger door parked in front of a house known to be frequented by drug users.
Mr. Budzyn said that they pulled up in their unmarked car and asked to see the driver's license, and that the driver, Mr. Green, then reached toward the glove compartment and dropped what appeared to be cocaine. Mr. Budzyn said Mr. Green refused to open his clenched right hand and began struggling in the car.
"I reached in and grabbed his right arm," Mr. Budzyn testified. "Mr. Green came up with both of his legs and kicked me in the lower leg and right knee."
 
14 Blows to the Head
 Mr. Budzyn testified that he noticed Mr. Nevers tapping Mr. Green's hand with a flashlight, but added that those were the only blows he saw.
An assistant medical examiner ruled that Mr. Green died from at least 14 blows to the head.
Earlier in the trial, several witnesses testified that they saw Mr. Budzyn hold Mr. Green in a headlock in the car and swing a heavy police flashlight at his head. But they said they could not see whether Mr. Green was actually hit with the flashlight.
Mr. Budzyn said he dropped his flashlight early in the struggle and never swung it at Mr. Green. He said he did not see Mr. Green being hit, but heard a couple of thuds and later saw Mr. Green's head covered with blood.
Prosecution witnesses said Mr. Nevers hit Mr. Green repeatedly, and that Mr. Lessnau punched and kicked him after pulling him from the car.
 
Blood on Partner's Hands
 Mr. Budzyn said he did not see what was going on outside the car because he was busy retrieving the cocaine and other items. Afterward, he said, there was blood on Mr. Nevers's hands and flashlight.
"I saw Larry, who was huffing and puffing," Mr. Budzyn testified. "I thought he was having a heart attack or something."
Mr. Budzyn said he obtained peroxide from an ambulance driver and poured some over Mr. Nevers's hands "to get rid of the blood," because he and his partner feared that Mr. Green might have had AIDS.
Mr. Budzyn denied earlier testimony that he washed his own hands and flashlight with the peroxide. Police technicians have testified that they found blood in the car and on Mr. Nevers's clothing and flashlight, but not on Mr. Budzyn or his equipment.
Under cross-examination, Mr. Budzyn said there was no reason Mr. Green should have been killed.
The three former police officers are being tried together. But Mr. Budzyn and Mr. Nevers have separate juries, and Mr. Lessnau's case will be decided by Judge George Crockett 3d of Detroit Recorder's Court.
Mr. Nevers and the jury hearing his case were excused from the courtroom during Mr. Budzyn's testimony today.

HEADLINE: Prosecutors Reported Seeking to Widen Inquiry on Rostenkowski

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
As Capitol Hill buzzed about the news that one of its most powerful members had been accused of embezzlement, Federal officials said today that prosecutors were trying to broaden the case against Representative Dan Rostenkowski.
Officials and defense lawyers involved in the long-running investigation of Mr. Rostenkowski said prosecutors had been gathering evidence against him about a series of transactions in Chicago in an effort to link separate accusations of wrongdoing into a single, more serious case. 
 In doing so, the prosecutors would be following a tactic recently employed against other, less influential members of Congress: bringing charges under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The law, which provides especially severe penalties and gives prosecutors more time to act, was intended to create a new weapon against organized crime. It has been applied in other areas as well, a practice that has drawn criticism from defense lawyers.
 
Making Best of Situation
 Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, returned to Washington today from Chicago to begin delicate negotiations to move President Clinton's economic program through Congress and tried to act as if nothing had happened.
He refused to answer questions posed by reporters in the hallways of Congress and after emerging from a lunch at the White House with Mr. Clinton and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the head of the Senate Finance Committee.
Mr. Clinton, too, seemed intent on making the best of the situation. He allowed himself to be photographed with Mr. Rostenkowski during the lunch and insisted in response to a question that the Congressman's legal problems would have no effect on the budget deliberations.
"We've got a lot of work to do," he said in the White House family dining room. "Chairman Rostenkowki's done a great job with this budget so far and we've worked very closely together. And we're going to work today. I don't know anything about the rest of it."
Fellow lawmakers also said the latest disclosures would have little political impact. Representative Jack Brooks, the Texas Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee, echoed the views expressed by other colleagues, telling a reporter: "It's just a cloud. It's not a rain cloud, honey. It's a light cloud."
Mr. Rostenkowski has firmly controlled the committee he leads, the Ways and Means Committee, which writes tax legislation, and his support for the President's agenda on health care and welfare has been considered critical for passage. Under the House Democratic rules, he would have to step down as head of the committee if he was indicted.
On Monday the former postmaster of the House of Representatives reached a plea agreement with prosecutors and said he had helped the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee embezzle more than $20,000, according to court papers and Federal prosecutors. The former postmaster, Robert V. Rota, pleaded guilty to three misdemeanor counts of conspiracy and embezzlement and acknowledged that he had helped an undisclosed number of representatives steal tens of thousands of dollars for almost 20 years.
 
Immunity for Aide
 In recent weeks, the authorities have granted immunity to Virginia C. Fletcher, an aide to Mr. Rostenkowski for more than 30 years and his closest personal assistant, in exchange for her cooperation in the investigation, lawyers involved in the case said.
The investigation in Chicago is seeking to determine whether Mr. Rostenkowski converted campaign and taxpayer money for his own use and whether the racketeering law could be applied, Federal officials and defense lawyers said. No indictment is expected for weeks.
In his court appearance on Monday, Mr. Rota said he had given $21,300 to a person identified only as "Congressman A" from May 1985 through April 1991. The periodic payments described in court papers ranged from $900 to $2,800. Neither Mr. Rota nor the Government identified "Congressman A." But they provided voucher numbers for some of the transactions which, when matched with publicly available records, showed that the payments had been received by Mr. Rostenkowski.
 
Disbelief Among Colleagues
 Democrats and Republicans said they were puzzled about what could possibly motivate a man who had access to hundreds of millions of dollars in his fund raising and lobbying to steal in the petty amounts prosecutors have suggested.
"We've been friends for such a long time, I just can't believe the son of a gun would get himself involved in something like this," said Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader. "I can't believe it. I don't want to believe it."
But Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip from Georgia, used Mr. Rota's guilty plea to attack the Democrats.
"This is not a Congress scandal," Mr. Gingrich said. "Just as in Japan, this is about corrupt one-party rule for four decades. These are Democrats being named by a Democrat appointee under indictment."
In the pending public corruption cases the Government has charged that officials used their Congressional offices or campaigns as criminal enterprises. Those cases have been filed against Representative Joseph M. McDade, Republican of Pennsylvania, and two former Democratic members, Nicholas Mavroules of Massachusetts and Albert G. Bustamante of Texas.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Sears Reports Strong Rise In Second-Quarter Earnings

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 20

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company took another big step toward repairing its tarnished image on Wall Street today, posting a sharp jump in second-quarter profits.
Sears said the earnings reflected a faster payback than projected on its overhaul of retailing operations, including the recruitment of outside senior managers, closing some stores and renovating others and shutting the legendary Sears catalogue. 
 Additionally, the Allstate Corporation, which is 80 percent owned by Sears, reported surprisingly positive results, reflecting lower-than-expected losses for the insurer in automobile and catastrophe coverage.
"The economic environment hasn't improved all that much," said Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears and one of the most visible targets of restive shareholders before the company's drastic restructuring plan was announced last year. "We are generating a lot of the momentum internally."
 
'Starting to Catch Fire'

 
 The gains marked the second straight quarter that Sears had pleasantly surprised investors with the progress made under Arthur Martinez, who was recruited last year from Saks Fifth Avenue to oversee the revamping of retailing operations.
"They are starting to catch fire," said Edward A. Weller, a retailing analyst for Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco. Analysts had been raising estimates for the quarter based on monthly retail reports that showed Sears had fared better than most competitors. Still, their consensus had remained substantially less than the figures Sears reported today.
Sears said its net income in the three months ended June 30 more than tripled to $1.01 billion, from $325.5 million in the second quarter of 1992. That increase included a number of extraordinary gains and losses, among them a $635.1 million gain on the Allstate public offering in June and $145.3 million in expenses from early retirement of debt.
The quarter's figures also included income of more than $122 million from discontinued operations, mainly the interest Sears had in Dean Witter, Discover & Company after the public offering of the financial services and credit card company's stock in February. That remaining 80.1 percent stake in Dean Witter was spun off to Sears shareholders on June 30.
Revenues rose 5.6 percent for the quarter to $12.16 billion, from $11.51 billion a year ago. The year-ago figure excludes revenues from businesses the company has since exited.
 
Spinoffs a Key

 
 The restructuring plan included the sale of 19.9 percent of Allstate and a similar chunk of Dean Witter, Discover & Company to the public, the spinoff of the rest of Dean Witter to Sears shareholders, and the sale of the Coldwell Banker real estate operations.
The figures that really pleased Wall Street, though, were those showing that operating income from the Sears stores and other retailing outlets had jumped nearly 149 percent in the three months ended June 30 to $162.5 million from $65.3 million in the second quarter of 1992. Sears shares jumped $4.125, to $50.125, with more than four million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Most of the gain reflected ridding the balance sheet of the catalogue and other money-losing retail businesses. Still, income from the continuing business rose a solid 24 percent gain from $131.1 million and revenues from those businesses grew 6 percent, to $6.85 billion, led by strong sales in apparel and appliances.
Sears also benefited from the success of its public offering of Allstate shares on June 3 and Allstate's higher earnings, which lifted Sears's net income from its share of the insurance company 61.9 percent, to $371.8 million, from $229.6 million a year ago. Allstate's revenues rose just 4.2 percent, to $5.23 billion, but income from investments grew while the number and severity of property and casualty loss claims fell.
 
 
Allstate's Income Rises 55%

 
 Allstate reported that operating income for the second quarter rose 55 percent, to $351 million from $227 million, or to 83 cents a share from 52 cents a share. Allstate nearly broke even on an underwriting basis, spending $1 in claims and expenses for every $1 of premium income. In the corresponding period last year, Allstate spent $1.065 in claims and expenses for every premium dollar.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Allstate's shares closed up today 25 cents, to $30.625.

HEADLINE: Clinton Rallies Party Around Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
His economic program on the line, President Clinton gave a rousing speech today to a group of Democratic lawmakers who are crucial to the success of his plan, demanding that they exercise the political courage necessary to raise taxes and cut spending.
"Yes, it is painful," the President declared. "Yes, it is difficult. But it is progress. It is change. It will make a difference. We have come this far. This is no time to turn back. We have been bold. This is no time to be timid. We have faced this crisis squarely. This is no time to blink." 
 It was the first time he had addressed a large audience on Capitol Hill in public since his State of the Union Message in February, and he spoke with the same fervor and focus that won him rave reviews then.
"All the easy things have been done," the President said, and then he drew a prolonged ovation when he added: "The cost of doing nothing is far higher in political and economic terms than paying the price of progress today."
 
Concerted Drive
 The speech was delivered to about 150 Democratic conferees on the budget legislation and members of their staffs who gathered under the chandeliers in the Caucus Room of the Cannon House Office Building, across Independence Avenue from the Capitol.
It came as House and Senate conferees began in earnest a drive against a deadline of the first week in August to write budget legislation, and it touched off a full-bore drive by the President and others in the Administration to sell the economic program.
For weeks, Democrats in Congress have faulted the President for what they saw as laxity in promoting his economic plans and have fretted that the prospects for his program were falling at the same rate as his popularity rating.
Just this morning, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is the chief Senate conferee on tax matters, said that as of today he did not have the votes in the Senate to pass a deficit-reduction measure that could also pass the House of Representatives, and he suggested that the White House did not grasp that reality.
 
Some See a Turning Point
 But the speech, given shortly after the President had lunch with Mr. Moynihan and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the most important conferee from the House, boosted the spirits of the legislators more than anything else in months, and some suggested it would be a political turning point.
"The President hit this into the cheap seats," said Representative Jim Slattery of Kansas, a moderate who has sometimes been at odds with Mr. Clinton, especially on energy taxes. "I'd love to have him come to Kansas and explain this to the people of Kansas."
Representative Henry A. Waxman of California called it "a terrific speech to stir us up."
But will it swing any votes? "I think it may," Mr. Waxman replied. "It makes us refocus."
For the next two weeks, Mr. Clinton plans to concentrate almost entirely on getting the budget enacted, speaking here and twisting arms there in what could be a make-or-break period for his Presidency.
Others in the Administration have their roles also. Last week, the White House distributed a memorandum, "Hallelujah: Change is Coming," including pointers like: "Any time you're asked about a specific in the economic plan, look for ways to bring it back to the general points that this is good for the country, and this is real change."
 
Tough Road to Compromise
 The budget legislation was initially approved by the narrowest of margins -- 219 to 213 in the House in May and 50 to 49 in the Senate last month with Vice President Al Gore casting a tie-breaking vote.
The House and Senate bills are similar in most respects. They would reduce the Federal budget deficit by a total of $500 billion over the next five years, largely by raising the taxes of wealthy individuals and cutting military spending.
But there are enough differences, especially over energy taxes and spending on social programs, that finding an acceptable compromise will be touch and go, and even the President's staunchest supporters are edgy.
Senator David Pryor of Arkansas said he had told his friend the President, "Each Democratic Senator has tremendous power, and we can't afford to lose a single vote."
This morning, the conferees on tax issues tentatively approved several items where the House and Senate bills were identical or differed only slightly.
 
Action on Corporate Tax
 The agreed, for instance, to raise the corporate tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent and to prohibit in some circumstances tax deductions by publicly owned companies for the salaries of executives exceeding $1 million. They also agreed to deny business deductions for club dues, including airline and hotel clubs, and to prohibit business executives from deducting their spouses' travel costs when they accompany the executives on business trips.
Tonight, the House conferees made their first offer of compromise to their Senate counterparts, and like the initial offer in a typical labor negotiation, no consequential concessions were made. The Senate conferees will make their first counteroffer Wednesday.
In his speech this afternoon, the President avoided specific controversies. He never mentioned, for example, energy taxes.
But he gave some clues to his thinking when he said he did not believe Medicare spending should be limited any more than it was in the Senate's bill, and he said he would insist on some tax breaks for small businesses and on special tax treatment for businesses that open in certain poor neighborhoods.
"Somehow," he said, "we haven't found a way to take a big old knife and cut through the rhetorical fog that has been blanketing our efforts in this town for the last several months."
"We can come out of this conference with a plan that can pass the conference and, more importantly, can pass the political judgment of the American people if we make sure they know what is in it," he said.

HEADLINE: CHANGE AT THE F.B.I.;
Clinton Names New York Judge As F.B.I. Chief

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
President Clinton finished assembling his roster of top crime fighters today with the announcement that he would appoint Judge Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court in Manhattan to replace William S. Sessions as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
In making the expected appointment of Mr. Freeh, who ended up as the only member on the Administration's short list for the F.B.I. job, Mr. Clinton also sought to lay to rest an issue that has hung like a cloud over his Administration for six months: the turmoil within the F.B.I. as Mr. Sessions fought to stay in his job. Mr. Sessions was dismissed on Monday, after he had refused to resign. 
 The appointment of Mr. Freeh is subject to confirmation by the Senate. Mr. Clinton has selected Floyd I. Clarke, Mr. Sessions' deputy and political nemesis, to serve as director in the interim.
 
Main Threats to Society
 Citing white-collar crime, drug trafficking and gang warfare as the prime criminal threats to society, Mr. Clinton said he expected Judge Freeh to join Attorney General Janet Reno and his drug policy coordinator, Lee Brown, as "a street-smart front line against crime."
"These law enforcers did not learn about crime in theory books," Mr. Clinton said. "They learned about it on the streets and in the courtroom, and they have learned the best lessons of state and local enforcers."
Mr. Freeh's appointment won immediate endorsements from leading senators. Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said that Judge Freeh's credentials appeared impressive and that he intended to work to have a Senate vote on the nomination by the August recess. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee, which will vote on the nomination, also praised Mr. Freeh, calling him "ideally suited for the job."
Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, joined Judge Freeh at the White House announcement today and also promised quick action on his nomination.
 
'Instant Credibility'
 "Lou Freeh brings instant credibility to the job," Mr. D'Amato said.
There was no sign of trouble for the Freeh nomination today. It will probably come before the Senate Judiciary committee once the panel finishes its work on the nomination of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court.
"Anyone doubting the need for an efficient F.B.I. need only read the front page or watch the evening news," Mr. Freeh said at a Rose Garden ceremony. "What most Americans once thought impossible has now occurred here: a terrorist bomb that killed, maimed and spread terror in our nation's largest city. "We now live in a global village in terms of law enforcement."
Mr. Clinton made clear that he will quickly seek to capitalize on the bipartisan approval that has greeted his nominations of Judges Freeh and Ginsburg. He went to Capitol Hill today to lobby wavering members of Congress on his economic plan, and he will make the same pitch to small-business owners in Maryland on Wednesday.
"We have come this far," he said today to the members of the budget conference committees. "This is no time to turn back. We have been bold. This is no time to be timid. We have faced this crisis squarely. This is no time to blink."

HEADLINE: Rebate Offer Should Not Harm G.M.

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 20

 BODY:
G.M.'s proposed settlement of lawsuits related to the company's pickup trucks is unlikely to create a huge financial liability for the No. 1 auto maker, analysts said today.
Late Monday, the General Motors Corporation said it would settle 36 class-action lawsuits by giving certificates for a $1,000 rebate on the purchase of a new truck to owners of G.M. pickups equipped with side-mounted fuel tanks from the years 1973 to 1987. Critics say the trucks are more likely to catch fire or explode in an accident than other vehicles. 
 G.M. said the settlement would not be a financial drain on it, even though the value of the rebates could theoretically exceed $5 billion, since 4.7 million to 6 million trucks are involved.
But Ron Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, estimated that the rebate program was likely to be far less expensive, costing about $1 billion. "Many of these coupons are going to end up in the hands of people who were going to buy these trucks anyway," he said.
Wendy Needham, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York, called the program's cost minimal. "It's a way to deal with the agony of litigation," she said.
The rest of Wall Street appeared to agree with those assessments. G.M.'s shares rose $1.125 today, to $48.875.
The settlement, which is subject to approval by a Federal district court in Philadelphia, did not resolve G.M.'s dispute with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The Federal agency has sought a truck recall, but G.M. has refused, maintaining that the trucks are safe.
Lawyers for the plaintiffs said they could still seek damages for personal injuries since the settlement applied only to economic loss caused by the trucks' reduced resale value.
Results of a similar move by Audi in 1988 implied that G.M.'s program might cost far less than $1 billion.
Less than 1 percent of the roughly 200,000 owners of the Audi 5000 used $4,000 to $5,000 discounts offered by the German auto maker toward the purchase of new Audi models. The discounts were offered after consumer groups contended that the Audi 5000 was prone to sudden, unintended acceleration. If the same percentage of owners of G.M. pickups use the discounts, the cost to G.M. could be less than $50 million.

HEADLINE: Angrily, Clinton Defends Record

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
As reporters questioned him by satellite hookup today, President Clinton angrily declared that he had built a record of uncommon success in his first six months and accused the news media of blocking his message.
Mr. Clinton's satellite interviews were intended to spread his economic message without going through the filter of Washington press coverage. But when the reporters in Louisiana and Wisconsin questioned him closely about his commitment to the energy tax he has proposed and his ability to keep promises, Mr. Clinton grew impatient. 
 "I would like for you to go back and analyze the first six months of the previous Administrations and tell me who got more done in six months," he said. "If you can tell me, I'll be glad to hear it. If there isn't anybody you can find who's done more, then we need to examine why the American people don't know that."
He also grew angry when he was asked whether a strong leader would have compromised on a promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military.
"I am the first President who ever took on this issue," Mr. Clinton responded tightly. "Is that a sign of weakness?"
Gay troops, he said, "are much better off today because we took an honorable compromise."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- ADVERTISING;
A Corporate Campaign Tries Selling Toyota's U.S. Presence.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
IN the old days, the words "economy car" in advertising carried an unambiguous meaning. They described a vehicle that was small, affordable and efficient.
These days, it's more complicated. Clouded by lopsided trade balances, a troubled economy and issues of protectionism, a sales pitch is not necessarily what it seems. For example, a current ad for Toyota appearing in news magazines shows a spiffy new four-door Camry in profile below big red and black letters that say, "economy car," which it may well be, at a base price of $14,000. 
 But less than a sales pitch for Toyota the car, the ad is selling Toyota the company -- Toyota, the American company, at a time when large segments of the population have grown sensitive to the origin of the products they purchase. Not to be minimized as a motivation to buy, those kinds of sentiments are why a variety of companies pluck the chords of nationalism in their ad campaigns, like Wal-Mart's "Sam's American Choice" or Du Pont's use of "Made in the U.S.A."
Never mind that some products, or parts of some, like a Toyota Camry, might be made elsewhere. Patriotism is often the last refuge of a salesman for its power to sway an undecided buyer or a buyer for whom nationalism might be the tie-breaking factor.
The Toyota ad, which was created by the Oasis International Group in New York, makes the point that Toyota, as a Japanese company with an American presence since 1957, now employs 15,000 people in the United States through a $5 billion investment, and invests another $4 billion through the purchase of parts used to make the cars.
"At Toyota," the copy reads, "we believe in the importance of investing in the economies where we do business."
A companion ad shows the same picture of the Camry amid copy that says, "We buy the best parts in the world, no matter which state they're from." Surrounding the picture are the names of 44 parts and the American states in which they are made.
In both ads, the implicit message is that while this is a Japanese-brand car, it is American made, and that's good for the United States economy.
"These are is not intended to be political ads," Tim Andree, group manager of external affairs for Toyota in New York, said. "It's for educational purposes about a global company with a Japanese name. The point we want to make is that Toyota's presence in America is positive. As we've grown here, we have reinvested, and we will continue to invest in the market."
At least six Japanese auto makers manufacture cars in the United States. They include Honda, Nissan, Mazda, Mitsubishi and Suburu, as well as Toyota. Their plants employing a total of more than 35,000 Americans, according to figures complied by the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association in Washington. In a 16-page brochure, the association uses charts, graphs and maps to show how the United States economy has benefited from Japanese car makers.
But in some ways, does not even a suggestion of nationalism as a rationale for purchase provide yet another means to widen the kind of socio-ethnic differences that divide a society? Expert opinions vary.
"The question is whether the ad improves a perception or exacerbates a problem," said Jack Myers, who has written several books on advertising, including "Ad Bashing: Surviving the Attacks on Advertising."
"It raises the question," he added, "whether they should be trying to compete as an American company or trying to legitimize the internationalism of their business. The more you cater to nationalistic tendencies, the more the propensity of nationalism gains strength, and that isolates. And that's dangerous."
Sal Randazzo, a senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York and the author of "Mythmaking on Madison Avenue," said he'd like to give the car manufacturer the benefit of the doubt.
"If it's true that Toyota has contributed to our society and is responsible for all those jobs, then they have the right to blow their own horn to offset that quote, foreign, unquote perception," he said. "I don't see anything inherently wrong with it. A consumer is buying the company as much as buying the product. So I think it's legitimate, especially with American companies pushing nationalism. If the Japanese companies didn't do it, they would be left in that other place."
He added, "I would just like to think they're doing it for the right reasons."

HEADLINE: Prescription for Airline Industry: Tinker Just a Bit

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With Congress making noises about stanching the airline industry's financial hemorrhage and President Clinton going out of his way to lend a sympathetic ear to the industry's pleas for help, free marketeers have been on the defensive.
At best, they figured, the commission set up to advise the President and Congress on how to solve the industry's problems would merely be a soapbox for complaints about unbridled competition. At worst, they thought it would rally a coalition of interest groups that would lobby for reregulation of fares and routes. 
 The panel -- named the National Commission to Ensure a Strong, Competitive Airline Industry -- issued its preliminary report Monday, and it did, in fact, debate steps back toward regulation.
 
Strongly Held Views
 But free-market-minded members including John Robson, a former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, and Daniel Kasper, a consultant at Harbridge House in Boston, made clear that the group -- a politically awkward assemblage of special-interest representatives and public-policy notables appointed by Congress and the President -- would never reach consensus on a radical departure from open competition.
The free-market camp reportedly received crucial support from a panel member, Herbert Kelleher, the president of Southwest Airlines and the head of the only post-deregulation airline that has minted money in both good times and bad.
On balance, suggests Alfred Kahn, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, which has been abolished, and the guru of transportation deregulation in the Carter Administration, "The commission deserves credit for resisting what must have been very strong political pressures to reregulate." What's more, he notes, its proposal to reorganize the air traffic control system on a businesslike footing is eminently sensible.
Almost everyone agrees that stockholders and creditors in the airline industry have lost pots of money in the last few years. That, however, is about all they agree on.
Some members of Congress, notably Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, chairman of the Commerce Committee, say that the industry's lemming-like rush to expand with borrowed money proves that airline deregulation has been a bust.
Some, including Robert Crandall, American Airlines' outspoken president, blame the bankruptcy laws, which have permitted a host of insolvent carriers to keep flying.
 
Placing Fault
 Some link the red ink to larger macroeconomic forces. "The losses in the industry are closely correlated with recession and jet fuel prices," commented David Swierenga, chief economist of the Air Transport Association.
Still others -- probably including most economists -- are skeptical that there is cause for concern if too many planes are chasing too few passengers. "If there's overcapacity in the business, it's no one's fault but the airlines," said William Niskanen, chairman of the conservative-leaning Cato Institute in Washington.
The commission did recommend that bankrupt carriers be forced to reorganize or go out of business within one year. But it rejected the idea that fire-sale pricing by bankrupt carriers was the primary cause of the industry's problems. A one-year deadline is not likely to draw anyone to the barricades.
The group also went along with the idea of creating a board to keep the Transportation Department informed on the financial status of the airlines, a proposal dismaying to some. Mr. Kahn sees it as the proverbial camel's nose. But Mr. Kasper reassures, insisting that advice means no more than advice. "The commission does not favor reregulation," he emphasized.
While the commission went out of its way to avoid heavy-duty controversy, it did offer recommendations that are sure to stir the waters.
One is to lower the tax burden on airlines, a proposal that Washington will not welcome in the midst of delicate negotiations over deficit reduction. Many industries have been reeling under the brunt of the 90's slowdown, and it is far from clear why the industry should be singled out for special treatment. But the carriers may yet benefit from forces beyond their influence: the House version of the budget bill offers relief from the alternative minimum tax for all corporations including airlines.
But the recommendation with the greatest potential impact concerns the Federal Aviation Administration.
 
Freedom for the F.A.A.
 The commission wants to "corporatize" the F.A.A., freeing it from the inertia of Government procurement policies and giving it wide discretion to deliver services and meet its revenue needs from cost-based user fees.
This is not likely to happen next month or next year: lawmakers are sure to resist any administrative change that puts beyond their control decisions about which airport needs a new computer or what brand the F.A.A. buys. But this proposal does give the airlines, their unions and their suppliers a very practical goal around which to close ranks. And that is no small achievement.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Citicorp's Income Posts Sharp Gain In Quarter

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, posted sharply higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, continuing its recovery from a disaterous run-in with bad real estate loans.
In what is turning out to be a very good period for America's banks, several other large banking companies also reported increased earnings yesterday, including the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Nationsbank Corporation. 
 Citicorp reported earnings of $446 million, up from $143 million in the second quarter last year. Citicorp earned $370 million in the first quarter before a $300 million gain for accounting changes.
In the second quarter, Citicorp earned 88 cents a share, sharply higher than the 60 cents a share analysts had expected. Most of that difference was accounted for by higher trading profits. Other large banks, including Chase Manhattan and J.P. Morgan, have also benefited from volatile currency and bond markets.
Citicorp said it had revenues of $352 million from currency trading and $220 million from securities trading, both nearly double the level of a year earlier.
The bank's losses from bad loans continued to decrease. The bank's credit costs, which include bad debts written off and the expense of managing troubled assets, were $297 million for loans to business, down from $380 million in the first quarter and a peak of $792 million in the fourth quarter of 1991.
Credit costs from consumer loans declined slightly, to $708 million, adjusted to include credit card loans that were packaged and sold as securities, compared with $716 million in the first quarter.
The bank reduced its portfolio of North American real estate assets by $900 million, to $15.6 billion, with most of the decrease coming from borrowers paying off their debts. The bank's problem real estate loans and holdings of foreclosed property also declined in the quarter.
The bank's operating costs were up 4 percent from the year before, representing higher spending on advertising in the United states and investments in the consumer business in developing countries
Citicorp also continued to increase its capital, although the bank remains the least well capitalized of the country's major banks. The bank's Tier-1 capital ratio, a key measure of financial strength, increased to 5.7 percent of assets from 5.2 percent at the end of March and 4.3 percent a year earlier. The country's largest banks averaged a Tier-1 capital ratio of 8.8 percent in the first quarter.
Citicorp increased its profitability, posting a return on equity of 16.9 percent for the quarter, a relatively high figure, more than triple the rate a year earlier. The bank said it had better results in less developed countries of Latin America and Asia than in the recession-bound developed world.
As they have with other banks, analysts following Citicorp have begun to turn their attention from current problems to the prospects for future growth.
"The major concern is the slow recovery in the U.S. and the recession in Europe will slow the improvement in Citi's credit quality and its new business flow," said Diane B. Glossman, an analyst with Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines After a Lift Linked to Hint of a Rate Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other leading currencies yesterday after getting a brief lift from the Federal Reserve chairman's suggestion that United States interest rates would rise if inflation began to take off.
Gold prices fell overseas, but were mixed domestically. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery was at $392.20, down 20 cents. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $391.80, up 60 cents. 
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress that the inflation level was "disappointing." He indicated that the Fed would raise interest rates if prices started to shoot up.
The dollar, which had traded at 1.7063 German marks late Monday, rose to 1.7150 marks after Mr. Greenspan's remarks. But it drifted down to 1.6997 in late trading in New York.
Also in New York, the dollar was quoted at 108.15 Japanese yen yesterday, down from 108.46 a day earlier. The British pound, meanwhile, rose to $1.5110 in New York, from $1.4985 on Monday.
 
Warning Not So Dire
 Normally, an indication of higher interest rates would spur investment in a currency. But currency brokers said investors did not regard Mr. Greenspan's warnings as that dire.
They said the market was not as concerned that the recent run-up in gold prices indicates impending inflation, as Mr. Greenspan had suggested in his remarks.
"I'm not certain how high of a concern Mr. Greenspan raised with his comment about gold," said Rick Porter, vice president and manager of corporate treasury at Bank Brussels Lambert.
Investors may also have bought German marks because of a rumor in the markets that Germany has exceeded its targets for growth in the money supply, traders said. Rapid money growth produces inflation. If Germany's money supply is expanding faster than expected, the central bank would likely keep interest rates high.
Traders also noted that investors' fears had been calmed about imminent disruption in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. Such worries last week had prompted speculators to buy dollars and sell European currencies.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
CATARACT surgery today is a far cry from the procedure of decades past. Back then, patients waited until their vision was nearly totally obscured by a cloudy lens and were then hospitalized for 10 days or more, their heads immobile with sandbags while their eyes healed. They were then sent home with Coke-bottle spectacles that restored their sight but greatly enlarged and distorted visual images.
Today the surgery is usually an outpatient procedure under local anesthesia, with a rapid return to normal activities and excellent vision correction with ordinary lenses. It is often done as soon as the cataract begins to interfere with normal activities. Nearly everyone, regardless of medical history, can have the surgery. 
 In the last decade or so cataract surgery has become so swift, safe and effective that some experts say it is now being done too soon or too often on patients who may never need it. About 1.3 million cataracts are removed in this country each year and as the population ages, the pool of potential patients keeps growing.
With surgeons' fees ranging from $1,000 (under Medicare) to as much as $5,000, and with surgical centers charging $1,200 to $4,000 or more for anesthesia and materials, cataract surgery mills have sprung up, and unnecessary cataract surgery has become an economic and medical concern.
However safe, cataract surgery is not free of risk. Patients who are told they have cataracts should understand more about the condition, when something should be done about it and risks and benefits of the various procedures involved.
 
Who Has Cataracts
 A cataract is a clouding of the normally transparent lens of the eye, the disk in the center of the pupil that directs incoming images to the retina. The condition can be caused by many noxious factors, including trauma, toxic substances, metabolic problems, like uncontrolled diabetes, and excessive exposure to sunlight. But the most common cause is simply a natural aging process.
Cataracts develop slowly and may never reach the point where they interfere with a person's chosen activities. However, some people mistakenly think their gradual loss of visual acuity is an inevitable and uncorrectable part of the aging process, and may suffer needlessly when simple surgery could restore their sight.
Population studies suggest that 15 percent of people from 50 to 85 years old have cataracts "ripe" enough to reduce their visual acuity. Some clouding of the lens can be detected in more than 40 percent of people from 55 to 64 and in up to three-fourths of those from 65 to 74, but only a minority have significant visual loss.
In a recent consensus report, the United States Agency for Health Care Policy and Research recommended that a loss of visual acuity to 20/50 with glasses be used as an objective criterion for surgery. However, the agency emphasized that more subjective criteria, involving the patient's visual demands and infirmities, determine the need for surgery.
Thus, surgery may be warranted to remove a relatively young cataract from someone who finds that it interferes with reading, driving or playing tennis, but a more advanced cataract may not be removed from someone who neither reads nor drives, but mostly walks and watches TV.
 
Treating Cataracts
 Modern cataract surgery typically takes less than an hour and involves a small incision through the cornea and sclera that permits the surgeon to push out or suck out the cloudy lens, leaving the lens capsule in place. Some surgeons use a procedure known as phacoemulsification, in which the lens is first shattered by ultrasound waves and the pieces are sucked out through a tiny incision.
In either case, in 90 percent of cases an artificial lens is slipped in to replace the one that was removed. But unlike a normal lens, the artificial one is adjusted only for distance vision and cannot change shape to focus on nearby images. So about two to four months later, after the eye has fully healed and stabilized, the patient is fitted with standard eyeglasses to restore near-normal acuity.
Most patients go home the same day, wearing an eye patch for 24 hours, and returning to normal activities the next day. They are advised to avoid exertion like bending and heavy lifting for several weeks. They get antibiotic and steroid eye drops to prevent infection and reduce inflammation.
Besides the minimal risks of local anesthesia, other risks include hemorrhage, infection and damage to the retina. The most common complication is a vision-obscuring thickening of the lens capsule. A laser is typically used to prevent or relieve the problem, but laser therapy also has risks.
In a study of 57,103 Medicare cataract patients by researchers at Georgetown and Johns Hopkins universities, 2 percent of patients who have the laser treatment suffer serious retinal damage and partial or total loss of vision in the affected eye. Of the more than half-million people treated each year with the laser, younger white males are at greatest risk of this complication, the researchers found. They advised using the laser only for patients impaired by postoperative clouding of the lens.
 
Precautions
 In choosing an ophthalmological surgeon to treat your cataract, look for someone who has done hundreds of the procedures but avoid those who do only cataract surgery lest you fall into the hands of a cataract-mill surgeon who cares more about the fee than the patient's quality of life.
If you get the feeling that you are being railroaded into surgery you are not sure you need, or if you are troubled by a cataract your surgeon is reluctant to treat, seek a second and, if necessary, a third opinion.
Also check your insurance coverage carefully. Medicare and most private insurers typically reimburse 80 percent of the surgeon's fee and what are deemed "reasonable" charges by the medical center. But ambulatory surgicenters certified by Medicare receive the full reasonable charge, reducing the financial burden on the patient. Like Medicare, private insurers may have caps on the amount they will pay, which could mean a big bill for the patient.
 
All About Cataracts
 Dr. Julius Shulman, a New York ophthalmologist, has revised his book "Cataracts" (St. Martin's Press, $18.95), which covers everything about the condition, from causes and diagnosis to treatment and recovery.
Also consider these protective measures: Stay out of the sun as much as possible; if you wear glasses, get lenses with full ultraviolet protection, and do the same with sunglasses. Consume plenty of fruits and vegetables rich in antioxidant vitamins, beta-carotene and vitamin C, and consider taking a daily supplement of vitamin E.
