HEADLINE: 'Expert' Babies Found to Teach Others

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
IT was during the blustery days of last March that 10-month-old Russell Ruud taught the other babies in his day-care group a lesson their parents may have wished he hadn't: how to unzip the Velcro chin straps of their winter hats.
"One day I went to pick Russell up and his teacher told me that the other mothers were complaining that their children had learned from him how to take off their hats," said Dr. Judith Ruud, Russell's mother and, at the time, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, just a few blocks from the Trinity Preschool in Manhattan. 
 "I never showed Russell how to unzip the Velcro," said Ms. Ruud, now with the Congressional Budget Office in Washington. "He learned it by trial and error, and the other kids saw him do it one day when they were getting dressed for an outing."
While Russell's tutorial was perhaps not what all parents would want their children to learn at school, it exemplifies something that new research is identifying as an unexpected advantage of day care and play groups: even the youngest toddlers are able to learn new skills from each other, and the abilities one acquires can quickly spread to others.
"The surprise is to find that preverbal babies can take home with them what they learn from other babies," said Dr. Andrew N. Meltzoff, a developmental psychologist at the University of Washington, who has conducted a series of studies with 128 toddlers showing they have a remarkable ability to learn from each other, and that what they learn in a group is retained outside the group setting. An article on his findings appears in the July issue of the journal Developmental Psychology.
To be sure, every parent knows that children learn a lot from their playmates. But the new findings push back the earliest age at which children were thought to learn skills from each other to a stage of life before children are able to talk.
 
Positive Picture of Day Care
 One implication is that day care for young toddlers may represent an enriched educational setting simply because it exposes children to other children and their diversity of simple skills. The findings come at a time when day care is a fact of life for more and more parents; Census Bureau data suggest that one of the fastest-growing segments of the work force is mothers of children under 1 year old.
The new research may offer a bit of solace to working parents with regard to a choice that many cannot avoid. And these findings fit with others that give a positive picture of the long-term impact of early day care.
"We have data showing that the earlier kids start in high-quality day care, the more advantaged they are intellectually and socially in the long run," said Dr. Tiffany Field, a psychologist in the pediatrics department at the University of Miami Medical School.
In her research, published in the journal Child Development in 1991, Dr. Field evaluated 84 children in the first through sixth grades and found that those who had started day care early fared best academically and socially.
Other experts are more cautious. "There may be some small advantage for very young children in day care because of this kind of imitative learning, though I certainly wouldn't make that a main reason for sending a child," said Dr. Lewis Lippsitt, a developmental psychologist at Brown University.
The learning that goes on in the first year or two of life is through watching and imitating. Such learning among toddlers in day care is something like the cooperative learning that is gaining popularity in elementary and high schools. Some experts believe this pooling of skills may in part explain other findings of enhanced development among children who attended high-quality day care when compared with those who stayed home or had poor care.
 
Babies Remember Skills
 "The new twist was to test whether young toddlers would imitate their peers, and whether this learning was robust enough to persist at home after a substantial passage of time," said Dr. Meltzoff, who did the research with Elizabeth Hanna, a graduate student. Psychologists have long studied how infants use a natural talent as mimics to learn how to handle the challenges of life.
The researchers invented five simple toys that a 1-year-old could master with some coaching, so that none of the babies would have seen them before or learned how to use them elsewhere. One toy, for example, was a collapsible plastic cup made of progressively larger rings; the cup would collapse if a child pushed it down with a flat hand. Another allowed a baby to ring a bell by pressing a button hidden in a hole in a box.
In the first phase of the study, babies an average of 14 months old were trained as "experts" by sitting on their mother's laps while they watched an experimenter demonstrate a toy. The children then tried the toys themselves and were praised for using them correctly.
Next, the expert babies showed other babies how each of the five toys worked by playing with them while the others watched. The babies who watched were given a chance to play with the toys for a few minutes immediately after the demonstration; they played with each of the five toys correctly 64 percent of the time.
In a later phase of the study, with children of about 20 months old, expert toddlers were brought into a day- care center and, after playing with the other toddlers, demonstrated the toys while the others were seated around a table watching. The expert babies demonstrated each toy just once, with the others watching but not allowed to touch. Then all the toddlers went back to playing.
It wasn't until two days later, when the toys were brought to the homes of all the toddlers who had watched, that they were able to play with them at all. They played properly with the toys 72 percent of the time.
 
Advantages Persist for Years
 "These findings provide direct evidence that young toddlers in day care centers can learn and remember what they see other children do, even after a substantial delay and in a completely different setting," said Dr. Meltzoff. "And this learning is without any chance for trial and error themselves, but simply by watching another toddler do something just once."
While earlier research, including several studies by Dr. Meltzoff, had demonstrated that even very young babies can imitate simple acts, these experiments are the first to test if toddlers can remember and repeat what they have seen after time has passed and in a different setting, without the memory cues that setting might offer. Such long-term transfer of memory is considered a crucial test of learning in everyday life.
"This imitative learning is a large part of why kids in good early day care have advantages in the long run," said Dr. Field. "When we looked at kids in elementary school, the earlier they had started day care, the higher their scores on math tests and the more likely they were to be in gifted programs, the more popular they were with their peers, the more assertive their teachers rated them and the more emotionally stable they were."
The advantages of early day care may persist into the teen-age years, according to findings from a 1992 Swedish study, which evaluated 128 children at age 13. A government subsidy allows for what many experts consider to be model day care programs, and many Swedish children begin day care before they are 1 year old. The Swedish study focused on children who entered day care at from 6 to 12 months of age.
In an earlier evaluation of the children when they were 8 years old, the Swedish researchers found that those who entered day care before their first birthday were rated by their third-grade teachers as more persistent, independent, verbally facile, calm and socially confident than other children. They found no negative characteristics common to the children in early day care group.
Five years later, as the children entered adolescence, some advantages for those who entered day care at an early age still held: they performed better academically and were more creative, popular and independent than the other children.
 
Finding Quality Day Care
 The quality of day care is crucial. "Low-quality day care does not have the advantages," said Dr. Field. In addition, while these two studies show surprisingly long-term benefits of day care, experts say that the final word about advantages and drawbacks of day care is not yet in. A large Federal study of many different sites is now under way.
Points to look for in day care include an optimal ratio of children to teachers. If there are too many teachers, for instance, they may socialize more with each other than with the children; if there are too few teachers, the result is a destructive chaos. For 1-year-olds, a 4-to-1 ratio of children to teachers is considered best; for 2 and 3 year olds there should be an 8-to-1 ratio and for 4 and 5 year olds there should be a 12-to-1 ratio, said Dr. Field.
"High quality also means an enriched environment, with plenty of toys and other materials, enough space for kids to play on their own and a well-organized daily routine," he said. "In addition to what kids in day care learn from each other and their teachers, they also learn how to get along as sociable creatures, so that when they get to grade school they don't have to figure that out and can focus better on their academic work."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Blue-Chip Park Plan On Shaky Foundation

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If George Steinbrenner considers New Jersey a serious bargaining chip in his threat to abandon Yankee Stadium and New York, he probably shouldn't be so quick to take a free ride across the George Washington Bridge.
New Jersey officials have suggested that they could finance a stadium for the Yankees with gambling revenues from Atlantic City casinos, but baseball officials long have been uncomfortable with any link to casinos. 
 Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and the man in charge of major league baseball in the absence of a commissioner, said yesterday that he had not heard about the New Jersey plan. But he added: "That raises an interesting question that would have to be looked at."
 
Money for a Stadium
 The state's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority receives 1.25 percent of the gross winnings from each of Atlantic City's 12 casinos. The money is used primarily for housing and economic development in Atlantic City and South Jersey, but Nicholas Amato, head of the authority, has said that money -- as much as $250 million -- is available for projects in North Jersey.
Some of those funds, he said, could help finance a baseball stadium. Other state officials have supported the idea, which would not require taxpayer approval. The Yankees, who held talks with Amato last year, have declined to comment on the possible casino plan.
Talk of a stadium for the Yankees comes at a time when the casinos are pushing the State Legislature to approve betting on professional sports at the casinos. A provision in a Federal law gives New Jersey until the end of this year to consider legalization of sports betting. All professional sports oppose such betting as a threat to the integrity of their leagues, and the issue faces possible insurmountable obstacles in the state.
Fay Vincent, baseball's most recent commissioner, said yesterday that proponents of legalized sports betting in New Jersey have proposed putting a percentage of money gambled on sports into the casino reinvestment fund.
"That would be perverse," Vincent said in a telephone interview, of the idea of luring the Yankees to New Jersey with gambling money when baseball is totally opposed to sports betting.
"Baseball's leverage would be to say there's no way we'll approve a move to New Jersey," he added, "unless you drop the idea of sports betting at the casinos. George Steinbrenner and baseball should come out strongly and say they won't consider a move otherwise."
A few years ago, when he was still the commissioner, Vincent recalled, the idea of sports betting was under consideration by the District of Columbia council.
"I took the position that if D.C. passes sports betting, Washington will not be a candidate for an expansion team," he said. "It's consistent. Any community that takes a position that's so negative to sports should recognize what it's doing."
 
Voters Reject Plan
 New Jersey doesn't seem to have an alternative to the casino-fund proposal. In a referendum in 1987, the state's voters rejected a proposal to build a stadium with public money, and given the economy in recent years, the voters would not be expected to be any more inclined now to approve such spending. Although the Yankees' lease with the Stadium runs through 2002, a new ball park, regardless of the location, would need to be in the works well before the deadline.
If baseball's executive council, after investigating a casino-fund idea, found it onerous (one council member yesterday called it "a somewhat vexing matter"), Steinbrenner would be left without the New Jersey option, which has been his most attractive and -- to New York -- threatening choice.

HEADLINE: Top Chefs Try to Develop Taste for Amazon Fish At Rain-Forest Benefit

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
FOR the last few years, we've been inundated with rain-forest products, especially fruits and nuts, to highlight the plight of threatened tropical regions. Now, along come fish.
An exotic contingent consisting of tucunare, filhote, tambaqui, pescada, piramutaba and dourada were recently flown to this country for a benefit that had two goals: to interest chefs in using the Amazon fish, and to alert people that fish, too, are linked to the imperiled ecology of rain forests. 
 The benefit, in East Hampton, L.I., on Kay LeRoy's rolling lawns, raised money for the Rainforest Alliance, a nonprofit organization based in New York that is dedicated to preserving the world's tropical forests.
About the only fish from the Amazon River most people can name is the voraciously carnivorous piranha, which, although supposedly delectable, was not served at the benefit because it is annoyingly bony. But there were plenty of other choices, as there are 3,000 species of freshwater fish that inhabit the Amazon, a river system that includes a fifth of all the world's river water.
By creating a larger market for the fish, fish farms could be organized in the Amazon region. That would help preserve the rain forest by creating jobs for local people and using, but not overusing, the local resources.
"Deforestation not only destroys land, it also damages the Amazon flood plain which is the habitat of these fish," said Michael Goulding, a research scientist at the University of Florida in Gainsville who is director of the alliance's Amazon Rivers Project.
Each guest paid $250 to taste the fish and trappings created for them by some of the New York area's best-known chefs, including David Bouley, Gilbert Le Coze, Jean Jacques Rachou, Ed Brown, Charles Palmer, Michel Bourdeaux, David Waltuck, Eric Ripert, Debra Ponzek, Andre Soltner and Pat Trama. These chefs, who either work in Manhattan or East Hampton, would not normally touch a frozen fish, much less a block of tucunare or a whole frozen tambaqui.
But freezing the fish was essential because of the hot climate and the remoteness of the fishery, 1,000 miles up the Amazon in Brazil. It also destroyed any parasites that might be present in the fish.
Although initially wary of using frozen fish, the chefs were generally impressed with their taste. One that was served, tambaqui, eats fruits and nuts from trees that become submerged when the Amazon floods. It grows to 70 pounds and has bones like spare ribs and teeth like a horse. "It's like nothing I've ever seen, and I'd use it again," said Charles Palmer, the chef and co-owner of Aureole in Manhattan.
Among the dishes served were Moroccan spiced tambaqui with sweet onion marmalade, filhote with mango salsa and crispy ginger, and marinated pescada with green papaya and herbs. Alderwood smoked piramutaba with quinoa tasted better than smoked sturgeon.
Leonard Schwartz, chairman of the Rainforest Alliance, admitted that importing the fish to a place surrounded by plenty of fish of its own "was a crazy, wild thing to try to do." The party served not only as a debut for the fish, but raised money for the Amazon Rivers Project, a five-year, $500,000 program designed to help preserve the rain forest by making the Amazon economically productive.
"We are trying to show that by making the fish an important resource it makes more sense to maintain the tropical forest than turn it into grazing land," Mr. Goulding said. None of the fish are endangered in this area of the Amazon, he said, but a delicate balance must be maintained.
"These fish have been exported for 30 years, mostly to Europe and Africa," he said. "But developing an American market for them will add to their value and make it more essential to preserve the habitat."
Jeffrey Moats, the president of Kapok International, the fish-processing company based in Cleveland that imported the fish for the party, and who is working with the Brazilian Government to better organize the fish-processing industry, began selling the fish to restaurants in Cleveland in March; he said the response was encouraging. He added that he was meeting today with Julia Child, who has expressed interest in using the fish.
Even chefs like Mr. Bouley, who is accustomed to having halibut and fresh, hand-picked scallops flown to his restaurant from Maine in a matter of hours, had high praise for the firm-textured, flavorful pescada and said he would serve fish like these.
At the benefit, the chefs were busy tasting each others' food. A few were grudging in their praise. "The fish was better than I thought, even though it was frozen," said Mr. Soltner, the chef and owner of Lutece. "It would have to be fresh before I use it."
Mr. Soltner, who admitted that the last time he used frozen fish was 30 years ago, was unfamiliar with the latest techniques in flash freezing, which can bring fresh fish to 60 degrees below zero in just a few hours.
He also hedged his bets by grinding the dourada into mousse, then studding the mousse with salmon, wrapping it in brioche and serving it with watercress sauce, a less effective way to showcase the flavor and texture of the fish than simply sauteing it and serving it with a splash of sherry vinegar on a bed of summer vegetables, as Gilbert Le Coze and Eric Ripert of Le Bernardin did.
"This fish reminds me of pompano," Mr. Le Coze said.
In coming months, New Yorkers may have a chance to judge for themselves.

(Michael Goulding)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
High Stakes; Low Sense Of Values

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
IN launching an investigation into Michael Jordan's gambling habits, the National Basketball Association has embarked, or rather, has been taken on a far-reaching ride across revealing, occasionally treacherous landscape.
The investigation has taken the league to a bail bondsman in the Carolinas who was murdered and a drug dealer who was convicted. To Monte Carlo for an Olympic tuneup and late night-early morning visits to betting parlors. To Atlantic City, where Jordan and his father went out on the town the night before a Knicks playoff game. To San Diego, where Richard Esquinas -- Jordan's golfing partner turned tell-all author -- alleged that high-stakes golf matches left Jordan hundreds of thousands in debt. 
 Now the investigation has spilled over into the National Football League. Esquinas reportedly said that he was told by Jordan that Lawrence Taylor of the Giants owed the Bulls' star $150,000 in golf bets. Taylor said he owed substantially less.
Another report alleges that Mark Jackson of the Los Angeles Clippers lost $22,000 to Jordan playing cards. Jackson has admitted playing cards but denies owing $22,000.
Regardless of Jordan's activities, the N.B.A. has to know by now -- if it hasn't known for years -- there is a deeply entrenched gambling culture in all professional sports leagues.
The N.B.A. should also know that there is a burgeoning resentment over a perceived careless, self-indulgent attitude by its athletes. The betting disclosures typify a disturbing, cavalier attitude toward the prosperity the players have inherited.
Joe Morris, the former Giants running back, recalled that for many players, card games and dice games were practically a ritual of road trips. "On a West Coast trip I've seen a guy lose his shirt by the time we get out West and win it back by the time we come home," Morris said.
Morris recalled one trip when the team plane was about to land. "Just as the landing lights came on, a teammate asked me to lend him $100," Morris said. "By the time we landed, he'd already lost it."
A veteran offensive lineman recalled being astounded his first year in the N.F.L. by the consistently high sums of money being won or lost on trips. By his third year, the lineman said that he'd accepted gambling as part of team subculture.
Many fans have expressed ambivalence over Jordan's high-stakes gambling adventures. For others, there is a certain charm to the riverboat gambler he embodies.
For the N.B.A., however, and by extension the N.F.L., major league baseball and the National Hockey League, the evidence of a greater involvement in gambling by athletes weakens the foundation of sports.
The primary attraction of sports is that victory is determined by who runs fastest, who jumps highest, who makes the best uses of skills. The athlete who falls into debt, falls into bad company or under bad influences compromises the sport.
Once the public suspects that athletic contests are manipulated, that players are compromising their performances to affect a certain outcome, the foundation will erode.
Thirty years ago, the N.F.L. was hit by a betting scandal that resulted in the suspensions of two of the game's biggest stars -- Paul Hornung and Alex Karras -- for betting on league games and associating with gamblers.
College basketball was rocked by scandals in the 1950's and 60's. In 1920, eight Chicago White Sox players were indicted on charges of conspiring with gamblers to fix the 1919 World Series. Pete Rose was banned from baseball in 1989, presumably for betting on games.
In following the Jordan trail, the N.B.A. must ultimately determine how a league that has grown on the strength of its entertainment appeal can devise a policy that balances an athlete's right to privacy with responsibility to the league and the public.
For many segments of that public, especially those who work with young people, the most disturbing aspect of the unfolding gambling revelations is not an integrity issue, but rather the thread of waste and self-indulgent behavior by some athletes.
Those who defend Jordan argue that, so long as one has the resources to back it up, enormous losses are acceptable.
But this isn't about money, it's about values. With so much of the country stuck in a recession, with businesses shrinking their work forces and with so many of our youth locked out of opportunities for lack of resources, hundred-thousand- dollar gambling debts and $20,000 card games seem a bit excessive.
Even for millionaires.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MEIKO SCIENTIFIC IS AWARDED LIVERMORE CONTRACT

 BODY:
Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory said yesterday that it had awarded the Meiko Scientific Corporation of Waltham, Mass., a $17.5 million contract for a Meiko CS-2 Massively Parallel Processor computer system. When the decision was first disclosed in March, concerns were raised over national security and economic competitiveness because Meiko was a subsidiary of Meiko World of Britain. And the company had been criticized for the sale of a supercomputer to Israel. But a Livermore official said yesterday that the same precautions were being taken with respect to Meiko as with other computer contractors who have foreign ownership or foreign sales.

HEADLINE: Stocks Stage Rebound, With Dow Up 9.50

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks moved higher yesterday on rebounds in a number of sectors that recently endured selloffs. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.50 points to finish at 3,544.78 in heavy trading.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 277.4 million shares, up from 216.4 million on Monday. 
Robert C. Walberg, an analyst with MMS International, said the early tone was set by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in testimony to Congress.
Mr. Greenspan expressed concern about the rate of inflation, which caused a selloff in bonds and equities. However, the stock market was able to turn around in the afternoon, led by the recently beleaguered drugs and high-tech issues.
 
Companies' Gains Help Stocks
 Helping stocks turn up were better than expected earnings at a number of companies and a drop in oil prices.
Transportation stocks got a lift from the drop in oil, as airlines stocks lead a surge in the transport sector. AMR, the parent for American Airlines was up 2 3/8, to 63 3/8, while Delta Air Lines gained 1 3/4, to 50 1/4, and UAL, the parent for United, rose 4 3/4, to 138.
About the only new economic data were the June housing starts, which were unchanged from May and had little impact on the market, traders said.
Bargain hunters also played a role in limiting the downside.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.28 point, to 447.31, while the Big Board composite gained 0.38 point, to 247.71, and the Nasdaq composite gained 6.07 points, to 701.90.
Among stocks making contributions yesterday, Sears, Roebuck gained 4 1/8, to 50 1/8. The giant retailer reported second-quarter profits of $2.63 a share, compared with 85 cents a share for the quarter a year ago. The latest quarter also included a $635.1 million gain from the Allstate Corporation's initial public offering.
McDonnell Douglas rose 5 5/8, to 80 7/8, as Morgan Stanley and Cowen & Company upgraded their recommendations to buy. Monday the company reported a second-quarter profit of $4.33 a share, against 12 cents a share.
Cai von Rumohr, the analyst at Cowen & Company, raised his 1993 estimate to $11 a share from $9.25 and 1994 estimate to $11.50 a share from $10.
Alpha-Beta Technology, the developer of pharmaceutical products made of complex carbohydrates, fell by 2, to 25, as Alex. Brown & Sons lowered its recommendation to buy from a strong buy.
The stock price of the Amtech Corporation jumped 4 3/4, to 23 3/4, after Union International des Chemins de Fer, which represents 32 European railroads, selected Amtech's electronic anti-shoplifting tags as a standard for the continent. Traders said the stock had fallen by 3 in the last three days amid reports of setbacks on two contracts to install electronic equipment.
Intermagnetics General said it had entered into an agreement with the Chrysler Corporation to supply the auto maker with its refrigeration system. Delivery of the system, which does not use freon, is pending regulatory approval. Intermagnetics rose 6, to 15 1/2, up more than 63 percent

CORRECTION-DATE: July 23, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about Tuesday's stock market trading misidentified the products made by the Amtech Corporation. They are electronic identification tags for vehicles, not anti-shoplifting devices.

HEADLINE: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: On the Streets;
After Report, the Talk Of Residents Is Tense

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
The streets of Crown Heights were calm yesterday, but the talk was tense and filled with anger and hurt.
The day after a state report sharply criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins, top City Hall aides and the police leadership for their handling of the Crown Heights violence, the thoughts and emotions of blacks and Hasidic Jews seemed as divided as when the neighborhood erupted in disturbances two summers ago. 
 Many Jews expressed a feeling of vindication that their story had finally been told, but they fretted that justice had still not been served. But many of the neighborhood's blacks charged that Mr. Dinkins was being unfairly judged because of his race and complained that the state investigation had not gone far enough in getting to the underlying grievances behind the violence.
Like much of what goes on between the races in Crown Heights, blacks and Jews kept their opinions among themselves. Jews talked in the shopping district along Kingston Avenue with its kosher shops and Hebrew bookstores, and blacks gathered on Utica Avenue, with its Caribbean specialty shops and bodegas.
"The main question now is who is going to pay" for mistakes made by the police and City Hall, said Zohar Eisenberg, 42, a Hasidic man. "We've already paid with our blood."
Like many other Hasidic Jews, he was highly critical of Mayor Dinkins, whom the report cited for a chain of leadership failures in dealing with the distrurbances in which Jews were singled out by bands of black youths.
"People will remember in November," said Dena Gorkin, who is 29 and the mother of three.
"We can't wait until then," added Michael Atland, a middle-aged Lubavitch Hasid who is from France. "He must step down now. This report is nothing but a cover-up."
Opinions on Utica Avenue were starkly different. "They are trying to bring down a good black man," said Noreen Dowridge, a homemaker walking with her daughter, Keshia, 7.
"The Jews are going back to the same old way -- crucifying a black man," she said. "The Mayor had nothing to do with what went on here. It was young people who took everything in their own hands. The cops were the ones who were supposed to do something. Were they supposed to beat black people for nothing?"
Richard Green, executive director of the Crown Heights Youth Collective, said the report unfairly placed the onus for the disturbances on black youths. "There were young people out from both communities," he said.
Mr. Green said the Mayor and the Police Department acted appropriately during the violence. "He handled this like a statesman," he said.
 
Author Is Faulted
 Several blacks who were interviewed complained that the report was critical only of black actions and not of those of Jews. They faulted the report's author, Richard H. Girgenti, the state's Criminal Justice Director, for not thoroughly investigating the death of Gavin Cato, 7, the child whose death in an auto accident ignited the four days of violence. The vehicle was driven by a Hasidic man.
Several leaders in the black community said the report represented another instance of "preferential treatment" for Hasidic Jews, a claim echoing a refrain during the 1991 disturbances. Some black people said then that Jews got special consideration from city agencies, including the police, which provided the head of the Lubavtich movement, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, with a police escort.
A home health aide, who identified herself as C. Beddeau, said her granddaughter was one of the people who tried to lift the car off Gavin when it pinned him to a wall.
Ms. Beddeau lives in the building at President Street and Utica Avenue, where the accident occurred. She said that she gave a statement to state investigators. "I never heard anything else about it," she said. "They're covering up something."
Winston Gilbert, a Crown Heights resident from Grenada, said the report provided justice for Yankel Rosenbaum, 29, the Hasidic scholar fatally stabbed in the disturbances, but not for Gavin Cato. "Only one side of justice I have seen," he said.
Many Jews, however, dismissed any equation between the death of Gavin in an auto accident and the stabbing death of Mr. Rosenbaum.
The state investigation was ordered by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last year after a jury acquitted a black teen-ager in Mr. Rosenbaum's death.
Rabbi Yehuda Krinksy, the spokesman for the Lubavitch Hasidic Movement, the major Jewish group in Crown Heights, said the report "corroborates the claims of the Jewish community, victims of the Crown Heights pogrom of August 1991."
For many residents, both black and Jewish, the release of the state report recalled the horror of that summer. Several people on Utica Avenue expressed dismay that the report failed to note that blacks in Crown Heights were also targets of violence by Jews. The report said Hasidic Jews were singled out by bands of black youths.
Yitzchok Bitton, who moved to Crown Heights more than a decade ago from France, remembered walking through the neighborhood with his son, then 12, on Aug. 20, 1991, the second day of the disturbances.
Police officers were armed in riot gear as he passed. "I asked if it was safe to go down the block," he recalled. "And they said yes." Halfway down Carol Street, he said, he and his son were thrown to the ground by 50 youths wielding bricks, bats and razors and chanting, "Jew! Jew! Jew!"
"There were police at both corners, but no one came to help us," he said.
"No one wants to put down the Mayor," said Mr. Bitton, a former full-time rock musician who now manages a Hasidic hotel. "But you have to bear responsibility for your actions." He said he did not believe that it was an issue of the Mayor's race but of his competence.
On Utica Avenue, Beryl Duffie, unemployed and the mother of two, said the report reopened wounds still raw and healing. "Right now," she said, "everybody hates everybody."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On the surface yesterday in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, one day after the release of a state report on riots there two years ago, calm prevailed as people passed beneath a sign announcing the coming of the Messiah. But talk among blacks and Jews revealed much bitterness over what the report said. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow, in 10.62 Rise, Reaches a High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at an all-time high yesterday on a day when all other market indicators moved in the opposite direction.
Relying primarily on a combination of rebounding stocks and some companies that reported decent earnings, the blue-chip indicator rose 10.62 points, to 3,555.40, edging above the previous high of 3,554.83 established on May 27. 
 The broader market was mixed as prices faded under pressure of a weak bond market, which was still smarting from the Congressional testimony of the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, Tuesday in which he expressed concern about inflation.
 
Strong Volume
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was strong for the second consecutive day, at 278.6 million shares traded, up from 277.4 million Tuesday. For the third straight session, losing issues outnumbered gainers, 1,051 to 923.
With no economic news to trade on and stocks being influenced by earnings and forecasts, one trader noted that the equity market just tagged along with bonds because it was the path of least resistance.
"The biggest notice was the bond market," John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president and director of research for Advest Inc. said, "as concern about food price inflation showed signs of heating up because of flooding in the Midwest."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell by 0.13 point, to 447.18, and the Big Board composite lost 0.11 point, to 247.60. Trading on the Nasdaq pulled the composite down by 1.82 points, to 700.08, while the American Stock Exchange composite slid 0.48 point, t0 433.31.
Interest rates moved higher as bond prices fell. "There is also the concern about short rates coming up," Mr. Shaughnessy said.
Mr. Shaughnessy noted that the combination of soft crude oil prices and a possibility that jet fuel would be exempted from the proposed fuel tax continued to lift transport issues. The Dow Jones transportation average gained 4.27 points, yesterday, to 1,573.21.
American Airlines' parent, AMR, rose 2 1/8, to 65 1/2; Delta Air Lines, rose 1/2, to 50 3/4, and UAL gained 3/8, to 138 3/8, all on the New York Stock Exchange.
Elsewhere, United Technolgies, one factor in the Dow's gain, rose 1 5/8, to 54 7/8.
Intel, still in litigation with Advanced Micro Devices over the copyright of its 486 micro chip, was off 7/8, to 51 1/8, in Nasdaq trading, while Advanced Micro, was up 3/8, to 24 7/8, on the New York exchange.
Compaq Computer jumped 3 3/8, to 49, as the PC maker said its second- quarter earnings rose to $1.21 a share from 35 cents, exceeding analysts estimates of $1.17 a share.
Announcing that it hade settled litigation against the Snap-On Tool Corporation, Envirotest Systems rose 1 1/4 in Nasdaq trading to 9 3/4, while Snap-On gained 1 5/8, to 40 3/8, on the New York exchange.
Traders said a Merrill Lynch analyst, Douglas Groh, had raised IMC Fertilizer Group to a long-term buy, citing probable higher demand for its products because of damage to cropland caused by the Mississippi River flooding. IFL rose 1 3/8, to 30, on the New York exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Japan's powerful civil servants resist a dose of deficit spending.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"WHAT the world needs from Japan is a sustained period of domestic demand-led growth," Lawrence H. Summers told a group of movers-and-shakers from the Japanese business community.
The lecture, delivered by the Under Secretary of the Treasury on the eve of the Tokyo summit meeting, was not the first the Japanese had heard on this theme. Nor, with President Clinton gearing up for his international "jobs summit" and Congress itching to shove some Toyotas off the pier, is it likely to be the last: Most Western economists believe a big tax cut would be the best way -- perhaps the only practical way -- for Japan to get Washington off its back.
But even if the executives wholeheartedly agreed, they would probably not be able to make their opinions felt. For in contrast to virtually every other modern democracy, the inner circle of Japanese economic policy-making is dominated by deeply conservative civil servants adept at resisting interest group pressure. "They are pre-Keynesians," concludes John Makin of the American Enterprise Institute, bureaucrats who would rather "risk a 1930's-style depression" than use deficit finance to stimulate the economy.
There is still a chance, though, that the better-than-expected electoral showing of the Liberal Democratic Party -- and the relative failure of the splinter Japan Renewal Party that was not-so-quietly backed by the Ministry of Finance -- will lead to changes previously beyond the reach of big business. Ironically, suggests Jan VanDenBerg, an economist formerly at Merrill Lynch who is now writing a book about Japan, the old line L.D.P. that lost its credibility as servants of the commonweal "is on the side of good sense."
Japan's economic growth slowed to a crawl in 1991 and actually slipped into reverse in the second half of 1992. By no coincidence, imports fell sharply, reopening the yawning trade gap that had largely been closed in the late 1980's.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development forecasts that Japan's current account surplus, the broadest measure of its financial balance with the rest of the world, will reach a record $150 billion next year. What's more, unemployment will continue to creep up.
The Western medicine of choice would be a dose of fiscal stimulus, increasing demand for both domestic products and imports. Cutting taxes, particularly on consumer goods, would be the speediest means to that end. And it would probably be the most popular, giving Japan's involuntarily ascetic citizenry a chance at a better life.
But Shafiqul Islam, an economist at the Council on Foreign Relations, points with considerable sympathy to the ideological barriers to opening the fiscal spigot. During the 1970's, Japan's ruling politicians fell into habits of deficit spending not unlike America's in the 1980's. And the hard-won success of the bureaucracy in wrestling the budget back into the black, he notes, has left a deep mark on the Ministry of Finance: "They now feel it's their responsibility to keep the budget balanced." Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is less reverent about what he sees as a power grab in the face of a weakening government: "The Ministry of Finance gets its jollies by saying no," he concludes.
Two big fiscal packages, announced with fanfare by the Miyazawa Cabinet in August 1992 and April 1993, were both trimmed back by the bureaucrats. Mr. Makin estimates they will ultimately deliver one-third of the promised punch. Ms. VanDerBerg thinks the effective stimulus could be even smaller, reflecting an idiosyncrasy of Japanese Government finance.
Since the deficit debacles of the 1970's, she points out, the Ministry of Finance has refused to issue bonds to cover operating budget deficits; only "construction" bonds used to finance public works, are permitted. Thus a shortfall in tax revenues, stemming from the unusually slow recovery, is almost guaranteed to cause a cutback in nonconstruction outlays by Tokyo.
The reversal of fortune of the Liberal Democratic Party in the wake of one too many financial scandals might be expected to strengthen the bureaucrats' capacity to resist calls for any change in economic policy. But this time the Ministry of Finance may have outsmarted itself.
By most reports, the economic bureaucrats were banking on the total collapse of the L.D.P., with the void to be filled by a coalition led by their ally, former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata. Now it appears that the L.D.P. will once again be able to cobble together a government -- one that will have strong incentives to punish the mandarins for playing power politics.
It is unclear whether the Japanese Parliament would be able to marshal the expertise, let alone the will, to manage economic policy without the advice and consent of the bureaucracy. But, then, many things about post-election Japan are unclear. This time, at least, the L.D.P. could publicly reconcile its inclination to old-style patronage finance as the solution to Japan's very new problem of Western-style slow growth.

HEADLINE: Where Once Only Garbage Grew, a Secret Garden

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
There's a new buzz coming to a Bronx neighborhood that stands on the cusp between urban disaster and revitalization. It is not the buzz of summers past, the sound of windows shaking with the violent vibrations of a passing car's stereo at full blast, or the buzz teen-agers feel from the marijuana sold openly in their streets.
This time, it is the gentle sound of honeybees drawn to a patch of climbing hydrangea nestled in Manhattan euonymus and honey locust, all freshly planted in a triangular lot behind a towering tenement in Morris Heights. 
 Seven months ago, the tract on Townsend Avenue near 174th Street was a smelly tangle of 50 tons of garbage piled 10 feet high. Today, it is a delicately landscaped plot known as the "secret garden." And it is both source and symbol of a larger neighborhood rejuvenation that owes much to what city officials describe as an emerging strategy to do more with less by coordinating the work of disparate municipal agencies.
In less than six months, the city's departments of parks, transportation and sanitation and the Parks Council, a private, nonprofit group, turned a litany of chronic eyesores into small steps toward renewal of this neighborhood of crowded tenements, busy storefronts, broken pavement and graffiti.
Besides clearing and planting the garden, they removed tons of refuse along the neighborhood's Jerome Avenue exit from the Cross Bronx Expressway, planted flowers on the steep banks on the expressway as it approaches the neighborhood and erected fences from Walton Avenue to Jerome Avenue near 174th Street to discourage illegal dumping. Old fences were painted a gleaming green; a plaza was cleaned and paved; a sidewalk was fixed; handball courts were repainted, and graffiti removed.
 
'It's Just Beautiful'
 "It's just beautiful, beautiful," said Oreeetea Maldonado, who moved to Morris Heights three years ago with her son, now age 6. "I love it and my son loves it."
Still, there are some in the neighborhood, like Angel Medrano, an unemployed building superintendent, who say the area will always be prone to self-destruction and despair. "There's nobody around here who wants to build anything up," said Mr. Medrano, 42.
Yet, in an era when most cities face cutbacks and calls for fiscal restraint, New York City officials say they believe that a well-coordinated cleanup by government can encourage a self-sustaining effort by neighborhood residents -- saving public resources in the long run.
"If people begin to see more than just the minimum is being done, then they in turn will say, 'I need to give something back,' " said Harvey Robins, director of the Mayor's Office of Operations and an architect of the strategy. "That is where the real ripple begins."
However, it has taken a spirit of cooperation within government to make that happen, because city agencies often lost sight of their missions in disputes over jurisdiction, said Joseph J. Timpone, director of the Department of Sanitation's Bureau of Cleaning and Collection.
"With this kind of approach, we can work with each other and develop communication between the agencies," he said of the coordination. "This way, you can see what the job needs and what you have to do, and when and where to get it done."
In fact, it was a collaboration between the city's Board of Education and the Agency for Child Development that ignited the Morris Heights cleanup, city officials say.
With demographic changes and housing redevelopment in Morris Heights came a rapid increase in school-age children. Board of Education planners decided that a new school was needed in the neighborhood. The Agency for Child Development, which is part of the city's Human Resources Administration, saw the need for a day-care and after-school center.
The independent government offices saw an opportunity to share their purposes and resources. The result, the $11 million Educare Center School, a handsome, three-story brick building, will open this fall.
"We decided to make this the prototype," said Rose Diamond, director of the Board of Education's Office of Strategic Planning. "This is the first time capital resources have been pooled. We saved a lot of money."
During an inspection of the school late last year, Mr. Robins, of the mayor's office, said he noticed something that dismayed him.
"In the back of the school, there was this major eyesore," he recalled -- a triangular lot filled with garbage, paper, old toys and broken bicycles. It took crews of six to nine sanitation workers 18 days to clear the lot by hand, sanitation officials said.
The Parks Council donated the landscape architectural work and about $10,000 in materials and staff time, its officials said, and the "secret garden" was born.
The garden project, in turn, opened the way for a series of cleanup projects surrounding the new school.
Daisy Alvira, 26, who has lived in the neighborhood for 15 years, said she could not remember when so much work had been done in her community. For years, she said, she was troubled by the mountain of garbage there. Now, she said, she is organizing children to help maintain the garden.
Unofficially, Magnolia Gonzalez, 12, who lives in a tenement overlooking the garden, is its caretaker. "I like everything about it," she said of the garden that has a spray of purple magnolia. "I go look at it every day."
But Fernando Martinez, the building's superintendent, is skeptical of the neighborhood's commitment. In the weeks since the garden was finished, signs of neglect are evident in its parched soil and creeping weeds. Some tenement residents have resumed their practice of tossing garbage down on the lot from their windows, Mr. Martinez said.
"Someone has stolen plants from here," he added.
But dismissing the superintendent's pessimism, Ms. Alvira looked at the children pressed in around her and said, "We can keep it nice."

The cleanup of vacant, trash-littered lots by several city agencies has inspired further efforts renewing the surrounding neighborhood. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)(pg. B1)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Debt Rules the Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Investors seemed to be hungry for higher yields and willing to take more risk to get them yesterday as they opened up and swallowed one of the largest mouthfuls of long-term debt ever.
On the same day, the Walt Disney Company sold $300 million of 100-year bonds, up from $150 million in the initial proposal, while the Tennessee Valley Authority sold $750 million of 50-year bonds, up from $500 million in its initial plan. 
 The numbers are a little staggering, totaling more than $1 billion in bonds that will mature after most people who bought them are dead.
Several money managers were quick to dismiss the idea of buying the 100-year Disney bond. They said it was a great idea for the entertainment company to lock in low-interest rates for a long time. But they said buyers were taking on considerable risk, especially because the bond can be called or paid off by the company in 30 years.
Disney would call the bond if interest rates declined, which is what bondholders want because prices rise when yields fall. "If things are working to your advantage they will take it away from you and if it is working to your disadvantage you get to keep it," said Charles P. Smith, a managing director at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore.
"I think we are getting to silly season on structures," added Thomas A. Shively, a senior vice president at State Street Research, a money mananger in Boston.
On the other hand, in the new world of low interest rates, money managers are looking for every extra bit of yield they can find and more and more companies want to lock in low rates for as long as possible. "So I think that is a great marriage," Mr. Shively said, adding, though, that it was not a match for him.
Mark A. Seigel, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company, the lead underwriter on the Disney deal, said the 100-year bonds were being bought by pension funds, insurance companies, banks and investment advisers.
The yield on the Disney bond was 7.55 percent, 95 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond. Mr. Seigel said the Disney bond was sold to more than 15 accounts and was attractive because some had a need for the longer maturity to match liabilities or to extend the maturity and to adjust the volatility of a bond portfolio. In additon, he added, "any pickup in yield enables investment managers to differentiate their performance."
Neither Mr. Smith nor Mr. Shively was interested in the idea of a 50-year bond either. But Geoffrey Kurinsky, a senior vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston, has bought plenty of 50-year bonds, including those sold by the T.V.A. yesterday and Conrail earlier this year.
He said he might buy a 100-year bond from the T.V.A. if he was confident about his ability to figure the right price. Mr. Kurinsky said a 100-year bond could be attractive because the giant utility is a quasi-government agency and that means there is almost no credit risk. But he was not interested in a 100-year Disney bond, which he said was only attractive as a "museum piece."
The T.V.A. 50-year bond can be paid off after 10 years, which does hurt its attractiveness. But Mr. Kurinsky said that compared with utility bonds with 30-year maturities or longer and single A credit ratings, the T.V.A. issue was a good deal.
For example, he said that single A utilities were selling at a spread over Treasury rates of 73 basis points while the T.V.A bond, which has an implied Triple A rating because of its quasi-government backing, came at a yield yesterday of 7.44 percent, 83 basis points over the 30-year Treasury yield.
And a 40-year issue by the Duke Power Company, which is callable in 10 years and rated double A, was sold Tuesday at a yield of 7.26 percent, 70 basis points over the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond at the time.
Mr. Kurinsky also argued that while the T.V.A. bond was callable in 10 years, he calculated that he would be getting a better deal than those from other utility bonds that are callable. For one reason, many utility bonds are callable after five years. And in the case of the T.V.A. bond, the premium the agency must pay in 10 years to redeem the bond earlier is higher than the normal premium paid when a bond is called.
The T.V.A. sale of 50-year bonds, with the First Boston Corporation as the coordinator, came along with an issue of $1.25 billion of 10-year notes that were sold at a yield of 6.30 percent, 50 basis points over the rate on the 10-year Treasury note.
 
Treasury Market

The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose sharply yesterday as prices fell in light trading. The yields on short and intermediate Treasuries also moved higher.
In trading yesterday, 30-year bonds fell 11/32 points as the yield jumped to 6.63 percent, from 6.55 percent Tuesday. The yield on the two-year note jumped to 4.12 percent, from 4.07 percent Tuesday and 3.97 percent Monday.
But traders did not seem to read too much into the selloff. Because the trading was light, the declines could have been exaggerated. In addition, many analysts have been expecting some kind of correction or consolidation after the recent rally that brought the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.54 percent, its lowest level in 16 years.
In addition, Treasury auctions are now on the horizon again, with sales of two-year and five-year notes next week and three-year, 10-year and 30-year bonds in the second week of August.
"The market was due for some consolidation," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. The trend from here, he said, will depend on the July economic data on growth and inflation that will be released next month and how well the coming Treasury auctions go.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
France Names First Companies for Selloff

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, July 21

 BODY:
France's conservative Government listed three household names and a tiny local bank today as the first companies it would sell off in a huge privatization program that it hopes will raise $78 billion over five years.
First to be sold will be the drug giant Rhone-Poulenc S.A. and Banque Nationale de Paris, followed by the oil powerhouse Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and a surprise candidate, the small retail Banque Hervet. 
 Banque Nationale de Paris, France's third-biggest bank, and Rhone-Poulenc, the world's eighth-largest pharmaceuticals company and the majority owner of Rorer Inc. of the United States, will start the program in the fall. Over all, 21 state-owned companies are to be privatized under the five-year plan that could raise 450 billion French francs, or about $78 billion.
Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, who heads the conservative Government that won power in March elections, has said he hopes to raise 40 billion francs this year through privatizations.
 
A Government Bond Issue
In anticipation of the proceeds, the Government raised 110 billion francs this month through a bond issue that will be spent in part on job-creation measures. Investors will be entitled to exchange the bonds for shares in newly privatized companies.
Apart from Banque Hervet, the list of candidates was in line with expectations, although the choice of Elf Aquitaine overrode the wishes of President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. He had said he would not block the privatization of Elf Aquitaine but called for extreme caution on the ground that oil and gas supply was a sensitive national-security issue.
France is among a number of European countries, including Italy and Sweden, that are beginning to sell off state-owned companies to private investors to reduce their budget deficits and make their economies more efficient.
 
Three Blue-Chip Companies
Rhone-Poulenc, Elf Aquitaine and Banque Nationale de Paris are blue-chip companies that are well known to the foreign investors on whom the Government will be relying to make the program successful.
Andrew Shepherd-Barron of the Kleinwort Benson brokerage firm in London said these three companies should pose no problem. "I believe there will be good interest in all those three," he said.
The Government did not offer details for the selloff, declining to give a timetable or to provide details as to how much of each company it would sell.
Analysts said the fate of the privatizations would depend not only on attracting foreign buyers but also on small French savers, many of whom lost money on the shares they bought during the previous conservative Government's denationalization drive in 1986 and 1987.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Gains Against Dollar As Yen and Pound Move Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its decline against the German mark yesterday, falling to 1.6977 marks in New York from 1.6997 a day earlier.
Currency brokers said the market remained focused on the European Monetary System, which fixes several European currencies in a tight trading range. The mechanism has come under assault repeatedly in recent months as speculators guessed weaker currencies would not be able to maintain their levels against the mark. 
 "We're seeing a continuing perception in the markets about instability regarding weak currencies in the E.M.S.," said John Nelson, director of global foreign exchange at Barclays Bank P.L.C.
Traders said investors would continue to buy German marks as a result of the persistent strength of that currency and because of German interest rates that are high relative to rates in the United States.
Germany's central bank lowered one of its interest rates yesterday, but traders said the move had little effect on the foreign exchange market. The Bundesbank lowered its securities repurchase rate -- used to set a variety of other rates throughout the German economy -- to 7.15 percent from 7.28 percent.
The dollar also lost ground against the Japanese yen and the British pound. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 108.13 yen in late trading, down from 108.15 yen on Tuesday. And the pound was quoted at $1.5165, up from $1.5110 the previous day.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.4995 Swiss francs, up from 1.4965; 5.8015 French francs, down from 5.8060; 1,595.00 Italian lire, up from 1,586.00, and 1.2766 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2790.

HEADLINE: South Africa Envoys Reflect Apartheid's End

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
They cannot vote in national elections in South Africa and are still classified as a black, a colored and an Indian in South Africa, but the three officials at the South African Embassy here emphasize that they are the visual signs abroad of the end of white rule at home.
South Africa's governing National Party and the African National Congress, the once banned anti-apartheid organization, have yet to work out the mechanics of ending the system of institutionalized racial separation. 
 But earlier this month, in a hiatus in the continuing discussions, Nelson Mandela, leader of the congress, and F. W. de Klerk, President of South Africa, shared the Liberty Medal in Philadelphia.
Now the three senior officers -- there are also three nonwhite assistants -- quietly explain South African Government policies, make speeches encouraging investment and educational links between the United States and South Africa, and lobby to end the sanctions that helped undermine white rule.
"I wanted to make sure the world saw that South Africa wasn't lily white, that there were other people with other views," said Vernie Chetty, who is of Indian heritage and is the embassy's liaison to Congress. Until two years ago, when she joined the foreign service, Ms. Chetty was a social worker.
Paul Jacobs, a second secretary for cultural affairs, wants Americans who supported the anti-apartheid movement to lend economic support to the democracy movement. President Bush lifted sanctions in 1991, but many American corporations have not rushed to reinvest in South Africa, uncertain about the stability of a country whose political future is currently being drafted.
"I do believe that the silent revolution, the revolution of ordinary people living their daily lives and excelling against all odds, needs to be rewarded," said Mr. Jacobs, who was the headmaster of three schools and saw the effects on his students of the boycott. Mr. Jacobs, who is colored, a South African term for people of mixed race, joined the foreign service two years ago.
There are no more than 30 nonwhite officers serving in the 70 South African embassies around the world. And having a dark face is no guarantee that views will be heard.
"It's a mixed reaction that you get," said Wesley Johanneson, the press secretary for the embassy.
Mr. Johanneson, a black who was second in command at the South African Consulate in Beverly Hills, Calif., before joining the embassy, has been in the foreign service since the mid-1970's. He has seen barriers fall and seen pay rates become equal.
"These days it's an accepted thing back home to have black diplomats," he said.
Still the presence of nonwhite South African foreign service officers is unknown to many Americans.
Harry Schwarz, South Africa's Ambassador to the United States, recalled a recent incident in which his secretary, one of the nonwhite assistants, took a call for him from an "obviously racist American" who wanted to know whether it was true that the blacks were taking over South Africa.
"You can imagine how she felt," Mr. Schwarz said. "I did not return the phone call."
Mr. Schwarz, a member of the opposition party and an opponent of apartheid since the 1950's, was named Ambassador two years ago.
Ms. Chetty, who joined her first protest against the South African Government when she was in the seventh grade, said she had never expected to be accepted into the foreign service. She joined, she said, as a challenge to show whites that there were nonwhites capable of competing with them.
"It was part of the new move toward democracy and I wanted to play an active role," Ms. Chetty said.
She said that initially she made little impact on Capitol Hill, but that this had changed because of developments in South Africa and the credibility of Mr. Schwarz as an opponent to apartheid.
"Still, some think you're an Uncle Tom or a stooge," said Mr. Johanneson, a career diplomat. "Others think, by God, it's high time."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Surging Silver Prices Fall And Some See Rally's End

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver prices tumbled yesterday on faltering demand for the metal, which has been one of the year's hottest commodities. Gold prices also dropped.
Silver for July delivery fell 9.5 cents, to $4.945 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. August gold declined $2.70, to $389.50 an ounce. 
 Silver's slide prompted speculation in some trading rooms that the metal had peaked after a rise of more than 40 percent from $3.64 for spot deliveries at the start of the year to the July 7 high of $5.14.
The market bounced off $4.925 in a similar plunge last week and is now likely to retest that support, said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York.
"If the $4.90 level gives way, we could see silver drop precipitously," he said. "The $4.80 or $4.70 area is quite possible, not in the next day or two, but in the next few weeks."
 
Speculative Interest Slows
 Analysts said the speculative interest that fueled the rally was drying up and traders were coming to terms with weak industrial demand -- both domestically and abroad -- which accounts for most silver consumption.
"The market needs some resurgence of bullion demand if it's going to extend the rally," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures. He said demand from Asia had been particularly weak.
Mr. Milling-Stanley predicted no strong rise in domestic use for the rest of the summer. Factory vacation shutdowns and Midwestern flooding should keep a lid on economic growth, at least until fall, he said.
On other commodity markets, energy prices rose. Light sweet crude oil for September delivery rose 9 cents, to $17.93 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The August crude oil contract expired Tuesday at $17.09 a barrel. August heating oil rose 0.43 cent, to 50.17 cents a gallon. August unleaded gasoline rose 0.70 cent, to 52.49 cents a gallon, and August natural gas rose 6.2 cents, to $2.095 for 1,000 cubic feet.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean futures fell for a second day amid mixed weather forecasts for the rain-drenched Midwest. July soybeans fell 3 cents, to $7.24 1/4 a bushel. The November soybean contract, representing this year's crop, dropped 8 3/4 cents, to $7.21 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Decline a Bit on Big Board

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The number of shares sold short declined slightly at the New York Stock Exchange in the last month but rose to another record at the American Stock Exchange, the exchanges reported yesterday. Merger activity, rather than pessimism about stock prices, appears to have caused some of the largest increases.
The Big Board reported that the overall short position for trades through July 7 was 1.039 billion shares, down three-tenths of a percent from a month earlier, when a record of 1.042 billion was set. 
 The American Stock Exchange figure was 97.3 million shares, up 6 percent from the previous month. New records for short interest at the Amex have been set in each of the past three months.
While those who short stocks, by borrowing shares and then selling them, are often hoping to profit from a decline in price, there are other reasons to make such a trade, including merger arbitrage. Such appeared to be the explanation for some of the rapid rises in short positions, including that in Hanson, which agreed to acquire Quantum Chemical using stock as well as cash.
Another form of arbitrage may have explained some of the increase in the short position in Repsol S.A., the Spanish oil company, which saw its short position rise 8.2 million shares, to 8.4 million. Holders of covertible bonds were allowed to exchange them for shares, and some might have locked in profits by shorting shares before the exchange.
The third-largest increase in short position, behind Repsol and Hanson, came in U.S. Surgical, a company that has suffered a continuing string of bad news. The short position rose 2.7 million shares, to 12.2 million. Those who sold short are ahead, for the shares have dropped in recent days to their lowest level in two years.
The largest decline in short position, a 5.3 million drop in LTV, represented a victory for short sellers over foolish speculators. As that company emerged from bankruptcy, its old common shares were exchanged for warrants worth far less than the shares had fetched.
One of the largest short positions, of 15.2 million shares, is in Walt Disney. That figure was down 570,035 in the month, as some short-sellers took profits. Disney has been under pressure in large part because of losses at is Euro-Disney theme park in France.

HEADLINE: Next Israeli Skirmish: Breaking Bureaucratic Grip

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 21

 BODY:
A traveler at Ben-Gurion Airport stood as a symbol last week of the distance some Israelis will go to evade the tangle of Government regulations, tariffs and penalties that rule their lives.
With customs inspectors on strike, he had wasted no time becoming a smuggler to get around the high taxes and protectionist import duties that make appliances here cost several times what they do in the United States. Unfortunately for him, the inspectors returned to work with a vengeance just before he arrived, and they found 17 fax machines in his bags. 
 Curbs on imports are the sort of tight controls that Yitzhak Rabin had pledged to unravel, and that commitment during his 1992 election campaign is a big reason why his Labor Party was able to return to power.
After a year as Prime Minister, Mr. Rabin has begun making good on promises by cutting some taxes, eliminating nuisance fees here and there and selling off parts of two state-held banks and a few other businesses. He has also been graced by substantial economic growth, 6.6 percent last year and 4 percent forecast for 1993, despite historically high unemployment that may determine whether Israelis ultimately judge him a success.
 
Rabin Commitment Questioned
 In reality, the growth began before he took office last July, and has little to do with his first tentative attempts to turn over Government-owned businesses to private hands. Critics complain that the Rabin Government could have gone much further in this regard, and question how committed it really is to abandoning the heavy controls that have been the Israeli way of economic life from its founding.
The deregulation effort certainly has not moved fast enough to satisfy travelers at Ben-Gurion. Not only did customs inspectors find the 17 fax machines in one man's bags. Another man was found to be carrying 3 fax machines, 2 professional-size video cameras and 11 stereo speakers. A check of his passport showed he had been in and out of the country three times in the previous week.
No one will ever know how many people took advantage of the strike and beat the odds, but the clearing-house scene at the airport showed how far some Israelis will go to beat a system they say is choking them.
Finance Minister Avraham Shohat insists that better times lie ahead and that his work in lifting controls and unloading Government companies has just begun.
 
Critics Seek More Proof
 "We now have a strong political commitment to privatization," Jacob Frenkel, Governor of the Bank of Israel, said in an interview with The Jerusalem Report magazine. "The decisions are in place, and the question is whether we are going to be sufficiently firm, determined and basically effective in implementing them."
That is no small question, however. It certainly has been raised by Israeli free-market advocates, who say this Government has yet to prove it is any more prepared than its predecessors to kick old statist habits. Some critics train their fire on the privatization program.
Thus far, the Rabin people have either sold or plan to sell roughly $1 billion worth of shares in state-owned companies, including pieces of Israel Chemicals Industry, Industrial Buildings, the large Labor-affiliated Bank Hapoalim and the smaller Bank Igud.
After years of Government talk and little action in this area, the sales are hardly trifles, Mr. Shohat said in a recent interview. Moreover, the fact that Bank Hapoalim shares were vastly oversubscribed in no time suggests that there is a considerable appetite out there for more.
But these companies are only a handful among the more than 150 in Government hands. And in the Hapoalim deal, the 18 percent of total shares that were put on the market somehow ended up being sold largely to funds under the control of the bank itself.
"It seems they're engineering the sales so that the only people who can buy are those considered to be 'our boys,' " said Daniel Doron, director of the Israel Center for Social and Economic Progress, a free-market research group in Jerusalem.
Other critics say the Rabin Government wasted precious time.
"Actions always fall short of words," said Zev Golan, associate director of the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies, another research group. "Rabin gets up and says in countless speeches that if he could give away these state companies, he would. If he's serious, why hasn't he done it?"
 
Economic Policy Stressed
 Government officials respond that it is no simple matter to turn around a socialist-inspired economy, especially in a beleaguered country filled with people not persuaded that good economics and national security necessarily go together.
In a sense, Mr. Rabin embodies this contradiction, having spent much of his life as a soldier, worrying less about capital formations than tank formations. Still, he has concentrated on economic policy to an appreciably greater degree than his predecessor, Yitzhak Shamir.
He has turned the Government's main focus away from expanding Jewish settlements in the West Bank to starting highly visible road projects inside Israel proper. Overriding objections from Finance Ministry bureaucrats, his Cabinet recently approved the creation of a free-trade zone in either Galilee or the Negev. The zone, which still needs Parliament's approval, is intended to liberate businesses from suffocating Government regulation, and sponsors say it can generate 20,000 jobs.
Jobs, Mr. Rabin knows, may decide whether he stands or falls, for he entered office on a promise to put Israelis to work, especially immigrants from the former Soviet Union. They continue to arrive -- and to have trouble finding jobs right away in their fields -- at a rate of more than 60,000 a year.
 
Exports Rise 14 Percent
 In many other spheres, the Prime Minister is doing well, even though 1993 economic growth is expected to dip to 4 percent from 6.6 percent last year because of a sharp drop in Government housing construction.
Israeli exports rose by 14 percent last year. Tourism boomed after a disastrous 1991 caused by the Persian Gulf war. And inflation, which galloped at triple digits a decade ago, slid below 10 percent in 1992 for the first time in memory.
Still, unemployment stays high, and opinion polls suggest it is the economic indicator Israelis study most closely.
It slipped recently from 11.2 percent to 10.6 percent, but Government economists acknowledge it is not likely to go appreciably lower for a long time.
While new immigrants are commonly seen as the heart of the problem, joblessness cuts deep among veteran Israelis. Military industries, suffering record losses, have dismissed many hundreds of workers, with more layoffs likely. Koor, the country's largest industrial conglomerate, has trimmed its work force, and so have smaller businesses.
Some relief came when the Government sealed off the occupied territories last March after a series of lethal attacks on Israelis by Palestinians. Immediately, tens of thousands of Arab laborers were kept from reaching construction jobs. While about 20,000 have since been allowed back into Israel, Zvi Friedman, spokesman for the Israeli Contractors Association, says 12,000 Israelis now work fulltime on construction sites that they would not even have looked at before March.
But although that helps, it does not put a big dent in the jobless rate. And it is clear that, for his own political welfare, Mr. Rabin will have to get many more Israelis back to work than a platoon of aggressive customs inspectors.
"The problem is that the longer an economy lives with unemployment, the longer the unemployment become hard-core," Rafi Melnick, deputy research director at the Bank of Israel, said. "It becomes very hard to get rid of it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Bluntly Tells Zairian President to Yield

BYLINE: Reuter

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
After two days of talks with a top Zairian official, the United States today accused President Mobutu Sese Seko of risking the lives of millions and threatening regional stability.
The State Department issued the tough statement after talks Monday and today between Assistant Secretary of State George E. Moose and Mr. Mobutu's envoy, Ngbanda Nzambo-ko-Atumba. 
 "We deplore the continuing crisis in Zaire and hold President Mobutu responsible for a situation which puts at risk the lives and welfare of millions of his countrymen and the stability of an entire region," the State Department spokesman, Mike McCurry, said.
 He said Mr. Ngbanda had delivered a response by President Mobutu to a letter from Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
"In his response, President Mobutu blamed the opposition and the High Council of the Republic for the continuing stalemate in Zaire and the resulting human suffering, including severe unrest in Shaba and Kivu provinces," Mr. McCurry said.
Mr. Moose told Mr. Ngbanda that "the United States finds this response to the Secretary's letter totally inadequate" and stressed that "the only solution to Zaire's crisis is a transition government accepted by all major parties," Mr. McCurry said. The primary objective of the transition must be agreement on a constitution, followed by free and fair elections, he added.
"It is abundantly clear to objective observers that President Mobutu bears responsibility for the continuing political impasse, economic deterioration and human suffering," Mr. McCurry said. "We call on him once again to allow the transition to proceed or bear full responsibility for the consequences."
Mr. Mobutu has kept power for almost 30 years by keeping opponents in disarray or buying off enemies.
His archrival, Etienne Tshisekedi, was elected Prime Minister last August. But President Mobutu installed his own man and revived his rubber-stamp National Assembly, causing Zaire to slide deeper into political chaos, with rival governments.
Despite human rights abuses and his use of power for personal enrichment, Mr. Mobutu became an ally of the United States and other Western powers during the cold war. Washington relied on Zaire as a supply route to rebels in Angola who were fighting the Marxist Government there.
Mr. Mobutu's usefulness to Washington faded as the Angolan war wound down and Soviet influence in Africa declined. Now the United States, France and Belgium are leading international efforts to force his ouster.
