HEADLINE: Rebellion Flares Anew in Northeast of India

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 21

 BODY:
When guerrillas ambushed a military convoy in the Northeast of India recently, killing more than 25 soldiers, they signaled a resurgence of their 40-year campaign for independence.
After decades of guerrilla war by a dozen ethnic-based insurgencies that has left thousands dead and tied down an estimated 40,000 troops in the Northeast, officials say the rebels are widening their activities, extorting money from businessmen in major towns, and kidnapping and killing officials. 
 The remote Northeast, roughly the size of Montana, Wyoming and Colorado and rich in minerals, is home to about 25 million people and encompasses seven states. They border Myanmar, Tibet, Bhutan and Bangladesh.
The insurgencies are rooted in ethnic, economic and religious factors that separate the Northeast from predominantly Hindu India, especially its politically powerful northern belt. The latest ambush took place in Manipur State, and officials blamed the National Socialist Council for Nagaland, the most powerful of the rebel groups. No group has taken responsibility for the attack.
Many Nagas are Christians, largely Baptists, who were converted more than 100 years ago by American missionaries. Other religious groups in the region include Presbyterians in Mizoram and Meghalaya states, and Buddhists, Hindus and Muslims in Manipur, Assam and Tripura states.
"India must face this reality: that the spirit of our people cannot be crushed by brute force or by flooding us with money," said Tubu Kevichusa, a lawyer from Nagaland who left India in the 1980's to work with the separatist Federal Government of Nagaland, based in Myanmar. He spoke to a reporter after returning to India.
The central Government in New Delhi has pumped money into the Northeast to build roads and state-run industries and help finance the strapped states, but it continues to be seen as an adversary in many parts.
Some Indians say the only solution to the insurgencies is greater political and economic autonomy for all 25 states in India.
In Manipur, Mizoram and Nagaland, as well in Assam, officials and human-rights advocates say there have been widespread human rights violations by troops and insurgents.
Some soldiers have been formally charged with rape, murder, destruction of churches, theft and torture, and many more have been accused of such crimes.
The largest state in the region is Assam, which, with a population of 22 million, is dominated by Assamese-speaking Hindus. There are smaller communities of indigenous peoples speaking other languages who want to carve separate states out of Assam. But the main Assamese rivalry has been between Hindus and Bengali-speaking Muslim settlers from Bangladesh.
"Many of these people have settled illegally here," said Dhiremn Bezbaruah, a newspaper editor. "They are still coming in and posing a threat to our culture and identity."
But Parag Das, a prominent Hindu editor who has been arrested twice for supporting the insurgents, said, "In many ways, we remain a colony, exploited and abused."

HEADLINE: BUDGET HAGGLING BEGINS IN EARNEST

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Some of the chief Democrats shepherding President Clinton's budget through a Congress thick with wolves met in a handful of ornate Capitol backrooms today, occasionally throwing out their staffs and abruptly slamming doors in reporters' faces.
This was a sign that discussions over the final form of Mr. Clinton's five-year package of tax increases and spending cuts had started in earnest, ending several days of political cameos on television talk shows and speeches about party unity and sacrifice. 
 Less clear was the degree to which the talks resolved any of several yawning differences between the more liberal House version of the bill and the more frugal Senate one over how much to raise taxes and increase spending on social programs.
Mr. Clinton proposed about $250 billion in new taxes and another $250 billion or so in spending reductions through 1998, which would reduce the growth of the Federal deficit by about $500 billion.
 
Moynihan Sees Progress
 At day's end, the chief Senate negotiator, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, emerged from behind one closed door and said he would submit a compromise proposal on Thursday to the House that makes "real progress" toward resolving the differences.
But almost as he spoke, a pivotal conservative Democrat in the Senate and an equally important liberal Democrat in the House were staking out separate and contradictory positions on the shape the bill should take.
The Senator, David L. Boren of Oklahoma, said in an interview that he believed the economic package should include "substantially more" spending cuts than tax increases, rather than the dollar-for-dollar ratio in the Senate version of the proposal. And he warned that he would not hesitate to vote against the package if it did not meet his satisfaction, even though the proposal squeaked through the Senate last month by only a one-vote margin.
"My vote just simply is not pledged," he said. "Whether I vote for it or not depends on what's in it."
Meanwhile, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan was saying that House liberals were becoming alienated by Mr. Clinton's hesitancy to support still more tax increases to finance social programs that are in the House version of the economic package, but were cut out or pared in the Senate version.
Mr. Rangel noted today that those programs could easily be paid for by raising the proposed new tax rate on corporate income to 36 percent from 35 percent, but that Mr. Clinton seems to have committed himself to oppose that. The current corporate tax rate is 34 percent but both the Senate and the House have agreed to raise it to 35 percent.
 
'We Made a Commitment'
 "No one has made a commitment to food stamps or the earned income tax credit," Mr. Rangel said. "So we have made a commitment."
The White House budget director, Leon E. Panetta, spent virtually all day with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen in Capitol Hill meetings, from a morning session with House Democrats to an afternoon meeting with Mr. Moynihan and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and the chief House negotiator.
Mr. Panetta said the Administration remains committed to a program that would reduce the growth of the Federal deficit by $500 billion over five years, more than some liberals favor and less than some conservatives want.
He and Mr. Bentsen also suggested that Mr. Clinton would support a fairly modest tax on gasoline and diesel fuel that would raise about $30 billion over five years -- the equivalent of about six cents a gallon. That is close to the 4.3 cent-a-gallon tax that conservatives forced into the Senate bill, and far less than the five-year, $72 billion tax on gas, diesel, coal and other forms of power that is in the House bill.
But neither they, the lawmakers nor Howard Paster, Mr. Clinton's lobbyist on the economic plan, were saying much else. Mr. Rostenkowski responded to a question about the fuel tax by forcefully closing the door to his spacious private office almost on the nose of one reporter.
Mr. Moynihan's Senate Democrats, who met in an anonymous third-floor warren wedged between the Capitol dome and a men's room, were so secretive that they tossed out most of their staff, summoning them only to ask questions. This evening, after one such call for "tax staff No. 1," four suit-and-tied staff members, lounging in the hallway outside, rose as one and trooped into the room, thick stacks of documents in hand.

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
FOR many children and adolescents, experimenting with petty crime is a part of growing up. It may be a way to fit in with a group or to test the limits of acceptable behavior. To the child, taking a "five-finger discount" on some makeup at the drugstore or spray-painting a name on a wall may seem relatively harmless, especially when compared with violent crimes.
But psychologists and criminologists urge parents to pay close attention to such incidents, for they may be the child's cry for help with other issues. There are patterns of behavior that predict which children treat delinquency as a passing phase and which graduate to more serious crimes as adolescents and adults. 
 "Parents shouldn't be overly concerned about a single instance of shoplifting, curfew violation and the like," said Paul Sweeney, who develops and researches programs for juvenile offenders at the Metro Dade Department of Justice Assistance in Miami. "Some of the research shows that up to 70 percent of adolescents admit to having done things like this."
Not being concerned doesn't mean ignoring the episode, of course. But the parental response should be in line with the extent of the problem. Overreacting with severe and inappropriate punishments may make matters worse for children who are simply testing limits. Underreacting to children who are at high risk may mean they don't get the help they need to break the cycle.
One of the best and most obvious predictors of later criminal behavior is the frequency with which a child or adolescent gets into trouble with the law. "If it happens twice within a year, I'd pay more attention to it," said Dr. Peter Mundy, a clinical psychologist who is the director of the psychological services center at the University of Miami.
The type of delinquent behavior is also important. "There's a big difference between the kids who commit property crimes and those who commit crimes against people," Mr. Sweeney said.
Boys are much more likely than girls to get into trouble with the law because of behavior that involves violence or aggression. Federal figures from 1988 show that 14-year-old boys were about five times more likely to be arrested for violent crimes than were 14-year-old girls. Among 18-year-olds, boys were more than 10 times as likely to be arrested. Girls, though, are more prone than boys to become involved in violations that apply only to minors, like running away from home.
As a rule of thumb, the younger a child is when he engages in violent or delinquent behavior, the more likely it is that that child will get into more serious trouble later. Certain personality characteristics are also associated with children who engage in repeated antisocial activities. "Impulsivity, sensation-seeking and defiance are all stable traits found among juvenile delinquents that can sometimes be seen as early as preschool," said Dr. Denise Gottfredson, an associate professor at the Institute of Criminal Justice and Criminology at the University of Maryland at College Park.
She quickly added that this does not mean that a young child who has these traits is doomed to a life of crime. Rather, children who act that way are at higher risk for criminal behavior later if they are exposed to other conditions.
"The best predictors of which children will graduate into a more permanent pattern of crime are their likelihood of being unemployed after leaving school and the amount of violence in their families," said Dr. Randall Curren, an assistant professor of education at the University of Rochester who studies the relationship between law and education.
Children who commit petty crimes as part of a group also warrant closer attention than those who act alone. Teen-agers crave acceptance by peers. This desire to fit in makes them vulnerable to accepting antisocial values and behavior if, in exchange, they gain attention and recognition. That's one of the attractions of youth gangs: they help adolescents feel important when the larger world is ignoring them.
 
If Troubled Youngsters Turn to Delinquency
 IF your child commits a petty crime like shoplifting or an offense like truancy, you'll probably hear him try to justify his behavior by saying "everybody does it" or "nobody's hurt by it." That is the time to make your values known, to help your child recognize that neither of those statements is true, and to show that there are consequences for such behavior.
"You have to give your child a way of making things right, such as returning the shoplifted sweater and, in addition, doing some free work for the store owner," advised Dr. Randall Curren, an assistant professor of education at the University of Rochester. "That lets your child clean the slate."
Here are some other things to consider if your child gets in trouble with the law, especially if it happens more than once:
Don't write it off as simply sowing some wild oats.
Go for outside help. Get some advice from a school guidance counselor. "Intervene early," said Dr. Denise Gottfredson, an associate professor at the Institute of Criminal Justice and Criminology at the University of Maryland at College Park. "The longer you let a pattern like this go, the harder it will be to do anything about it."
Don't go overboard with punishment.
An overly harsh response to a minor infraction may do little more than make your child more rebellious. For example, grounding your child for a month is impractical, if not impossible. It also allows him to stay upset with you instead of focusing on what he did wrong.
Remember that teen-agers thrive on responsibility and want to feel that you recognize their growing maturity. At the same time, they may need to be shown more acceptable ways of expressing their anger or of fitting in with a different crowd.
"Instead of trying to stop your child from doing these things, which you really can't control, tell your child you're trying to help him stop behaving this way because you care about him," said Dr. Peter Mundy, the director of the psychological services center at the University of Miami.
Check out your child's peer group.
This is difficult with adolescents, since they have so much more control over where they go and whom they see. But if your child is getting into trouble, it's the first thing you should look into. "One of the biggest correlates of delinquent behavior is hanging around with other kids who are delinquent," Dr. Gottfredson said. "Monitor your child's friends. Don't be afraid to question your child about whom he's spending time with."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NORDSTROM PLANS TO ISSUE VISA CARDS

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc., the retailer based in Seattle, announced yesterday that it planned to issue Visa bank cards through its affiliate bank, Nordstrom National Credit Bank. The company already has its own Nordstrom credit card. But use of the Nordstrom card has declined because customers have increased their use of bank cards with incentive programs, like the Citibank Visa card that awards holders points in American Airlines' frequent flier program based on their purchases, a company spokeswoman said. 
 Store credit cards also tend to charge users higher interest rates than bank cards. Nordstrom National has not yet made final the specific terms of its Visa card or related marketing programs.

HEADLINE: Farms Abandon the Oats Once Sown

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARFIELD, Minn.

 BODY:
There is no historic site marker on the shady dirt driveway down to Harold Hoppe's farmhouse here in western Minnesota, but perhaps there ought to be. Mr. Hoppe, who is 72, is the last farmer in this region who is betting heavily on a crop of oats.
Neighbors of Mr. Hoppe (pronounced HOP-ee) are not the only farmers to all but abandon the grain. Production of oats, the gasoline of the 19th century, when American commerce ran on horsepower, has fallen to the point where the United States, a leading exporter of oats in the 1980's, is the largest importer. 
 The simple explanation for why so many farmers have given up on oats is that other crops provide a better living. But beyond that is a complex web of forces that highlight many strengths and weaknesses of America's powerful agribusiness community and the role of both the Federal Government and world trade in modern agriculture.
"The trends make us quite nervous," said Penny Cate, the director of government relations for the Quaker Oats Company, the nation's biggest processor of oats for human consumption. "Once farmers grow less of a crop, it takes something extra to get them back."
The decline has come at a time when consumers' yen for oats in cookies, Cheerios and other foods is on the rise. Following reports in the late 1980's of the health benefits of oat bran, demand for oats in food leaped to more than 100 million bushels in 1990 from less than 50 million bushels in 1987. Demand has continued to rise more slowly since then, to 109 million bushels this year.
Beyond human consumption, however, the oats market has been crumbling for decades. Oats' use as a marketed animal feed is projected to be 225 million bushels this year, less than half the total just a decade ago.
The single biggest factor has been the declining role of the horse, the principal consumer of oats, in the domestic economy. But more recently, changes in farm equipment have played a role as well. Many Midwest farmers used to devote some land to oats, which typically mature in July, because they had land left over after allocating as much to corn or soybeans as their machinery could handle during the fall harvest. But today's combines cover far more ground, so farmers do not need to spread the workload.
With domestic production dropping, the imports have served to keep prices down. Good crops this year in Scandinavia and Canada are expected to compensate for output lost to weather and disease in the lower Midwest. Despite their distance from the American market, these nations have been competitive here with the help of farm and export subsidies.
But many foreign subsidies are being lowered, and the American oats processors are nervous that foreign farmers will respond by shifting production to other crops. That could create shortages, driving up oat prices for both processors and consumers.
 
 
Lack of Storage Space
 Signs of oats' decline are everywhere.
Farmers who used to control weeds and insects by alternating oats with corn or soybeans now rely more on chemicals. Many grain elevators in the heart of the farm belt have stopped setting aside storage space for oats. Oat seed growers are fewer and farther between, further limiting the options for those who want to keep some of their acreage in the crop. At the Chicago Board of Trade, all futures trading in oats is handled by a single floor broker who deals with a handful of local traders.
Companies like Quaker, Conagra and General Mills are fretting about the higher risk of price and supply fluctuations stemming from growing dependence on imports from Canada, Northern Europe and Australia. Since 1982, falling domestic output has pushed the average market share of foreign imports to about 15 percent. Instead of accounting for 20 percent or more of the world's exports, the United States now sucks in more than 60 percent of all imports.
The companies could guarantee domestic supplies by contracting with individual farmers, a widespread practice in hog and poultry operations. But the incentives the companies would have to offer to get farmers into such a program could be costly, and commitments to buy crops before they are planted expose processors to fluctuations in quality and output, said A. Bruce Roskens, Quaker's senior manager for commodity development.
 
 
Victim of Farm Supports
 Prices would have to rise sharply for a long time before farmers could be persuaded to expand oats production. Food processors and farmers say the problem is that Government farm-support policies have been skewed against oats for decades. Oat support prices are so low in comparison with other crops that less than half of the farmers growing oats bother to enroll in Government support programs, compared with 80 percent to 90 percent of those growing corn and other crops.
Farmers are reluctant to experiment with shifting land to oats, from corn or other more subsidized crops, because they are not permitted to bring that land immediately back into the richer subsidy programs if they do not like the results.
The support levels were set by comparing the energy value of different grains in relation to corn as animal feed. Oats, relatively high in protein and fiber, are low in energy content. That makes them good for horses, which have sensitive digestive systems, but a weak competitor to corn, soybean meal and other feeds used to fatten cattle and hogs. Thus, oats get Government subsidies based on their value in a market for which they are poorly suited.
"It's an artificial situation," said Michael McMullen, an associate professor of crop and weed sciences at North Dakota State University in Fargo, who runs one of the handful of university oats breeding programs left in the nation.
The American Oats Association, a Minneapolis-based trade group encompassing producers and processors, lacks the clout to improve oats' competitive position much.
"It's ridiculous that we are driving oats production out of the United States, but it is difficult to ask for subsidies for other crops to be cut," said William Vollink, director of commodity analysis for General Mills. "We are hoping to level the playing field by holding oats steady as the other programs are cut."
Agricultural experts say the slide in domestic oat production -- down to 300 million bushels, from 1.5 billion in 1955 -- has gone so far that a big rebound is unlikely. Once mentioned in the same breath as corn, wheat and cotton, oats are now no more than a sideline interest for the agricultural research community, the companies that develop agricultural machinery and the makers of the pesticides, herbicides and fungicides that have played such an important role in raising farm productivity.
Yields average just over 60 bushels an acre throughout much of the upper Midwest, the nation's oats belt. But in contests sponsored by Quaker Oats, young farmers who grow oats on prime lands with careful attention to disease control and other yield-enhancing strategies can produce 200 bushels an acre.
Researchers say that some chemicals used on other grains that could be effective on oats cannot be advertised for use on the crop. That is because the manufacturers have not bothered to invest the $150,000 or so that it would take to get the Environmental Protection Agency's permission.
The problem is that oats sell for such a low price that farmers are reluctant to invest much in products that might produce higher yields, said Leland Learned, a biologist in Kansas City, Mo., with the agricultural chemicals division of Miles Inc.
 Even those like Mr. Hoppe, who grows oats on 165 of his 200 tillable acres, have mixed feelings about the grain.
"If I was younger, I guess I'd try corn or soybeans," he said, noting that he expected to net just $9,000 after expenses this year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A survey shows that Tina Brown's New Yorker is attracting more, and wealthier,
readers.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
ONE might reasonably contend that The New Yorker's Valentine-week cover illustration of a black woman and Hasidic man kissing was a little too provocative. Or that this week's cover, showing an Arab boy at the beach jumping into sand figures shaped like lower Manhattan, might perpetuate a stereotype.
 But the results of a new survey show that most of Tina Brown's decisions as editor in chief have been well received. 
In its 30th annual study of magazine reader demographics, for the 12-month period ending in June, the Simmons Market Research Bureau found that The New Yorker had increased its readership -- the number of people who read one copy --by 13 percent, to more than 2.8 million. Ms. Brown succeeded Robert Gottlieb last September, which means she controlled the magazine for nine months of the survey period.
 Yet more important to a magazine straining to achieve profitability, even with its rich history of fine writing and clever cartoons, was the finding that the median household income of The New Yorker's readers had also increased, by 12.5 percent, to $61,515. Among leading general-interest and specialty magazines, several others, including Vanity Fair, Vogue and Conde Nast Traveler, experienced growth in both the readership and income categories, although none approached the levels achieved by The New Yorker.
 The Simmons survey also determined that the average reader of The New Yorker during the period was 46.1 years of age, compared with 47.7 in the prior 12 months.
 To many readers of The New Yorker, the obvious significance of the trends is that Ms. Brown carried out changes they liked, including a wider mix of articles; new uses of color, photographs and graphics, and controversial covers.
 To Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive of the magazine, it means that a prediction he made in April was wrong. If the patterns of growth translate to increased advertising through the rest of the year, as he expects, profitability might be achieved in four years instead of five.
 "Certainly, this is a validation of the new editorial product," Mr. Florio said yesterday. "We have done a lot of research on our own. We know our audience is younger, bigger, more affluent and better educated, but we were having problems finding that in syndicated research, for people to make their advertising decisions on it. Now, the whole thing has come together."
 The results of the Simmons survey follow other data suggesting that the new editorial formula has found favor with a wider audience. The Audit Bureau of Circulations found that paid circulation -- a figure that is always smaller than readership and a truer picture of the financial landscape -- had increased 5.1 percent, to 658,916, for the six months ending last Dec. 31, compared with the corresponding period a year earlier. Further, the Publishers Information Base found that The New Yorker had increased its advertising pages 16.9 percent for the first six months of the year, compared with the corresponding period of 1992.
Mr. Florio said The New Yorker was currently more than 200 pages of advertising ahead of last year's schedule. And three weeks ago, for the first time under Ms. Brown, the magazine raised its rate base -- the number of copies the magazine guarantees to advertisers that it will sell -- to 650,000 from 600,000.
 "If advertising budgets are tight, and they're all tight right now," he said, "advertisers will be very, very careful about what media they will choose this fall. If lists are being shortened, advertisers want to be absolutely sure of what they're buying."
 Traditionally, the advertisers have been companies associated with the kinds of goods and services that interest wealthier readers. Mr. Florio said he expects the magazine to attract even more of those advertisers now.
 "We've got 300 people here, and Tina is certainly the head of the class," he said. "We needed her to give us the product. But we are all very happy."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 22, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day on July 22 reported figures from Simmons Market Research Bureau showing that The New Yorker was attracting a larger audience. The account quoted a readership figure -- the number of people who read one copy of the magazine -- of more than 2.8 million, an increase of 13 percent from the previous year.
 The column should have added, however, that the figure for the readership increase was within the margin of sampling error and therefore not statistically significant. Thus the survey results should be considered tentative or suggestive.
